Abkhazia is also recognized by Russia  which fought a war with Georgia over it and another breakaway region  as well as Nicaragua and Venezuela. Tiny South Pacific island states have been a particular prize for Abkhazia, as they have been for decades for new nations seeking to bulk up on the number of countries offering recognition. The government of Vanuatu, which is in an economic slump, said in a statement that recognition was intended to foster the development of friendly relations and explore joint economic projects.

Produced by Bill Duke, D. Channsin Berry and Bradinn French, Dark Girls takes a compelling look at the impact of colorism: a state of prejudice, conscious and unconscious, that causes both black people and white people to label as more beautiful or desirable or intelligent individuals with lighter shades of skin, particularly when it comes to black women. Few among people of color are unfamiliar with the saying: If you are light, you are all right. If you are brown, you can stick around. If you are black, get back. A writer in The Washington Post aptly described the phenomenon a few years ago as the crazy aunt in the attic of racism.

I was staying at the Hotel Martinez, which, for those unaware, becomes so brimming with celebrities (from Vanessa Hudgens to Sarah Jessica Parker) during the film festival that every paparazzo in the world, and possibly the entire population of the South of France, hold vigil outside, cameras pointed at the door until they realize you are not, in fact, Clemence Poesy (thanks, though!). So when sharing an elevator with Jude Law, whether coming from the seventh floor gym or la plage across the street, is a real possibility, being caught barefaced is a bit daunting. As for my sleeping in makeup, blame Olivier Zahm and his Purple party at Le Baron, an early flight and the lack of the will to painstakingly remove the waterproof makeup I agreed to test for The Moment. title: Venice Biennale: An Installation Art Contest
description: VENICE  After the first day spent looking at most, but not all, of the national pavilions in the Giardini, this years Biennale has started to shape up as a knock-down, drag-out contest among immersive, environmental installation artworks. The battle is especially pitched on the little hillock dominated by the pavilions of Britain (Mike Nelson), Germany (Christoph Schlingensief) and France (Christian Boltanski), although the fray has also been joined by Switzerland (Thomas Hirshhorn) and the Czech Republic. At that pavilion, a little-known artist named Dominik Lang, barely 30 years old, has mounted a strangely affecting time-capsule-like installation featuring a great deal of generic postwar figurative sculpture by his father, Jiri Lang (1927-1996), who stopped making art years before his son was born. It serves as a sobering reminder of the obscurity that awaits most of the art produced at any given point in time, as well as the ability of art objects, being objects, to wait out different phases of neglect.

title: In Her Skin | Raquel Allegra
description: Summer is all about showing skin. But for those who arent into baring it all, one option is dipping into early fall offerings. Pared-down basics by the Los Angeles-based designer Raquel Allegra have long been favored by stars such as Halle Berry, Hanneli Mustaparta and Agyness Deyn. Although Allegra is best known for her supersoft cotton shredding technique, for her latest collection, which hits stores in July, she began thinking about leather. I asked myself, What do I want to wear as a second skin? The results include a dappled goatskin boucl cardigan that is as pleasing to the touch as it is to the eye  and that still leaves enough to the imagination. There are also slimming thigh-high leather leggings that mold to ones body, supple camel leather shirts and buttery black body-con dresses that look effortless and sensual, not overripe or overtly sexy. The collection, available July 31, ranges from $250 to $1,100 and can be purchased at barneys.com or netaporter.com.

description: JERUSALEM  More than a month after saboteurs blew up an Egyptian pipeline supplying natural gas to Israel, the line is repaired but gas is not flowing and foreign shareholders of the company suspect politics to be the reason. They are threatening legal action against Egypt.

title: A Camera, a Card, a Connection
description: According to my Twitter followers, certain laws govern the consumer electronics industry. Theres @Slbrinks Law: The cheaper the printer, the more expensive the ink cartridge. And @MichaeLVosburgs law: Any gadgets ease of use is inversely proportional to the number of engineers who worked on it. And @Invisible_Daddys law: Any cool feature you try to show your spouse wont work, discrediting your enthusiasm for your new purchase.

title: Phones Put a Bargaining Chip in the Car Buyers Hand
description: Car shoppers who thought that the Web would save them from wasting money were kidding themselves. As too many people have found, you can bring along boxes of printouts from car-advice sites, and slick or unscrupulous sellers will argue that the information is outdated or irrelevant.

title: Analysis: Nadal Shows Why He Is the King of Clay
description: The reports of Rafael Nadals demise are exaggerated, as he showed in Wednesdays straight-sets dismissal of Robin Soderling. With his level of play clearly rising, Nadal has swept into the semifinals at Roland Garros despite the negative buzz emanating from the press room and the locker room. Granted, Nadal has looked more vulnerable this spring than in any previous clay campaign, and, as the No. 1 player in the world, he knows that his every shot, and every utterance in news conferences, will be scrutinized, compared, assessed and commented upon.

title: Israel to Participate in 2013 World Baseball Classic
description: Too bad Sandy Koufax is not pitching anymore.

title: Shareholders Approve Massey Sale to Alpha
description: Shareholders of Massey Energy voted on Wednesday to approve the coal miners $7.1 billion sale to Alpha Natural Resources, despite the protests of several shareholders that sued to temporarily halt the deal.

title: Google Says Hackers in China Stole Gmail Passwords
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Wednesday that hundreds of users of Gmail, its e-mail service, had been the targets of clandestine attacks apparently originating in China that were aimed at stealing their passwords and monitoring their e-mail.

title: With These Rings
description: One was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. Another was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. The third is the spouse of the two-term governor of Indiana, who, until a few weeks ago, was considered by many as a leading candidate for the Republican Partys presidential nomination. But what does Cheri Daniels have in common with Elizabeth Taylor and Natalie Wood? Like them, she divorced one husband to marry another, only later to remarry the first husband. That marital roundelay, though almost never discussed by the couple, was largely considered one reason Governor Daniels decided against a White House run. As he explained last month: I find myself caught between two duties. I love my country. I love my family more.

title: Hochul Is Sworn In as House Member
description: Kathy Hochul, the Democrat who won a special election in upstate New York last week, was sworn in as the newest member of the House on Wednesday, giving her party a lift and reducing Republican dominance in the House by one.

title: A Love-Struck Romeo Finds Inspiration at Last
description: Unlike its writers-blocked hero Shakespeares Slave suffers from a few too many ideas.

title: Hewlett-Packard Sells Its Video Conferencing Business
description: Leo Apotheker, Hewlett-Packards chief executive, took a small step on Wednesday to refocus his slumping company by selling its video conferencing business.

title: In Wake of Natural Disasters, Insurers Brace for Big Losses
description: The devastation from the natural disasters that have ripped through parts of the country this year has been starkly evident. Hundreds of people have died and thousands of houses have been shattered in a deadly string of tornadoes. Millions of acres of farms were inundated and businesses shut down by flooding along the Mississippi River.

title: Battle For Libya | June 1, 2011
description: A bomb exploded Wednesday night in a parking lot outside a Benghazi hotel that has been a central meeting place for Libyan rebel leaders, diplomats and journalists. No deaths or injuries were reported.

title: Whats Going On at 40
description: Whats Going On, Marvin Gayes groundbreaking 1971 album whose socially sensitive subject matter Motown boss Berry Gordy Jr. initially believed would ruin Gayes career, is 40 years old this year. And as we all know now,the album, contrary to Gordys fears, became a critical and commercial success. More important, its message has remained timely and relevant over virtually its entire four decades of existence.

title: In Lady Gagas Album, Evidence of a New Order
description: A paradox of the new music industry: Albums sell less and less well every year, but as a marketing tool they are now more important than ever.

title: Plan for Chinas Water Crisis Spurs Concern
description: DANJIANGKOU, China  North China is dying.

title: Slaking North Chinas Thirst
description: The Chinese governments solution to a chronic drought in the north is to divert water from the Yangtze River.

title: Gold Mine Treasure: A New Worm
description: Single-cell organisms have been known to live deep in the earth, more than 9,000 feet below the surface.

title: Graphic Content | Heavy Metal
description: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts, a blogger, author, and a recent recipient of the National Design Award.

title: Groupon and Expedia to Offer Travel Deals
description: The market for Web sites that offer flash sales and discounts for travel packages and hotel rooms has a new competitor. Today, Groupon and Expedia announced a new venture, Groupon Getaways, which will offer discounts for hotel rooms starting in late June.

title: TimesCast | Sold This Way
description: A new online sales strategy helps make Lady Gaga's new album, "Born This Way," the fastest-selling album in six years.

title: Taliban Aim to Derail Afghan Security Transfer
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents have stepped up attacks in parts of Afghanistan scheduled to be handed over to Afghan military control next month and have put a new emphasis on a campaign of assassinations aimed at important officials around the country, Afghan officials say.

title: Brain Injuries Are Seen in New Scans of Veterans
description: A new study may help explain why some military personnel exposed to blasts have symptoms of brain injury even though their CT and M.R.I. scans look normal.

title: Children Are Among Casualties of Syrian Military Raids After Demonstrations
description: CAIRO  Syrian military forces killed 42 people Wednesday, including a 10-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl, in raids on a string of towns around the central city of Homs as the government continued trying to crush a three-month-old popular uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, human rights activists said.

title: State of Wonder
description: Chapter 1

title: Will Perilous Trek to Amazon Reveal Heart of Darkness?
description: Dr. Marina Singh, the 42-year-old research scientist who is the heroine of State of Wonder, Ann Patchetts most far-flung yet somehow least exotic book, is in her office at a large pharmaceutical company in Minnesota when the bad news arrives. Marina does unremarkable research on cholesterol. She is having an unremarkable affair with Mr. Fox, the companys C.E.O. The bland, far-from-fantastic Mr. Fox arrives to tell her that her research partner, Dr. Anders Eckman, has died of a fever in a remote part of Brazil.

title: Right Tools Unleash Creativity on an iPad
description: The iPad is great for activities like watching movies, surfing the Web, playing video games or reading digital magazines and newspapers. The rap against the iPad is that it is not as useful as a computer for creating.

title: China Extends Hand and Fist to Protesters
description: HOHHOT, China  As riot police officers pounced on ethnic Mongolian protesters on Monday, hauling at least a dozen into waiting vehicles, a young college student took refuge at a nearby cafe, shivering with fear. He checked a metal teapot for imaginary listening devices and glanced repeatedly at the door while explaining how soldiers had prevented thousands of his fellow students at Hohhot Nationality University from joining the rally.

title: Subtleties No Recording Could Catch
description: In the new-music world as elsewhere, scene makers and community builders come in a variety of shapes, sizes and inclinations. Important examples converged on Tuesday night when the Stone, the East Village performance space operated by the composer John Zorn, hosted the final evening of a two-week series produced by Innova, a hardy independent record label established in 1982 by the American Composers Forum in St. Paul. The program included two distinctive quartets that record for Innova: Zeitgeist, a mixed group from the Twin Cities, and the Prism Quartet, a saxophone ensemble based in New York and Philadelphia.

title: China Sends Polluted Water North
description: After billions of dollars spent on the project, water sent north along the eastern line is polluted by industrial runoff and municipal waste.

title: Oprahs Network Goes to the Movies
description: Fifteen years ago Oprah Winfrey introduced a book club to her talk-show viewers and thus began providing the publishing industry with its own version of an entitlement program. As a subsidizer of literacy, she brought Tolstoy and Faulkner to those not necessarily in possession of the Penguin Classics while primarily shepherding forgettable middlebrow womens fiction onto the shelves of those who might otherwise have been satisfied with People magazine. Three of her 10 selections in 1997 were childrens books by Bill Cosby, which should in itself sustain the question of her value as a national educator.

title: First a Toast to the Past, Then the Frolics of a Bubbly Balanchine
description: Although you dont need to know the ballets from one century to appreciate those from another, the connections are in some cases so profound that recognizing them deepens the whole experience. It was exciting on Tuesday night, amid American Ballet Theaters week of performances of Giselle ( 1841) across the Lincoln Center plaza at the Metropolitan Opera House, to watch New York City Ballet dance George Balanchines Donizetti Variations (1960) at the David H. Koch Theater. Although Donizetti has no scenery and no narrative, it looks at first like an outtake from the older ballets celebration of the festival of the vine, with the jollification of decorous peasants.

title: Just a Couple of Sports, Merrily Singing Along
description: If it is not their British accents, what accounts for the way British jazz and pop singers filter songs through a screen of hauteur? That slightly blas affect tinged Claire Martin and Richard Rodney Bennetts opening-night performance of their breezy Irving Berlin show, A Couple of Swells, at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday.

title: TimesCast | Twitter Trouble
description: June 1, 2011 - Representative Anthony D. Weiner finds that his sharp voice on Twitter can cut two ways.

title: Big Stars at 18, and Loving the Ride
description: LOS ANGELES  Sitting in a faux-leather booth at a waffle house here the other morning were two 18-year-olds. One was buttering her sourdough toast and giggling. The other was hacking into corned beef hash browns. A bored-looking waitress snapped her gum in the distance.

title: Works That Make Technology an Ally
description: Le Poisson Rouge became a de facto laboratory for a scientist of sound on Tuesday evening when the International Contemporary Ensemble presented works by Nathan Davis  as part of its ICElab residency at that Greenwich Village space.

title: Remembering a Champion Who Had Great Table Presence
description: One of the worlds greatest female bridge players, Edith Kemp Freilich, died on May 14 in Miami.

title: Google Calendars on the iPad
On Location | Dream House in Mexico
description: The geometrically shaped three-story house on Isla Mujeres is made from pumice and tile and inspired by the modern, clean lines of a nearby boutique hotel.

title: Architecture in Uniform
description: A new exhibition at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal considers architects role in World War II.

title: A Sliver of a Courtyard House in Paris
description: A designers 18th-century rental is only six-and-a-half-feet deep front to back.

title: A Toehold in Paris
description: AS a designer, Kein Cross is pretty good at estimating space, and when he saw the 18th-century courtyard house in Paris in an ad, he knew it was small  maybe 9 or 10 feet deep.

title: Case Stemming From Antiterrorism Registry Is Dropped
description: Immigration authorities announced on Wednesday that they will drop their case against Mohammed G. Azam, a young Bangladeshi man who had been fighting deportation since 2003, when he registered with a special post-9/11 program for Muslims.

title: A Gleaming Sculpture Facing the Caribbean
description: ISLA MUJERES, Mexico  For Richard and Karen Lock, all it took was a single trip to this small mellow island in the Caribbean Sea to know that they would someday build a home on its shores.

title: Shopping for Patio Umbrellas With Christopher Myers
description: A designer of urban outdoor environments went shopping for both affordable and out-of-the-park patio umbrellas.

title: Pull Up a Cupcake, and Then Eat One
description: The design of the newest Sprinkles Cupcakes shop, which opened recently on the Upper East Side, is an ode to the product. The cupcakes sold there, some of which are decorated with two-tone dots, inspired the large architectural dots that cascade down the facade (above). Inside, faux-leather hassocks are shaped like giant chocolate cupcakes frosted with colored dots. And the bands of color that run across the ceiling and down the wall are the companys signature colors, used in its packaging.

title: Reviving a Classic Swedish Textile Design
description: Fans of Swedish design may be familiar with Picknick, a pattern created by Marianne Westman in the 1950s for Rorstrand. A British company called New House Textiles, which has manufactured Swedish products for more than 30 years, has acquired the rights to Ms. Westmans pattern and is putting it on products like cutting boards, tea towels, trays and coasters (pictured).

title: Patio Umbrellas
description: WITH increasingly intense sun beating down on patios, decks and terraces, many people will soon be scrambling for shade on blistering summer days. Shade is an essential element of any garden, said Christopher Myers, the founder of Just Terraces, a New York design firm specializing in urban outdoor environments.

title: Wallpaper With a Life of Its Own
description: Payton Cosell Turner still thinks about a wallpaper that hung in the home in Connecticut where her grandfather, the legendary sportscaster Howard Cosell, lived. It was a fantastic frenetic laboratory print with beakers and test tubes flying everywhere, she said.

title: Using Gadgets to Zap Germs
description: TOILET SEATS get a bad rap, says Charles Gerba, an environmental microbiologist at the University of Arizona. Indeed, because of what goes on there, we tend to consider bathrooms  even the most respectable bathrooms  as generally less than sterile. That view, it turns out, is unfair.

title: A Fire Lookout on Solitude (and Lots of Time to Read)
description: In addition to an incredible view and a few months of monklike solitude, one of the perks of Philip Connorss job as a fire lookout in the New Mexico wilderness is a summer house.

title: A Los Angeles Bungalow That Doubles as a Sustainability Lab
description: Kelly Coyne and Erik Knutzen keep bees, grow vegetables and make their own cleaning products at their 1,000-square-foot house in Silver Lake.

title: Sales at John Derian, Broadway Panhandler and Others
description: Decoupage and other merchandise will be 30 to 80 percent off at the John Derian sample sale, through Sunday (decoupage crystal dome paperweights, originally $60, will be $25); 10 East Second Street (Bowery); (212) 677-3917.

title: A Larger Home for Bright Chair
description: After nearly two decades in the New York Design Center, Bright Chair is moving to a larger showroom. Weve tried to create an environment that shows how our products can be used in a residence, said Stan Gottlieb, the companys president.

title: Living Large, Off the Land
description: Los Angeles

title: 1937 in 2011?
description: Gauti Eggertsson has a nice piece on the New York Fed blog about the great monetary/fiscal mistake of 1937, which sent the Great Depression into a second downward leg. As he notes, the underlying situation bore a significant resemblance to current events: unemployment still high (actually under 10 percent if measured by modern standards, so quite similar to now), but with rising prices thanks to commodity shocks.

title: For an Underground Arts Show, No Subway Service. Again.
description: In its brief, half-decade history, the Bushwick Open Studios festival has earned a reputation as an eclectic, unpredictable entre into the underground Brooklyn arts scene, replete with cabarets, outr costumes, and free exhibitions from hundreds of local artists.

title: Yankees Ride Sparkling Starters to a Sweep
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It was the starters on the Oakland Athletics who were supposed to dominate this three-game series, a fledgling and talented bunch, none older than 25, all ranking among the American Leagues top 11 in earned run average. The Yankees countered with three pitchers, all 34 or older, none ranking in the A.L.s top 30 in E.R.A.

title: Remedies for Cellphone-Cancer Concerns
description: Now that the World Health Organizations International Agency for Research on Cancer has declared cellphones possibly carcinogenic, that is, apt to cause brain cancer, its worth reviewing ways to limit your exposure without resorting to a lead fedora.

title: Report Finds Inequities in Payments for Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare uses inaccurate, unreliable data to pay doctors and hospitals, the National Academy of Sciences said Wednesday.

title: The Thriving (Online) Shelter Magazine Industry
description: SINCE Domino, the beloved shelter magazine, folded in early 2009, its staff members have gone on to lucrative consulting jobs, top editing posts, even television gigs, but none have advanced as swiftly as Michelle Adams. At Domino, Ms. Adams was a 24-year-old assistant answering phones and running around Manhattan in search of blankets in exactly the right shade of purple. Two years later, shes the editor in chief of Lonny, a shelter magazine she co-founded. Already it has a cultlike following and has given rise to a mini-boomlet in online design publications.

title: Americans Are Joining Flotilla to Protest Israeli Blockade
description: When an international flotilla sails for Gaza this month to challenge Israels naval blockade of the Palestinian territory, among the boats will be an American ship with 34 passengers, including the writer Alice Walker and an 86-year-old whose parents died in the Holocaust.

description: The online start-ups Lonny, High Gloss, Rue and Matchbook are trying to fill the void left by their vanished print predecessors.

title: Shanahan Replacing Campbell as N.H.L.s Chief Disciplinarian
description: Colin Campbell will step down before next season after 13 years as the N.H.L.s chief disciplinarian, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday.

title: As Hurricane Season Begins, Heavy Storms Are Expected
description: The year began with birds falling out of the sky in Arkansas, followed by severe drought in some places and record-setting rainfall in others. This spring, a series of exceptionally destructive tornado swarms has wreaked deadly havoc across the South and Midwest, while a historic flood shoved its way down the Mississippi River.

title: Walt Baranger on ham radio; making better videos; the tech term "vaulting;" news.
description: Ham radio in the Internet age? It's alive and well, says Walt Baranger of the News Technology department at the Times. He chats with Bettina Edelstein and J.D. Biersdorfer about what's going on in the world of amateur radio. J.D. also speaks with Steve Stockman, author of How to Shoot Video That Doesnt Suck, about making better and more interesting home videos. And after his home network goes down, Pedro Rafael Rosado looks at the tech term "vaulting." The news roundup includes cellphones being seen as possibly carcinogenic; data breaches at Lockheed Martin and PBS; a forthcoming netbook/tablet hybrid with Intel processor called the Ultrabook; talk of a Facebook cloud music service; Apple getting set to talk about its next Mac OS X and iOS updates. J.D.'s tech tip: how to cut through desktop clutter on Windows 7 and Mac OS X.

title: Second Appellate Panel Hears Arguments on Health Care Law
description: CINCINNATI  A panel of federal appellate judges seemed eager on Wednesday to rule on whether it is constitutional for the Obama health care law to require that uninsured Americans buy medical coverage. But the judges must first decide whether the plaintiffs still have legal standing to sue, after one disclosed that she recently bought health insurance from her employer.

title: Running the Numbers on the Debt Ceiling Vote
description: Yesterday, the House of Representatives rejected an unconditional increase in the federal debt limit by a vote of 318 to 97, with all Republicans in opposition and Democrats splitting in favor 97-82.

title: S.E.C. Enforcement Lawyer Joins Simpson Thacher
description: Cheryl Scarboro, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commissions foreign bribery unit, is leaving the agency to join the law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett.

title: Advocates and Bankers Join to Fight Loan Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The weight of the mortgage crisis fell heavily on lower-income and minority communities, where first-time home buyers often fell victim to the predatory lending practices that resulted in an explosion of defaults and foreclosures.

description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  NASA, it seems, is having trouble letting go.

description: Hours after Bahrain officially ended 11 weeks of martial law on Wednesday, security forces attacked peaceful protesters in more than 20 villages with rubber bullets, stun grenades, shotguns and tear gas, according to human rights observers in Bahrain.

title: Crackdown on Dissent Continues in Bahrain, on the Streets and Online
description: After emergency rule was officially lifted in Bahrain on Wednesday, protesters who took to the streets in some places were dispersed with birdshot and teargas fired by the security forces, a rights activist told Agence France-Presse.

Rosalyn S. Yalow, Nobel Medical Physicist, Dies at 89
description: Rosalyn S. Yalow, a medical physicist who persisted in entering a field largely reserved for men to become only the second woman to earn a Nobel Prize in Medicine, died on Monday in the Bronx, where she had lived most of her life. She was 89.

title: Playing With Matches on the Debt
description: Just ignore Tuesdays vote against raising the debt ceiling, House Republican leaders whispered to Wall Street. We didnt really vote against it, members suggested; we just sent another of our endless symbolic messages, pretending to take the nations credit to the brink of collapse in order to extract the maximum concessions from President Obama.

title: Many Civilians Have Been Killed in Disputed Region of Sudan
description: JUBA, Sudan  Officials from the disputed Abyei area of Sudan said Wednesday that 116 civilians, including many children, had been killed last month when the northern Sudanese army seized Abyei.

title: A New York Staple, Korean Grocers Are Dwindling
description: Joo Han, the son of Korean immigrants, runs a Manhattan produce store that looks much as it did when his parents opened it a generation ago, working endless hours to forge a new life, banana by banana, milk carton by milk carton.

title: Former Police Chief Is Sentenced for Cover-Up in Mexicans Death
description: A former Pennsylvania police chief who was convicted of impeding a federal investigation into the beating death of a Mexican immigrant was sentenced to 13 months in prison on Wednesday, a lower-than-expected term in a case that had become a cause clbre for Hispanics.

title: As Arizona Fire Rages, So Does Rumor on Its Origin
description: PORTAL, Ariz.  It is a dramatic tale: that illegal immigrants being pursued by the Border Patrol started one of the nations largest wildfires, which has burned up more than 70,000 acres of national forest along Arizonas border with Mexico since it began almost four weeks ago. But the authorities say that despite the tales being repeated often by some residents of the rugged countryside here, they do not know for sure if it is true.

description: Ham radio in the Internet age? Its alive and well, says Walt Baranger of the News Technology department at the Times. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Mr. Baranger chats with Bettina Edelstein and J.D. Biersdorfer about whats going on in the world of amateur radio.

title: Governor Nominates Developer to Lead Thruway Authority
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has nominated a wealthy real estate developer to be chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, which oversees the Thruway and the states 524-mile canal system.

title: Christie Fields Criticism for State Helicopter Trip
description: Woe to the politician who claims to be fiscally responsible, in touch with regular folk, and turns out to have some pricey habits. Think Newt Gingrich and Tiffany, John Edwards and haircuts, Sarah Palin and clothes  and now, Chris Christie and helicopters.

description: ST. LOUIS

title: I.P.O. Talk, Demos at Tech Confab
description: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif.  The technology elite gathered for the annual AllThingsD conference here to discuss everything from the mood in Silicon Valley, to the latest technology gadgets and services. Here are a few highlights.

title: Fertility Loves Company: Why Mauve Stingers Dont Go Solo
description: By blooming in large numbers, mauve stingers were only doing what comes naturally: sticking together in order to reproduce more effectively.

title: Dallas Hopes Nowitzki Can Play Through Pain
description: MIAMI  Dirk Nowitzki lofted shots that the rim swallowed whole during practice Wednesday. Nowitzki, one of the N.B.A.s best shooters, will probably remain so Thursday in Game 2 of the finals against the Miami Heat  even with a torn tendon in the middle finger of his nonshooting left hand.

title: Small but Innumerable, Jellyfish Storm a Beach
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla.  They swarmed the beach, taking control of prime holiday sand and surf like a group of marauding spring breakers. Then, just like that, they vanished, leaving behind the damage: spoiled vacations, red welts, heaps of annoyance, discarded containers of vinegar and Benadryl and a crew of exhausted lifeguards.

title: Germans Deep Suspicions of Nuclear Power Reach a Political Tipping Point
description: BERLIN  Shortly after the earthquake and tsunami struck the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan in March, stores in faraway Germany began selling out of radiation-tracking Geiger counters. Sales of iodine pills to limit the absorption of radiation surged briskly, too, propelled by anxiety that people might find themselves engulfed in clouds of long-range radioactive fallout.

title: NYT: Front Page for 06/02/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 06/02/2011

title: Tossing No. 1 Ranking in Bag, Donald Sets Out After Another Top-10 Finish
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Among the things Jack Nicklaus values in golf, consistency ranks right up there with greens in regulation. So does normalcy, which the Memorial Tournament returned to this week with the presence of the worlds No. 1-ranked player.

title: A Voice From the Past
description: Now that the Supreme Court has given California the choice of shrinking its prison population drastically or making sufficient room for the prisoners it has, attention has naturally turned to how the financially strapped state will respond. But that focus shouldnt obscure the remarkable nature of what the court did last week when it upheld a lower courts order requiring California to reduce its prison population to no more than 137.5 percent of capacity within two years to cure overcrowding so severe that it amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.

title: At Least 4 Are Killed in Massachusetts Tornadoes
description: BOSTON  At least four people were killed when tornadoes touched down Wednesday in Springfield, Mass., and a number of nearby towns. The twisters flipped vehicles, collapsed buildings and stunned residents who are not used to such violent storms.

title: Taking In the Start of Hamptons Season
description: The sky had parted, Memorial Day weekend had arrived and Nocturnalist was ready for the Hamptons. On Sunday night we chose our most Hamptonish outfit and borrowed a very Hamptonish convertible. Each year, the long weekend marks the moment when much of Manhattans night life heads east, and we were primed to tail it the length of the Long Island Expressway.

title: Retroactive Reductions Sought in Crack Penalties
description: WASHINGTON  In a proposal that could allow as many as 5,500 federal inmates to apply for reduced prison terms, the Obama administration on Wednesday backed retroactively lightening some sentences for past crack cocaine convictions.

title: When the Nile Runs Dry
description: Washington

title: See No Wild Lands, Speak No Wild Lands
description: Writing about the environment does make one think about the costs and benefits of recycling. But let it be noted that, despite the temptation, this blog did not recycle the December headline that read Bush Policy on Wilderness Is Reversed.

title: World Bank to Help Cities Control Climate Change
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The World Bank signed an agreement on Wednesday with mayors from 40 of the worlds biggest cities to work on technical and financial assistance for projects to minimize the effects of climate change.

title: A Way Through the Debt Mess
description: THIS week House Republicans overwhelmingly rejected a plan to raise the nations debt ceiling without simultaneous cuts in taxes and spending, setting up a showdown with President Obama this summer over the budget.

title: Pakistani Spy Agency Denies Role in Journalists Killing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans premier intelligence agency, Inter-Services Intelligence, said allegations that its operatives were behind the abduction and killing of the journalist Syed Saleem Shahzad were baseless, and vowed Wednesday to help bring the perpetrators to justice.

title: For Her, Nearly Every Day Is a Party Day
description: As a teenager, Kristy Shelberg, stoked by Seinfeld and Friends and subscriptions to Vogue and Elle, plotted her escape from Creve Coeur, Mo., for New York City and a job in fashion or photography. She graduated in 2010 with a B.A. in marketing from LIM College in Midtown Manhattan, became Kristy Whitwell when she married her hometown sweetheart in July, and was hired last August as the event and party coordinator at the Scholastic Store in SoHo. Ms. Whitwell, 24, lives on Roosevelt Island with her husband, David, a classical trombonist attending the Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music.

title: The Cellphone Study
description: Cellphone users have every right to be befuddled. Just last year, a major study in 13 countries found no clear evidence that exposure to the radiation from cellphones causes brain cancer. Yet, this week, a panel convened by the same agency, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, declared that the radiation is possibly carcinogenic to humans. It made this pronouncement by press release before publishing a monograph that will lay out the basis for its concerns  and will give independent scientists their first chance to evaluate this new judgment.

title: Syed Saleem Shahzads Courage
description: The Pakistani journalist Syed Saleem Shahzad knew he was a marked man. Mr. Shahzad, who covered national security and terrorism, had received repeated threats from Pakistans powerful spy agency. Yet he courageously kept doing his job  until somebody silenced him. His body, his face horribly beaten, was buried on Wednesday.

title: Italy: Money Seized From Vatican Bank Is Released
description: Prosecutors in Rome ordered the release on Wednesday of 23 million Euros, or almost $33 million, seized from the Vatican Bank last year in a continuing money-laundering investigation. They said they released the money after the Vatican instituted new mechanisms to help it adhere to international anti-money laundering and antiterrorist financing standards. The changes included creating a financial watchdog to coordinate with international organizations  a new leaf for an organization known for its opaque finances. The Vatican on Wednesday said it appreciated the release of the funds. Prosecutors had preventively seized the funds last September and placed the banks top two financial officers under investigation on the grounds that they transferred the money without properly disclosing the sender or motive. The two officials remain under investigation but have not been charged with a crime. The Vatican has said the investigation is the result of a misunderstanding.

title: The Hague: Mladic Said to Be Cooperative
description: A war crimes tribunal official at The Hague said Wednesday that Ratko Mladic, who arrived there Tuesday, had been cooperative and appeared to have no cognitive difficulty. Mr. Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander, had earlier claimed he was mentally and physically unfit for trial. John Hocking, the court official, also said that Mr. Mladic was not placed on suicide watch. Mr. Mladic is due to make his first court appearance in a brief hearing on Friday, when he will be asked to enter his plea on charges including violations of the laws of war, crimes against humanity and genocide, court officials said. Mr. Mladic, 69, was arrested last week in Serbia after more than 15 years on the run. He spent his first night at The Hague in a separate section of the prison, without mingling with other tribunal prisoners, who include former friends and enemies from the Balkan wars.

title: Iraq: Blast at Policemans Wedding Kills 7

The blast went off before a significant number of people had arrived at the wedding, according to the security official. It was unclear who was behind the attack. Policemen and soldiers are often the targets of insurgents.

title: Vain Glorious | A New Book by Franois Nars
description: In his lush new how-to book, Makeup Your Mind: Express Yourself, the makeup artist Franois Nars uses real women as muses. Showcasing an incredible array of faces  there are all different ethnicities, ages and even a sprinkling of men  the dense tome contains before and after photos (shot by Nars himself) of each subject. A transparent overlay between the two shots shows you how and where to apply makeup, which is very effective. Seeing the outline of the shape you are trying to create helps you apply product in a more accurate, efficient way. Because you have a clear view of the before face, which is completely bare, you can see how a primer or a sheer glow or matte foundation changes skin quality, and how a simple application of makeup can bring a feature to life or downplay it. The book challenges you to take risks, and even the most seasoned makeup wearer will be enlightened. It brought me back to my teen years, when I delighted in playing with different, even extreme, looks. Building confidence and conveying a variety of moods through makeup, Nars inspires you to be playful, passionate, imaginative and, as he says, have an open spirit, and believe in your own beauty. Narss picks from his own line of cosmetics: the Multiple, All About Eve Eyeshadow Duo, EFA Night Infusion and the AquaGel Hydrator.

title: The Werewolf Within
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Alex Pappademass article (dare I say tribute?) in the magazine this week. Although Teen Wolf did well at the box office all those years ago, this current and rather astonishing flurry of attention and examination would certainly have been welcome on opening day. I believe that with any film, it is up to the filmmaker to put forth his or her story, and it is then up to the audience to ascribe motivations and meaning. Having said that, I thought you might be interested in a few of my intentions while directing the film. To me, this was never a film about a werewolf. It was about a normal kid fighting his way through puberty, girls, peer pressure, school, etc., who has a bomb dropped on him at the end of Act I. For me, the key scene in the film occurs when Scott, Michael J. Foxs character, reveals the wolf for the first time in public, during a basketball game. In about 20 seconds, the reactions of the actors go from horror, fear and amazement to curiosity and acceptance.

title: Does Twitter Make You Stupid?
description: As a high-school junior, I am deeply saddened by the attitude of despondency toward my generation expressed by Bill Keller in The Twitter Trap. There are some ill side effects of our prolonged exposure to the Internet, notably a shortened attention span and an unappeasable desire to be instantly gratified. But those are only the cons of being in constant communication with one another. Never before could a high-school student so brazenly reach out to a Harvard graduate student and ask for mentorship on his research paper. Never again will we think it odd for someone from the farthest corner of the globe to be exchanging witticisms on Twitter with a well-known celebrity.

Like Mad Men, this new X-Men indulges in period nostalgia as it gazes into the future, using the backdrop of the cold war (and its turtlenecks) to explore how the past informs the present (while also blowing stuff up).

title: 36 Hours in Stockholm
description: STOCKHOLMERS revel in the long days of summer when the sun rises as early as 3:30 a.m. and doesnt set until after 10 p.m. Many locals escape to their country houses, but those who remain in the city spend as much time as possible outdoors  an easy feat since water and parkland make up almost two-thirds of Stockholm. Situated on the Baltic at the mouth of Lake Malaren, Stockholm is built on 14 islands connected by bridges. On sunny days, waterside bars and cafes are packed with people wolfing down summer favorites like herring (served in a variety of ways) and toast Skagen (shrimp in mayonnaise with lemon and dill served with rye bread). Everywhere, visitors will find establishments  new and venerable  celebrating Nordic design, cuisine and culture.

title: Venice Biennale: The Enormity of the Beast

I spent the second day of press previews for the Venice Biennale in the Arsenale, a narrow gauntlet of art compared to the Giardini, with its discreet national pavilions and semblance of order. Here ILLUMInations, as the Biennale exhibition is called  having started in the spacious galleries of the Giardinis Central Pavilion  becomes a kind of extended scrum, spliced with additional national pavilions. The impossible enormity of the Biennale beast begins to sink in. title: Reliving a Drug Dealers Halcyon Days
description: Mr. Nice is an affable throwback to those guilt-free days when hippie drug dealers radiated the glamorous aura of avant-garde heroes risking prison to spread the doctrine of liberation through cannabis. The title comes from the name Donald Nice, one of many aliases adopted by Howard Marks, a notorious Welsh drug dealer, now 65, who made millions traveling around the world wheeling and dealing.

title: Q&A: Reopening Folders Automatically
description: Q.

title: DAVID SHAPIRO: Money Is No Object
description: Sue Scott Gallery

title: ALCHEMY & INQUIRY
description: Glyndor Gallery

title: A Night for the Faithful: Sister Act On Tap For Obama Re-Election Fundraiser
description: Tickets to the Broadway musical Sister Act usually top out at $200 for the best orchestra seats, but theyll zoom to $10,000 for the June 23 performance  because the price includes a photo shoot with President Obama, whose re-election campaign has chosen the production for his first major Broadway fundraiser for the 2012 cycle. One of the musicals lead producers, the actress Whoopi Goldberg, who starred in the original Sister Act movies, is a political supporter of Mr. Obamas and will host the evenings events at the Broadway Theater.

title: TOM FAIRS: Drawings
description: KS Art

title: Spare Times for June 3-9
description: Around Town

title: Financial Repression
description: Ive been getting questions about Carmen Reinharts new paper on financial repression (pdf) in the aftermath of large debt buildups, which asserts that said repression was a large part of the way the US and UK, in particular, dealt with their war debts.

title: Soaring Nods to Industry, Camping on an Island for the Summer
description: Since the city bought it for a dollar in 2003, Governors Island has evolved from a spooky relic to a postcollegiate playground to a family-friendly weekend destination.

title: Behold the Anonymous Downtrodden
description: Boris Mikhailovs photographs of homeless people in Ukraine are not for the squeamish. They are hard to look at, hard to look away from and hard to forget. The 19 examples in Case History at the Museum of Modern Art portray people who are far from conventionally attractive in grungy rooms or in wintry outdoor sites, naked or pulling aside their clothes to expose parts of their bodies ordinarily hidden from view. An older woman bends over to reveal buttocks ravaged by a pimply red rash. A young nude woman with arms tightly wrapped around herself stands in an evidently freezing bathroom next to a filthy toilet.

title: Behind the Cirque
description: A look at Cirque du Soleil and its reclusive impresario, Guy Lalibert.

title: Coming of Age, and Then to Terms
description: Submarine, the debut feature directed by Richard Ayoade, a well-known English television comedian, is as smart and self-conscious as its protagonist, a 15-year-old Welsh schoolboy named Oliver Tate (Craig Roberts). This is only fitting, since the movie, in the manner of precursors like Rushmore and Garden State, is more or less the movie Oliver would make about himself.

title: App Smart Extra: A Smartphone Magazine for Car Lovers
description: Car buyers can get real-time advice from a few good mobile apps, as todays App Smart column points out.

title: The Groupon I.P.O.: What Is Adjusted CSOI?
description: With its filing for an initial public offering, Groupon is shedding some light on its financials for the first time. But one question leaps out: What is the new metric the social-buying company calls adjusted CSOI?

title: Changing of the Baton At St. Martin in the Fields
description: The words Academy of St. Martin in the Fields are indelibly linked with the name  Neville Marriner in the minds of classical music radio listeners from recent decades. Now the academy, the renowned London chamber orchestra, will have a new name officially associated with it: Joshua Bell, who has been named the music director. Mr. Bell, who first played with the oft-recorded Academy in 1986, will spend six weeks next season performing with it as a violin soloist and directing from the leaders chair. His term starts in September and lasts for three years. Mr. Marriner, 87, founded the orchestra in 1958 and has the title of life president. Since 2000 Murray Perahia has been principal guest conductor.

title: Marions Shot Isnt Pretty, but Its Pretty Successful
description: MIAMI  It begins with a dainty tuck, hands pulled back, as if to shield himself from danger, the ball nestled against his clavicle. Shawn Marions feet rise in front of him, and his body becomes a drafting compass, his waist as its hinge.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for June 3-9
description: KIDSFILMFEST

title: Streetscapes | Fifth Avenue and 77th Street
description: William A. Clark lavished millions on his 1911 mansion at Fifth Avenue and 77th Street. His daughter Huguette, who died last month, lived there until 1927.

title: Resort: Castaways in Manhattan
description: On Thursday, the air swept clean of humidity, a few editors ducked into the shadows of 11 West 42nd Street and rode the elevator up to Michael Korss showroom. Waiters offered sparkling water and orange juice as perhaps 20 editors from various publications  Elle, W, Town & Country, In Style  stood in the blond-wood lobby checking their BlackBerrys or talking about when they were going to leave for the Hamptons or Fire Island for the weekend.

title: Remembering When Dad Came Out
description: There is all manner of love crisscrossing through Beginners, connecting mothers and fathers, parents and children, sons and lovers, men and their dogs. The love feels heartfelt but its difficult loving other people (the dog has it easy), a hardship thats evident in the happy-tearful faces, the tentative touches and searching glances that make this movie, or maybe all its yearning, so appealing. For the writer and director Mike Mills, who based this memory piece about a straight son and his dying gay father on his own life, love is a wonder even if its palpable reality largely remains elusive, a hoped-for gift locked in an adjacent room.

title: Series of Deft Negotiations Involving Ill-Advised Attire
description: Christine Elmo is easy to look at. Yes, shes attractive  petite with big eyes and a shock of dark hair  but Im talking movement-wise. She eats up a stage in bounding leaps, and shes terrifically precise, carving exact shapes in space that linger in the mind.

title: Hacker Group Claims Responsibility for New Sony Break-In
description: A hacker group calling itself LulzSec claimed responsibility on Thursday for breaking into a Sony Web site and stealing personal information of about 52,000 customers.

title: Jazz Listings for June 3-9
description: Jazz

title: A Double Helix of Art and Science
description: ANTOINE LAVOISIER was a scientific revolutionary. Among other things, this father of modern chemistry, as he is known, named oxygen and showed that breathing is a form of combustion.

title: Mercurial Dramas, Vertical and Horizontal
description: For all that he has been choreographing on both sides of the Atlantic for 15 years, Christopher Wheeldon is still young. Repertory on both sides of Lincoln Center Plaza has of late been enriched by three of his ballets. Last week American Ballet Theater presented the world premiere of his Thirteen Diversions at the Metropolitan Opera House; New York City Ballet recently revived his Polyphonia (2001) and offered his Mercurial Manoeuvres (2000) on Wednesday. He has made other fine works, but these three alone demonstrate why he has become so important to ballet worldwide.

title: Above the Grand Canal, Big Bamb Rises
description: VENICE  This jaded New Yorker wondered if it was really necessary to come all the way here to see Big Bamb: You Cant, You Dont, and You Wont Stop, a hugely popular installation by the artist twins Mike and Doug Starn when it appeared on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last summer.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for June 3-9
description: Classical

title: Instrumentalists at an Exhibition
description: In the left panel of Simon Dinnersteins painting The Fulbright Triptych a woman sits with a child on her lap. In the right panel a man also sits in a neutral posture. All three stare blankly out at the viewer.

title: 1. Make List; 2. Do Stuff
description: HERE is a partial list of the kinds of lists included in Lists: To-dos, Illustrated Inventories, Collected Thoughts, and Other Artists Enumerations, an exhibition beginning Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum: lists of bills to pay, things undone, failings in oneself and others; lists of people to call, stuff to buy, errands to be accomplished. There are also lots of lists of artworks, real and imaginary. Thats because all the material in the exhibition comes from the Archives of American Art at the Smithsonian Institution  mostly, as the curator of the exhibition, Liza Kirwin, remarked the other day, from drawers and folders marked Miscellaneous.

title: Delights Alongside Dark Notes
description: As the San Francisco singer Wesla Whitfield sang a slow, ruminative The Best Things in Life Are Free at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, you had the impression of a wise, silver-haired aunt gently reminding a high-strung, hyperactive nephew of what really matters. It is the flowers in spring and the robins that sing, not the toys he flung around the room in a fit of temper.

title: Dance Listings for June 3-9
description: Dance

title: Jazz in June: Sorting Through the Abundance
description: AS usual, jazz pervades June in New York City. Besides better-than-normal bookings in the clubs, were looking at the first Blue Note Jazz Festival (monthlong), the second Undead Jazzfest (June 23 to 26) and the 16th Vision Festival (Sunday through June 11).

title: Alia Creasey and Joshua Lilienstein
description: OF all the lines that Dr. Alia Creasey imagined might hook her into her dream relationship, this was not one: My hearing is not so good.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for June 3-9
description: Art

title: TimesCast | The Romney Factor
description: June 2, 2011 - Mitt Romney is officially running for president for a second time.

title: Gil Scott-Herons Link to Soccer
description: Last Friday, the music world lost a seminal figure in Gil Scott-Heron.

title: As Condos Fill, Retail Space Remains Vacant
description: RIVER LOFTS, a condominium at Laight and West Streets in TriBeCa, has attracted buyers like Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin, who live in a spectacular all-white apartment. At the same time, the buildings exterior has required such extensive repairs that, for much of the four years since it opened, it has looked more like a construction site than a posh residence.

title: Renovating City Hall, From Floor to Ceiling
description: High above the City Council chambers in City Hall on Thursday, Bertram Abdul spread a layer of plaster under the image of an eagle on the ceiling, finessing the edges to look like frosting on a cake.

title: Showing the Grandchildren a Grand Time in the Big City
description: Grandparents figured large in this weeks correspondence, as Mr. Critic received missives from parents of parents from here and from afar. This led to ruminations on what it means to be a child visiting New York City, and what it means to be a child who lives and eats out in restaurants here, and why it matters. As always, you can send your own questions about dining out in restaurants in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: So Successful, a New Ice Cream Shop Closes After 4 Days
description: If you thought the last thing brownstone Brooklyn needed was another purveyor of artisanal foods, you are officially wrong.

title: 72 Hours at the Venice Biennale
description: Christoph Niemann, the genius who recently discovered the shocking truth about the E.P.A., has arrived in Venice for the Art Biennale. Hell write about art, sure, but hes mainly there to chronicle the sublimity and ridiculousness of the scene. (Hes also going to complain about the fact that he lost his luggage on the way there, and hell be justified in doing so.) Anyway, his first postcards are already up, and theyre fantastic. Hell have many more coming over the next few days, so please keep checking back.

title: Huguette Clarks Worthless Girlhood Home
description: SINCE Huguette Clarks death last month, many eyes have zeroed in on her sumptuous suite of apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue, one of the most elegant buildings in New York.

title: Play On
description: The work of the Chinese artist Cao Fei turns its attention to childhood.

title: For Renters-to-Be, the High-Tech Lowdown
description: MILLIONS of New Yorkers are from outside the city, and many made the move as young adults. So hopeful transplants may believe that moving here and finding that first rental apartment will be a walk in the park.

title: Artists Heroic Struggle to Make Heroic Paintings
description: William T. Trego, a Victorian painter who specialized in battlefield scenes, killed himself by taking poison during a June heat wave in 1909, when he was 50. He was broke and physically debilitated from a childhood ailment that was probably polio.

title: IMHO
description: Humility has a bad reputation. The definition for humility and humbleness in my Random House dictionary includes: having feelings of insignificance, inferiority, subserviencelow in rank, importance, status, quality etc. But recently I sat in on a panel at the Association for Psychological Science convention where the scholars had a much more appreciative view.

title: The Work of Tod Seelie
description: The photographer Tod Seelie began taking snapshots of his friends. Now he brings his camera  and, with it, his audience  into some of the citys most unusual and arresting happenings.

title: A Place With the Family Seal of Approval
description: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least until my life expanded, she said.

title: Q & A
description: Two, and Only Two, Building Entry Keys

title: Syrians to March for Young Martyrs
description: Syrians calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down plan to march on Friday in memory of children who have been killed during the uprising, The Associated Press reports.

title: Statements Skip Over REITs Woes
description: Late 2007 was among the worst times ever to invest in real estate, and those who did so have losses to show for it.

title: The Peril of Social Media and the Jobless Rate's Effect on the President's Re-election Hopes
description: The peril of social media for N.Y. Congressman Anthony Weiner and the jobless rate's effect on the President's re-election hopes. Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman, Washington correspondent Sheryl Gay Stolberg, and chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: City Ordered to Continue Housing Programs Rent Payments
description: Updated, June 3 | An appellate court ruled on Thursday that the city must continue paying rent for thousands of families who moved out of city shelters through the Bloomberg administrations Advantage housing subsidy program.

title: On a Mediterranean Cruise Ship Steered by a Godardian Crew
description: Gertrude Stein once wrote that Ezra Pound, one of the sacred monsters of literary modernism, was a village explainer, excellent if you were a village, if not, not. Jean-Luc Godards place in late-20th-century French cinema is not unlike Pounds in midcentury Anglophone poetry: endlessly influential and perpetually controversial, a longtime resident of the middle ground between sage and crank. But at this point in his career Mr. Godard is better described as a village mystifier. Which is excellent if you happen to inhabit the global village of easily accessible, disposable images. We villagers tend to like our movies comfortable and familiar, and this mans job is to make them difficult and strange.

title: New Ad Attacks Obama on Peace Proposal
description: Continuing Republican attacks against President Obama for the details of his Middle East peace proposal, a conservative pro-Israel group has started running an advertisement describing Mr. Obama as having sided with the Palestinians.

title: With Yoga and Fasting, Graft Fighters Shake India
description: NEW DELHI  For more than 40 years, reformers and other agitators have tried in vain to cleanse India of corruption. They have staged demonstrations, candlelight vigils and protest marches for naught. In Parliament, efforts to create an independent anticorruption agency began in 1968. It still does not exist.

title: A Menagerie Where Pets Do the Staring
description: Every afternoon except Tuesday, when this Upper West Side temple to alternative pets  jungle birds, desert reptiles and all things aquatic  is closed, Bob Myles and his Norfolk terrier, Bruno, pop through the front door and make a beeline for the spectacular glassed-in aviary at the back. There, Bruno plants himself on his haunches, nose to glass, and stares at the parrots in free flight on the other side. Mr. Myles, who lives in the neighborhood, is a regular at the shop, Fauna, but not a customer. Bruno leads me here, and the people who run the store are very gracious about it, he said. They know were just here to look. The little green parrots are his favorites.

title: The Power of Voices Lifted in Song
description: Theologians and clergy members of every religious stripe may debate the existence of God until the cows come home. But as demonstrated by Rejoice and Shout, Don McGlynns documentary history of African-American gospel music, reasonable arguments are nothing compared with the power of voices lifted in song to invoke the Holy Spirit. Your religion or lack of one doesnt matter. At some point while watching the film, you may feel that music is God, or if not, a close approximation of divinity.

title: A Bullish Fox Says Sales Are Up 10 Percent
description: The Fox network announced a rather quick end to its upfront advertising sales Thursday, with a healthy increase that signaled how avid the market is for commercials on network programs.

title: T. J. Gottesdiener
description: Mr. Gottesdiener, 56, is a managing partner in the New York office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, one of the worlds largest architectural firms, best known for its skyscrapers.

title: Weiner Has Done Himself No Favors
description: At the end of the day, however, fair or not, many of the questions and most of the talk  theyre being fueled by Congressman Weiner himself.  Anderson Cooper on CNN

title: Obama Campaign Revs Up Money Machine
description: With his field of potential Republican opponents still taking shape, President Obama will seek to raise $60 million by the end of June for his re-election campaign and the Democratic Party.

title: When Is a Child Ready for Kindergarten?
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends, Football and Fun
description: Almost everyone who has ever been in a modern-art museum has had the experience of staring at some concoction  blobs of color, a mash-up of metals  and thinking the clich: But is it art? Something similar might occur to viewers of Turkey Bowl, a quirky offering by Kyle Smith that does nothing more or less than show a touch-football game among friends. Its sort of interesting, you might find yourself saying, but is it a film?

title: Handling Combat Stress
description: To the Editor:

title: The Politics of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Bloombergs Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: Standards at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Special-Session Time, but to Whose Advantage?
description: Texas lawmakers are back for a special session that started the day after their 140-day regular session. Thats something like sprinting to the finish of a long race and having your coach yell, just as you break the tape, One more lap.

title: An Environmental Horror Story
description: Thoroughly fed up but refusing to give in, the residents of the Coal River valley in West Virginia endure earsplitting explosions, raining boulders, toxic sludge and poisoned wells. Their tormentor is the union-busting, environmental-law-flouting Massey Energy Company and its use of the controversial mining strategy called mountaintop removal. Their solution is a grass-roots campaign to force the company to cease and desist, and Bill Haneys furious documentary, The Last Mountain, is completely on board.

title: A Welcome Mat for Builders
description: IN November 2007, a few months after Pat Meyersfield retired from the Great Neck school system, she and her husband, Sanford, drove through the North Fork visiting wineries, farm stands and model homes that in those days were popping up like clover in the midst of farm fields.

title: The Suburban Side of Newark
description: NEWARK

title: Legal Outsourcing Firms Creating Jobs for American Lawyers
description: Career prospects can look dim these days for young American lawyers.

title: Analysis: Nadal vs. Murray, and a Matter of Aggressiveness
description: Andy Murray faces Rafael Nadal in Fridays first French Open semifinal at Roland Garros. The two played a hugely entertaining match in early May in Monte Carlo, with Nadal prevailing in three sets. Murray is a shrewd tactician, a genius with the racket who can play with touch, power and variety. But he faces the top-seeded Nadal, who, as defending champion, appears to be playing better with each round.

title: McIlroy Has Eyes on Bigger Issues Than Golf
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  It was a mundane question for the Memorial Tournament co-leader Rory McIlroy on Thursday  Whats your plan leading up to the Open? And it generated a response that shed much light on the values and social conscience of McIlroy, a 22-year-old from Northern Ireland.

title: Coming Soon: A Town Within a City
description: YONKERS

title: When the Seller Is the Lender
description: MORTGAGE underwriting is tight, and home sellers are anxious to unload properties into a stagnant market  it sounds as if it could be time to consider seller financing.

title: Analysis: Schiavone Won by Playing Smart in the Wind
description: Francesca Schiavone played smart tennis in the wind to defeat Marion Bartoli in straight sets in a French Open semifinal Thursday at Roland Garros. Knowing that Bartoli thrives when she can control the middle of the court, where she drives double-fisted groundstrokes hard and flat into the corners, Schiavone used spin, height and placement to keep Bartoli off balance. The defending champion defended grittily, sliding on the clay to make Bartoli hit one more ball.

title: Democrats Voice Support for Elizabeth Warren
description: A group of Democratic lawmakers urged President Obama on Thursday to appoint Elizabeth Warren to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a plea that further escalated the bitter partisan battle over the fledgling agencys future.

title: A Malibu Mystery, Washed in by the Tide
description: MALIBU, Calif.  Descending the steep cliffside steps to a slice of sand near Point Dume can feel like arriving on a deserted island. There are no cars as far as the eye can see, just a small tuck of shoreline accessible by foot  and only by those who are willing to follow a winding dirt path.

title: The Dos and Donts of I Do
description: If there is a special hell for film critics, it probably has movies like Love, Wedding, Marriage on continuous rotation. A supposed romantic comedy with less romance  and significantly less comedy  than the instructions on a condom wrapper, this charmless clunker is the directing debut of the actor Dermot Mulroney. We can only hope that he isnt planning to quit his day job.

title: Captain Hannum Attends the Philippi Races
description: The sleepy hamlet of Philippi, nestled in the bucolic hills of western Virginia, awoke to bedlam on June 3, 1861. Early that morning, a federal force of about 3,000 in two columns converged on a camp of some 1,000 Confederates in what would be the first conventional engagement of the Civil War.

title: A Direct Approach to Disaster Relief From Procter & Gamble
description: MANY companies have donated money and goods in the wake of the tornado that devastated Joplin, Mo., and left at least 138 people dead. But in addition to donating to disaster relief groups, Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods giant, is taking the unusual approach of providing disaster relief directly.

title: Fighting Losing Battles Against Isolation
description: Fans of the guitarist-writer-actress Carrie Brownstein and her goofy television show, Portlandia, will need to adjust their expectations for Some Days Are Better Than Others. Starring Ms. Brownstein and another indie-music hero, James Mercer of the Shins, the film uses Portland and other Oregon locations (shot very prettily by Greg Schmitt) as a backdrop for neo-Depression anomie and darkly shaded melancholia.

title: At 46, Bernard Hopkins Keeps Surviving, His Way
description: PHILADELPHIA  For his latest reinvention, Bernard Hopkins  street thug, convict, boxer, champion, retiree, champion again  wants to inspire aging athletes and spread the gospel of healthy living. Yes, that Bernard Hopkins. Once prisoner No. 44145.

title: Banking and Bad Behavior
description: As expensive looking as any film about money ought to be, the Taiwanese historical melodrama Empire of Silver is rather an odd duck. (And not just because yes, that is indeed Jennifer Tilly in a supporting role.) Hovering somewhere between dryly factual base-touching and sails-to-the-wind dynastic extravagance, this weirdly engaging tale of banking and bad behavior makes 19th-century China look uncomfortably like 21st-century America.

title: In Bay Area, Youngsters Are More Prone to Bicycle Accidents
description: For the Sorensen family of Alameda, the sound of knuckles rapping on the garage door was a familiar annoyance. It was their 13-year-old son, Brandon, who knocked on the door so frequently to put away his bicycle that his parents finally got him an access code to open the garage on his own.

title: Companies May Face Rule to Shift Audit Firms
description: Publicly traded companies may be forced to change their audit firms after several years, the chief regulator of the industry said Thursday.

title: The Mistake of 2010
description: Earlier this week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York published a blog post about the mistake of 1937, the premature fiscal and monetary pullback that aborted an ongoing economic recovery and prolonged the Great Depression. As Gauti Eggertsson, the posts author (with whom I have done research) points out, economic conditions today  with output growing, some prices rising, but unemployment still very high  bear a strong resemblance to those in 1936-37. So are modern policy makers going to make the same mistake?

title: 25 More Cookbooks
description: ANCIENT GRAINS FOR MODERN MEALS. By Maria Speck. (Ten Speed Press, $29.99.) Mediterranean whole-grain recipes for barley, farro, kamut, polenta, wheat berries and more.

title: Up Front: Sam Sifton
description: In the age of Google, its not that hard to find a photograph of Sam Sifton  but were not about to make his day job, as the restaurant critic of The New York Times, any more difficult by printing one here. (Besides, he tells us hes taller now than in any extant picture, with much longer hair.)

title: Additional Gardening Books
description: Inspired by Seattle Tilth, a community of learning gardens, Lisa Taylors YOUR FARM IN THE CITY: An Urban Dwellers Guide to Growing Food and Raising Animals (Black Dog & Leventhal, paper, $18.95) includes helpful plant profiles and useful design ideas. For straightforward and lovely kitchen garden designs, along with helpful tips for companion plantings, consult Ellen Ecker Ogdens COMPLETE KITCHEN GARDEN (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, paper, $24.95). Graham Kerr, of Galloping Gourmet fame, makes the most mouth-watering garden-to-table connection with simple, unpretentious recipes in GROWING AT THE SPEED OF LIFE: A Year in the Life of My First Kitchen Garden (Perigee, $27). And for those who neglected to sow beans in the spring, its not too late. With the guidance of the clear, concise instructions in Edward C. Smiths VEGETABLE GARDENERS CONTAINER BIBLE: How to Grow a Bounty of Food in Pots, Tubs and Other Containers (Storey, paper, $19.95), you can get a complete kitchen garden going. Just be prepared to do a lot of watering.

title: Cookbooks
description: The lamb shakes rain from his wool, pea tendrils rise from the earth and a new yield of cookbooks arrives on bookstore shelves, ready for the fire. I worked with more than a dozen this spring, cooking like a summertime madman and considering sentences beautiful and lame. I read fantasy and prepared truth, imagined myself cooking in England and France, Mumbai and California, Italy, Spain, North Carolina, Georgia, Vancouver, Seoul. I made beautiful meals and terrible ones, found myself well instructed, poorly instructed, often coddled, sometimes lied to, perpetually amused.

title: Gardening Books
description: The garden book jury has returned a verdict. You are either growing vegetables or you have become one. Attitude looms as large as artichokes. Unfortunately, the important book on how exactly to overhaul farms too big to fail has yet to be written  mainly because the standard wisdom is that they are, by definition, beyond hope of sustainability. But with over 300 million people in the United States, and with the global population approaching seven billion, most people will continue to depend for their meals on staggeringly large-scale agriculture. Whats to be done?

title: Travel Books
description: Failed relationships, broken marriages and dead-end careers are among the catalysts that lead this seasons travel writers to hit the road. The escapees range from a middle-aged journalist seeking high-altitude transcendence in the Himalayas to a frustrated poetry scholar in search of beauty among the holy spots of Iran. And then theres the global nomad torn between a longing for domestic tranquility and a masochistic impulse to throw himself into the worlds messy heart. This summers selection also includes authors driven by simple journalistic curiosity and academic inquiry, but its the more tortured souls whose journeys resonate the most.

title: Fall of the Wild
description: GLEN ELLEN, Calif.  Dead at the age of 40, Jack London left behind more than 50 books produced by his fevered pen, a string of opinionated lovers and a Sonoma Valley ranch he described as heaven on earth.

title: Antagonists Abound in the Initial Plot Line
description: Edmonton Oilers defenseman Ryan Whitney, at home in Boston, told a sports radio station Wednesday that the Vancouver Canucks were an easy team to hate.

title: The Depravity Factor
description: By now you have probably heard about Hamza Ali al-Khateeb. He was the 13-year-old Syrian boy who tagged along at an antigovernment protest in the town of Saida on April 29. He was arrested that day, and the police returned his mutilated body to his family a month later. While in custody, he had apparently been burned, beaten, lacerated and given electroshocks. His jaw and kneecaps were shattered. He was shot in both arms. When his father saw the state of Hamzas body, he passed out.

title: Showdown on Swipe Fees Likely Soon
description: The battle on Capitol Hill over capping swipe fees, the charges that banks collect from retailers when a customer makes a purchase with a debit card, could be approaching a final showdown.

title: Hong Kong Looks to Regain Footing as I.P.O. Leader
description: HONG KONG  Is Hong Kong, the global leader for initial public offerings in 2009 and 2010, in danger of losing its coveted title this year?

title: Japans Misguided Foreign Acquisitions
description: Japan Inc.s latest mantra is that, with the domestic market shrinking, companies must hurry to make acquisitions abroad. But they should resist the temptation of international mergers and acquisitions adventurism. Creating more competitive enterprises through domestic consolidation would be better for the country in the long run  not to mention for shareholders, who are too often an afterthought in Japan.

title: Living In | Ozone Park, Queens
description: The housing stock consists mainly of single- and two-family detached colonials on roomy lots; an architectural exception is Tudor Village.

title: For Men, Shot at Final Is Just a Part of the Stakes
description: PARIS  The focus in mens tennis has shifted at this Grand Slam tournament. For years, it has been on Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, but this time  from practice courts to match day  the emphasis has been on the games third man turned essential man: Novak Djokovic.

title: Syria Continues Attacks on Protesters While Calling for Dialogue
description: CAIRO  Syrias military forces continued pressing to crush a three-month-old popular uprising on Thursday, shelling a string of southern and central towns even as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned President Bashar al-Assad that his legitimacy had nearly run out.

title: Chemicals in Farm Runoff Rattle States on the Mississippi
description: As the surging waters of the Mississippi pass downstream, they leave behind flooded towns and inundated lives and carry forward a brew of farm chemicals and waste that this year  given record flooding  is expected to result in the largest dead zone ever in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Battle For Libya | June 2, 2011
description: Libyan rebels went through military training in Benghazi before heading to the frontline.

title: IPad Rivals Fail to Gain Traction, a Report Says
description: Technology companies who hoped to outdo the Apple iPad by offering alternate slate-like products are not seeing the demand they hoped for from consumers, according to an analysts report issued by JPMorgan Chase.

A former gateway to Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, the arch is today a national historic site; it even appears on the 100-afghani note. The arch withstood centuries of invasions, but today its a crumbling mess of inept supports and clumsy renovations.

description: In the middle of February, 300 men and women of voting age answered a special summons for jury duty at the federal courthouse in Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn. They were ushered into a grand ceremonial courtroom to see if they might be candidates to serve as jurors in the case of the United States of America v. Vincent Basciano. His nom de mob is Vinny Gorgeous.
