description: From Todays Times:

title: Despite Criticism, Berlin Art Festival Arrives
description: When Based in Berlin, an art festival runningJune 8 to July 24 at a handful of venues around the city, was first announced at the end of last year, it was dubbed a Leistungsschau  an exhibit of achievement  for young Berlin artists, complete with a citywide open call. The city had allotted about 1.4 million euros (about $2 million) to the exhibition.

title: Tip of the Week: Seeing the Forest for the Windows
description: Need to find a certain open window on your desktop  but you cannot fully see it in the clutter of other open windows on the screen? Both Windows 7 and Mac OS X include features that help you focus quickly on the one window you need to find.

title: A Turning Point for the East Village, 20 Years Later
description: When the city of New York built a band shell near the southern end of Tompkins Square Park in 1966, it was quickly embraced by people who began using it for concerts, rallies and poetry readings. Twenty-five years later, after police and protesters battled during a Memorial Day concert in the park, city officials closed it for renovations that lasted more than a year and included the destruction of the band shell.

title: Reaching Your Limit as a Business Owner
description: I remember the day I reached my limit with the retail coffee and espresso business that my husband and I started in 2003. When we started our little food service venture, it was supposed to be a fun project that would eventually run itself and act as an additional source of income for our household. But after three years, two locations and countless hours, it became evident that our plan was easier said than done.

title: Bodies Recovered After Migrants Boat Founders
description: PARIS  The Tunisian authorities have recovered the bodies of 150 refugees, mostly sub-Saharan Africans, who drowned after their boat foundered this week in the Mediterranean Sea, a United Nations official said Friday, but up to 120 refugees were still missing.

title: Nadal Beats Murray to Reach Finals
description: PARIS  Rafael Nadal of Spain defeated Andy Murray of Great Britain, 6-4, 7-5, 6-4, to reach the final round of the French Open Friday, giving him a chance to win a sixth crown at Roland Garros.

title: Good News, and Bad, About Community Services
description: Five years ago, the first edition of The Maturing of America, a report undertaken by the National Association of Area Agencies on Aging with groups representing local governments and city planners, found that most communities hadnt begun to plan for the tidal shifts of the coming years. The proportion of people older than 65 is expected to swell from 13 percent of the nations population today to nearly 20 percent by 2030.

title: The Woman With Creeping Paralysis
description: SYMPTOMSA 50-year-old woman came to the emergency room at St. Marys Hospital in Waterbury, Conn., with severe tooth pain. After several hours she was sent home with a painkiller and an antibiotic to treat a presumed dental abscess. The pills didnt help. Two days later, the woman awoke in excruciating pain. It felt as if a knife were being plunged into her tooth, her jaw, her face. She called her son, but as soon as she began to tell him how terrible the pain was, he cut her off: Ma, why are you talking like that? Her words were slurred, as if she were having a hard time getting them out of her mouth. Hang up, he told her; then he called 911.

title: Five-Ku: Short Poems on the Films of Brad Pitt
description: Thelma and Louise: Your abs alone deserved aStar on Walk of Fame. Moral of Se7en:When a psycho sends FedExNever sign for it.

title: In Israel, a Soccer Game Reflects a Divide
description: Its 10 minutes before game time, and the police lined up outside the entrances of Doha Stadium arent letting anyone in. If Bnei Sakhnin, the only Arab-Israeli team in Israels first division, loses today, the club will drop to the second division, an ignominious distinction, the equivalent of going from the major to minor leagues in baseball.

title: How Football Players Got Trounced by Glee
description: You cant blame NBC for thinking that it had a winner on its hands when Friday Night Lights had its premiere in 2006. The football drama translated the nostalgia and longing of small-town existence into moments of surprising sweetness and grace, while embracing dramatic improvisation and documentary-style camera work that placed this naturally humble tale at the stylistic forefront of TV. And it did this in the service of its central story, which, along with dissecting the harsh continual sorting of winner from loser in American life, thoughtfully explored 1) the little triumphs and defeats of high school; 2) the perils of striving for an egalitarian marriage; 3) the trials of young love; 4) the charms and flaws of a small town; 4) the charms and flaws of people who live in small towns; and 5) the uncertain futures of young people with big (and often delusional) dreams.

title: A Theory of Conspiracy Theories
description: Dear Mr. Keller: Last night on the PBS NewsHour, they had a story about some Los Angeles Times reporters who uncovered corruption in a nearby, small city in California. The newspaper eventually received a Pulitzer Prize. That is what you can have if you will talk with me. Within one hour, I will convince you and your staff that Lee Oswald did not assassinate President Kennedy. Then, I will give you the evidence for the real killers, and how the cover up could be perpetrated. It is a great story, fully documented and supported with facts, many from the Warren Commission itself!!

title: Barbara Sinatras Way
description: In your new book, Lady Blue Eyes, you describe one of your earliest visits to Frank Sinatras Palm Springs home, when you were still married to his neighbor, Zeppo Marx. You were keeping time for a charades game, and when you called time on Sinatra, he grabbed a clock from your hands and smashed it against a door. You never thought, Wow, getting involved with this man might be dangerous?  I never felt danger around him. He was always very much a gentleman, and he really cared about treating me well. He came from Hoboken, where the streets were very tough. I guess some of that came back when he was drinking.

title: Lesson Lent
description: My daughter-in-laws parents forgot to make payments on the $17,000 loan they took out for her college 14 years ago, when she was 19. Now they owe $40,000, and their tax refunds and Social Security are being garnished. Her parents are of limited means. My son is not, but he and my daughter-in-law believe that this is a problem of her parents own making (through mismanagement of money, gambling and not working as much as they could) and the debt is their responsibility. What do you think? J.G., BOCA RATON, FLA.

title: Who, What and Where is Bon Iver?
description: Even by Kanye West standards, the Bowery Ballroom show last November was a spectacle. West had chosen the tiny club for a surprise concert, celebrating the release of My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, and it didnt take long for the scrum outside to get ugly. Having tickets, which went on sale that day and sold out instantly, didnt guarantee entry. The line stretched around the corner, and for most people, thats as far as they got. Even those who made it inside  rappers, models, record-company executives, Diddy, Spike Lee, ordinary fans with the good fortune to have shown up very early  had to endure an hours-long wait.

title: Wednesday Night Is All Right for Loving
description: Love is blind. Of course it is. Still, theres no reason to believe that there arent legitimate, data-driven ways to improve your dating life. So I recently joined up with Christian Rudder of OkCupid, a matchmaking site that takes a playful attitude toward the data it collects (like which camera takes the most successful profile photos). I asked Rudder if there was a way to determine which days of the week  and which times of day  are the best to meet someone at a bar. What he came up with is something called the sexual availability index.

title: Whole-Life Premium
description: Lacy, the auto-insurance agent, transfers me.

title: Bulb In, Bulb Out
description: Over the past few years, in conditions of strict secrecy, a multinational team of scientists has been making a mighty effort to change the light bulb. The prototype theyve developed is four inches tall, with a familiar tapered shape, and unlighted, it resembles a neon yellow mushroom. Screw it in and switch it on, though, and it blazes with a voluptuous radiance. It represents what people within the lighting industry often call their holy grail, an invention that reproduces the soft luminance of the incandescent bulb  Thomas Edisons century-old technology  but conforms to much higher standards of energy efficiency and durability. The prototype is supposed to last for more than 22 years, maybe as long as you own your house, so you wont need to stock up at the supermarket. And thats fortunate, because one day very soon, traditional incandescent bulbs wont be available in stores anymore. Theyre about to be effectively outlawed.

title: In Defense of the Slow and the Boring
description: WHAT is boring? This question was inspired by a piece in the May 1 edition of The New York Times Magazine by Dan Kois that offered a cheerful conformists take on what in certain circles is sometimes termed slow cinema and that he simply finds boring, the equivalent of eating his cultural vegetables. Mr. Kois writes that he knows hes supposed to embrace celebrated films that he variously describes as slow-moving, meditative and stately, austere and deliberately paced. But he cant, wont, doesnt like or understand them. In this he empathizes with his 6-year-old daughter, Lyra, who, at a friends urging, tuned into Phineas and Ferb, a TV show that she doesnt fully get but watches aspirationally, as a sort of challenge to herself.

title: Defiant Showman Demands His Wow
description: MONTREAL  With a wolfish grin, mangled pinky and a bald head shaped like a bullet, Guy Lalibert, a co-founder and the owner of Cirque du Soleil, looks like a man with a plan for world domination. Appearances, in this case, do not deceive.

title: E. Coli Source Remains a Mystery as Death Toll Rises
description: BERLIN  German health experts sought without immediate success on Friday to identify the source of a strain of E .coli spreading alarm through Europe, which international officials have described as a super toxic variant of the infection.

title: Campaign Catch-Up: The Republican Candidates
description: The 2012 presidential campaign is picking up steam, and it can be hard to follow all of the candidates and potential candidates. So The Caucus has a roundup of what theyve all been up to.

title: Friday Reading: Why Obesity Can Affect Economic Success
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Sketching a New Home for the Buffalo
description: Got a flair for graphic design and a passion for buffalo? The Interior Department has an assignment for you.

title: Hiring in U.S. Slowed in May With 54,000 Jobs Added
description: After several months of strong job growth, hiring in the United States slowed sharply in May, suggesting the economy may be running out of steam once again.

title: Extra! Extra! Lindeberg Has Landed!
description: Its big news when the Swedish import Johan Lindeberg, former C.E.O. of Diesel and creator of the popular J. Lindeberg label, celebrates a new project. His vowel-free clothing line, BLK DNM, a well-edited collection of downtown must-haves for men and women (available at us.blkdnm.com), will soon have a temporary home at Pop 1 in SoHo, starting June 8.

title: Suicide Bombers Attack a Mosque and a Hospital in Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD  Violence erupted north of Baghdad on Friday as a suicide bomber attacked at a mosque, and then several hours later another suicide bomber attacked the hospital where the wounded were being treated.

title: Yemeni President Wounded in Palace Attack
description: WASHINGTON  The embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, narrowly survived an attack on the presidential palace Friday morning when an explosion wounded him and a half-dozen other government officials in a brazen strike sure to intensify Yemens bloody civil conflict.

title: Dr. Jack Kevorkian Dies at 83; A Doctor Who Helped End Lives
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the medical pathologist who willfully helped dozens of terminally ill people end their lives, becoming the central figure in a national drama surrounding assisted suicide, died on Friday in Royal Oak., Mich. He was 83.

title: Shares Drop on Weak Monthly Jobs Report
description: Stocks on Wall Street slumped on Friday after a disappointing monthly government jobs report showed that hiring in the United States slowed in May, sending both the Dow and the broader market down to their fifth consecutive weekly loss.

title: Keep My Boldface Name Out of It
description: WAS that Lady Gaga touring a penthouse at the Soho Mews in what looked like a bra and panties? Yes, it was. But, a broker joked, the apartment had too many windows and so she didnt buy there. Instead, it was Justin Timberlake who took the place.

title: Big Deal | A Castle, in Yonkers, on the Market for $4.95 Million
description: Kohle Yohannan is a writer, but he is often at a loss for words when he tries to describe the house he recently decided to sell.

title: An Early Celebration Leaves the Heat With a Game 2 Hangover
description: MIAMI  Eleven months later, LeBron James and Dwyane Wade are still being pilloried for their prancing. The two hyper-scrutinized Miami Heat stars cannot pump a fist, high a five or otherwise show elation without a quick backlash.

title: What A Drag
description: From Goldman Sachs, an estimate of the federal budget impact on growth. The gray line shows the direct impact, the blue line includes the induced multiplier effects. Notice that this shows the rate of change, not the level effects. I explained the difference a while back.

title: The American Way
description: From First Draft:

title: Libyan Dissident Says She Was Beaten in Qatar During Forced Deportation
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, on Thursday Qatar forcibly deported a Libyan woman whose mistreatment by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi made her a symbol of its brutality.

title: Liquidity Preference and Loanable Funds, Still (Wonkish)
description: More than two years have passed since the big debate over the effect of budget deficits on interest rates in a liquidity trap. The original argument of the anti-stimulus types was that large-scale government borrowing would drive up interest rates even in the face of high unemployment, and that this would hurt the economy. At that time the argument was framed in terms of simple crowding out, not solvency. And I argued that the whole thing represented a failure to understand basic macroeconomics.

title: We Want Your Travel Questions
description: Do you have a question about an upcoming trip? Looking for information on where to go? Youve come to the right place. For our regular Q&A column, which appears both on this blog and in our print section, we want your questions about travel. Post them below, or e-mail them to travmail@nytimes.com. (A tip: be specific, but not too specific. And ask ahead of time  if you are hoping to travel next week, its probably too late.)

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: The Logic in Refusing to Block Masseys Sale
description: Stuart Grant, one of the name partners of the law firm Grant & Eisenhofer, is mad.

title: As Styles of Handball Clash, Two High-School Stars Are Disqualified
description: The finer points of street handball, unlike other youth sports, are not learned from camps and coaches and clinics, but from pickup games on hot concrete courts around the city. There is no professional league to aspire to; college scholarships are rare.

title: Robert Redford, Mr. Nice Guy
description: We all like to count among our friends principled people who are serious about their chosen profession and dedicated to working toward the greater good. But do we want to read about them? Thats the uphill battle fought by Michael Feeney Callan in his meticulous, tiptoeingly respectful Robert Redford: The Biography, which covers in detail Redfords four-decade acting career, his emergence as a director and his dedication to environmental causes. Redford is also, of course, the founder of the Sundance Institute, established in 1981 to help independent filmmakers polish their skills and bring their work to a wider audience; in 1985 he expanded the Sundance empire by taking over the United States Film and Video Festival, thereafter known as the Sundance Film Festival.

title: How Obama Loses
description: I didnt care much for Mitt Romneys speech yesterday announcing his presidential bid. It struck me as vintage Romney, by which I mean it resembled a somewhat tin-eared consultants idea of the kind of political speech right-wing primary voters want to hear. (Okay, now the anti-European boilerplate: The President seems to take his inspiration not from the small towns and villages of New Hampshire but from the capitals of Europe. Now the hyperbole: We are only inches away from ceasing to be a free market economy. Now the completely non-specific promises to cut spending: I will cap federal spending at 20% or less of the GDP and finally, finally balance the budget. Now the clunky one-liner: You know, if you want to create jobs, it helps to have had a job. Now wait for the applause )

title: SmartyPig Cuts Interest Rates Yet Again
description: Its official: After cutting its interest rate for the third time in nearly nine months, SmartyPigs rates are no longer the most attractive in the land of online savings accounts. The spectacled Pig is merely average.

title: Assessing the Value of Owning Dividend-Paying Stocks
description: THE first security I was ever aware of was a dividend-paying stock, the AT&T shares that my grandfather, a retired postman, owned when I was little. Those shares along with some other dividend-paying stocks formed the foundation of his nest egg. By reinvesting his dividends, he was able to amass sizable savings for someone who probably never earned more than $20,000 a year.

title: What Dick Van Dyke and Barbara Eden Wrought
description: In the snowy cathode days before cable TV, let alone niche channels like Nick at Nite or TV Land, misshapen UHF antennas and God-forsaken rabbit ears pulled in, if you were lucky, three networks and a handful of independent stations. The latter broadcast an era-and-mind-scrambling mixture of reruns  a daily delirium wherein The Honeymooners might rub shoulders with The Avengers, The Rifleman was just a shot away from That Girl, and a mad parade of castaways, cowboys, talking horses, detectives, bewitching witches, doctors, avuncular Martians, fugitives and flying nuns followed Route 66 straight into The Twilight Zone.

title: Edwards Charged With Election Finance Fraud
description: John Edwards, the former Democratic senator from North Carolina and nominee for vice president in 2004, was once one of his partys most promising young stars. But on Friday he found himself in a stunning fall from grace  in a courtroom in North Carolina, being read his rights.

title: A Daughter Remembers Cary Grant
description: When Jennifer Grant was born, in 1966, a 62-year-old Cary Grant retired from movies to concentrate on fatherhood. Following a divorce from Jennifers mother, Dyan Cannon, soon after, he began keeping an actual vault of photographs, audiotapes, Super 8 films and meticulously labeled aides-mmoires of and for his only child. Jennifer Grants stream-of-consciousness hagiography offers glimpses of this material, along with a torrent of filial piety.

title: Indictment Shows Six Counts Against Edwards
description: John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina and presidential candidate, was indicted Friday morning by a grand jury in Raleigh on charges that he violated campaign finance law during his 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Paramount Pictures, From the Peak
description: In 1967, when the lumbering old Hollywood studios were about to be shaken up by independent, visionary filmmakers, Peter Bart left his job as a New York Times reporter to become Paramount Pictures No. 2 production executive. Infamous Players, Barts breezy, anecdotal account of his eight years at the studio, casts him as the level-headed Sancho Panza to his pal, the production head Robert Evans, who comes across as a risk-taking, eventually cocaine-fueled Don Quixote. Together they led Paramount out of the dark ages of big-budget disasters like Darling Lili into the glorious, cutting-edge era of The Godfather, Rosemarys Baby and Chinatown.

title: The Commentariat Candidate
description: Jonathan Chait thinks Paul Ryan will run for president, and that he might well be the Republican nominee. Interesting point. On the surface, it seems crazy: Ryans budget plan is, after all, both spectacularly bad policy and spectacularly bad politics. But Ryan may have a secret weapon: despite everything, much of the punditocracy (myself obviously not included) still has a crush on him.

title: Metropolitan Museum Raising Suggested Admission Fee
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, facing what it calls a number of daunting, ongoing budgetary challenges, has decided to raise its suggested admission fee to $25, from $20, where it has been set for the last five years. The change takes effect July 1.

title: A Chronicler of the Art-Vandal Underground
description: In the windy darkness of a recent spring morning, 30 people of an arty, mostly Brooklynite persuasion gathered after midnight for an illicit get-together in a maintenance shed, high atop the Williamsburg Bridge. Billed as the Third-Annual NYC Undercover, You-Might-Be-Arrested, Clandestine Errantry Trespassing Adventure Party, the event attracted members of a distinct, risk-taking subset of the New York art world  heights-loving writers, courageous painters, a devil-may-care guitarist, a guy lugging bongos and the Williamsburg photographer, Tod Seelie  all of whom had been quietly invited to the late-night affair by its pseudonymous organizers, Agent Verde and Agent Rojo.

title: Restaurant Critic Sam Sifton on New Cookbooks; An Overview of Books on Gardening; Best-Seller news
description: This week, Times restaurant critic Sam Sifton discusses new cookbooks coming out this season; Dominique Browning with an overview of books on gardening; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. The Book Review's Senior Editor, Alex Star is the host this week.

title: Federer Beats Darkness and Djokovic to Reach Finals
description: PARIS - Roger Federer defeated Novak Dokovic, 7-6, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, to reach the finals of the French Open Friday and snap Djokovics winning streak of 43 consecutive matches dating to last year.

title: Fears, and Opportunities, on the Road to Retirement
description: IM not near retirement age  nor am I sure I ever will be  but I do feel as if Im being inundated with conflicting messages about aging.

title: Not Your Brothers Circus: Cirque du Soleil Prepares for Return to New York
description: The first time I saw Cirque du Soleil was in Washington in the early 1990s and it was like no circus I had ever seen. There were no lumbering animals or clown cars. These performers were whimsical, the mood oddly dreamlike and, in between the death-defying acrobatics, there were moments of minor-key theatrical grace.I loved it.

title: Donnie Walsh Is Leaving the Knicks
description: In a surprising twist, the Knicks announced late Friday morning that Donnie Walsh would be leaving his post as team president when his contract expires at the end of this month. The team characterized Walshs exit as by mutual agreement between him and the teams principal owner, James L. Dolan.

title: Child Safety Seats With a Racing Pedigree
description: You have to wonder why nobody thought of this before.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Storytelling
description: Todays poem, chosen from more than 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Samantha, who is 16 and lives in Beacon Falls, Connecticut.

title: Still Captivated by Bob Dylan
description: He arrived on the scene in the 1960s, nowhere near fully formed, but aware of his talent and ready to go to work. He may not have considered himself a member of the counterculture in those days, but he found his audience among its number. He was nimble and unsentimental. He did not hesitate to move on to other interests, other sounds, while many of his first admirers seemed stuck in place. Now in his seventh decade, Greil Marcus still writes with the almost foolish enthusiasm of a young person, and when he takes on Bob Dylan, who inspired him to become a writer, he is at his most alive.

title: Cookbooks in Review
description: The New York Times Book Reviews Summer Reading issue is out this week, and I did my part for the Diners Journal crowd with a round-up review of a dozen or so summer cookbook titles. Take a look at it, and then bring your thoughts back here to our burgeoning community of the food obsessed.

title: Death of Israeli Tycoon Is Latest Twist in Scandal
description: JERUSALEM  Sammy Ofer, an 89-year-old Israeli shipping tycoon whose company is at the center of a storm over alleged dealings with Iran, died after an illness on Friday. It was the latest twist in a saga that has riveted Israelis and stirred furious speculation about possible links between wealth, power and Israeli intrigue.

title: The Life and Times of Metallica and Queen
description: There is no such thing as a happy rock band. With the inexplicable exception of U2  who have, to all appearances, somehow remained on good terms, from band practice in high school to sold-out stadiums in middle age  virtually every group of note either crashes and burns or struggles through hard times to reach a grudging business agreement that keeps them working.

title: Taking a Baseball Bat to Your Childs Cellphone
description: The latest viral parenting video show an irate father destroying his daughters cellphone after apparently finding some sexts sent by the teenage girl. First he pounds the phone with a baseball bat on the garage floor. Then he tosses it and swings, appearing to connect several times. Someone films the whole episode.

title: The Mystical Heart of British Folk Music
description: Early on in Electric Eden, Rob Youngs awesomely researched, somewhat deranged history of visionary music from Britain, we read about the wanderings of an old-timey folk singer named Vashti Bunyan. She appears on a hedgerow-lined country road in 1967, a humble seeker who lived outdoors in a camp in a clearing in some Kentish woods. A page later we find out that the camp was actually right next to the suburban art school her boyfriend attended, and that the squatters had been hurried off posthaste by the local police.

title: Brains of the World to Cogitate for Bragging Rights
description: All over the world this Saturday, know-it-alls will be furrowing their brows.

title: Greek Talks Pave Way for Fresh Bailout Funds
description: ATHENS  Greece moved closer on Friday to receiving a second bailout after agreeing to new measures to bring down its debt.

title: Jack Kevorkian and Me
description: Twenty-one years ago this week, I had just learned I was pregnant with my first child. I was absorbing that news when a family in Portland, Ore., held a press conference to announce that their wife and mother, Janet Adkins, had died in a rusty 1968 Volkswagen van rigged with a suicide device built by a man named Jack Kevorkian.

title: The Girls Next Door
description: Theres not much going on in the small town of Orchard Park, N.Y.

title: Game 2, Through Two Lenses
description: The way Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals ended became instant fodder for the perfect sports debate: did the Mavericks victory from 15 down with less than eight minutes to go against the Heat represent an epic comeback by Dallas or a monumental collapse by Miami? Was it heroism led by Dirk Nowitzki, or the Big Three coming unglued? Spirited revenge or self-immolation?

title: A Former Spy Chief Questions the Judgment of Israeli Leaders
description: JERUSALEM  The man who ran Israels Mossad spy agency until January contends that Israels top leaders lack judgment and that the anticipated pressures of international isolation as the Palestinians campaign for statehood could lead to rash decisions  like an airstrike on Iran.

title: Pikas Have Moved to Higher Ground
description: The pika, a small mammal that lives in talus slopes at high elevations in the mountains of the American West, has disappeared in the last decade at a rate five times faster than they disappeared during the 20th century, according to a study out this month.

title: An Enthusiasts Guide to the Tabloid Murder
description: Americans are generally not too kind when our cherished icons, literary or otherwise, indulge their interests in something other than what they are known for. No one really wanted Michael Jordan to play minor league baseball, or Stephen King to write about dragons, and I am certain no one wants to listen to Russell Crowe sing. Of course, there are exceptions. Paul Newman did make a mean balsamic vinaigrette.

title: AT&T Races to Expand the Network
description: Much of the $18 billion AT&T will spend this year will be diverted into upgrades and expansions to meet the surging demands on the 3G network.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Prada Predicts $218 Million in First-Half Profit
description: Prada, the Italian fashion house, said Friday in a filing to the Hong Kong stock exchange that it expected to report at least 150.7 million euros, or $218 million, in profit for the six months ending July 31, and announced ambitious growth plans once its issue is completed.

title: New State Bar Chief Focuses on Veterans Issues
description: Sometime in the past year, Vincent E. Doyle III was at a charity dinner with his wife to raise money for Iraq war veterans. The veterans needed money for things like modifying their homes.

title: Considering the Lobster
description: Its nearly impossible to put a live lobster into a pot of boiling water without asking yourself, Does it feel pain? In Richard J. Kings elegant little history of the worlds pre-eminent crustacean, he reveals that anguishing over this final vestige of what it is like to butcher or kill our own food isnt restricted to our PETA-sensitized age. Apparently, its been debated in the West since at least the early 19th century.

title: Of Writers and Boxers
description: Today, championship boxing is lucky to win half a column in the sports pages. There was a time, though, when things were otherwise. In one of two introductions to At the Fights, George Kimball, who edited this anthology with John Schulian, recalls the 1910 fight between Jack Johnson and Jim Jeffries: More than 600 writers of varying stripes augmented the ringside crowd of 20,000 spectators. . . . Western Union transmitted more than a million words of copy, a record that would stand until Lindbergh touched down . . . 17 years later. And as indicated by the editors elsewhere in the book, when Jack Dempsey defended his title against Georges Carpentier, the coverage in The New York Times consumed not just the sports section on July 3, 1921, but almost the entire paper.

title: Building the Perfect bike
description: Evangelizing cyclists will often pronounce, in a moment of populist zeal, something like: It doesnt matter what you ride, as long as you ride. This is a rather oleaginous half-truth spread across a larger reality. It may not matter what you ride, but it matters deeply what I ride. People pick up on this. A Brooklyn bike shop owner recently described to me the almost apologetic air of patrons bringing him bicycles for repair, as if they feared the dusty specimens they had just freed from storage revealed some philistine streak, as if they knew some better bike would complete them.

title: St. Derek Jeter
description: The Yankee shortstop Derek Jeter is widely revered as a dignified and respectful clutch hitter, a leader by example and an adroit spouter of clichs who has managed to remain scandal-free and child-friendly even during baseballs steroids era. Ian OConnor isnt about to challenge that view, as he makes clear in the introduction to his new hagiography, The Captain. When OConnor writes that he spent 18 months in search of the tangible explanation for Jeters intangible grace and the passion behind his pinstripes, he is more than foreshadowing that he did not unearth Montgomery Burns-like evil within this biracial golden child.

title: The Glory of Joe DiMaggio and Hank Greenberg
description: Yale University Press, the pre-eminent academic publishing house, founded in 1908 by George Parmly Day, decided to roll out two books on baseball in the same month of 2011. Who wants to tell the Mayans their calendar is a year off?

title: Silent Slugger
description: Here are just a few of the interesting things Stan Musial, the great slugger for the St. Louis Cardinals, didnt do:

title: Baseball Chronicle
description: UPPITY  My Untold Story About the Games People Play.  By Bill White with Gordon Dillow.  Illustrated. 303 pp. Grand Central. $26.99.

title: Science and the Race for the South Pole
description: With the 100th anniversary of the conquest of the South Pole coming this December, books about Antarctica will be everywhere this year. One of the first out of the gate is An Empire of Ice, which looks at Antarctic exploration through the lens of science. Yes, many of the famous adventure tales are here, including the central one in which Roald Amundsen beats the less-prepared Robert Falcon Scott to the South Pole, and then Scott and his men perish on the way home. But to Edward J. Larson, a professor of history and law at Pepperdine University, the important thing about this story is not who arrived first at the pole, but who did the best field research along the way. And by this measure, Scott was the clear victor. If the race to the South Pole eventually consumed Scott, it was never at the expense of science, Larson contends.

title: Memoirs of an Insatiable Traveler
description: Travel and sexual conquest have long been cast as male impulses, from Casanovas far-flung affairs to the promiscuity of the modern adventure hero. Men know they are sexual exiles, Camille Paglia has written. They wander the earth seeking satisfaction, craving and despising, never content. There is nothing in that anguished motion for women to envy. But then Paglia hadnt read Wanderlust.

title: Extreme Travel of 45
description: Adventure these days is merely an experience that allows for a modestly elevated number of variables  renting a car without a GPS unit, for instance, or visiting a friend in East Flatbush. Not that the world is denuded of excitement. Its just that true adventure requires something that defies an itinerary: failure. Failure is the engine of adventure.

title: Who Really Discovered America?
description: This slim work of historical investigation covers three subjects: a 14th-century voyage across the North Atlantic; a 16th-century publishing event; and a 21st-century quest. Andrea di Robilant is a distinguished scholar of Venetian history, and in Irresistible North, his third book, he strives to bind his tripartite material into a persuasive narrative unity.

title: A Journey Down South Americas Spine
description: He may call himself an aging backpacker, but Michael Jacobs is hardly a rough-and-ready, revel-in-the-wilderness kind of guy. The first clue comes early in Andes, his rambling account of a journey from the northern reaches of South Americas great mountain range to its icy finish in Patagonia. The book is dedicated to his brother  and to the bus drivers of the Andes.

title: Paul Therouxs Travel Miscellany
description: Thoreau said he couldnt preserve his health and spirits unless he spent four hours a day sauntering. Rousseau passed most of his last 15 years in walking. Everything is finished for me on earth, he declared, a touch melodramatically. People can no longer do good or evil to me. . . . Here I am, tranquil at the bottom of the abyss, a poor unfortunate mortal, but unperturbed, like God himself. Wordsworth walked about 180,000 miles in his lifetime, in spite of being not a well-made man, according to Thomas De Quincey (who added that his friends legs were serviceable). When a visitor asked Wordsworths servant to show him his study, she answered: Here is his library, but his study is out of doors.

title: Bahrain Grand Prix Approved Despite New Clashes
description: Updated | 2:49 p.m. Hours after Bahrains security forces again fired tear gas at protesters on Friday, the World Motor Sport Council unanimously approved a decision to hold the Bahrain Grand Prix in October. The race was to have been held in March, but was postponed as the country struggled to come to grips with mass demonstrations against the government.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Collected Cool
description: Waiting for trade is a common refrain from comic book fans. Rather than pick up the monthly issues of a comic book series, many fans haveopted to wait (sometimes patiently) for the collected edition of the title to arrive months later. Its a risky proposition  if the monthly sales of a book sink, the chances of a collected edition may decrease dramatically. While softcover and hardcover editions have proved popular with fans, theres been a growing number of deluxe, Absolute, Martini and Omnibus editions that have been catching fire.

title: Girls of a Certain Age Challenge Hollywood
description: WHO wants to watch a tween girl on the big screen?

title: UBS Hires Tech and Media Banker From Deutsche Bank
description: UBS said on Friday that it had hired Yusuf Nahmiyas as a managing director for its technology, media and telecommunications mergers team. Mr. Nahmiyas was most recently at Deutsche Bank and was previously at JPMorgan Chase. He is the Swiss banks latest hire amid a series of high-profile defections.

title: DVD Extras From the Barbara Sinatra Interview
description: Kitty Kelley got scads of attention for her 1991 book, Nancy Reagan: The Unauthorized Biography, by alleging that Frank Sinatra and Nancy Reagan carried on an affair for years, even during Reagans years in the White House. In Kelleys book, Old Blue Eyes and Old Adolfo Suits would supposedly disappear for three-or four-hour private luncheons' in the family quarters. At the time, some disputed the claim in print.

title: Picturing Mob Violence
description: A few months ago, Barry Bearak called. Barry lives in Johannesburg, where he and his wife, Celia Dugger, have been our bureau chiefs for southern Africa for the past three and a half years. He called to describe a video he had recently seen of a mob that was beating and killing a man. Barrys response was immediate: he had seen something terrible, something terribly wrong, and he had to understand why it had happened. Barry won a Pulitzer in 2002 for his coverage of life in war-torn Afghanistan; in 2005, he recreated the day the tsunami wiped out much of Banda Aceh, Indonesia, telling the stories of six survivors. Suffice it to say that he works tirelessly to get the details that convey the truth of the matter, which he does in this most recent piece, a powerful, disturbing story, Death by a Thousand Blows, that appears in this Sundays magazine.

title: Renewed Interest in Dividend-Paying Stocks
description: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about a type of stock that had fallen into disfavor over the last couple of decades because it had none of the go-go appeal of a technology start-up  the dividend-paying kind. Paul speaks to several financial advisers who say they are now promoting dividend-paying stocks to people who still have money in cash or low-yielding bonds.

title: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Venice Biennale: Money Talks, Make That Sings
description: Lets please dispense with the clichs about art and money and instead take a look at getting hold of cash in Venice. There is only one A.T.M. machine in the whole of the Giardini, the gardens at the tip of the city that is home to the national pavilions. Its in a space of its own at the back of the American pavilion.

title: Just One Look | Michael Kors Resort
description: Michael Kors has been all over the map  in a manner of speaking. His resort collection was inspired by his first trip down under, where he was blown away by the urban beach culture. (Women wear bathing suits as lingerie, he exclaimed. Divine!) His homage includes a double-faced crepe rashguard dress and this three-piece power suit. Wish we worked in that  office.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $11,750,000
description: A co-op at Harperley Hall, a 1911 Arts and Crafts-style building at 41 Central Park West, was the biggest sale of the week, closing for $11.75 million, according to city property records.

title: Chopin, Schubert and Dietrich (the Latter Nude)
description: AFTER Blonde Venus flopped in 1932, Paramount decided to break up the powerful creative alliance between the director Josef von Sternberg and the actress Marlene Dietrich, whom he had discovered in Germany and brought to Hollywood. While Sternberg, who was Jewish, entertained bizarre fantasies of returning to Germany to work for the state-controlled studio Ufa (he thought the Germans would treat him as the great artist he was), Dietrich was hustled directly into The Song of Songs, which has recently surfaced as half of a Pre-Code Double Feature available exclusively through the TCM Web site. (The other film is This Is the Night.)

title: Paperback Row
description: THE LAST HERO: A Life of Henry Aaron,  by Howard Bryant (Anchor, $16.95.) Henry Aaron was his eras greatest hitter; when he retired, in 1976, after a 23-year career, only Ty Cobb had more hits or scored more runs, and no one had more home runs. Bryants book is a rigorously researched and illuminating portrait of Aaron  he was the last Hall of Famer to play in the Negro Leagues  and his dogged pursuit of Babe Ruths career home run record.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GREATER JOURNEY: Americans in Paris,  by David McCullough (Simon & Schuster, $37.50.) An exploration of the intellectual legacy that France settled on such 19th-century visitors as Mark Twain, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Samuel Morse and many others.

title: Science Fiction Chronicle
description: ZOO CITY  By Lauren Beukes.  Angry Robot, paper, $7.99.

title: Bleak Childhood, Dark Comedy
description: Why do good things happen to bad people? For some of us, this is one of lifes big questions, bigger perhaps than those all-stars: What makes Iago evil? How can a country justify firing both missiles and schoolteachers? The undeserved job promotion, the bequest without cause, the random assigning of accolades or attention: when unmerited rewards are doled out to others, some of us are capable of descending into decades of moping.

title: After the Holocaust
description: For Silvana, the Polish Holocaust survivor at the center of Amanda Hodgkinsons accomplished first novel, 22 Britannia Road, maternal love is a heart-scorching, perilous emotion. During the war, threats to the life of Aurek, her young son, were everywhere: from the filthy skies, raked with thunder clouds and German planes, to the sunless, brambly depths of the Polish forests, where she and Aurek, like two figures in a fairy tale, hid out for years. They are rescued from a refugee camp by Janusz, the husband and father from whom they were separated at the beginning of the fighting. Janusz brings them to Ipswich, to the small house and garden that give the novel its title. There Silvana forces herself to believe that a normal life is possible: that she and Janusz will rediscover themselves as husband and wife, that Aurek will have a father  and that the secret still threatening her sons security will stay buried.

title: Inside the List
description: CON LAW: Beach-reading season may be in full swing, but that doesnt mean there isnt a whole lot of constitutional law being debated on the best-seller list. In Wheres the Birth Certificate?, at No. 14 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list, the veteran conspiracy theorist Jerome Corsi argues that Barack Obamas supposed foreign birth runs afoul of Article 2, Section 1, which requires that the president be a natural-born citizen. (Didnt Donald Trump ruin that story line a few weeks ago?) Meanwhile, in Steve Berrys latest pretzel of a thriller, The Jefferson Key (No. 5 on the fiction list), the swashbuckling Justice Department operative Cotton Malone comes out of semiretirement to foil a presidential assassination rooted in a secret clause encoded in Article 1, Section 8.

title: Bookshelf: Growing Up
description: LITTLE MIST  By Angela McAllister. Illustrated by Sarah Fox-Davies.  32 pp. Knopf. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

title: The Murder That Transfixed 1930s Paris
description: On Aug. 21, 1933, Violette Nozire, the 18-year-old only daughter of an engine driver and a housewife who lived in a claustrophobic two-room apartment in the working-class 12th Arrondissement of Paris, gave her parents drinks laced with a lethal dose of barbiturates. Her father died. Her mother, who drank only half her glass, fell into a deeply drugged sleep, but survived. When Violette was arrested  after a brief attempt at flight and a costly shopping spree paid for with her parents pilfered savings  she gave a full confession. She also explained, as motive for her crime, that her father had been raping her for the past six years.

title: Teaching Aliens How to Lie
description: The innovative and protean British writer China Mivilles declared ambition to write a novel in every genre offers an insight into his powers of invention. Im in this . . . business for the monsters, he said in an interview a few years ago. Unfortunately, you cant really sell books of monsters to publishers. They insist on stories linking them. To create the necessary narratives, Miville repurposes genre formulas like a salvage artist, mixing a connoisseurs respect for recovered materials with heretical joy in putting them to surprising uses.

title: Richard North Pattersons Al Qaeda Thriller
description: Nothing solidifies the reputation of a spy novelist so much as prescience. Graham Greenes Quiet American appeared only a year after the French defeat at Dien Bien Phu, and before American advisers had been sent to Vietnam in large numbers. Four years before the Cuban missile crisis, with Fulgencio Batista still in power, Greene wrote another novel, this one about possible secret military installations in Cuba. As for Ian Fleming, his vision of nonstate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons remains the most frightening and relevant aspect of the James Bond series.

title: The Mystery of a Sisters Death
description: Two years ago, a British study suggested that men and women who grew up with sisters had happier lives and rosier outlooks than men and women who didnt. The presence of even one sister in a household was enough to foster an atmosphere of emotional openness that helped family members communicate and tackle problems. No such benefit accrued to people who had only brothers. The study was small  only 571 subjects took part  but it was heartening to think that sisters, so often portrayed as fractious rivals, envious of one anothers attractions and covetous of one anothers friends and clothes, might actually serve as mortar binding the bricks of a familys psyche.

title: Lynne Tillmans Innovative Stories
description: Despite the claim of the title, Someday This Will Be Funny, you wouldnt want to reach for Lynne Tillmans new book just for a good howl. In fact, that someday the title promises may never come. Tillmans stories are too piercing, the obsessions of her characters too connected to their psychic wounds, for them to be considered exactly funny. In any case, it isnt someday but rather meantime that counts for readers. And in the meantime, Tillmans fictions tend to be (to steal a line from one of her stories) as outrageously ineffable, obdurate and evasive as the forms of desire they describe. Gorgeously at ease and technically virtuosic, the stories are ever on point  on point, that is, if the point of your reading has more to do with psychological nuance and bravura performances of language than with conventional story lines.

title: Teens After Armageddon
description: How many times can the world come to an end? For Saba, the fatalistic 18-year-old heroine of Blood Red Road, quite a few. She lives long after Earths last major civilization, the Wreckers, went extinct. Her mother died nine years earlier, giving birth to Sabas sister, Emmi. The lake beside her familys shack is drying up, replaced by a wasteland of dust storms and heat.

title: Figuring Out Dad
description: Twice in The Absolute Value of Mike, 14-year-old Mike is asked, Whats your story? The first time he equivocates, talking instead about the circumstances that surround him. The second time, he evades: I  I dont know. Both are deceptions that come out of a humiliating sadness; because he does know his story. He is the kid whose father is a math and engineering genius, burdened with an un-smart son, one who is bound to disappoint and will probably end up on the street, because he is so much less than his father.

title: Ghostbusters
description: Its almost summer, so lets get serious about those vacation reading lists. On second thought, lets save the 600-page historical sagas and thickly plotted espionage thrillers for another day and kick back with something weird and wonderful  like a supernatural mystery.

title: When New York City Went Dark
description: If you believe that books set in your neighborhood will somehow help your child love to read, then you would be lucky these days to be a parent in Brooklyn. Books for children by Brooklyn authors now match the similarly numberless books by Brooklyn-based authors for grown-ups.

title: An Illustrated History of the Funny Papers
description: In 1906, the poet Ralph Bergengren, in the name of common sense and Christianity, denounced the Sunday comics supplement as pandemonium, . . . the clamor of hooting mobs, the laughter of imbeciles, and the crash of explosives.

title: FIA Reinstates Bahrain Grand Prix
description: The Bahrain Grand Prix will go ahead this year, after the World Council of the International Automobile Federation voted to reinstate the race at a meeting in Barcelona today.

title: FIA Reinstates Bahrain Grand Prix
description: The Bahrain Grand Prix will go ahead this year, after the World Council of the International Automobile Federation voted to reinstate the race at a meeting in Barcelona today.

title: Olympic Gold, or the Stanley Cup?
description: The Sedins said it. Patrice Bergeron said it. Ryan Kesler said it.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Governors Island again plays host to the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic on Sunday starting at 11 a.m. It is free for the public to attend the game, which starts at 2:30 p.m. Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group will have a Restaurant Row selling food, and Veuve Clicquot will set up lounges selling flutes and bottles of Champagne.

title: Mourning a Boy, Crowds in Syria Defy Crackdown
description: CAIRO  Syrians poured into the streets on Friday in some of the largest antigovernment protests yet despite the shutdown of much of Syrias Internet network, which has been crucial to demonstrators ability to mobilize and a major source of information for those outside the country.

title: City Opera to Lay Off 11 Workers
description: New York City Opera, as part of its resuscitation plan, will lay off 11 of its 48 administrative employees and eliminate four open positions, according to a company memorandum obtained on Friday. The layoffs are part of a reorganization approved at a May 19 board meeting when the company formally decided to leave its home, the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The memorandum did not identify the jobs and City Opera officials had no comment.

title: Video: The Week in Politics
description: Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss Mitt Romneys official announcement to run for president and how Sarah Palins road trip to New Hampshire stole some of his thunder.

title: Oilers Brule Saves Bonos Day
description: Usually, its not advisable to pick up hitchhikers. Its right up there with Moms stern warnings about not taking candy from strangers.

title: History Repeats for a Correspondent in Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  In March 2003, the Pentagon described its airborne onslaught on Baghdad at the outset of the campaign to topple Saddam Hussein as one intended to provoke shock and awe.

title: Near Barcelona, Gems From Ancient Rome
description: WHAT draws travelers to the northeast of Spain? Cutting-edge food, of course. To Barcelona? Modernist architecture, perhaps. Along the coast, the beaches. And to Tarragona, a laid-back city about 60 miles south of Barcelona, the ancient ruins. On our first afternoon there, my husband and I headed from our hotel down the broad promenade of the Rambla Nova, the citys main artery. We stopped at one of the outdoor cafes along the way, mixing with a crowd that seemed more local than tourist, and ordered gin-and-tonics.

title: A Feminist Riot That Still Inspires
description: A quartet of teenage girls was onstage at the Knitting Factory, the Brooklyn club. Playing guitars and wearing mini-skirts, they did a tuneful pop cover of Ben Lees I Wish I Was Him, about the 1990s alt-rock heartthrob Evan Dando and given a flip by these long-haired 14- and 15-year-olds who called themselves Toy Sugar. Performing the song in 1994, Kathleen Hanna did that first, when, as the frontwoman for the punk band Bikini Kill and a founder of the feminist riot grrrl movement, she made it her business to overturn gender norms in a way that you could sing, or scream, along to.

title: The Secrets of Tarragona
description: Much of this Spanish citys richly layered history can be found within the Old Citys ancient walls.

title: Caucus | The Week in Politics
description: Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss Mitt Romney's official announcement to run for president and how Sarah Palin's road trip to New Hampshire stole some of his thunder.

title: Making a Hipper Hybrid by Gilding the Prius
description: SCAN a roster of Toyota Prius buyers and youll find performers, policy makers and entrepreneurs. After being bowled over by the boldface names  Apples Steve Wozniak, Googles Sergey Brin, earth-conscious artistes from Natalie Portman to Bill Maher  I wonder this: cant these people afford a nicer car? Shouldnt someone as cool as Mark Ruffalo (who cleverly called his Toyota the Priss) drive something thats faster and sleeker than a garden gnome?

title: St. Anns Warehouse Scrambles to Find New Home
description: St. Anns Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater whose versatile and cavernous playing space has become a magnet for New York and overseas acting troupes, is now confronting a likely fate that its leaders had worked years to avoid: homelessness.

title: Riot Grrrl Revisited
description: The 1990s indie rock movement is being reexamined by academics and icons like Kathleen Hanna.

title: Edwards Might Have Broken Distracted-Driving Law en Route to Court
description: As my colleague Katharine Seelye reports, John Edwards, the former Democratic senator from North Carolina and presidential candidate, was indicted Friday morning on charges that he violated campaign finance law and is scheduled to appear in a federal court in Winston-Salem, N.C., this afternoon.

title: Walsh to Leave Knicks, Turnaround Unfinished
description: Donnie Walsh, who revived a flagging, dysfunctional Knicks franchise and repeatedly stated his intention to complete the turnaround, is instead stepping down as the team president in a dispute over his authority.

title: Creole Choir of Cuba Brings Islands Music to Brooklyn
description: For those who associate modern Cuban music with a Latin jazz sound, here comes the Creole Choir of Cuba to blow away those expectations with their first concert in this country.

title: The Minimalist: Four-Spice Salmon
description: Mark Bittman is revisiting recipes from vintage Minimalist columns for a new series of videos.

title: James Arness, Marshal on Gunsmoke, Dies at 88
description: James Arness, who burnished the legend of Americas epic West as Marshal Matt Dillon, the laconic peacemaker of Dodge City on Gunsmoke, one of the longest-running dramatic series in television history, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: A Revival In Manufacturing Seems to Be Fading
description: The strong revival of worldwide manufacturing seems to have slowed.

title: June 5  11
description: Theater

title: Whats In A Name?
description: A lot, or at least thats what Republicans think. Greg Sargent reports that theyre demanding that a TV station stop running ads saying that the GOP wants to end Medicare; the claim is that this is a lie, because the new program the GOP wants to impose in place of Medicare is still Medicare.

title: Dance for a Cause and Let the Votes Fall Where They May
description: And now, a public-service announcement about public-service announcements.

title: Another Tale, or Two, Of That Operatic Figaro
description: FIRST The Barber of Seville, then The Marriage of Figaro. Then what? Whether we are speaking of the plays of Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais or the operas they inspired, the Figaro triptych many have dreamed of  including Beaumarchais himself  remains an elusive goal. On Friday the Whitsun edition of the Salzburg Festival revives an opera that just might serve as the missing third panel: I Due Figaro (The Two Figaros), by Saverio Mercadante.

title: Stravinskys Devil, Reignited
description: THE setting, dialogue and dance steps of Igor Stravinskys Histoire du Soldat, a music-theater piece from 1918, are as malleable as the Faust story on which the work is based. What doesnt change is the music: a tart panoply of jazzy figures, dance forms and marches.

title: Stay Away From Our Pay, Private Equity Tells Washington
description: The private equity industry has a knack for transforming losing companies into surprising success stories.

title: Have Any Point Shoes In a Mans Size 9?
description: CORY STEARNS sat on the floor of an American Ballet Theater studo holding a pair of satin point shoes as if he were trying to decide between two loaves of bread.

title: Revealing Excessive 401(k) Fees
description: You may not realize this, but your 401(k) or other workplace retirement plan is not free.

title: The American Phil Hill, Formula One Champion, Remembered at Monza
description: The career of the late Phil Hill, the American who won the Formula One world championship 50 years ago, will be celebrated this weekend at a series of vintage car races at the speedway in Monza, Italy.

title: Garden of Big Sounds, Yielding Hybrid Crops
description: Ryoji Ikeda

title: House Rebukes Obama for Continuing Libyan Mission Without Its Consent
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives voted Friday to rebuke President Obama for continuing to maintain an American role in NATO operations in Libya without the express consent of Congress, and directed the administration to provide detailed information about the cost and objectives of the American role in the conflict.

title: Shining a Light on Your 401(k) Costs
description: In this weekends Your Money column, Im back on the topic of 401(k) plans and how to bolster returns by making them less costly.

title: 3-D Star Wars Theme Park Attraction
description: Among Star Wars fans, the most vivid depiction of the icy planet of Hoth, the lush jungles of Kashyyyk and the underwater Gungan world on Naboo exist on celluloid.

title: Judge Advises N.F.L. and Players to Continue Efforts to End Dispute
description: ST. LOUIS  With the start of the 2011 regular season less than 100 days away, and recent negotiations providing hope for a settlement, the N.F.L. and its players faced off in a federal appeals court Friday to determine how much longer the lockout could last.

title: Making It Easier to Navigate by Subway in Queens
description: In a godsend for G train riders  and proponents of clarity on the subway map  New York City Transit has introduced a free, sheltered transfer between the G and No. 7 trains at the newly christened Court Square subway complex in Long Island City, Queens.

title: A Rant of His Own: V.S. Naipaul Takes on Women Writers
description: Paul Theroux has described his onetime mentor, the Nobel laureate V. S. Naipaul, as a grouch, a skinflint, tantrum-prone, with race on the brain. Mr. Theroux and Mr. Naipaul may have reconciled at a literary festival in Britain this week, but other critics are using new derogatory adjectives  like arrogant and sexist  to describe Mr. Naipaul after he declared that no female writer was his literary equal.

title: In Cajun Country, in Search of the Boucherie
description: WE had come a long way for a hog killing, but the butcher had chosen that day of all days to have a meltdown. Nobody at La Grande Boucherie des Cajuns  an annual festival in St. Martinville, La., celebrating the Cajun tradition of boucherie, or the communal butchering of hogs  knew what had set him off. It might have been the thunderstorm that had hit town that morning, blowing tents from the festival grounds and drenching vendors. Or maybe it was the unseasonably cool air; a cold chopping block could make for unpleasant butchering. Whatever it was, he had packed up his apron and butchering tackle, locked the hog in the trailer, and sped off  presumably to the hogs relief.

title: A Low-Rise Shanghai Market
description: IN a corner of Shanghais old French Concession neighborhood, in the shadow of half-constructed high-rise apartment blocks, is something rather striking for a city going up at such a dizzying pace: a rooftop garden, complete with a resident rabbit and chicken.

title: Mother and Sons, on the Same Track
description: MY sons have always loved trains. Most children do. I have vivid memories of mine as small boys crowding the window at the front of the car next to the conductors booth, crowing with glee at the powerful speed with which the world rushes past. For years, my older son had been fantasizing about taking a train all the way across the country. Suddenly this winter, the constellation of vacations lined up; one was on break from college, the other from law school. We stopped dreaming about the journey, and started planning it.

title: Hotel Review: Singapore Moon Hotel
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Letters: Leaving the Dog at Home
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, Making the Skies Friendly for Pets (May 22): My daughter and her fianc flew here with Ben, an 11-pound Jack Russell-poodle mix and rescue dog, from New York last Christmas. Because the Delta check-in people didnt know how to deal with the pet paperwork, they almost missed their flight. They also paid through the nose to put Ben in cargo, and had to buy a carrier with specific dimensions. Ben survived the flight in fine fettle; not so my daughter and her fianc. They say never again.

title: Enclave Embraces Brotherly Love
description: Mount Airy, a neighborhood of North Philadelphia, has recently attracted an influx of businesses that are embracing its diversity.

title: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
description: WHAT follows are the final essays we will print from the Why We Travel submissions. On April 3, inspired by an essay titled Why We Travel by Paul Theroux, we asked readers to write us with their answers to that question. Hundreds responded, and we have published 11. There is a link to those essays here: travel.nytimes.com/why-essays.

title: White Nights of St. Petersburg, Russia
description: THE motorized launch cruised toward the Hermitage, the former Winter Palace of the czars, passing underneath a low arched bridge that I feared would graze my scalp as we glided beneath it. Just ahead, a boisterous wedding party on the deck of a wooden cruiser filled the air with vodka-fueled shouts of gorko!, meaning bitterness, a traditional Russian encouragement to the bride and groom to kiss and thus provide the guests with the opposite of what was being proclaimed.

title: White Nights in St. Petersburg
description: St. Petersburg, Russia, celebrates the arrival of summer, when the sun barely sets, with parties along the citys rivers and canals.

title: How to Add Flaxseed to Your Diet
description: Flaxseed is credited with a number of health benefits, including better digestive health, lower cholesterol and fewer hot flashes during menopause. But how do you add flaxseed to your diet?

title: A Familys Fellow Traveler, From Tropics to Tundra
description: ON a recent Saturday, Blaine Benson sifted through a folder of documents, the remains of a road trip taken 40 years ago. Among the ephemera were Pan Am airline tickets, ferry receipts, invoices for car repairs and a mileage log, handwritten on white notepad pages.

title: Average Length of Unemployment at All-Time High
description: The average unemployed person in America has been looking for work for 39.7 weeks, or more than nine months. That is the longest average unemployment spell since the Labor Department started keeping track in 1948:

title: The Week in Pictures for June 3
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Patterns: More People Praying About Health, Analysis Finds
description: More Americans are praying about their health, researchers have concluded.

title: Awareness: Top 5 Donts for Doctors in Primary Care
description: Antibiotics for sore throats and CT scans for minor head injuries in children are among the most wasteful practices in primary care medicine, a national physicians group said last week. Among the others are electrocardiograms performed routinely on healthy adults and widespread prescribing of brand-name statins to reduce L.D.L., or bad cholesterol.

title: Screening: Saliva Test for Cytomegalovirus Proves Accurate
description: A new test offers a rapid, inexpensive and highly accurate method for screening newborns for cytomegalovirus, which can cause permanent hearing loss, researchers said on Wednesday.

title: Food Groups? You Call Those Food Groups?
description: Dont get us wrong. The new national Food Plate that the first lady unveiled on Thursday to replace the long-ridiculed food pyramid has its charms  nice proportions, easy-to-remember categories, potential to improve the health of Americans.

title: Buyer Emerges for the Dallas Stars
description: The long search for a buyer of the ailing Dallas Stars may be nearing an end, solving another financial headache for the N.H.L. Tom Gaglardi, a businessman from Vancouver, British Columbia, is expected to pay roughly $250 million for the team and half of the lease to the American Airlines Arena, according to a person with direct knowledge of the deal.

title: Obama Hails Auto Industrys Turnaround in Visit to Chrysler Plant
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  President Obama hailed the auto industrys comeback at a Chrysler plant here, two years after the companys bailout, but warned several hundred appreciative workers that headwinds continued to buffet the economy  the closest he came to referring to the days disappointing employment report.

title: Golden Age for Older Women At the Highest Levels of Tennis
description: PARIS  Li Na, the Chinese tennis sensation who will play in the French Open final on Saturday, was not entirely joking when asked about her age.

title: Murano Pursues a Renaissance
description: MURANO, Italy  The quasi-monastic quiet of this lagoon island a short vaporetto ride from Venice has been broken intermittently in recent months by ear-splitting saws and the low grumble of heavy machinery.

title: A Hybrid Looks for Higher Ground
description: With the CT 200h, Lexus is betting that car buyers are ready for a premium hybrid.

title: Whats So Bad About Meat?
description: I can only begin to imagine the number of people who found my last column outrageously presumptuous, since I didnt bother to justify or define its underlying principle: that being that meat-eating is bad.

title: Saving Sarah From Herself, Oprah Style
description: CHICAGO

title: A Future Beyond Glass
description: As Muranos glasswork industry dwindles, local leaders hope plans to develop tourism on the island will help revitalize the economy.

title: Book Review Podcast: Cooking and Gardening
description: The Summer Reading special issue of the Book Review features cooking, gardening and travel roundups. On this weeks podcast, The Timess restaurant critic, Sam Sifton, discusses the seasons new cookbooks, good and bad; and Dominique Browning reviews the new crop of gardening books. As always, Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Alex Star, the Book Reviews senior editor, is the host this week. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Pradas Revealing Numbers
description: The Italian fashion house Prada says its net profit more than doubled in 2010, as it prepares for a $2 billion Hong Kong initial public offering.

title: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
description: ON April 3, along with the essay by Paul Theroux titled Why We Travel, readers were asked to submit essays of their own to answer this question. Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. Here are the final selections that illustrate the vast range of our readers experiences. Thanks to everyone who responded; it was a pleasure to read of your travels. The Editors

title: Protesters Cross Bridge to Oppose Plan to Shut Firehouses
description: The battle over a plan to cut 20 of the citys firehouses escalated on Friday as more than 1,000 protesters marched across the Brooklyn Bridge to harshly criticize the man who has proposed the cuts, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Authorities Poised to Pile on Goldman Over Financial Crisis
description: The kids in my old neighborhood used to play a game called dogpile, in which someone would yell out a name and everyone would jump on top of that person until he fell to the ground.

title: Penguins Huddling
description: Half of a penguin colony during the aggregation and huddling process. As the temperatures fall, larger and more stable huddles form until nearly all the penguins formed one large huddle.

title: SUNY Official in Bruno Case Resigns
description: A top official at the State University of New York accused of giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has resigned amid mounting scrutiny of his conduct.

title: Look of the Moment | Heidi Klum
description: The Look: Vertical horizon  a simple cardigan and tee gets glam when paired with gam-lengthening cropped trousers.

title: Group Posts What It Says Are Iranian Government E-Mails
description: Anonymous, a group of activist computer hackers, posted more than 10,000 e-mails on Friday that it said were taken from Iranian government servers.

title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Tablet Cases * But Were Afraid to Ask
description: Ive been churning through tablet  namely iPad  cases for the last few weeks in a mad search to find one that fits my mood and style. Along the way, I believe I have come up with a taxonomy of cases for various users. What follows is a short description of each type and an assessment of the ideal purchaser.

title: TimesCast | June 3, 2011
description: Yemens president is wounded in a rocket attack; a grand jury indicts John Edwards in campaign funds abuse case; and Chinas Li Na hopes to be the first Asian to win a Grand Slam tennis tournament.

title: Did SocGen Bet Against Its Own Share Price?
description: 4:20 p.m. | Updated to correct reference to hedging strategies.

title: Did SocGen Bet Against Its Own Share Price?
description: 4:20 p.m. | Updated to correct reference to hedging strategies.

title: More Than a Room of Ones Own
description: Women writers are quite different, said V.S.Naipaul in an interview at the Royal Geographic Society, picked up by The Guardian. I read a piece of writing, and within a paragraph or two I know whether it is by a woman or not. I think [it is] unequal to me. (To see if you have the masters knack for sexing literature, go to what  New York magazine calls Guess the Sex of the Authors on the V.S. Naipaul Test on the Guardians Web site.) He goes on to explain that, in part, women fall short because they arent the boss at home. She is not a complete master of a house, so that comes over in her writing too. Maybe Virginia Woolf should have asked for more real estate.

title: Liver Disease Keeps Uncle Mo Sidelined
description: Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who was scratched the day before the Kentucky Derby, has been diagnosed with a liver disease called cholangiohepatitis.

title: The Art Worlds New Darlings
description: Adel Abidin and Ahmed Alsoudani, the young artists who represent Iraq at the 54th Venice Biennale, were sitting on the terrace of the Bauer Hotel here at dusk on Wednesday, studying their elaborately hand-written invitations to a private dinner given by Franois Pinault, the French billionaire. How would they cross the water to San Giorgio Maggiore Island?

title: Money Woes Force Hiatus for Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas
description: The fledgling Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, with few contributions on the horizon and facing rising costs, is suspending operations, its chairman said on Friday. The orchestra, based in New York, was founded in 2004 by Alondra de la Parra, a rising young Mexican conductor, and made a specialty of Latin American music. It toured in Mexico recently in honor of the countrys bicentennial and gave three or four concerts a year in New York. Ms. de la Parra and the orchestra also released a recording of Latin American works last year.

title: Liberal Bias Takes Toll On Hollywood Non-Partisan Group
description: LOS ANGELES  The dust-up around Ben Shapiros book, Prime Time Propaganda: The True Hollywood Story of How the Left Took Over Your TV, has taken a toll on a values-oriented Hollywood organization that prides itself on reaching across partisan lines. That is the Caucus for Producers, Writers and Directors, whose members include Tom Hanks, Dick Wolf, Garry Marshall and some of the more prominent creative types in television.

title: A Photo Booth for Instagram Users
description: You can always tell the good parties from the bad ones based on the number of photos taken.

title: The Return of the Blue-Collar Downturn
description: For much of 2010, the slumping economy was affecting white-collar, highly educated workers almost as much as it was affecting less educated and blue-collar workers. Thats no longer the case. In recent months, the economy has once again been easier on college graduates than it has on everyone else, much as it was during nearly all of 2008 and 2009.

title: Bookshelf: Growing Up
description: Reviews of new picture books.

title: Music Pick of the Day: Gil Scott-Heron
description: Gil Scott-Heron died last week. A pioneering artist and progenitor of rap and hip-hop, Scott-Heron, who battled substance abuse for decades, experienced a resurgence in popularity last year after a new album reminded audiences of his thought-provoking lyrical prowess.

title: Bringing Home the Wrong Race

title: City Report Finds No Work Slowdown in Blizzard Cleanup

title: Exhibition Shows Fierce Art Patronage of the Fierce Steins
description: If Gertrude Stein is remembered as the force behind the legendary Saturday soires on the Rue de Fleurus in Paris  where artists, writers, collectors, dealers and curiosity seekers would gather in the early 20th century to see the most revolutionary art of the moment on the walls thats because she was the one retelling the story in her writings, while sidelining her brothers Leo and Michael, and Michaels wife, Sarah. The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso, and the Parisian Avant-Garde, which opened at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on May 21, presents the more complete story of the fiercely intellectual, risk-taking and competitive siblings who put these artists on the map through their visionary patronage.

title: Checking It Twice
description: Whether youre simply organized or mildy compulsive, a list can provide the structure for the everyday. However, when the to-do list is compiled by such artistic luminaries as Pablo Picasso, Alexander Calder and Franz Kline, it transcends its ostensible purpose and provides insights into the life and times of its maker. This is obvious from a new show  To-dos, Ilustrated Inventories, Collected Thoughts, and Other Artists Enumerations, curated by Liza Kirwin from the Smithsonians Archives of American Art  that opened today at the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan. For example, Pablo Picassos recommendations for inclusion in the 1913 Armory Show, the first international exhibition of modern art in the United States, astutely foresaw the historical importance of Marcel Duchamp, Fernand Leger and Juan Gris. Franz Klines shopping list for booze for his 1960 New Years party was evidence of his financial success (it was a hefty bill for the time) as well as his social nature. The artist Adolf Konrad illustrated his 1962 packing list: Khaki trench. Check. Six pairs of socks. Check. Sunglasses. Check. Two lemons. Check. Ah, the beauty of the artfully organized.

title: This Sunday: A Meaningful Death
description: A couple of months ago, when we started putting credits and email addresses for the editors of feature stories on the magazines table of contents, Jack Shafer, media critic for Slate, felt inspired to not only mock the plan, but to impugn the editing profession generally. Try complimenting an editor sometime about a good piece in his publication, Jack wrote, and youre certain to get this eye-rolling response: You shoulda seen it when it came in!'
