Incredulous at this display of mom corniness, he asks if she is joking. No, she isnt, and she tells him, Im not going to end up on some reality television show with a pregnant 16-year-old.

title: N.B.A. Lifts ABC
description: ABC dominated Thursday nights ratings with coverage of the National Basketball Association Finals, while reruns on CBS eked out a second-place finish, ahead of Fox. According to Nielsens estimates, 7.7 million viewers tuned in to So You Think You Can Dance in the 8 oclock hour, a large enough audience to give Fox a modest lead in the time slot, ahead of CBSs repeats of The Big Bang Theory (7.4 million) and Rules of Engagement (6.7 million). But at 9, Foxs rerun of Glee (4.2 million) struggled opposite CBSs CSI (8 million). Meanwhile preliminary overnight estimates for the ABC basketball broadcast were just slightly lower, compared with Game 1 on Wednesday night, which attracted 15.2 million viewers. NBC finished a distant fourth on the night with low-rated reruns of its comedy lineup. At 10, NBCs premiere of Love Bites averaged 2.5 million viewers, lagging well behind CBSs repeat of The Mentalist (8.8 million) in that hour.

title: A Big Man Who Can Belt a Tune Isnt Afraid to Show a Mellow Side, Too
description: Gregory Porter has most of what you want in a male jazz singer, and maybe a thing or two you didnt know you wanted. A former outside linebacker (at San Diego State, on scholarship) and musical theater veteran (It Aint Nothin but the Blues, on Broadway), he brings to the stage an expressive physicality. His sturdy baritone and sure projection make him a natural belter, but he knows how to sidle up to a melody, working quietly with tension and release. He also knows how to write a song, and put together a show.

title: Show Within a Show Gets Its Own Shot

description: In the wake of scandals that have felled two New York governors and multiple state lawmakers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature announced an agreement on Friday to overhaul the states ethics laws as part of an effort to stem corruption and misconduct in Albany.

title: An Impatient Davis Rejoins the Mets, But Only as a Temporary Spectator
description: Walking with only a slight limp and carrying his protective boot in his hand, Mets first baseman Ike Davis arrived in the clubhouse before the game with Atlanta on Friday, which could have been greeted as good news.

title: Told to Keep Low Profile, Chinese Artist Takes a Stand
description: BEIJING  After 10 hours of questioning and 7 more locked up alone in an interrogation room, Wang Jun was shown the door of a police station on Thursday night and given some parting instructions: Keep your name off the Internet, move to another part of town and do not talk to anyone but yourself.

title: Just Drive, She Said
description: Two Saudi activists get into a car .

title: Womens Final Preview: Schiavone vs. Li
description: Saturdays match between the defending champion Francesca Schiavone and Chinas Li Na pits two tour veterans with contrasting styles against each other in a final that caps a wildly unpredictable  but very entertaining  French Open.

description: BENGHAZI, Libya

description: The nonchalant look prevails at the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturdays.

description: Jamel Shabazz is marking the 10th anniversary of the book of New York City photographs that put him on the map.

title: Captives Own Account of 18 Years as a Hostage
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A normal morning violently interrupted. Day after day of fear, sexual assault and loneliness. A desperate striving for normalcy in depraved surroundings.

title: Ungainly Knicks Lose a Man of Elegance
description: Rest assured that if  and only if  Friday was the last day that Donnie Walsh served as the chief administrator of a professional basketball team, he went out in character, as a consummate professional. Not a coincidence, for anyone who was paying attention for the last three years.

title: In Alabama, a Harsh Bill for Residents Here Illegally
description: Alabama has passed a sweeping bill to crack down on illegal immigrants that both supporters and opponents call the toughest of its kind in the country, going well beyond a law Arizona passed last year that caused a furor there.

title: Hanging Out With Cool Cats
description: The jazz flutist Dave Valentin has toured the world as a headliner, playing with everyone from Tito Puente to McCoy Tyner, but he always returns to the Bronx, where he was born 59 years ago. Home is a modest one-story bachelor pad in Harding Park, a hidden waterfront stretch of winding streets, close neighbors  and the occasional crowing rooster  better known as Little Puerto Rico. He won a Grammy in 2002 with Dave Samuels and the Caribbean Jazz Project, and this month he will release his latest album, Pure Imagination, in which he overdubs himself playing five flutes. Not surprisingly, Sundays usually include at least one practice session.

title: Despite Protests, Grand Prix Schedules Race for Bahrain
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  The organizers behind the Bahrain Grand Prix decided on Friday to schedule the auto race, delayed because of an antigovernment uprising, despite pleas from local and international human rights organizations to stay away.

title: In Queens, New Mothers and Old Asian Custom
description: Katy Lu opened the front door of the two-story house near the Queens Botanical Garden. Why dont I show you the babies first? she said in Mandarin Chinese, leading the way up a staircase and past a small kitchen where a rice cooker sat on a table.

title: I Cant Promise You A Rose Garden
description: But I can promise you a panel discussion on Charlie Rose, tonight. Me, Jared Bernstein, Ken Rogoff, David Walker.

title: To Cushion Against Losses, Fed Considers Raising Capital Requirements for Banks
description: WASHINGTON  Determining which financial companies are so large that their failures could pose a risk to the nations financial system should be done using a transparent and replicable formula that makes it clear to the financial firms, the markets and the public what institutions are covered, a Federal Reserve governor said Friday.

title: Al Qaeda Urges Attacks in West
description: In a new video, an American-born spokesman for Al Qaeda urged Muslims in the West to initiate attacks against Western and Jewish targets.

title: Riding Hundreds of Miles, and Just Getting Started
description: A STEADY rain pelted the New Jersey back roads, and the sun had recently crested over Princeton and was just illuminating a small but hardy group of cyclists setting out on a 125-mile ride. In most cycling circles, the distance would be a major undertaking. For this group, it was a mere tuneup.

title: What Do Economic Models Really Tell Us About Elections?
description: Yesterdays column on the weak historical relationship between the unemployment rate and presidential performance generated a mostly favorable reaction. But I also got a few replies wondering how to reconcile these findings against the claims, made with some frequency by political scientists, that presidential elections can be forecast with pinpoint accuracy provided that you know the economic fundamentals.

title: Views of New York, From Past to Present
description: THE New York of Leonard Lyons was a dream, the cultural critic John Leonard once wrote, but in dreaming it he had dreamed his way out of the Jewish ghetto and the candy stand his mother ran on the corner of Rivington and Ridge Streets. For exactly 40 years, from 1934 to 1974, he prodigiously churned out six columns a week brimming with anecdotal insights into celebrities (from Albert Einstein to Truman Capote) rather than headline-grabbing gossip.

description: To the Editor:

Technology and Love
description: To the Editor:

title: From Federers Supporters, Cheers and I-Told-You-Sos
description: PARIS  Their son had ended Novak Djokovics lengthy winning streak and kept him, perhaps, from becoming the No. 1 player in the world. Roger Federers father, Robert, passed around beers. His mother, Lynette, talked happily about all the people who were wrong about her sons career slide.

title: City Critic: Be a Broadway Star!
description: To test a new board game called "Be a Broadway Star!", Neil Genzlinger challenged several real Broadway performers to a match.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: At a Policemens Gala, One Well-Protected Guest
description: The only thing that kept us from an apoplectic fit on Thursday night was our fear of the following headline: Reporter Arrested at Policemens Gala. And despite our Nocturnalist correspondents calm, cool demeanor, it seemed it almost happened.

title: Youve Got 2 Minutes to Cry. Go!
description: Youd think that with all the money theatrical producers lose, theyd be pretty good at crying. But the other night, Ken Davenport, who is such a producer, could not shed even one tear on demand.

title: Podcast: Job Woes, Pet Boom and Annuity Puzzle
description: The economic recovery from the shock of the financial crisis has never been all that strong, but the Labor Departments monthly report on jobs and unemployment painted a picture of an economy that may be struggling even to keep growing.

title: At the Center of the Global E. Coli Scare, Hamburg Frets
description: HAMBURG, Germany  It is a worrisome time in this wealthy port city, known for its 19th-century churches and busy canals, where more than 100 people have fallen ill since the outbreak of a potentially lethal form of E. coli, putting 20 patients in intensive care, including five pregnant women.

title: Ryancare Versus Obamacare
description: Some commenters have asked a good question, albeit in a belligerent tone: how does the Ryan plan differ from the Affordable Care Act? After all, in both plans people are supposed to buy coverage from private insurers, with a subsidy from the government.

title: Even Strength Has Been the Bruins Big Advantage
description: If the Boston Bruins come back from their early deficit to win the Stanley Cup, they will probably do so by defying the hockey bromide that you cannot succeed without a good power play.

title: Hacking of White House E-Mail Affected Diverse Departments
description: WASHINGTON  The computer phishing attack that Google says originated in China was directed, somewhat indiscriminately, at an unknown number of White House staff officials, setting off the Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry that began this week, according to several administration officials.

title: Leaving Her Mark With the Well Worn
description: Art can, at times, have a bit of an audience problem. On the one hand, it wants to speak to the largest population. On the other, it wants to participate in conversations that only a handful of people are knowledgeable about  philosophy, say, or politics, or art itself. Betsabe Romero, an artist born in 1963, who was educated in Mexico and Paris and now lives in Mexico City, has hit upon a solution.

title: Shouts of Fore! and Budget Talks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner are taking their budget negotiations to a place where a lot of deals get done in the business world: the golf course.

title: When the Impresario Is Also a Performer
description: The celebrated guitarist and occasional impresario John Scofield has never let his penchant for the blues get in the way of a good free-form improvisation, and in Shades of Jazz, a three-show summer series he curates at the Katonah Museum of Art, he indulges these predilections as both performer and presenter.

title: Summer Programs for Children Who Bring Their Muses
description: FOR Michaela Mahon, 15, of Syosset, a yearly summer routine of going to arts camp began back in 2003, when her mother, Joan, got a new job.

title: Uncle Mo Found to Have Liver Disease
description: Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who was scratched from the Kentucky Derby the day before the race, has a liver disease called cholangiohepatitis, his internists said in a statement. The ailment is a severe inflammation of the bile passages and the liver.

title: Massey Energys Ex-Chief Rejects Finding in Blast
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks after an independent government commission concluded that Massey Energy was to blame for the explosion that killed 29 coal miners last year, the companys former chairman released a report on Thursday disputing the panels finding.

title: Yes, Medicare Is Sustainable In Its Current Form
description: I keep seeing people say that Medicare in its current form is not sustainable, as if that were an established fact. Its anything but.

title: Dancing on a Cloud, Over Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Adapting a Show for Children With Autism
description: When Lisa E. Cooney, director of education for the Paper Mill Playhouse, called a meeting last November to discuss the particulars of Stone Soup and Other Stories, a childrens show to be presented June 11, there was crying at the conference table.

title: A Remade Hole May Prove to Be the Undoing of Some
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  For the past two days, golfers have moved through the leafy corridor from the 15th green to the 16th tee at Muirfield Village Golf Club, walking slowly, almost warily, like patients headed to the orthodontist. Some glanced at the new pond, others stared at the narrow putting surface that was splayed out horizontally like a thin strip of green bacon amid three dollops of gleaming white sand bunkers.

title: Vanuatu Recognizes Abkhazia. Or Maybe Not.
description: MOSCOW  Three days after Abkhazia announced that a fifth government  the tiny, impoverished Pacific island nation of Vanuatu  had agreed to formally recognize its sovereignty, an official from Vanuatu said the report was false, as a behind-the-scenes diplomatic competition went into overdrive.

title: Arts and Ideas Festival Extends Reach Across Borders
description: NEW HAVEN

title: A Neighborhood Changes; Its Ice Cream Girl Doesnt
description: As Maria Campanella steers her truck through the streets of Bensonhurst, she blasts the speakers, blares the horn and rings the bells.

title: When Teachers Talk Out of School
description: IN 1927, a schoolteacher in Secaucus, N.J., named Helen Clark lost her teaching license. The reason? Somebody had seen her smoking cigarettes after school hours. In communities across the United States, that was a ground for dismissal. So was card-playing, dancing and failure to attend church. Even after Prohibition ended, teachers could be dismissed for drinking or frequenting a place where liquor was served.

title: Caffeine Jolt, With a Smile
description: On a steamy Saturday morning, I had to dodge toddlers and strollers to get in line at the Black Cow Coffee Company in Pleasantville, but the clientele was so cheerful, and Michael Grant, the shops co-owner, and his fellow baristas were so adept at fielding orders, that the wait was, well, a pleasant one.

title: In a World of Tastes, No Easy Labels
description: ON my first visit to Myong Gourmet, my guests and I were greeted by a round of amuse bouches: smoked duck with pickled radish and, I believe, crme frache. The tastes blended wonderfully, but what was the orientation? French? Asian? New American? Next came a bowl of warm pita wedges matched with three spreads: edamame and tofu, some kind of pickled vegetable, and fruit and tofu. Again, delicious. And again, I felt a little unmoored.

title: Spanish Players Deflect Questions on Rivalries
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Iker Casillas and Andres Iniesta slid their chairs up to the table  on the same side, literally and figuratively, for a change  and waited for the questions they knew were coming. They will play for Spain in an exhibition game against the United States at Gillette Stadium on Saturday, but on Friday many of the questions  predictably, inevitably  revolved around their two club teams: Casillass Real Madrid and Iniestas Barcelona.

title: Why Khodorkovsky Matters
description: Over the past six months, Ive written three columns about Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former Russian oligarch who has been in prison since 2003, charged, tried, convicted  and recently reconvicted  on transparently bogus tax and embezzlement charges.

title: A Renaissance on Main Street
description: IF you are looking for evidence that Riverhead is undergoing a renaissance, it can be found at 1 East Main Street. This 1929 building, home to offices and shops in the past, reopened in September after a renovation, with the Dark Horse restaurant on the first floor. (There are apartments upstairs.)

title: Rieslings for Summer
description: Few summer whites offer charms to rival those of young rieslings, especially when the vineyard and cellar reflect German wine culture.

title: Rubbermaid Cuts Its Full-Year Profit Forecast
description: Newell Rubbermaid, the maker of Sharpie pens and plastic storage containers, cut its full-year profit forecast Friday on slumping consumer spending, setting off a 12 percent decline in its share price. Profit, excluding costs for restructuring and other items, will be at least $1.60 a share, down from a projection of at least $1.67, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News had forecast a profit of $1.69 a share. More than two-thirds of Rubbermaids sales come from the United States, where persistent joblessness and surging prices for food and gas have forced shoppers to watch their wallets. The company lowered its growth forecast for sales, excluding foreign currency fluctuations, to 3 percent to 4 percent. That is down a point from a previous estimate April 29. Stock in Rubbermaid, which is based in Atlanta, fell $2, to $14.97 a share.

title: Indelible Pizza
description: Wedged between Starbucks and Subway in a one-story red stone building, Stretchs Pizza is easy to overlook. Taste one of its delicious pizzas, though, and the two-year-old pizzeria makes a much more lasting impression.

title: Authentic Flavors and Parisian Charm
description: DISTANCING itself from a formal French restaurant right from the start  Bohemian is part of its subtitle  Caf Lola in Fairfield has the eclectic charm of an authentic Parisian cafe, with two intimate dining rooms conducive to cozy conversation.

title: Wal-Mart to Buy Back Billions More in Shares
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Wal-Mart said on Friday that it would buy back $15 billion more of its shares to try to improve returns for its shareholders.

title: Chrysler Favors Stock Sale by U.A.W. Retiree Trust
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Chryslers chief executive said Friday that a public stock offering remained the preferred method for a health care trust to sell its ownership stake in the Detroit automaker.

title: False Choices
description: Fridays jobs report was abysmal.

title: Obama Lauds Bailout at Visit to Chrysler Plant
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  If the 2012 election is about the economy, as most people think, then President Obamas visit on Friday to this struggling manufacturing city on the Ohio-Michigan border captured as well as any day could the complicated campaign he is likely to face  playing both offense and defense, taking credit and deflecting blame.

title: U.S. Wont Become Isolationist, Gates Tells Worried Asian Leaders
description: SINGAPORE  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged Saturday that the United States would sustain its military presence and diplomatic involvement in Asia, as he sought to calm regional worries about the potential for a new isolationism brought on by fiscal difficulties at home.

title: Do You Know the Duffin Man?
description: Spring was rather elusive this year, but Peter Lloyd, one of the owners of Brownie Points Bakery in downtown Summit, was undeterred: he had the walls of the shop painted sky blue, and decked out the windows and shelves with bird houses, daisies and tufts of artificial green grass.

title: Italian, Inventive, and Keen on Vegetables
Before Bike-Share Effort Starts, Concerns Are Raised About How It Will Work
description: The Bloomberg administration is only months away from rolling out an ambitious bike-share program intended eventually to rival ones in London, Paris and Washington, yet the proposal has already been plagued by questions of its viability.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 3, 2011

title: Ghosts of Guatemalas Past
description: IN 1954, the American government committed one of the most reprehensible acts in its history when it authorized the C.I.A. to overthrow the democratically elected leader of Guatemala, President Jacobo Arbenz. It did so secretly but later rationalized the coup on the ground that the country was about to fall into communist hands.

title: Connecticut House Debates Requiring Sick Pay
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives debated late into Friday night as members considered a bill that would make Connecticut the nations first state to mandate that some employers provide paid sick days to employees.

title: Complex Case Ahead for Prosecutors
description: The criminal case against John Edwards on misuse of campaign funds will be a challenge for federal prosecutors, experts in campaign finance and corruption said.

title: How a Democracy Works
description: President Obama, who has spent two and a half years not delivering on his promise to fix immigration, gave a speech in El Paso last month and cloaked his failure in tough statistics  this many new border agents, that much fencing, these thousands of deportations.

title: Saturday: Scraps in the Sticks
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Not that its about me, but the first thing that struck me about todays puzzle was the appalling number of adult beverages it would take to get me up on stage at a KARAOKE BAR. Im not a shy person by any stretch, but for some reason the thought of getting up and singing by myself in front of other people terrifies me. The last Christmas party I attended for Bust Magazine (disclosure: I construct their X Games crossword puzzle) was held at a karaoke bar here in New York City, and although I had immense fun with my fellow Busties, you would not have been able to get me up on stage if you tried. NO SIREE BOB. I will gladly applaud and cheer wildly for others, though.

title: President Assads Bloody Hands
description: Syrians have shown extraordinary courage, standing up to President Bashar al-Assads reign of terror. We wish we could say that about the international community. So long as Mr. Assad escapes strong condemnation and real punishment, he will keep turning his tanks and troops on his people.

title: Give Me the Permits, or Else
description: It sounded like a simple bit of noncontroversial Senate routine: raising the salary of Interior Secretary Ken Salazar to the level of his cabinet peers. Then, with all the finesse of a shakedown artist, Senator David Vitter, Republican of Louisiana, declared that he will keep a legislative hold on the $19,600-a-year raise until Mr. Salazar has his department approve more deepwater drilling permits in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Baseball Awaiting Records on Colons Stem Cell Treatment
description: When it was disclosed that Bartolo Colon had received a novel stem cell treatment on his ailing elbow and shoulder, Major League Baseball said it would investigate, in part to ensure that Colon had not benefited from any banned substance as part of the medical procedure.

title: What Do You See on Your Plate Today?
description: Lets face it, if the food on your plate forms a pyramid, youre probably eating too much. And yet the symbol meant to guide Americans eating choices has long been the food pyramid, one that has grown more abstract and harder to understand over the years even as the nutritional guidelines have improved. On Thursday, the secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack, and the first lady, Michelle Obama, abandoned the pyramid and unveiled its replacement: a dinner plate known as MyPlate.

title: Settlements End Suits Over Raids By Officials
description: Two groups of plaintiffs have settled lawsuits against law enforcement agencies that raided several St. Paul buildings in advance of the 2008 Republican National Convention, searching for information about protests or unlawful activities. Items seized in the raids, according to court documents, included pamphlets titled Wash Your Own Dishes and Activists Guide to Basic First Aid.

title: Rodriguez Affirms Defense of His Cousins Presence
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Alex Rodriguezs cousin Yuri Sucart supplied him with steroids from 2001 to 2003 and was subsequently barred from having any contact with the Yankees or their facilities. Rodriguez was asked Friday what Sucart does for him now.

title: Outbreak in Europe May Revive Stalled U.S. Effort to Tighten Rules on Food Safety
description: The deadly wave of food-borne illness in Europe, caused by a rare form of E. coli bacteria, could finally push the United States to take long-delayed steps to protect the food supply in this country from a similar group of toxic organisms.

title: War of Ideas on U.S. Budget Overshadows Job Struggle
description: WASHINGTON  A run of disappointing economic data, punctuated by Fridays employment numbers, is emboldening Congressional Republicans in their standoff with the White House over the best way for the government to encourage growth.

title: Zimbabwe: Church Officials Detained
description: Four Anglican priests and 11 church wardens were arrested Wednesday for trying to prevent people allied with a supporter of President Robert Mugabe from taking over the home of the rector of St. Marys Church in Harare. The 15 were released on Thursday. The Mugabe supporter, Nolbert Kunonga, an excommunicated bishop, is seeking control of thousands of church properties across four countries. We are angry we are not being protected by the police, the new bishop of the Harare diocese, Chad Gandiya, said Friday.

title: Libya: Rape Accuser Says She Was Beaten in Qatar
description: Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan woman who became a symbol of resistance when she said she had been raped and beaten by Qaddafi militiamen, told CNN on Friday that she had been beaten again, this time by officers of the government of Qatar, who deported her Thursday to the rebel stronghold of Benghazi. The reason for her deportation was unclear, and Qatari officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Mets Day Starts With Bad News, and Gets Worse With Latest Collapse
description: Another difficult day for the Mets began Friday afternoon when first baseman Ike Davis limped into the clubhouse and explained that his injured left ankle was still inexplicably sore. A few hours later, the Mets were making dubious history on the field with another late-inning collapse.

title: As Catholic Schools Close in Major Cities, the Need Only Grows
description: Amid the grandeur and permanence of St. Patricks Cathedral, they marched down the aisle in pairs, the graduating seniors of Rice High School in Harlem. They were the 70th commencement class in the schools history, the latest to bear the venerable epithet of being Rice men.

title: Strong G.O.P. Field?
description: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the strength of the Republican presidential field.

title: Using Legacy of Watergate, John Dean to Teach Ethics
description: It was a telling list.

title: Florida: Rights Groups Challenge New Voting Law
description: The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida filed a suit in federal court on Friday to block a state law that makes it harder for voters to change addresses at the polls and for third-party voter registration groups to operate. The A.C.L.U., joined in the suit by Project Vote, says the law should not take effect anywhere until the Justice Department reviews it to ensure that it does not discriminate against members of minorities in five Florida counties that qualify for protection under the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act. The state law, signed by Gov. Rick Scott two weeks ago, took effect immediately, except in those five counties. In six weeks, this ill law was conceived, drafted behind closed doors, jammed through the Legislature, signed by the governor and is being rushed to a speedy and illegal implementation, said State Senator Arthenia L. Joyner, who also joined in the suit.

title: Photo Replay: June 3
description: A look at the day in sports, from the Iranian womens national soccer team to the New York Mets.

title: Elmer G. Pratt, Jailed Panther Leader, Dies at 63
description: Elmer G. Pratt, a Black Panther leader who was imprisoned for 27 years for murder and whose marathon fight to prove he had been framed attracted support from civil rights groups and led to the overturning of his conviction, died on Thursday in a village in Tanzania, where he was living. He was 63.

title: Stolen Data Is Tracked to Hacking at Lockheed
description: Lockheed Martin said Friday that it had proof that hackers breached its network two weeks ago partly by using data stolen from a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to tens of millions of computer users.

title: Between Young and Old, a Political Collision
description: LAKEWOOD, Colo.  Economic wreckage in Americas older population is easy to find in the ashes of recession. And when combined with the politics of a presidential election next year and talk in Congress of cuts to the system of health and economic support for retirees, the result could be volatile.

title: Where Prisoners Can Do Anything, Except Leave
description: PORLAMAR, Venezuela  On the outside, the San Antonio prison on Margarita Island looks like any other Venezuelan penitentiary. Soldiers in green fatigues stand at its gates. Sharpshooters squint from watchtowers. Guards cast menacing glances at visitors before searching them at the entrance.

title: Venezuela's Prison Paradise
description: On the outside, the San Antonio prison on Margarita Island looks like any other Venezuelan penitentiary. But venture inside and you'll see how far the rabbit hole goes.

title: Under Scrutiny, Official at State University Resigns
description: A top official at the State University of New York accused of giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has resigned amid mounting scrutiny of his conduct.

title: Central Park Zoo Bear Is Euthanized at 25
description: New York City got a bit less fluffy this week.

title: Battle For Libya | June 3, 2011
description: In LIbya, rebels continued their battle against the forces of Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Ray Bryant, Jazz Pianist, Dies at 79
description: Ray Bryant, a jazz pianist whose sensitivity and easy authority made him a busy accompanist and a successful solo artist, beginning in the mid-1950s, died on Thursday. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: EDITOR'S NOTE

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: The Lies They Tell
description: We are covering the final season of Friday Night Lights according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

title: Sony Admits That Web Site Was Hacked
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment confirmed on Friday that hackers had broken into one or more of its Web sites and said it was taking steps to prevent a recurrence.

title: Johanna Fiedler Dies at 65; Wrote of the Met Opera
description: Johanna Fiedler, a publicist who wrote tell-all books about the Metropolitan Opera and about growing up as the daughter of Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops, died on May 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

title: Why the Gold Cup Is More Important Than Beating Spain
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  One by one on Friday, United States Coach Bob Bradley and his players talked about what a privilege it is to play Spain. Special, Bradley called it. Exciting, said Clint Dempsey. A terrific opportunity, said Carlos Bocanegra.

title: Despite Novas Solid Performance, Yankees Stumble Against Angels
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Ivan Nova had no time to react when Torii Hunter ripped a line drive directly at his head. So he threw up his glove for protection, the ball striking the heel, then his left hand, before rolling away. That play, which occurred in the fifth inning of the Yankees 3-2 loss to the Los Angeles Angels on Friday, was a microcosm of Novas night. He was adept at avoiding precarious situations, but unable to dodge them all.

title: The Early Word: Rebuked
description: Todays Times

title: In Afghanistan, Gates Stresses U.S. Is Committed to the Fight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday that the United States should stick to its full counterinsurgency strategy in Afghanistan at least through this year, even as American forces begin a drawdown in July and some in Congress argue that the current mission is too expensive to continue.

title: Li Beats Schiavone: French Open Womens Final
description: Li Na, a 29-year-old from Wuhan, China, became the first man or woman from Asia to win a Grand Slam singles title on Saturday, beating defending champion Francesca Schiavone from Italy, 6-4, 7-6(0). Li, cool and calm as she won point after point in the second-set tiebreaker, fell onto her back when Schiavones last shot landed long.

title: Pakistani Militant Chief Is Reported Dead
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  One of Pakistans most wanted militant commanders, Ilyas Kashmiri, was killed in an American drone strike in the tribal territory of South Waziristan, residents and a militant active in the area said Saturday. But Pakistani and American officials cautioned that they had not been able to confirm his death.

title: The Lonely Crowd(ing Out)
description: A few commenters have suggested, in response to my post on the utter failure of the claim that budget deficits would drive up interest rates even in a liquidity trap, that things might look different if we looked at real rather than nominal rates.

title: Hitting the Slow Lane Cross-Country on a Moped
description: About a year ago Mikael Tarkela heard some disturbing news about the 1976 Peugeot 103 moped that he had been storing in a warehouse in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: A Farm Sale of Integrity
description: Carole-Terese Naser is the new general manager of Runnymede Farm in North Hampton, N.H. She fell in love with horse racing when Dancers Image won the Kentucky Derby in 1968.

title: Fatal Fatalism
description: Our current economic discourse is pervaded by fatalism. Leave aside the people who insist that somehow Obama has destroyed capitalist incentives by passing Mitt Romneys health care plan and threatening to raise tax rates to Clinton-era levels. Even among people who should be sensible, you hear many assertions that run something like this: historically, recovery from financial crisis is usually slow, so we have to accept a slow recovery this time around too. Actually, thats more or less what Obama has been saying.

title: Supporters of a Yoga Guru Assemble for an Anticorruption Protest in India
description: NEW DELHI  Led by a prominent yoga guru, thousands of protesters on Saturday staged a huge anticorruption protest in the heart of Indias capital, gathering beneath a vast outdoor tent for a yoga session, followed by a hunger strike orchestrated as a pressure tactic against the government.

title: Whale Wars Leader: Arrest Me or Shut Up
description: Amid scrambling to presentations at the World Science Festival and a United Nations screening of a remarkable new film, the Journey of the Universe, I slipped in 45 minutes to interview Paul Watson. Hes the founder of the anti-whaling Sea Shepherd Conservation Society and central character in the popular Whale Wars show on Animal Planet, which began its fourth season on Friday night and may have a new focus next year. Heres part one of the interview:

title: Italian Vogue Adds to Its Curvy Message
description: Real Beauties is the title of the June issue of Italian Vogue, which highlights women with more shape than the typical model. Steven Meisel shot the feature in a private home in Los Angeles.

title: For Bosh, Trip Home Reflects a Road Back
description: MIAMI  Not everybody in Dallas rejoiced when Mavericks forward Dirk Nowitzki spun past the Miami Heats Chris Bosh for the winning layup Thursday night in the waning seconds of Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals.

title: Afghans Want Sanctions Lifted on Taliban Figures
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  United Nations officials expect Afghanistan to make a serious effort to ask the Security Council to lift sanctions soon against more than 40 Taliban figures  more than a fourth of all those who are now on the organizations blacklist of Al Qaeda and Taliban members.

title: Variety: An Insane Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  I painted my entryway and living room recently, and the entryway to my house now sports a sunny, lovely Mediterranean yellow hue, which warms everyone who comes into my home and makes me very happy.

title: NATO Begins Helicopter Attacks in Hopes of Ending the Stalemate With Qaddafi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  In a move to intensify pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, NATO introduced attack helicopters into its air campaign against Libyan forces for the first time on Saturday, military officials said.

title: Li Na Dethrones Schiavone at French Open
description: PARIS  Which woman had the weight of China on her shoulders? It was easy to get confused on Saturday with Francesca Schiavone more on edge and off target than Li Na for much of the French Open final.

title: Drug Can Reduce Risk of Breast Cancer, Study Says
description: CHICAGO  A drug now used to prevent recurrences of breast cancer can also reduce the risk of it occurring in the first place, providing a new option for women at high risk of getting the disease, researchers reported here on Saturday.

title: As Web Returns, Syrians Post More Video of Fridays Protests and Clashes
description: Updated | 4:03 p.m. On Saturday, after Syrias government restored the Internet access it had cut off on Friday, in an attempt to disrupt the communications of protest organizers, Syrian activists were able to upload video of Fridays demonstrations and clashes to the Web.

title: As Labor Dispute Goes On, Some Are Looking Past Football
description: As the N.F.L. lockout wound through the legal system, Matt Kroul returned to the family farm in Iowa. There, amid soybeans and sweet corn and cattle, he works through footballs work stoppage. The bonus: his 86-year-old grandmother cooks lunch.

title: In Connecticut, Paid Sick Leave for Service Workers Is Approved
description: After 11 hours of debate in Hartford, state legislators approved a bill on Saturday to make Connecticut the first state in the nation to mandate paid sick leave for hundreds of thousands of service workers.

title: Syrian Tanks Move in on City as Thousands Mourn Protesters Deaths
description: CAIRO  Syrian tanks took up positions outside the city of Hama on Saturday, where tens of thousands of people took to the streets to mourn the deaths of at least 65 protesters gunned down by security forces there the day before.

title: After Two-Year Break, a Special Grand Slam Rivalry Is Renewed
description: PARIS  No two men have met in a Grand Slam final as often as Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, but there were times that it seemed it might not happen again.

title: Lawrence Eagleburger, a Top Diplomat, Dies at 80
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a troubleshooting diplomat and senior foreign policy adviser to presidents who served the country for more than 40 years, including 42 days as secretary of state at the close of President George Bushs term, died on Saturday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 80.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JON STEWART

title: Obama Retools 2008 Machine for Tough Run
description: CHICAGO  Saddled with a faltering economic recovery, President Obama is rebuilding the campaign machinery that vaulted him into office, hoping it can overcome the challenges of persistently high unemployment and a fractured coalition of supporters.

title: Fighting Words
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a Republican who has won attention for preaching belt-tightening, faced criticism himself last week after he took a state helicopter to see his son play a high school baseball game and then flew to a meeting of political supporters. (Mr. Christie later paid $2,151 for the cost of flights he took to his sons games; the State Republican Party reimbursed the state $1,232 for the flight to meet with supporters.)

title: Bend Me, Shape Me: The Heavy-Metal Version
description: ITS hard to beat the versatility of plastic on a production line. Melt and inject it into molds, let it cool and harden, and out comes an endless variety of parts at high rates of speed.

title: Rays Test of Riches: Extra Draft Picks
description: The Tampa Bay Rays had to make a decision before last season. They could field a team with several potential free agents and try to win a championship, or they could trade those players for prospects. They chose the first path, won the American League East and let every free agent go.

title: Considered: John Edwards
description: Courtrooms can be tricky places. For John Edwards, a skilled trial lawyer and a Democratic candidate for president in 2008, it was the place where he first found his fortune and fame.

title: Prime Number
description: 85,000: The estimated maximum number of people killed in the Haitian earthquake last year, according to a new draft report prepared for the United States Agency for International Development. That figure is well below the death toll of 316,000 announced by Haitis government in January. An American official backed away from the new tally  by an outside research group that also found that other aspects of the disaster had been overstated  saying it was beyond the scope of the commission and purely reflects the views of the author.

title: Prospect Heights, 4:40 A.M.
Citing Medical Needs, Yemeni Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON  Yemens embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for urgent medical treatment of wounds sustained in a bold attack on the presidential compound, Saudi officials said, abruptly shifting the political calculus that has allowed him to cling to power despite months of protest and violence.

title: Power? Thanks, but Id Rather Have Influence
description: This interview with  Bing Gordon, a partner with the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Back Then: 1990
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the central, controversial figure in the national debate over assisted suicide, died last week at age 83 in a hospital outside of Detroit. title: Edwards Case Casts Spotlight on a Long Reclusive Donor
description: Rachel Mellon, now 100 years old and long one of the richest women in America, has lived a life of maximum discretion and minimum exposure.

title: Focusing on the Social, Minus the Media
description: THE scene unfolding at the Thai restaurant in Brooklyn was like that of any other casual dinner party. A small group of people sat around a wooden table, passing large dishes of spicy red curry and fried rice, drinking cold beers and swapping war stories about apartment hunting in New York.

title: The Annuity Puzzle
description: IMAGINE a set of 65-year-old identical twins who plan to retire this summer after long careers. Well call them Dave and Ron. They have worked for different employers and have accumulated retirement benefits worth the same amount in dollars, but the benefits wont be paid out the same way.

description: WASHINGTON  If a maybe-candidate for president does not issue an official schedule to the news media as she tours around in something that closely resembles a campaign bus, did the tour really happen?

title: A Leaner, Fitter Berkman Regains His Form
description: ST. LOUIS  Lance Berkman played in a World Series with Andy Pettitte. Last fall, they were teammates again in the playoffs. They are each from Texas, earnest and friendly, married with four children, borderline Hall of Famers who pepper conversation with words like heck and golly.

title: The Old Lance Berkman Is Back
description: ST. LOUIS  If the Yankees had somehow managed to win Games 6 and 7 of the American League Championship Series in Texas last fall, Lance Berkman would have been their first baseman in the World Series. (Mark Teixeira was out with an injury.) Seven months later, this still sounds bizarre to Berkman, who had always been a Houston Astro until a trade to New York in July.

title: Should (Could) America and Pakistans Bond Be Broken?
description: WASHINGTON  Americas tormented relationship with Pakistan has long had the subtlety of a professional wrestling match. So when frayed relations turned openly hostile in recent weeks, it was hardly a surprise to see Pakistani officials flirt publicly with China, Americas biggest rival in Asia.

title: The Guilt of Trading Too Much
description: FOR nearly all investors, frequent trading is a terrible proposition. Many people know they trade more than they should  but they just cant stop.

description: WE live in the midst of broken systems, or so it seems. From our education system to our financial and health care systems, we are confronted with all manner of interconnected problems. As if that isnt enough, the system we rely on for our very sustenance  the one that delivers our food  is also in a state of disrepair.

title: Side Effects? These Drugs Have a Few
description: Dr. Jon Duke of Indiana University was trying to figure out why his patients blood platelets were abnormal. Could it be a side effect of one of the dozen drugs the man was taking, a number that is not uncommon among elderly people?

description: Q. Youve just graduated from college but couldnt find a job or internship in advance  so you are moving back in with your parents. Can you take some time off before restarting your job search?

title: Farming to Franchising
description: I GREW up on a 100-acre farm in Michigan with almost every farm animal imaginable, including horses, peacocks, pigs, sheep and chickens. At age 6 or 7, Id watch my father butcher the cows and Id help pick the feathers off the chickens after they were slaughtered. I wouldnt have the stomach for that today.

description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The list of pitchers includes an up-and-coming starter and a down-and-out reliever, a begoggled right-hander and a nearsighted left-hander. One is from Canada and one plays there now. The final one played for nine teams, three of them twice, over 19 seasons.

description: The rubber match between the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom and the Preakness Stakes champion Shackleford is, indeed, on for the 143rd renewal of the Belmont Stakes.

description: Ever since Jim Tressel resigned as Ohio States football coach on Monday, the fallout, the universitys president, E. Gordon Gee, said, has been like a tsunami. Gee acknowledged that the university had turned into a punching bag in the national news media. He also apologized for the way that he and the university handled parts of Tressels case.

description: The N.H.L. announced last week that its senior vice president for hockey operations, Colin Campbell, would no longer oversee player discipline beginning next season. Campbell, tired of the pressure that came with the job, suggested the change.

title: The Curious Case of Nelson Obus
description: Nelson Obus is on no ones list of Wall Street titans. He is just another guy who chased that golden dream: catch the morning train into Manhattan, run a small but prosperous hedge fund, catch the evening train out, back to a leafy island of suburban wealth.

As the scrimmages against the Chinese national team and the Connecticut Sun progressed across five 10-minute periods Monday at the Madison Square Garden Training Center, John Whisenant never sat. He paced in front of the Liberty bench, evaluating and coaching all at once.

Phelps, 25, who has won 16 Olympic medals, including 14 gold, said it was a cool feeling to have his own game. JOE BRESCIA

title: Video of Syrian Funerals and Demonstrations

Razan Zeitouneh, a Damascus-based activist, said as many as 100,000 people came out in mourning.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Americas Energy Options
description: Last week, under the headline Invitation to a Dialogue: The Energy Future, we introduced a feature in which we will occasionally invite readers to respond to a particularly provocative and interesting letter. We hope to spur a dialogue on issues of national or international importance. Here is the original letter, followed by a sampling of reader responses, and a rebuttal from the first writer.

title: Sticker Shock
description: Lots of happy talk accompanied the Obama administrations unveiling of new fuel economy stickers for cars and light trucks that will include annual fuel costs and information about emissions. The new stickers, mandatory starting with the 2013 models, are a big improvement on the simple miles-per-gallon estimates on the present label. If they were there right now, we suspect many car buyers would be experiencing a new sort of sticker shock.

title: Overlooking Oversight
description: In late May, Congress extended three enhanced surveillance powers that were granted to the government after the 9/11 attacks  two in the Patriot Act and one from a related intelligence law. In doing so, lawmakers neatly managed to avoid any lapse in those powers. They failed miserably in their duty to carefully re-examine the provisions, trim back excesses, and add safeguards to protect civil liberties. In other words, they ignored the whole point of requiring that the provisions be periodically reviewed.

title: Loan From Russia Props Up Belarus
description: MOSCOW  A Russian-controlled economic assistance fund agreed on Saturday to extend a $3 billion loan to Belarus, propping up the countrys teetering economy  and with it the authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

title: John Edwards, A Cautionary Tale
description: Self-destruction in politics is painful to watch for voters whose hopes are stirredtime and again by the high promises of a compelling candidate. The case of former Senator John Edwards is especially tawdry and disturbing. He was criminally indicted on Friday on charges of misusing hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations to keep his mistress and their baby a secret while he pursued the White House in 2008 and protected his public image as a devoted family man.

title: Drinking In the Draught of June
description: If we could bottle a few days to uncork later in the year  when the wind has got us by the neck and the curbs are full of taxi-slush  these would be the ones: early June, the days of peony and iris. Conifers still wear the green tips of new growth, and a few of the hardwoods, hickories especially, still show a last vestige of May. Otherwise, the trees have cast their pollen and fledged completely. Now come the deep, dark shadows of late summer.

title: After Disputed Call, Schiavone Folds in Final

This year the company will add substantially to its work force of more than 5,000 in that Silicon Valley city, and it has just leased nine acres to expand its campus.

JONATHAN CURIEL

description: Texas Democrats never had much hope in this Legislature, where Republicans have a huge majority and an unshakeable drive to slash spending without raising taxes or dipping into the states giant savings account.

description: During the regular session, Gov. Rick Perrys top legislative priority for higher education was the implementation of a financing system that rewards universities for graduating more students, not just for getting students into classes. To reach its 2015 goals, Texas needs to increase the number of degrees awarded by 46,000 each year.

title: Sunday: Cagey Answers
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  We last saw Yaakov Bendavid a little over a year ago (Across Lite, Solution, blog) when he flip-flopped on us. Today we welcome him back, and for what? So he can switch letters on us. We sit here, reading clue after clue, patiently filling in letter after letter  on a Sunday, mind you, our day off  and this is the thanks we get. I tell you, kids nowadays.

title: Lyle Lovett on Theaters With Magic
description: Last month, Texas politicians on both sides of the aisle found something they could agree on: House Concurrent Resolution 165, which named Lyle Lovett the 2011 Texas state musician. Its an obvious honor to bestow upon the guy who wrote Thats Right (Youre Not From Texas). But as with the former honoree Willie Nelson and the Legislatures 2012 selection, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top, the consistency of Mr. Lovetts four-decade career makes him one of the states most obvious  and instantly recognizable  good-will ambassadors.

title: Reader Comments on Sundays Column
description: My Sunday column perhaps contains a hint of bile: it reflects my distress at where the economic debate in this country is going, and at the rising levels of economic inequality. Im afraid that efforts to address the budget mess  a serious challenge, but a medium- to long-term one  will aggravate the inequality and reduce opportunity in this country. In short, I worry that Republican or Tea Party budget policies will make America look more likewell, thats the point of the column.

title: Protecting the Food Supply
