title: A Warming Planet Struggles to Feed Itself
description: CIUDAD OBREGN, Mexico  The dun wheat field spreading out at Ravi P. Singhs feet offered a possible clue to human destiny. Baked by a desert sun and deliberately starved of water, the plants were parched and nearly dead.

title: Damaging the Earth to Feed Its People
description: On a warming planet, humanity faces a great challenge in feeding itself at reasonable cost in the coming century, as I explain in Sundays paper. An issue I raise only in passing in the article is that agriculture itself is one of the earths greatest environmental threats.

title: Questions on Climate Change and the Food Future
description: Justin Gillis is taking reader questions on the potential effects of  climate change on the global food supply and will respond this week on the Green blog.

title: Back in Winnipeg, Bettman Strikes Different Chord
description: The contrast between what Gary Bettman said in 1995 and 96, as the Winnipeg Jets prepared to leave Manitoba, and what he has said in the last few weeks, as the N.H.L. prepared to return there, shows how much he has learned about the sensitivities of hockey fans in the intervening years.

title: Mets Knock Bay Down a Peg or Two
description: Jason Bay, the struggling slugger with the $66 million contract, was joined by Manager Terry Collins as he sat down to eat hours before the Mets played the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night at Citi Field. Collins had a quick piece of news that was not tough for Bay to digest: he was being demoted.

title: Efforts to Ban Circumcision Gain Traction in California
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  When a group of activists proposed banning circumcision in San Francisco last fall, many people simply brushed them aside. Even in that liberal seaside city, it seemed implausible that thousands of people would support an effort to outlaw an ancient ritual that Jews and Muslims believe fulfills a commandment issued by God.

title: A Grass-Roots Fight to Save a Supertree
description: NANJING, China  Tall as a 15-story building, with a mighty trunk, crooked branches and kingly canopy of leaves, the London plane tree, Platanus x acerifolia, is prized by horticulturists and city planners as a supertree, immune to urban grime and smog.

title: A G.O.P. Hopeful Gathers Momentum as More Voters Like What They Hear
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Michele Bachmann was campaigning just north of here, the Sarah Palin tour was rumored to be arriving soon, and Mitt Romney was on his way to announce his entry into the presidential race.

title: Showdowns for Young Stars Provide Glimpse of the Future
description: Two recent exhibition matches in St. Louis could help pave the way for an American to have a shot at the world title after the next championship match in 2012.

title: DAntoni a Question Mark as Walsh Moves On
description: Mike DAntoni is comfortable with the transition game. It is a staple of his high-octane offense and an unfortunate reality of the coaching life. Momentum can shift quickly, unexpectedly.

title: Sammy Ofer, Magnate and Israeli Power Broker, Dies at 89
description: JERUSALEM  Sammy Ofer, the Israeli international shipping magnate, philanthropist and art collector who headed a family ranked as the richest in Israel, and whose company is at the center of a storm over dealings with Iran, died at his home in Tel Aviv on Friday. He was 89.

title: Signs of an Urban Rivers Revival in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Every urban river is a political canvas. What was, in hard industrial eras past, melds to what is and what might yet be.

title: A Polarizing Figure in End-of-Life Debates
description: In reports of Dr. Jack Kevorkians death on Friday at the age of 83, the general rule of obituaries held: Do not speak ill of the dead.

title: Edwin Honig, a Poet, Professor and Translator, Dies at 91
description: Edwin Honig, a poet, critic and translator known for his elegant English renditions of seminal works of Spanish and Portuguese literature, died on May 25 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 91.

title: With More Important Games to Come, U.S. Is Taught Low-Cost Lesson
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Bob Bradley and the United States national team never made any secret of the fact that Saturdays exhibition game against Spain was not as important as the game they will play against Canada on Tuesday. That could be a good thing  it will make the loss easier to forget.

title: Torrid Start, Frigid Finish as Stricker Holds Lead
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Steve Stricker almost made himself look unbeatable on a blazing Saturday afternoon at Muirfield Village Golf Club, holing out from the fairway at the second hole for eagle, then ripping his approach from 238 yards to within 7 feet at the fifth and brushing that in for another eagle.

title: Urgency Is Business as Usual for Heat
description: DALLAS  The Miami Heat again embraced its inner enigma amid a cross-examination of why the Dallas Mavericks now own home-court advantage, if not the psychological edge, in the N.B.A. finals.

title: Leo Rangell, a Stalwart of Freudian Talk Therapy, Dies at 97
description: Dr. Leo Rangell, a leading psychoanalyst during the heyday of classical Freudian talk therapy in the 1960s and 70s, and a relentless advocate for the slow approach to treating emotional distress even as antidepressants and managed care made short-term treatment the norm, died on May 28 in Los Angeles. He was 97.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 5
description: Following the revelation of Mays disappointing job numbers, the Sunday shows are almost single-mindedly focused on the economy this week. The White House is sending Austan Goolsbee, chairman of President Obamas Council of Economic Advisers, to be its representative in the discussion on ABCs This Week and CNNs State of the Union.

title: For the Jobless, Little U.S. Help on Foreclosure
description: The Obama administrations main program to keep distressed homeowners from falling into foreclosure has been aimed at those who took out subprime loans or other risky mortgages during the heady days of the housing boom. But these days, the primary cause of foreclosures is unemployment.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Hughes Takes Baby Steps
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  On a sun-splashed June afternoon in Southern California, it felt like early March in Florida for Phil Hughes. His second spring training continued Saturday, when he threw 22 pitches to hitters from the mound at Angel Stadium, where he moved ever closer to an eventual return. Hughes remains at least a month away, according to Manager Joe Girardi, but his progress has allowed him to start looking ahead.

title: Photo Replay: June 4
description: A look back at the day in sports, from the triathlon championships in Madrid to the French Open.

title: Green Men to Invade Boston
description: The Vancouver Canucks superfans, the Green Men, are on their way to Boston for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Bay Is Dropped in Order, and Gee Keeps Rising for the Mets
description: Jason Bay, the struggling slugger with the $66 million contract, sat down to eat hours before the Mets played the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night and was joined by Manager Terry Collins. Collins had a quick piece of news that was not tough to digest: Bay was being dropped in the batting order.

title: Quiz: Locked-Out Players Become Jacks of New Trades
description: With their time off, some lesser-known N.F.L. players have been making a living at other pursuits.

title: Rafa vs. Roger: One for the Ages
description: Rafael Nadal looks to win his sixth French Open Sunday as he faces his longtime friend and rival Roger Federer in the finals of the French Open. Nadal has beaten Federer four times here at Roland Garros, in the semifinals in 05, and in consecutive finals in 06, 07, and 08. Federer won here two years ago, defeating the only man to ever beat Nadal at Roland Garros, Robin Soderling, in the final. Federer advanced to the final with his upset win on Friday over Novak Djokovic, in a stirring match that will be remembered for its high level of play.

title: Lauren & Alex
description: Lauren Blasch and Alex Carabelli met during their freshman year at Boston University. In this homemade video, they describe how their friendship turned into love.

title: Jane & Nathaniel
description: In this homemade video, Jane Borden & Nathaniel Stogdill tell how they met like people did 20 years ago, by running into each other at a coffee shop.

title: Lillian & Adam
description: In this homemade video, New Yorkers Lillian Baharestani and Adam Archer reflect upon how they met in San Francisco.

title: Morgan & Ross
description: Morgan Brooks and Ross Thompson's parents have known each other for 25 years but they connected in 2004 when Morgan went to Ross' birthday party. They share their story in this homemade video.

title: Burrows Strikes In Overtime To Put Canucks In Command
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Alexandre Burrows, who escaped suspension in the wake of a biting incident in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, scored two goals, including the winner 11 seconds into overtime, and gave the Vancouver Canucks a 3-2 victory here on Saturday night and a 2-0 series lead over the Boston Bruins.

title: Alaina & Hale
description: In this homemade video, Alaina Stahl and Hale Simon recount how they started falling in love after Thanksgiving with Hale's family.

title: Keila & Daniel
description: In this video produced by Joel Witmer, Keila Lopez and Daniel Harrington describe how they found happiness together online.

title: Larry & Jeremy
description: Larry Slater says he moved to Alabama to settle down and coincidentally he met Jeremy Erdreich four days later.

title: Jennifer & Cory
description: Twelve years after meeting and nine years of dating, Jennifer Atanasoska and Cory Davis share their story in this homemade video.

title: Stacey & David
description: In this homemade video, David Abeles says he took the role of Santa Claus in the Radio City Christmas Spectacular because traveling with 32 Rockettes was alluring. He ended up falling for Stacey Sund.

title: C. C. Sabathia Makes Himself at Home on the Road
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  It was understood during the 2008 off-season that C. C. Sabathia preferred to pitch for a team on the West Coast. It is where he grew up, where he felt comfortable and where he has pitched so well over the last week for the team that signed him: the Yankees. Sabathia worked the first eight and two-thirds innings Saturday night against the Los Angeles Angels before giving way to Mariano Rivera, who needed one pitch to secure the final out of a 3-2 victory at Angel Stadium.

title: Israeli Troops Advance Into Gaza
description: Israeli ground troops and tanks cut swaths through the Gaza Strip, bisecting the coastal territory and surrounding its biggest city as the new phase of an offensive against Hamas gained momentum.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Spain
description: The game was ugly. And the player ratings are, too.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 4, 2011

title: Discovering Science on Governors Island
description: Children identified plant species, built robots and gazed at the sun as part of a World Science Festival event on Governors Island.

title: Malhotra Returns From Injury and Helps Buoy Team to Win
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  An eye became the focus of the Stanley Cup finals on Saturday, after a set of teeth and a finger were a distraction on Wednesday.

title: Remembering Hall of Famer John Henry Johnson
description: John Henry Johnson, one of the best all-around backs in N.F.L. history, died Friday at age 81. He may not be as famous as some other Hall of Famers, but he left his mark, both on his teammates, and especially on those who played against him. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.

title: At the Scoop, a Summer of Culture in London
description: A sunken, 1,000-seat, open-air amphitheater on the South Bank of the Thames with stunning views of Tower Bridge and the Tower of London is the setting for the annual Scoop at More London festival, running this year through the summer with a program of theater, music and film  all free.

title: Five Tips for Rainy Day Photography
description: Not many of us will risk our lives racing into the path of a tornado to photograph the funnel, like cameraman Jim Reed, but many of us will risk our cameras in the rain trying to get a shot of a kids soccer game or an impressive cloud formation.

title: Googles New Chromebook Explained
description: Update Sunday, June 5 7:52 p.m.: Clarified that, while Chromebooks do have a hard drive, that drive is used by the OS, not for a users data storage. Also changed wording to indicate that data is not in Googles possession, necessarily, but whichever cloud-based service a user is using.

title: French Open: Rafael Nadal Beats Roger Federer
description: Rafael Nadal won his sixth French Open, tying Bjorn Borgs record, with a 7-5, 7-6(3), 5-7, 6-1 victory over Roger Federer, his primary rival and the winner of 16 Grand Slam tournaments.

title: After Raid, Indian Gurus Protest Stirs a Firestorm
description: NEW DELHI  A sobbing but defiant Swami Ramdev vowed Sunday not to be intimidated by a police crackdown that dispersed thousands of followers massed for a hunger strike to protest corruption. He blamed the governing Congress Party for turning a peaceful protest into chaos.

title: Protesters in Yemen Rejoice as Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Thousands of antigovernment protesters celebrated in the streets of Yemens capital on Sunday, setting off fireworks and slaughtering cows to mark the departure of President Ali Abdullah Saleh for medical treatment, despite new uncertainty about when  and even whether  he would agree to a lasting transfer of power.

title: Israeli Soldiers Shoot at Protesters on Syrian Border
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces fired at pro-Palestinian protesters on the Syrian frontier on Sunday as they tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks, reflecting a new mode of popular struggle and deadly confrontation fueled by turmoil in the Arab world and the vacuum of stalled peace talks.

title: Stage Version of Once Will Start Downtown
description: Rather than open on Broadway in the fall as producers originally hoped, the musical adaptation of the 2006 Dublin-set indie film Once will receive a downtown production at New York Theater Workshop in November, with Broadway a possibility after that, according to executives involved with the show.

title: Womens Preview: U.S. vs. Mexico
description: HARRISON, N.J.  As the United States womens national team prepares to play Mexico on Sunday in its final domestic World Cup tune-up match, some of the players on the other side of the field will probably look familiar.

title: Fireworks in Yemens Change Square
description: As my colleague Robert Worth reports, on Sunday Yemenis crowded into an area of the capital, Sana, they have renamed Change Square to celebrate the departure of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who went to Saudi Arabia on Saturday for urgent medical treatment.

title: Drugs Show Promise Slowing Advanced Melanoma
description: CHICAGO  Two new drugs have been found to prolong the lives of people with advanced melanoma, representing what researchers say is notable progress against the deadly skin cancer after decades of futility.

title: Farming in a Challenging Climate
description: The deep, almost inherent, adaptability and resilience of the worlds farmers makes them well suited to deal with a changing climate. But they are also dealing with limits to usable land and water, rising populations and the near-insatiable appetites of the worlds fast-expanding middle class.

title: Iran Protests Hijab Ban
description: As if FIFA did not have enough problems, now comes word that Iranian soccer officials plan to lodge a protest against a FIFA official who prohibited Irans womens national team from taking the field in an Olympic qualifying match because the players were wearing the traditional Muslim head cover, the hijab.

title: Canadian Health Care in Perspective
description: Yesterday I pointed out that Canadian Medicare looks much more sustainable than our system. But how good is their system, eh? Well, the Commonwealth Fund does regular surveys of health system performance on a variety of indicators; the latest is here (pdf). The summary table:

title: Business Expansion and the Political Climate
description: So I didnt have much time to take down the Chamber of Commerce guy on This Week today. But if you look at the National Federation of Independent Business survey (pdf), youll see a lot of businesses complaining about the political climate  hey, a lot of them watch Fox  but very few actually saying that this climate is deterring expansion:

title: Inquiring Minds on Governors Island
description: Is Kentucky bluegrass really blue? What is a weed? Why do plants need to shoot their seeds?

title: 2 Are Killed in Sixth NATO Copter Crash Since Late April in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two NATO service members died Sunday when their helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan. It was the latest in a string of crashes in recent weeks that were being investigated.

title: Steeper Pullout Is Raised as Option for Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas national security team is contemplating troop reductions in Afghanistan that would be steeper than those discussed even a few weeks ago, with some officials arguing that such a change is justified by the rising cost of the war and the death of Osama bin Laden, which they called new strategic considerations.

title: Prospect of 2nd Greek Bailout Worries Economists
description: VENICE  As European leaders move toward a second bailout for Greece, some economists are warning that a new rescue would merely kick the countrys problems further down the road and might not avert a default that could strain Europes monetary union.

title: First Place for X-Men: First Class
description: One of the years best-reviewed wide-release movies, X-Men: First Class, took in a solid $56 million at the North American box office over the weekend  easily enough for No. 1 and to help reboot a sagging franchise. Facing audience and critical rebellion over the last two X-Men installments, Tom Rothman, co-chairman of 20th Century Fox, took creative risks with First Class that appeared to pay off, including casting a cadre of untested young actors and approving a screenplay that includes Russian, French, German and Spanish dialogue  highly unusual for a summer blockbuster. In partial release overseas, the film took in an additional $64 million. The Hangover Part II, the raunchy buddy comedy from Warner Brothers, was second with an estimated $32.4 million for a two-week total of $187 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Kung Fu Panda 2 (DreamWorks Animation via Paramount) was third with about $24.3 million, sending its two-week total past $100 million. Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides showed continued life in fourth place, taking in about $18 million for a three-week total of $190.3 million. The crude comedy Bridesmaids (Universal) was fifth with about $12 million for a four-week total of $107.3 million.

title: Nadal Equals Borgs Record With Sixth French Open Title
description: PARIS  Bjorn Borg could not make it to Roland Garros on Sunday, which turned out to be a missed opportunity. It would have made for just the right photograph: Borg handing over the Coupe des Mousquetaires to his successor in the soft evening light in Paris.

title: Every Homes a Castle, Cinderella
description: Last week came the unhappy news that the housing market had plunged in March, with analysts telling us that the downward spiral would proceed indefinitely. Faith in the market has been further tarnished, and were told that renting appeals. As one housing-industry expert explained: There was a time when owning a home was a symbol you had made it. Now its O.K. not to own.

title: Weighing In on Synthetic Tracks
description: Since their arrival on the horse racing landscape, synthetic tracks have been the subject of fierce debate.

title: American Wins Boys French Open Title
description: PARIS  Unseeded Bjorn Fratangelo of the United States defeated Dominic Thiem of Austria, 3-6, 6-3, 8-6, on Sunday to win the French Open boys singles championship.

title: No BELL Prize
description: Via Edward Hugh, I see that the BELLs  Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania  are now being lauded as great success stories for having maintained their euro peg and avoided default.

title: Health Care Zombies
description: I actually first encountered the term zombie lies with regard to Canadian health care, where false beliefs  like the one about hordes of Canadians heading to America for care, which is completely untrue  just keep coming back, no matter how many times theyre killed by evidence.

title: In Golf, Justin Timberlake Sees Metaphors for Life
description: Justin Timberlake does not moonwalk, or dance at all, after making a birdie putt on the golf course.

title: Teeing Off With Justin Timberlake
description: On Par columnist Bill Pennington hits a Brooklyn golf course with entertainer Justin Timberlake.

title: Will Victory Spur Athletic Reform in China?
description: BEIJING  Li Nas victory in the French Open on Saturday thrilled China, but some observers wondered whether the countrys sports machine would allow many other athletes to follow her unorthodox career path.

title: Old Patina Encircles Fresh Art in Venice
description: VENICE  Illuminations, the title of the main exhibition at the 54th Venice Biennale here, is meant to evoke the notion of artists as a source of enlightenment. But that does not necessarily mean new, cutting-edge artists. Much of this Biennale is more subdued and less experimental than in years past, more of a nostalgic meditation on life and art than a revelatory peek into the future.

title: Palin Says She Didnt Err on Paul Revere
description: Sarah Palin defended her historical account of Paul Reveres famous midnight ride of 1775 on Sunday, telling an interviewer I know my American history.

title: Wade Finds Himself in Familiar Surroundings
description: DALLAS  Dwyane Wade has strolled these corridors many times in the last five years, but never with the resonance he felt upon returning to the American Airlines Center this weekend.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Albertina Sisulu, Who Helped Lead Apartheid Fight, Dies at 92
description: JOHANNESBURG  Albertina Sisulu, considered by many to be the mother of South Africas liberation struggle, a woman who was hounded and jailed by the apartheid government but who lived to see her children assume leadership roles in a democratic nation, died here on Thursday. She was 92.

title: In Search of the True Self
description: Mark Pierpont used to be an important figure in the evangelical Christian effort to help cure gay people of their homosexual desires. He started out just printing up tracts and handing them out in gay bars, but his ministry grew over time, and eventually he was traveling the world and speaking to crowds that sometimes numbered in the thousands. There was just one problem. Mark Pierpont himself was gay. He continued to feel sexual desires toward other men and was constantly engaged in an effort to suppress them. In the documentary film Protagonist, Pierpont movingly describes his inner conflict, saying that he sometimes felt an almost physical revulsion at his own desires and would then think: Good. I hate this. I hate sin, just like God hates sin.

title: At the Bienniale
description: The 54th Venice Biennale, on view until November, includes a diverse array of exhibitions, from 89 countries, scattered across the city.

title: In Pandoras Valuation, a Few Sour Notes
description: Pandora Media is distinctly Web 2.0. Its Music Genome Project tailors Internet radio stations to individual tastes. Pandora is using that digital DNA to capitalize on investor demand for hot technology plays, with an initial public offering that could value the company at $1.4 billion. But investors should be going in with their eyes, and not just their ears, wide open. Pandoras business model is pretty old school.

title: If You Celebrate Nihilism, Is It Somethingism?
description: Hunter Hunt-Hendrix, the frontman and dogma director of Liturgy, the Brooklyn black-metal band, has a lot to say about the genre. He says it with his boyish mien, reminiscent of Shannon Hoon: soft, long hair; baby face; ever-present faint smile. He says it with his vocals, which are notionally the growls that predominate the music, though he delivers them gently, like a cat lapping up water. Mostly what hes saying to purists is: Kiss off.

title: Monday: Jug Band Instrument
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  There doesnt seem to be a special occasion for this puzzle, but its a fine tribute nonetheless. Gary Whitehead offers us a shout out to WEST POINT, the military academy that has been churning out Army officers since 1802.

title: In Philadelphia, an Operatic Portrait of a Stepmother for the Ages
description: PHILADELPHIA  Unsettling news from the financially struggling Philadelphia Orchestra, whose recent announcement of shortened seasons, a smaller ensemble and a populist programming agenda sent tremors of shock and dismay throughout the classical-music world, paints a bleak prognosis for progressive artistic initiatives here. But look at whats going on in the city this month, and a different picture emerges.

title: A Mistress of Voltaire, Set to Video
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  At a gathering like the Spoleto Festival USA here, the profusion of events large and small often yields revealing juxtapositions, not necessarily intended. Two unrelated programs last week showed the good and the bad of combining classical music with video projections, a recourse hailed in some quarters as an ideal way to attract new listeners in a visually oriented age if not the very salvation of the field.

title: Cuban Visitors Share Sounds and Moves of Their Roots
description: Music follows historys paths. One leads to the Creole Choir of Cuba, which is known there as Grupo Vocal Desandann, the Choir of Descendants. The choir made its exhilarating United States debut on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the S Cuba! Festival. Desandann is a 10-member voice-and-percussion choir from the Cuban city of Camagey, although only four men and five women performed Saturday because of the seemingly inevitable visa problems. The choir is made up of Cuban descendants of Haitians who were twice displaced: first from Africa to Haiti by the slave trade, then from Haiti to Cuba in waves dating back to Haitis 1790 revolution. Their families held on to the Haitian Creole language and to songs remembered through generations.

title: Dreams of a Dying Courtesan
description: At a certain point in Lady of the Camellias  and that point is pretty much the beginning  the audience member driven to despair by the inanity before her is reduced to trivial entertainments like counting the number of times Armand Duval, the ballets petulant leading man, casts himself to the ground in a fit of something or other.

title: An Affair, a Murder, a Sensation
description: Before it became one of the most familiar premises for hard-boiled fiction and film noir, the tale of the wife who coaxed her lover into getting rid of her annoying husband and cashing in on his life insurance was an actual news event. As he writes in an essay called Whence Novels Come (posted on the Web site of Santa Clara University, where he teaches) Ron Hansen found this out only accidentally. But he has made it the basis for A Wild Surge of Guilty Passion, a novel that separates the mawkish tabloid murder case from its later, tougher incarnations.

title: Experimental Sounds, Soothed by the Waves
description: Looking at a concert program on Friday and seeing that the opening work was by Charles Wuorinen, I was expecting the thorny, dense style  fascinating but difficult to penetratethat is his trademark.

title: When a Nobel Prize Isnt Enough
description: Lexington, Mass.

title: More Jersey Shore
description: Maybe MTV has figured out a way to keep Jersey Shore on the air for eternity. (Cue the rapture predictions once more.) With production of Season 4 of this hit reality show about to be shown, the network said it had ordered a fifth season, to begin production this month in New Jersey. The cast members (including Snooki, below) evidently wont have much time for a vacation between their on-camera vacations. On Friday MTV said that Season 4, based in Italy, would have its premiere on Aug. 4. Jersey Shore is, by far, the most popular series in MTVs history.

title: Broader Conflict Is Feared as Fighting Breaks Out on the Border
description: JUBA, Sudan  Fighting broke out in a heavily militarized part of Sudan on Sunday, United Nations and Sudanese officials said, escalating tensions between the northern and southern areas of the country a month before it is to be officially divided.

title: Upright Citizens Brigade Joins SiriusXM Radio
description: The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater will start a weekly hourlong live radio show on SiriusXM Radio, that satellite radio company announced. Live From UCB Theater will record a different show each week at its theaters in New York and Los Angeles, showcasing the comedy troupes usual mix of improv, sketch comedy and stand-up. The first episode will run at 11 p.m. on Saturday on the radio services Raw Dog Comedy Channel. The partnership increases the potential audience for Upright Citizens Brigade performances from 245, the maximum number of seats sold at its two theaters combined, to 20.6 million, the reported number of SiriusXM subscribers. This is just one step in our secret evil plan to take over the world! Oops, Amy Poehler, a founding member of the group, said in a statement. The initial shows will include Totally J/K, hosted by Joe Mande and Noah Garfinkel; Waiting for Obama: A Night at the Hall of Presidents; and The Roast of Justin Bieber. We were always told we had a face for radio, Ms. Poehler said. We just never knew it would be satellite.

title: A Galaxy of Ballet Stars Spinning in a Flickering Universe
description: High among the highlights of American Ballet Theaters annual eight-week spring season are its world-class guest ballerinas. This year the company is graced by Alina Cojocaru, from the Royal Ballet in London; Natalia Osipova, from the Bolshoi in Moscow; Polina Semionova, from the Berlin State Opera Ballet; and Diana Vishneva from the Mariinsky of St. Petersburg. Nowhere else in the world will you find the like.

title: A Troubling Trend for the Heat
description: DALLAS  Miami has established a fairly reliable winning formula, and it does not involve shooting dozens of 3-pointers. So the first two games of this series provided an anomaly and a concern. The Heat took 54 3-pointers in Games 1 and 2, and just 50 free throws.

title: Taking the Customer From Check-In to the Checkout Line
description: BUSINESSES and advertisers are using retail check-in services on mobile phones and daily deal Web sites to stay in constant contact with their customers these days. Now a new feature from Meebo is trying to bridge the gap between check-ins at brick-and-mortar locations and online deals by allowing users to check into Web sites.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for April (Tuesday); Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); trade deficit for April, weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade inventories for April (Thursday); and import prices for May (Friday).

title: Syrian Army Kills 38 In North, Reports Say
description: CAIRO  Syrian military forces were reported to have killed 38 people in the northern province of Idlib on Saturday and Sunday, demonstrators and rights activists said, as security forces appeared to redeploy from other towns to join the latest front in the harsh crackdown on a three-month-old popular uprising against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Keeping Count, Getting a Clue
description: The Memorial Weekend Sectional Flight A/X Swiss Teams was played at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan eight days ago. It was won by Jeanne Rahmey, Win Allegaert and Rizo and Jack Alhale of New York. They finished 6 victory points ahead of Susan Schnelwar, Jesus Arias, Bill Begert and Doug Heron of New York.

title: With Pitching and Power, Yankees Pass a Road Test
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  The way their schedule falls, the Yankees reward for playing nine games on the West Coast against the three best rotations in the American League is an unforgiving homestand. Going to New York are the rival Boston Red Sox, who have rebounded from a miserable start, then Cleveland and Texas, who lead their divisions. But so do the Yankees, who did more than just survive what could have been a ruthless trip.

title: For Couric, ABCs Pitch Proved Best
description: On Feb. 8, executives from NBC, including Steve Burke, the new chief executive, and Steve Capus, the president of news, made their way to the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan, prepared to make a pitch to bring their one-time news star, Katie Couric, back into the network fold.

title: Cellphone Fears, Twitter Tears
description: When it comes to cultural shifts and personal regimes, Im with Dr. Spock: Trust yourself. If you give some new practice a real try and you like it, keep doing it. If it seems weird, it probably is.

title: Data Grows, and So Do Storage Sites
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When people had only one or two computers, file sharing wasnt a big worry.

title: Polo as a Sport for the People? Maybe for People in Seersucker
description: For a few hours on Sunday, Governors Island became something of a Hamptons satellite, dotted with people in Nantucket reds, linen suits, Lilly Pulitzer pinks and sunhats that seemed as wide as a city block.

title: Lowering the Bar in Olympic Bidding
description: NBCs Olympic reign could end Tuesday in a hotel in Lausanne, Switzerland, when it faces ESPN and Fox in an auction for the rights to the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, and 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.

title: Projects Use Phone Data to Track Public Services
description: When New Yorkers head underground, they cannot always be sure of what awaits them. The citys subway system can be mysterious, with daily delays resulting from minor emergencies, track work and other events in the tunnels that riders know they will never truly understand.

title: Deadly E. Coli Outbreak Linked to German Sprouts
description: BERLIN  Local German officials said Sunday that they had evidence that tainted domestic sprouts had caused the deadly E. coli outbreak that has afflicted Germany and unnerved fresh-produce markets throughout Europe, and they shut down the farm in the northern part of the country where the sprouts were grown.

title: Displaced in Sudan
description: Refugees from the contested Sudanese border town of Abyei have found themselves cramped together at a makeshift camp in the town of Turalei.

title: No Radios by the Fountain, Please! Or Cellos!
description: The crisp new signs began going up in some of the most popular spots in Central Park near the end of May. In large white letters on green backgrounds they announce that the areas have been designated Quiet Zones, and that musical instruments and amplified sound are not permitted. Some of the signs cite the authority of the Central Park Conservancy, the private organization that manages the park. Others also bear the name of the citys Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: Brinkmanship in Sudan as a Deadline Nears
description: AGOK, Sudan  In the past few weeks, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been accused of orchestrating a genocide in Darfur, seems to be steering his country back toward war.

title: Online Video Start-Ups Seek to Carve Out a Place Beside YouTube
description: CHICAGO  For many Internet users, YouTube is synonymous with online video. But Mike Michaud and several friends who live in suburban Chicago are trying to change that.

title: U.S. Women Top Mexico on the Way to Germany
description: HARRISON, N.J.  For more than 90 minutes Sunday, the United States womens national team swung unproductive crosses into the middle of Mexicos penalty area or tried to barge its way within whispering distance of goalkeeper Ceci Santiago.

title: Mets Leave Bay Out of Lineup
description: A night after Manager Terry Collins dropped the struggling Jason Bay to sixth in the Mets order, Bays name was not on the lineup card for Sunday nights series finale against the Atlanta Braves.

title: A Generation Faces the Road Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Aging, Yes, but Still Consuming
description: For AARP, 50 is the new 65. And as the company begins a new advertising campaign this week, it wants media buyers and advertisers to keep that in mind.

title: A New Way to Measure Hospital Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Redistricting
description: To the Editor:

title: Entering Kindergarten
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Still Looking at Rodriguezs Care by Indicted Doctor
description: Just days before the Yankees headed north from Florida to begin the 2010 season, third baseman Alex Rodriguez sat down for an interview with investigators for Major League Baseball near the teams spring training complex in Tampa.

title: StarGreetz Has Star Backers
description: LOS ANGELES  Many young companies are trying to seize on the intersection of social media, personalization and celebrity, but StarGreetz.com has something most do not: a pack of prominent Hollywood backers.

title: Cuomo Health Adviser Absolved in Ethics Inquiry
description: A health care consultant with close ties to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not violate state lobbying regulations when he contacted state officials on behalf of a Queens hospital seeking more Medicaid financing, a confidential investigation by the state ethics commission has determined.

title: Showdown Puts Sizzle Back in the Belmont
description: The Kentucky Derby champion Animal Kingdom arrived at Belmont Park on Sunday, ensuring that the 143rd Belmont Stakes will not lack in star power or drama. With the Preakness Stakes champion Shackleford already on the grounds, next Saturdays race will be viewed through the prism of a championship showdown.

title: Bruins Failing to Be Strong to the Finish
description: BOSTON  The Vancouver Canucks won the first two games of the Stanley Cup finals at home by the narrowest margin possible, but each time, they prevailed by being the more energetic team in the final minutes.

title: John Henry Johnson Dies at 81; Inspired Fear on the Field
description: John Henry Johnson, a brawny but agile runner and a powerful blocker who starred for the San Francisco 49ers, the Detroit Lions and the Pittsburgh Steelers in a Hall of Fame career spanning 13 professional football seasons, died Friday in Tracy, Calif. He was 81.

title: Uneven Growth for Film Studio With a Message
description: LOS ANGELES  Doing well is difficult. So is doing good.

title: Burress Will Soon Be Free to Redefine Himself
description: Plaxico Burress will be released from the Oneida Correctional Facility in Rome, N.Y., on Monday. Television trucks and cameras, which began gathering at the facility last week, will be on hand to record the moment, which comes three years and four months after Burress made a game-winning touchdown catch for the Giants in Super Bowl XLII.

title: Bank Shares Take a Beating, and It May Not Be Over Yet

Etudes for an Astronaut, described in program notes as one mans search for his place in the universe, was already in motion as the audience entered La MaMas intimate club space. In head-to-toe black and flip-flops Mr. Gries repeated a movement sequence that gave his body  through deceptively simple means of sitting, standing, leaning and rolling  a sense of melting and hardening. In Etudes he is searching for balance between inner space (as in the mind) and outer space (the world).

title: ABC Is a Winner With the N.B.A.

title: New York City Ballet Adjusts Its Ticket Pricing
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is not the only cultural institution around playing with its prices (raising its suggested admission fee to $25 from $20 as of July 1). New York City Ballet has also adjusted its prices for subscription tickets in Lincoln Centers David H. Koch Theater for its 2011-12 season in an effort to increase ticket revenue by 5 to 10 percent, the companys spokesman, Robert Daniels, said in a telephone interview. City Ballet, whose dancers include, at left, Robert Fairchild and Teresa Reichlen, is not simply raising prices. Instead, it is offering a wider range of prices within each section, with some seats becoming more affordable and others more expensive. For example, seats in the orchestra, which in the 2010-11 season have ranged from $85 to $100, will now be $26 to $119. (Orchestra seats for American Ballet Theater performances at the Metropolitan Opera House run $30 to $102.) Seats in the third ring, formerly $50 or $60, will now range from $26 to $103. New audiences especially want to come in, want to sample the company at a lower ticket price, Mr. Daniels said, so we wanted some of those ticket prices to be available in the orchestra level, where they didnt used to be.

His point, at least as I understood it, was that most politicians are raging narcissists of one stripe or another, walking a tightrope between flagrant egotism and true pathology. But public figures who pass through the fire of a major scandal-driven humiliation have a rare chance to come to terms with that narcissisms catastrophic consequences, and as a result many of them probably come out of these kind of self-inflicted disasters as better people  and perhaps, by implication, better public servants  than your typical Joe Q. title: High Notes | New Art on the High Line
description: Section 2 of the High Line, which opens to the public tomorrow, passes just beyond Frank Gehrys IAC building and Jean Nouvels 100 11th Avenue Residences one block to the west. With the installation of Sarah Szes Still Life with Landscape (Model for a Habitat), some of the more modest denizens of the neighborhood will have a piece of starchitecture to call their own. The sculpture, a dynamic steel and wood complex of bird, ladybug and butterfly condos, sits between 20th and 21st Streets, and serves as a sort of gateway onto the High Line microclimate known as the Chelsea Thicket. Among its noteworthy amenities are feeding trays that will be regularly restocked with seeds and nectar, and miniature troughs designed to catch rainwater. But as with any luxury real estate development  even one with a boldfaced name attached to it  its occupancy rate is not a guarantee. Its really an experiment, says Lauren Ross, the curator and director of arts programs at Friends of the High Line, adding that Sze consulted various urban birding groups but received conflicting predictions. It functions first and foremost as sculpture. We are not sure how wildlife will respond to it.

Mickey has seen better days, apparently. Hes gray. And his eyes are x-ed out, as if he just drank from a bottle labeled Poison. Donnelly, 36, who is better known by his alias, KAWS, is getting ready to haul a 16-foot-tall version of this mouse, titled Companion (Passing Through), from the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., to the Standard hotel in New York. A graffiti artist, illustrator, toymaker, sculptor and painter, Donnelly first collaborated with the hotel earlier this year, with a series of blue, red and green light bulbs that sold out in a matter of days. For all of his visibility in the worlds of fashion and art, Donnelly remains an unassuming, self-proclaimed blusher from New Jersey. title: For City Opera, Spare Show May Signal Future
description: If New York City Opera were a thriving company with stable finances, a clear vision and a home base, the gratifying program it presented on Monday night at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem would have come across simply as a successful effort at community outreach.

title: Would Guccis Owner Look Good in Prada?
description: PARIS  A spate of big-name deals in the luxury sector  Bulgari, Jimmy Choo, Jean Paul Gaultier  has left everyone wondering whats next.

title: The Lowdown | Yimmys Yayo
description: If there is such a thing as cult celebrity in the blogosphere, then the man behind Yimmys Yayo embodies it. Any post on his sexy, well-curated blog could trigger a virtual avalanche of traffic, and his following spreads from Sydney (where hes based), to Berlin, New York and pretty much anywhere theres Internet access.

title: The Ironman Triathlon Comes to New York
description: Bringing the nations biggest triathlon to the nations biggest city turned out to be an organizational feat comparable to the Ironman itself. When it was officially announced Tuesday that the Ironman U.S. Championship would be contested in New York and New Jersey in August 2012, it capped seven years of planning with the knowledge that the 140.6-mile course could not involve closing any New York City streets.

title: Grassley Grants More Time for S.E.C. Response
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking more time to respond to a Congressional request regarding how the agency handled referrals about suspicious trading activity at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

title: Leaving a Warming Arctic
description: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

title: A Heckuva Book Pitch. Thats Putting It Mildly.
description: Last October, just before the deal-making frenzy of the Frankfurt Book Fair, the indie publisher Johnny Temple received an e-mailed book proposal that he was tempted to brush off.

title: Living a Drug Life in a World of Snow
description: The title of Joonas Neuvonens Reindeerspotting: Escape From Santaland makes explicit the films premise: to take the kind of intimacy and immediacy Danny Boyle achieved in his fictional story of Glasgow heroin addicts, Trainspotting, and apply it to a documentary about Mr. Neuvonens fellow drug users in northern Finland.

title: That Look, That Weiner-Spitzer-Clinton Look
description: The names may change, but the face remains essentially the same.

title: Mourning, Bach and a 9/11 Theme
description: Among the many fascinating details that have punctuated the pianist Simone Dinnersteins long and winding road to success, one in particular resonated during a brief recital she gave on Monday evening at St. Pauls Chapel in downtown Manhattan. On learning that she was expecting a baby in 2001, Ms. Dinnerstein decided to master Bachs Goldberg Variations as an accompaniment to her pregnancy. Seven months into both personal journeys, she was at home in Brooklyn on the morning of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Judge Wont Reconsider Decision on Corporate Donations
description: A federal judge on Tuesday denied a request by prosecutors to reconsider his ruling last month striking down a ban on direct contributions from corporations to political candidates, setting into motion what could be a pivotal court battle over one of the biggest legal and political issues of the day.

title: Taking on the Risks of a Mixed Lineup
description: Sampler programs  bits and pieces from different artists  are a gamble for both presenters and audiences. Perhaps everyone will show the same kind of work? Perhaps all the lighting will be dim and the costumes brown? Perhaps the styles will be so widely disparate or obscure as to leave watchers with furrowed brows?

title: How Does a Choreographer Create Art? Day by Ho-Hum Day
description: The movies like to present portraits of artists who create great works all at once, driven to some sort of divine (perhaps substance-enhanced) frenzy in the dark hours of the night. But anybody who has ever really engineered something, be it a table or a painting or a dinner party, on some level understands that this isnt the way it happens for most of us  even those residing in that dubious category, genius. In her fine 2003 essay Dailiness, in an anthology, Choreographic Encounters, the choreographer Susan Rethorst muses on the day-by-day practice of dance making.

title: Glenn Beck's New Venture
description: On Tuesday, Glenn Beck revealed he's taking his show online, shunning the traditional TV format, and will charge viewers a monthly fee to watch it.

title: Who Are The Rentiers?
description: Following up on my rentier post and the eurocentric followup, a question: who are we talking about? That is, who stands to gain from deflation, and lose if inflation is, say, 4 percent over a period of 10 years? Is it little old ladies living on fixed incomes, and salt of the earth workers who have scrimped and saved?

title: TimesCast | Expressing Shame
description: When Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York held a news conference on Monday and admitted to lying, Dan Hill, an expert in the role of emotion in consumer behavior, was watching.

title: Enjoying the Quiet Pleasures of a Meeting of Minds
description: Vinicius Canturia and Bill Frisell sat facing the audience, but angled toward each other, throughout their calmly transfixing show at the Highline Ballroom on Monday night. Each cradled a guitar  nylon-string acoustic for Mr. Canturia, electric for Mr. Frisell  and both often had slight smiles on their faces, the sort of expression you might wear while hearing an old friend tell a fondly half-remembered tale. The setting was sparse, but the performance, part of the Blue Note Jazz Festival, conveyed a sense of fullness.

title: TimesCast | Weiner's Constituents
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner's New York constituents speak out.

title: In the Labyrinth of Medical Research
description: There is great ambition in Matthew Maguires drama Wax Wings, at the Wild Project, not least in its inquiry into scientific issues. The play, presented by the Creation Production Company, of which Mr. Maguire is co-artistic director, offers copious information about the dengue mosquito, the form of pneumonia known as SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) and the pressures that researchers endure from their backers. It also addresses conflicts between faith and rationality; the drive to reproduce and the impulse to resist it; and the relative merits of expediency and caution in a crisis. The debates, unfortunately, dont end there.

title: A Superheros Day (and a Damsels) Never Ends
description: Fridays show had been over for a couple of hours, but Reeve Carney and Jennifer Damiano were still working hard for Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark at Joe Allens, the Broadway watering hole. The two young stars were downing fries and sandwiches when a table of tipsy fans came by, one of them calling himself an investor in this $70 million musical.

title: My Top 10 Business Travel Tips
description: Over the past decade, I have gone from being an aggressive domestic traveler to being an aggressive global traveler, constantly visiting our various foreign locations and opening up new operations. I travel so much that I can relate to George Clooneys character in the movie Up In the Air. (Last year, I traveled more than half a million miles!)

description: Tim Pawlenty hails from Minnesota, where folks are Midwest nice. But you wouldnt know that from listening to him recently.

title: The Trick an Animal Cannot Learn: How to Be Wild Again
description: Theres no denying the aww appeal of a man and an elephant walking down a street, hand in trunk. title: ABC Rules Again on Monday Night
description: The Bachelorette had the highest ratings in prime time on Monday, extending ABCs winning streak to 13 weeks as the most-watched network on the night. According to Nielsens estimates, 8 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 10 p.m. for Week 3 of this reality dating series, easily outperforming Foxs second-season premiere of MasterChef in the 8 p.m. hour (4.3 million). But the news was not all positive for ABC as its new 10 p.m. series, Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition (5.7 million), lagged behind its time-slot competitors, Law & Order: Los Angeles on NBC (6.2 million) and a rerun of Hawaii Five-0 on CBS (6.5 million). For the night CBS ranked second, broadcasting repeats of its sitcom lineup from 8 to 10. NBC was third with reruns of Minute to Win It at 8 (3.9 million) and Law & Order: Criminal Intent at 9 (4.5 million). Fox finished in fourth place, garnering 3.4 million at 9 for a repeat of House.

description: Joe Girardi says he got to know Dante Bichette in 1993, when both joined the Colorado Rockies, an expansion team. The Rockies lost 95 games and were outscored by more than 200 runs, and Girardi and Bichette were about as opposite as two players could get.

Its not the first time that N.B.A. teams have courted Messina  he has turned down offers from Sacramento, Toronto and New Jersey. But this time he appears ready to make the jump.

title: A Break for the Philharmonics Summer Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic is taking a break from its normal early-summer concerts in New York City parks, adding performances in September instead. The orchestra will perform with the tenor Andrea Bocelli on Sept. 15 on Central Parks Great Lawn, a special event outside its usual parks series. Two days later at Avery Fisher Hall, it will play William Waltons music from the movie Henry V, narrated by Christopher Plummer, and music from Shakespeares time. The concert had originally been planned for the spring but was moved because of a conflict with Mr. Plummers schedule, said the orchestras spokesman, Eric Latzky.

title: U.S. Endorses Secretary Generals Re-election
description: The White House on Tuesday endorsed Ban Ki-moon for a second term as secretary general of the United Nations, helping assure his re-election. Under Bans leadership, the United Nations has played a critical role in responding to crises and challenges across the globe, the White House said. Mr. Ban, a former foreign minister for South Korea, has led the United Nations through recent crises involving Libya and Ivory Coast. He has served since December 2006.

A similar measure in San Francisco is scheduled for a fall vote.

title: Sudan: Foreigners Evacuated in Border City
description: Fighting continued on Tuesday between northern troops and soldiers aligned with the southern Sudanese in Kadugli, the capital of Southern Kordofan State, forcing about 400 foreigners to be evacuated, the United Nations said. At least six people were killed in the last two days, the United Nations said, adding that about 3,000 people had taken shelter at a nearby hospital on Monday night. Southern Kordofan is on the border between northern and southern Sudan, which is to declare its independence next month.

The courtroom was mostly empty but for a few lawyers and federal agents and a handful of journalists and onlookers who had followed the case with cultish fascination.

title: E. Coli: Dont Blame the Sprouts!
description: One hundred thousand E. coli can dance on the head of a pin; it may only take 50 to make you sick enough to die. Benign E. coli are everywhere, even in your own pink gut right now, and all E. coli can live on (or in) things as different as sprouts, burgers and water. But if you were able to trace back far enough, their reservoir is most likely the gut of mammal: a goat, a sheep, a deer, even a majestic elk or a dog. Theyre most often associated with cows.

description: The matter of Anthony D. Weiner, unclothed congressman, is being lodged by Democratic Party elders with the House ethics committee, a holding room where it will remain until either it, or he, goes away.

description: A COUPLE of years ago, Jason Wang graduated from Washington University in St. Louis with a bachelors degree in business. At the moment, he is dishing out spicy hand-cut rice noodles in a narrow storefront in the East Village, and seems pretty thrilled about his career path.

title: The Earth Is Full
description: You really do have to wonder whether a few years from now well look back at the first decade of the 21st century  when food prices spiked, energy prices soared, world population surged, tornados plowed through cities, floods and droughts set records, populations were displaced and governments were threatened by the confluence of it all  and ask ourselves: What were we thinking? How did we not panic when the evidence was so obvious that wed crossed some growth/climate/natural resource/population redlines all at once?

title: After 40 Years, the Complete Pentagon Papers
description: It may be a first in the annals of government secrecy: Declassifying documents to mark the anniversary of their leak to the press. But that is what will happen Monday, when the federal government plans to finally release the secret government study of the Vietnam War known as the Pentagon Papers 40 years after it was first published by The New York Times.

description: TWO of the worlds largest hotel companies are reaching out to other industries to establish partnerships that they hope will help their luxury brands continue their recovery.

title: The Gas Is Greener
description: IN April, Gov. Jerry Brown made headlines by signing into law an ambitious mandate that requires California to obtain one-third of its electricity from renewable energy sources like sunlight and wind by 2020. Twenty-nine states and the District of Columbia now have renewable electricity mandates. President Obama and several members of Congress have supported one at the federal level. Polls routinely show strong support among voters for renewable energy projects  as long as they dont cost too much.

title: The Cup Finals Are Leaving a Nasty Mark
description: BOSTON  The image remained seared into Stanley Cup memory the day after Vancouvers Aaron Rome flattened Bostons Nathan Horton with a thunderous shoulder five minutes into the Bruins 8-1 victory Monday night: Horton lying motionless on the ice, his eyes staring blankly at the TD Garden ceiling, his arm upright, frozen frighteningly in position as the Bruins medical staff rushed out to care for him while Rome headed to the dressing room with a five-minute interference major and a game misconduct.

title: Pawlenty Calls for Greater Tax and Spending Cuts Than G.O.P. Rivals
description: WASHINGTON  Former Gov. Tim Pawlenty called on Tuesday for more than $2 trillion in tax cuts for individuals and businesses over the next decade and two to three times as much in federal spending reductions and loophole closings, saying that such policies would drive rapid economic growth.

title: For Dad, Candy Made From Beer
description: Fathers Day is not gleefully anticipated by chocolatiers, except, perhaps, by a company called Beercandy. The owner, Steve Casselman, a brewer in Santa Clara, Calif., began experimenting with beer-based candy more than 10 years ago with lollipops. More recently, hes used beer to flavor the caramel fillings for chocolate-covered candies, which hes been selling online since fall. Beers bitter edge is a nice balance for the caramel and chocolate. The India pale ale caramel is covered with white chocolate; the lager caramel, with milk chocolate. The robust stout is dipped in dark chocolate, and the raspberry flavor of the lambic comes through its dark chocolate shell. His latest treat is beer-flavored taffy. He also sells Hop Drops, made by Bob Bero under the name B-Hoppy, which are flavored with the oil of American Cascade hops for a citric flavor. (Hop Drops and taffy are at right.)

title: Smoky Salmon for the Pantry
description: In 1978, Bruce Gore founded Triad Fisheries, a Seattle company whose boats became known for salmon gutted and flash-frozen on board. Now, it has hot-smoked Coho salmon in six-ounce jars that dont need refrigeration until opened. The smoky pieces are perfect for quick canaps, sandwiches and garnishes.

title: Fresh Eggs So Local, Theyre at Your House
description: Imagine fresh eggs from your own backyard. Jason Stroud, an antiques restorer in Red Hook, Brooklyn, knows that pleasure well. And he has started sharing it, helping urban homesteaders set up backyard coops with the appropriate kinds of chickens. He has been so busy since he started building and selling the coops a couple of months ago that he is phasing out his antiques business.

title: In Weiners District, Supporters Still Are Easy to Find
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who is embroiled in a scandal over sexually explicit exchanges with women, announced on Monday that he would leave his political fate to the voters in his district, saying that, My constituents have to make a determination.

description: HARTFORD  In a year when conservative politics have dominated even traditionally Democratic states like New Jersey and New York, Connecticut is closing out its most activist, liberal legislative session in memory.

description: Siddharth Iyer spent eight Mays cramming for finals, first at Stuyvesant High School and then at Columbia University.

description: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer that has come under sharp criticism in recent months for its double-digit rate increases, said on Tuesday that it planned to cap its earning and refund the bulk of any excess income to its policyholders.

title: Weiner Faces Calls to Resign and Tries to Make Amends
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York, reeling from revelations of salacious online behavior that threaten his political career, moved rapidly on Tuesday to make amends as Republicans called for his resignation and leading members of his own Democratic Party distanced themselves from him.

description: Reva Medical, a maker of medical devices in San Diego, wanted to go public last year to raise money to satisfy impatient venture capitalists and finance research for its heart stents.

title: The Switzerland of America
description: East Tennessee, wrote a pamphleteer shortly after the end of the Civil War, had long been considered the Switzerland of America. Its towering mountains locking up deep, rich and verdant valleys and coves, its succession of ridges and valleys, its magnificent forests, its roaring streams, the general fertility of the soil, the glory of the climate, the salubrity of the atmosphere, the sublimity, beauty and picturesqueness of the scenery, the freshness and voluptuous abundance of the country, all conspire to make it one of the most desirable spots in America.

title: Keeping Protectionism at Bay
description: The worlds big trading nations have done a fairly good job over the last two years of resisting protectionism even as their economies stalled or shrank. But their patience with open markets seems to be wearing thin.

title: Ambitious Goals for Ford
description: Ford Motors punchy global ambitions are not as worrying as they look. The Motor City automaker expects to sell eight million vehicles a year by the middle of the decade, according to the plan unveiled on Tuesday by Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive. That is 50 percent higher than Fords showing in 2010 and more bullish than the one-third sales pickup he sees for the industry.

title: Calling for Achievable Target, Christie Plans Cut in States Renewable Energy Goals
description: Gov. Chris Christie said Tuesday that he planned to scale back New Jerseys goals for renewable energy as he looked for an achievable approach to generating electricity in the state.

title: Hovnanians Revenue Falls 20%, a Worse Loss Than Expected
description: Hovnanian Enterprises, the home builder, reported a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday as revenue fell 20 percent amid slumping demand for new houses.

title: The Fair Rewards of Invention
description: Before the Bayh-Dole Act was passed in 1980, the billions of federal dollars spent on scientific research rarely benefited the public through commercial applications. Fewer than 5 percent of government patents were licensed to industry. To push patents into practical use, the law set up a scheme for awarding the rights to institutions, like universities, that have incentive to bring inventions to market.

title: An Unexpected Trend Toward Office Sublets
description: Six months ago, when the law firm Venable began a search for a permanent home in New York, it did not end up moving far. Venable, based in Baltimore, had been subletting 52,000 square feet at 1270 Avenue of the Americas. With the agreement about to expire, it decided to stay on and sign a direct lease with its landlord, Tishman Speyer, for the same space.

title: Search for Bodies Resumes on Long Island, Aided by Aerial Images
description: BABYLON, N.Y.  It was 84 degrees on Tuesday, with an abundance of sun and a healthy breeze  the kind of day that Oliver Kurzyp and Adam Janowski could not let pass without a trip to the beach.

title: Andrew Gold and the 70s Sound
description: At one time, I thought I owned every album Andrew Gold played on between 1974 and 1980, nearly all of them recorded and produced in southern California. I was wrong. I never owned the albums he recorded with Barbi Benton, Hugh Hefners girlfriend in the early 1970s, even though she went to high school with me. I wasnt intentionally collecting Gold, who died last week at age 59. He just happened to back up, produce or appear with nearly everyone I was listening to at the time.

title: Rector at Muslim University in Russia Is Shot to Death
description: MOSCOW  Gunmen on Tuesday killed the rector of a Muslim university in southern Russia who had been leading a government-sponsored effort to counter violence in the region by reviving the local traditions of Sufi Islam that he said were less likely to inspire suicide bombers.

title: Countering Video Game Rivals, Nintendo Introduces a Touch-Screen Wii
