description: The new owner of a venerable hotel, and the famed restaurant within, is asking former and potential customers to vote on keeping the eaterys familiar name or changing it.

title: Regulator Warns of Cheetah Traders
description: Bart Chilton, a Democratic member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, fears that cheetahs are running wild on Wall Street.

title: Taxes on Car Sharing Outpace Sales Tax Rates, Study Finds
description: Car sharing services pay an unfair tax burden, contends an as-yet unpublished study from the Chaddick Institute for Metropolitan Development at DePaul University in Chicago.

title: Rosie Perezs Prom Night
description: Its hard to believe, but the Oscar-nominated actress Rosie Perez (Do the Right Thing, Pineapple Express) wasnt always the sassy, silver-tongued woman weve come to recognize. I had such a bad speech impediment as a result of the emotional trauma I was going through in my life, Perez says. I couldnt even say my name correctly. I would say, Wosie Pewez. But when Perezs fifth grade teacher, Mr. Mackey, asked her to sing one of her favorite Jackson 5 songs, she discovered the impediment disappeared. It changed me, she says.

title: Obama Talks Up Job Training
description: President Obama went to a community college near Washington on Wednesday to talk up a $2 billion program aimed at tailoring lessons across the country to match the needs of manufacturing companies.

title: Readers Ask: Give a Dog a Bone?
description: Are bones good or bad for dogs? Is it important to vary what your cat or dog eats? Do foods cause those fatty lumps that appear on the sides of our pets?

title: Going Natural Requires Lots of Help
description: MAELING TAPP remembers the moment three years ago when she saw her mother and sisters wearing their coil-prone hair in its natural state and decided that she, too, would stop slathering caustic paste onto her scalp to burn her own similarly textured locks into straight submission.

title: More Stomach-Churning Facts about the E. Coli Outbreak
description: Well, at least someone isnt worried about food-borne illness. Wouldnt you know it would be a Republican senator from Oklahoma.

title: Beauty Spots
description: AGE-APPROPRIATE Weve all seen women in their 50s who have been applying the same stuff to their faces since their 20s. The Makeup Wakeup (Running Press, $23) might help prevent that pitfall. Written by Lois Joy Johnson, a founding editor of More magazine, and Sandy Linter, a makeup artist who has worked with Christie Brinkley, Sigourney Weaver and Katie Couric, the book offers product advice and tips on mixing makeup with dermatological or cosmetic surgery procedures.

title: Angry Homeowners Foreclose on Lenders
description: Owners of a house in Florida have engineered a reverse foreclosure against a bank. That makes two so far this year. Just one more, and its officially a trend, right?

title: Near Athens, a Tropical Maisonette with a Shared Pool
description: A four-bedroom townhouse is on the market for 950,000 euros ($1.365 million) in this development in Voula, a suburb of Athens, Greece.

title: House Hunting in ... Greece
description: A four-bedroom town house with a shared pool in Voula, a suburb of Athens

title: Fishburne Leaving CSI
description: After two seasons, Laurence Fishburne is leaving the cast of CSI, one of the longest-running series on prime-time television.

title: Shawn Green Says Hed Play for Israel
description: When Major League Baseball announced last week that Israel would be included in the next World Baseball Classic, it triggered speculation about which current professional players might join the team.

title: Devorah Rose, a Celebrity of Her Own Making
description: THERE is a certain kind of socialite who spends her summers in the Hamptons: perhaps the daughter of a Manhattan real estate millionaire or media magnate; maybe an intern at Vogue or Sothebys who takes the jitney on Fridays to her parents estate on Further Lane. She hopes to meet a wealthy financier and settle with him into a classic six on the Upper East Side. And her summer get is an invitation to the exclusive party held every Fourth of July at the Georgica Pond manse of the billionaire Ronald Perelman.

title: A Voice From the Past Advises Cuomo on the Future
description: Chances are its not going to be on the average New Yorkers summer reading list, but Andrew M. Cuomo took it along in 2010, the year before he became governor, on an Alaskan cruise with his two daughters.

title: ABC Lands Exclusive Interview With Jaycee Dugard
description: ABC News announced Wednesday that Diane Sawyer had landed an exclusive interview with Jaycee Lee Dugard, the California woman who was kidnapped at age 11 and held against her will for 18 years.

title: The Caucus | Anthony Weiner's Fate
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Michael Barbaro talk about what's ahead for Representative Anthony D. Weiner as he tries to weather a scandal.

title: Delta Apologizes for Charging Returning Troops $2,800 Baggage Fee
description: Delta Airlines is apologizing to a unit of soldiers returning from Afghanistan for charging them more than $2,800 in checked bag fees on their flight from Baltimore to Atlanta on Tuesday.

title: Animal Kingdom Is the 2-1 Favorite for the Belmont
description: The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom was made the 2-1 morning-line favorite to become the 12th horse to win both the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes on Saturday in the 143rd running of the Triple Crowns oldest and longest leg.

title: Gateway to Boston Harbor Islands
description: The Boston Harbor Islands national park area may no longer be Bostons best-kept secret.

title: An Overnight Train Ride to a Final Destination: College
description: The college search is more than just a choice. It questions identity, aspirations and ability. However, these combined facets do not painlessly produce an answer.

title: Basic Tools to Make Your Own Magic
description: SO often mens wear is about hand-holding, or outright traffic-directing. Please save me from my baser instincts, the unsure customer says. Help me. Guide me. Clothe me.

title: On Top
description: REVELERS mourning the loss of Beige at B Bar have a new place to dance the pain away on Tuesday nights. Last month, the night-life doyenne Susanne Bartsch started On Top, a Tuesday party at Le Bain, the dark aerie opposite the Boom Boom Room on the 18th floor of the Standard hotel.

title: Renaming the Ethics Bill, and Asking for Money
description: ALBANY  By the end of last week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders had managed to agree about changing a host of sensitive ethics regulations, including strengthening financial disclosure rules and opening up the possibility that legislators convicted of felonies could lose their pensions.

title: Facebook Face Recognition Feature Draws Privacy Scrutiny
description: BRUSSELS (Bloomberg News)  European Union data protection regulators said on Wednesday that they would investigate Facebook over a feature that uses face-recognition software to suggest peoples names to tag in pictures without their permission, and a privacy group in the United States said that it planned to file a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission over the feature.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, India and Washington.

title: Russia Finally Gets to See a Martha Graham Dance
description: The work of Martha Graham, the legendary choreographer who redefined modern American dance, has been performed all over the world before and since her death in 1991 - with the exception of Russia. That will change on June 23 at a gala celebrating the acclaimed career of Diana Vishneva at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, Janet Eilber, artistic director of the Martha Graham Company, said Wednesday.

title: Wakefields Act Changes but Never Gets Old
description: Tim Wakefield has been around the major leagues for what seems like forever, and just when it seems he might not be there much longer, he floats, like a knuckleball, right back into the thick of things.

title: Phones as Gifts: How to Navigate a Maze of Choices
description: WITH the iPhone now available through two networks, a profusion of Android phones hitting the market and an abundance of apps for every phone, you might think it would be easier than ever to find the right phone to give as a gift. But the vast number of choices makes it harder than ever. I mean, what is HSPA+, anyway?

title: Private Equity Princes Are Said to Seek the 76ers
description: A pair of private equity executives are in negotiations to acquire the Philadelphia 76ers, according to people briefed on the talks.

title: Just One Look | Derek Lam Resort Collection
description: Derek Lams resort collection can be read as a travelogue of his recent visit to Asia. Bhutan inspired a graphic skirt made of juteyarn and black linen, he explains of his fusion of inspirations. The beach life of Phuket inspired the sexy scuba sweater on top.

title: CHCM
description: 2 Bond Street (Broadway); (212) 673-8601; chcmshop.com.

title: How I Learned to Stop Worrying by Loving the Smartphone
description: WHEN I think back to what I was like before the advent of the smartphone, I realize I must have been a quivering ball of anxiety.

title: Nations Bombing Libya Ask for Help Amid Strain
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Nearly 12 weeks into the air campaign against Col. Muammer el-Qaddafis government, the growing strains of the operation on the participating nations dominated a NATO defense ministers meeting in Brussels on Wednesday.

title: On Location
description: A three-bedroom house near Zurich is extensively renovated, and the design and construction were overseen by the owners architect son.

title: In Switzerland, Minimalism and Industrialism
description: WETTINGEN, Switzerland  Seen from the street, Ratibor and Nada Hadzimanovics home, a boxy three-floor structure with a beige plaster exterior, a half basement peeping above ground, and a pitched terra cotta tile roof, isnt much of a looker. Neither is its location in Wettingen, a small town dotted with vineyards and farmland about 15 miles northwest of Zurich. Opposite the house are a plumbing and heating outfit, and a nondescript pink-and-gray apartment complex.

title: Homeless Veterans Sue Over Neglected Campus
description: LOS ANGELES  It is a 387-acre campus of green fields and low-lying buildings in a prosperous neighborhood, donated to the federal government more than 100 years ago for use as a Pacific Coast home for wounded veterans. But over the last 20 years, as Los Angeles has become inundated with homeless veterans, advocates for the homeless say the campus has become a symbol of a system gone wrong: as veterans sleep on the streets, many of its buildings lie abandoned and one-third of the land has been leased for commercial use.

title: A Cause With Every Party
description: IT was a sunny, warm Memorial Day weekend in Fire Island Pines, and Josh Wood sat in his seaside garden, laptop open and phone to his ear. A fountain burbled in the ornamental pond. The roses were in bloom. Led Zeppelin played over outdoor speakers.

title: How Apple Can Make Money From Higher-Quality Songs
description: Whenever Apple introduces a new mobile device, I go through an anxious ritual: trying to decide how much memory I need in the device.

title: You Can Also Lead a Horse to Nirvana
description: LAST Sunday evening, Buck Brannaman strolled the High Line, two stories above the streets of Manhattan and hundreds of miles from his native habitat, the ranch country where he runs clinics in enlightened horsemanship. The documentary Buck, which won a Sundance audience award this year and will open on Friday in New York and Los Angeles, details his shaman-like skills around horses and the people who ride them.

title: Banks Defeated in Senate Vote on Debit Card Fees
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate refused Wednesday to delay new rules that would sharply cut the fees that banks can charge retailers to process debit card transactions.

title: Activist or Terrorist, Rendered in Red, White and Green
description: WHEN Daniel McGowan moved in with his sister after college, he was so passionate about recycling that he took all the labels off her canned food. The problem was, he didnt wait for her to open the cans. I didnt know if I had soup, or what kind of soup; I dont know if theres peas, or corn, Lisa McGowan said in an interview. He said, I never thought of that.

title: Shaping Energy Menus Through 2030
description: 4:42 p.m. | Updated Im in Waterloo, Ontario, for the final two days of a summit aiming to clarify how science and technology can meaningfully improve the worlds energy menu by 2030. Theres a layered discussion underway, hosted by the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics, involving both established analysts and researchers and younger scholars and students.

title: New Questions Rise in Cause and Trajectory of Germany E. Coli Outbreak
description: BERLIN  As Germanys tally of deaths increased in what has become one of the worlds most lethal infections of E. coli, new elements of confusion surfaced Wednesday with conflicting signals about whether the outbreak is abating and what caused it.

title: A Fight Over Anne Franks Fallen Tree
description: AMSTERDAM  From the window in the attic of her familys hiding place in Amsterdam, Anne Frank could see the crown of an old chestnut tree growing in a neighbors garden. For two years, it was her only contact with nature.

title: How Dimon Played on Wall Street
description: In an exchange with Ben S. Bernanke of the Federal Reserve, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, questioned whether regulation was too harsh. CNBC discusses whether this is the broad industry view.

title: Good Boy! A Trainers Tony Treat
description: BROADWAY bears a distinct resemblance to a wildlife preserve these days, with its war horses and Bengal tigers jockeying for Tony Awards Sunday night (and flying spiders biding their time until next season). What better year, then, to give a special Tony to the animal trainer William Berloni, who found Little Orphan Annie her first Sandy and has since put hundreds of critters through their paces?

title: Steeds to Spiders
description: A look at some of the hoofed and fanged creatures on Broadway this season.

title: Video: Weiners Fate
description: Megan Liberman and Michael Barbaro discuss whats ahead for Representative Anthony D. Weiner as he tries to weather the scandal from his salacious online behavior.

title: Welcome to the Recovery
description: For unrelated reasons (textbook!) I just reread Tim Geithners unfortunate August 2010 op-ed Welcome to the Recovery. Even at the time, it seemed tone-deaf to both the economic and the political realities; now, of course, it looks much worse.

title: Frank Moss of the MIT media lab; Joshua Brustein on Web photo rights; news.
description: J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Frank Moss, former director of the MIT Media Lab and author of the new book "The Sorcerers and Their Apprentices," which looks at the lab's approach to creating innovative technologies. Ever wonder who controls the images you post online? Bettina Edelstein speaks with the producer of the Times technology section, Joshua Brustein, about the murky world of photo rights on the Web. Alan Yacavone of the News Technology desk stops by to talk about Apple's planned new rollouts  the Lion version of OS X; iOs 5's new features for Apple mobile devices; and the forthcoming iCloud, with untethered syncing across devices. Other news includes reaction to the proposed AT&T and T-Mobile merger; lots of new stuff for gamers via 3E; a software update for BlackBerry PlayBooks; and a new report that says the iPad still rules in the tablet market. J.D.'s tech tip: using smart playlists to explore your own music collection in iTunes.

title: Who Is Monzon?
description: The staff at Sagamore Farm, once owned by Alfred G. Vanderbilt and being restored by the Under Armour founder Kevin Plank, sent us these videos of Monzons final work before the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Tony Picks, Courtesy of Michael Musto
description: In the week leading up to the Tony Awards on June 12, ArtsBeat is asking several celebrity theatergoers who are not Tony voters to pick their favorite shows, actors and designers in the New York Timess interactive Tonys ballot.

title: The Stories Behind the Work
description: Eric Wilson visited the photographer Arthur Elgort in his SoHo studio, where the two spoke about some of the most memorable photographs Mr. Elgort has taken over his 42-year career.

title: A Visit With Arthur Elgort
description: One of the more poignant moments during the fashion awards on Monday night happened when the Council of Fashion Designers of America honored the photographer Arthur Elgort, who has been creating images for Cond Nast magazines for over 42 years. Mr. Elgort suffered a stroke last year, but he has recovered considerably and is back at work.

title: Fill-In | The Science of Hamburgers
For Mets, Collegiality Is Part of Closing
description: Before a recent game at Minute Maid Park in Houston, Jason Isringhausen and Francisco Rodriguez walked out of the clubhouse together toward the field. In the hallway, Isringhausen held open a door to allow his teammate to pass through first.

title: Lock Up Your Safes
description: Having a nice strong safe with sturdy locks is not much help if someone can just wheel the whole thing out the door of your apartment. Such a brazen act of criminality was performed, and captured on video, in a building in Elmhurst, Queens, recently.

title: The New Bohemians: Casting Announced for Rent Revival
description: The names Idina Menzel, Anthony Rapp, Taye Diggs, Wilson Jermaine Heredia, Jesse L. Martin, Adam Pascal, and Daphne Rubin-Vega didnt mean much in the theater world until they became stars in the 1996 musical Rent, a Pulitzer Prize-winning hit Off Broadway that quickly transferred to Broadway and won the Tony Award for best musical.

title: Envelope, Please, for the Great Parking Facilities of 2011
description: There is no shortage of field guides to the greatest driving roads in the United States, where switchbacks, curves and corkscrews test the mettle of wannabe Earnhardts. High-riding trail raiders can reference a wealth of catalogs and online forums for remote routes guaranteed to crack teeth and shred oil pans.

title: Remembering Waitz, a Champion and Companion
description: Jack Waitz keeps learning about his wife, Grete Waitz, since she died April 19 at the age of 57. People tell him about their one meeting, stories that glow with kindness and generosity.

title: Before the Mosquitoes Come
description: Natalie Boelman, an ecosystem ecologist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, writes from the North Slope of Alaska, where she is studying the effects of climate change on the interactions among plants, insects and migratory songbirds.

title: U.S. Is Falling Behind in the Business of Green
description: LEICESTER, England  The Mark Group started hunting for a new untapped market when it realized that its core business  insulating old homes using innovative technology  would drop off in coming years. Based in this rust-belt city, the company had grown rapidly over the last decade largely because of generous and mandatory government subsidies for energy conservation that impelled the British to treat their homes.

title: S.E.C. Stops Would-Be Buyers of Pabst Beer
description: An effort to buy the maker of the oft-ironically enjoyed Pabst Blue Ribbon beer has fizzed out, after the Securities and Exchange Commission became involved.

title: In 2nd Week, Lady Gagas Sales Plummet, but Shes Still No. 1
description: In Week 2 Lady Gagas album sales have come down to earth. But shes still No. 1.

title: Mark Teixeira Returns to Yankees Lineup
description: The day after a fastball by Jon Lester drilled him in the knee with such force that he left the game, Mark Teixeira was in the Yankees lineup, batting third and playing first against the Red Sox.

title: Ta Obreht Wins Orange Prize for Fiction
description: Ta Obreht won the Orange Prize for Fiction on Wednesday for her debut novel, The Tigers Wife, making her at 25 the youngest person to win the award. The winner, chosen by a panel of five judges, was announced in London. The award is given annually for the best novel written in English by a woman and comes with a prize of about $49,000.

title: The Bruins Keep Their Lucky Jacket in Hortons Stall
description: BOSTON  A powerful talismanic artifact has been hanging in Nathan Hortons stall in the Boston dressing room for several days: a 1980s vintage shiny black and yellow Bruins jacket. What first seemed to be a joke now has become a symbol of the Bruins feelings for themselves as a team and for Horton in particular.

title: F.D.A. Issues Safety Alert on Zocor
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday announced new safety restrictions on high-dose simvastatin, also known as Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug taken by an estimated 2.1 million Americans.

title: Euro Zone | Summer in Stockholm
description: If Northern Europe were pressed to name its cultural capital, it very well might be Stockholm. Built on 14 islands, the Swedish city buzzes with a robust dining scene, high-end design, smart new hotels and dozens of museums. And in the summer, Stockholm hosts a clutch of food and music festivals, among them a jazz festival, June 17-19, and the Culture Festival, Aug. 16-21, when the citys plazas and parks fill up with spectators for some 500 musical acts, readings and comedy shows.

title: The Resort Shows: Artists and Rebels
description: Reed Krakoff used the term warm minimalism to describe the changes  actually, improvements  offered in his resort line. Mr. Krakoff, trying to establish a look with his still-new signature label, makes progress with a more feminine-looking bunch of clothes that plays on rounded edges, easy volumes and intense colors offset by fleshy beige tones. Those colors  ultraviolet blue and green, coral and cinnamon  are his strength. Theyre sharp and specific, with a modern art reference that he likes. See a green panel on a sleeveless wrap dress in an abstract blue python print, and you think, as intended, Rothko. Its not all highfalutin: Mr. Krakoff also showed a well-done blazer in beige lightweight wool with a double lapel, a nice way to suggest layering. He paired the jacket with soft red trousers. Also strong were a leather shift, pounded thin like a cutlet, and an electric blue python skirt with pleating at one side.

title: Hour by Hour, a Measure of Economic Stress
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, highlighted a relatively obscure measure of economic health, aggregate hours of production workers, to make the important point that our economy is not very healthy at all.

title: A Partnership Forged by a Mutual Love of Music
description: David Parker and Jeffrey Kazin are not romantically involved  but there are all kinds of love affairs. Misters and Sisters, which had a short run at Joes Pub last week, is Mr. Parkers latest piece on that postage-stamp stage, and its an ode to the relationship between the two men, who have worked together for 21 years.

title: F.A.O. Sees Stubbornly High Food Prices
description: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations is out with a new report this week on the world food outlook. The general picture is consistent with the themes I outlined in my recent piece on the food supply.

title: McDonalds to Serve Sustainable Fish in Europe
description: PARIS  McDonalds, the worlds biggest fast-food company, said Wednesday that it had reached a deal under which a nonprofit organization would certify as sustainable the catch used for each of the 100 million fish sandwiches the chain sells in Europe every year.

title: Recovering From the Red Flood
description: Eight months ago, a containment reservoir in western Hungary collapsed, releasing a million cubic meters of highly corrosive red mud that covered more than 2,500 acres.

title: TimesCast | June 8, 2011
description: Syrian refugees cross into Turkey to escape escalating violence; Saudi Arabia's rulers use money to buy stability; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on continuing repression in Bahrain.

title: Live Tweeting a Home Birth
description: Speaking of Twitter, this is another, er, unusual, use of the new tool. The British photographer Mary Wycherley gave birth at home Monday morning, and she and her husband, Martin Carr, live tweeted the event to thousands. It all happened during morning rush hour in England, and a cheer reportedly went up on at least one commuter train when the couple announced their daughter, Sailor Carr, arrived.

title: The Problem With Obamas Re-Election Pitch
description: As you might have seen, my colleagues Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg did a nice job of previewing President Obamas re-election campaign in a front page article on Sunday. One line in particular jumped out at me: With their hopes dashed of substantial improvement in unemployment anytime soon, aides indicated that the theme was likely to be less morning in America and more dont change horses in midstream.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, India and Washington.

title: Yankees Put Chamberlain on D.L. With Elbow Injury
description: On Tuesday, Manager Joe Girardi watched Mark Teixeira writhe in such pain after being struck by a pitch that he thought Teixeira broke his right kneecap. On Wednesday, Teixeira seemed one of the healthier players in the Yankees clubhouse.

title: Does This Swimsuit Make Me Look Fat?
description: IN its Platonic ideal, a bathing suit removes you momentarily from yourself, and perhaps unleashes heretofore dormant aspects of your personality. Wriggle into a great-looking suit thats black and snug and tailored, and suddenly youre ready for an underwater cocktail party; rock a pair of floral Hawaiian board shorts and suddenly youre convinced that the only way to spell dude is with two os.

title: Nice Jacket, but It Cant Do My Taxes
description: CLOTHES, much like everything else in modern life, are into multitasking.

title: 2,500 Firefighters Struggle to Restrain Arizona Blaze
description: SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz.  The massive wildfire that continued its surge Wednesday through eastern Arizona was sending burning embers miles downwind, igniting dozens of smaller fires that required the urgent attention of firefighters and raising the prospect of the fire greatly extending its 11-day run, the authorities said.

title: Zen Farm
description: Zen Farm

title: The Latest From Steve Jobs: iSpaceship
description: Its well known that Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, has had a hand in the design of just about everything Apple makes, including the Macs, MacBooks, iMacs, iPods, iTunes, iPhones, iPads and, now, the iCloud.

title: India
description: 1: ACCELERATED HISTORY

title: An Intimate Biography of Millions
description: The critic Dwight Macdonald liked to lower the boom on academic books, especially biographies, that he called lumbering dinosaurs with brains the size of a teacup. Patrick Frenchs recent biography of V. S. Naipaul, The World Is What It Is (2008), was the opposite kind of book. It moved with feline grace and instinctual wit. It mapped its subjects plus-size talent and ego like an MRI scan.

title: Toys for the Father Whos Not Too Grown Up
description: AS a father of 19 years, I can say with some degree of authority that some Fathers Day gifts have been better than others. There was that year I was blindfolded and led to the garage to find a large box containing an unassembled lawn mower. It was a nice gift, but it made me feel that I should mow the lawn.

title: Tunisia Postpones Election, Possibly Aiding New Parties
description: CAIRO  The interim Tunisian government on Wednesday postponed the first election since the ouster in January of the former dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, citing technical problems for the delay but also inevitably reshuffling Tunisian political dynamics.

title: Smartphone Games Worth Downloading
description: Seth Schiesel discusses six video games designed for cellphones.

title: Revenge as a Dish Served in Mason Jars
description: A bad breakup inspires an odyssey into the realms of exotic spiritualism  or at least highly decorative forms of revenge  in Tanya Sarachos play Enfrascada, the first production in the Clubbed Thumb theater companys annual Summerworks festival at Here Arts Center. The first significant salvo in what has become an exhausting gantlet of June-to-September festivals in New York, the Summerworks series has previously presented early work by talented writers including Sarah Ruhl, Gina Gionfriddo and Adam Bock.

title: With Smartphone Games, Downtime Becomes a Pastime
description: All right, fess up, people. Have you never played a game on your cellphone? Really? Im here to let you know you can come out of the closet now.

title: Reader Q. and A.: In India, Dynamism Wrestles With Dysfunction
description: India, with one-sixth of all humanity, is expected to become the worlds fastest-growing economy as soon as next year thanks to aggressive, free-wheeling businesses that in many cases are becoming the behemoths that state-run goliaths are in China.

title: Susan Stroman Signs On to Direct Stage Musical of Tim Burtons Big Fish
description: Susan Stroman, the Tony Award-winning director and choreographer (The Producers) who was nominated for both jobs on The Scottsboro Boys in this Sundays Tonys competition, has her next Broadway project: A musical adaptation of the film and novel Big Fish, aiming to open in spring 2012, the producers announced on Wednesday.

title: Winning Games for Tablets
description: Some tablet games that Seth Schiesel found most enjoyable.

title: Games on Tablets: Lean Back, Commence Tapping
description: Tablets are just great for gaming. Everything that modern cellphones bring to games  touch screens, tilt sensitivity and of course constant Internet access  the tablets do better. The screens are finer and larger and the games are more immersive. And you can use a tablet in ways and places that rarely work for even the smallest netbooks.

title: Just One Look | Reed Krakoff Resort Collection
description: Reed Krakoff is one to wear his knowledge of art on his sleeve. His resort collection took its cues  and also perhaps its often vibrant hues  from the likes of Mark Rothko, Helen Frankenthaler and Josef Albers.

title: Booth for Two, Dialogue Optional
description: People with intimacy issues  which is to say most respectably neurotic New Yorkers  may need to steel themselves before a visit to Theater for One, in which a single actor and a single audience member are sequestered in a plush red booth in Times Square for a one-on-one performance. The experience will last no longer than a few minutes but is likely to settle somewhere in your soul for a lot longer than most of the splashy jamborees in the neighboring theaters do.

title: Last Days, Perhaps, for Group That Sued for Poor School Districts
description: After a series of setbacks, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy organization whose victory in a historic lawsuit brought billions of additional dollars to poor school districts in New York State, has run out of money to sustain itself, the organization said.

title: Affordable iPad Cases, or Not So
description: WHICH would you rather have: three iPads or an iPad case?

title: The Defense Was Accurate; The Bidding Was Less So
description: When the Eastern States Regional was canceled for lack of a suitable location in New York, the one event that survived in the replacement, the Memorial Weekend Sectional, was the Reisinger Knockout Teams.

title: The Green, Green Sod of Home
description: Ever since the 1994 World Cup in the United States, when organizers for the New York/New Jersey site came up with an innovative tray system at to lay grass over an artificial turf field at Giants Stadium, the idea of plopping the real stuff on top of the fake stuff as a short-term solution has gained  forgive me  traction.

title: Using the Right Lens for the Right Photograph
description: A SWISS Army Knife is a terrific tool that is useful for a lot of tasks, but dont try to tile a kitchen with one. Some jobs require specialized tools. And so it is with camera lenses.

title: Cuomo Urges Broad Limits to N.Y. Public Pensions
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, joining a parade of officials from across the country who are seeking to rein in spending by limiting public employees pensions, proposed Wednesday to broadly limit retirement benefits for new city and state workers in New York.

title: Campsite Discounts for Great Outdoors Month
description: Are you itching to pitch a tent beneath the stars?

title: Weiners Wife Is Pregnant
description: Their marriage has become the subject of intense speculation and scrutiny amid an embarrassing online sex scandal.

title: Club Mixes Old, New and Blue
description: From the outside the club appears to be just another shuttered and somewhat grotty East Village storefront, and the interior, with its scarred wooden floor and graffiti-daubed walls, isnt any more impressive. Instead, its what happens onstage that has made Nublus reputation as an incubator of musical talent, with some of the most adventurous and varied offerings in the city.

title: Update Your Car With GPS, Radar and Other Gadgets
description: TYING a big red bow around a new sports car is one way to give someone the latest in-car technologies, but for most of us thats just a marketers fantasy. Fortunately, there are plenty of high-tech baubles that can be added to your own car to improve safety, convenience or both. And you dont have to take out a new loan to get them (or give them).

title: Despite Drop, Americas Got Talent Still Draws a Crowd
description: Opposite Game 4 of the National Basketball Association Finals on ABC, Americas Got Talent saw a drop in its ratings compared to its premiere a week ago the NBC reality show still outperformed all other programming on the night excluding basketball. According to Nielsens estimates, 12.7 million viewers tuned in to Americas Got Talent at 8 p.m., down from 15.3 million who watched the two-hour premiere last week.

title: Footnote
description: The producers of the Broadway musical Million Dollar Quartet announced on Tuesday that the show would transfer Off Broadway to New World Stages after it plays its final performance at the Nederlander Theater on Sunday. No opening date for the Off Broadway production was announced.

title: Trolling Heaven and Earth for Sounds
description: As cultures blend, as art forms meld with one another and with science and other disciplines, all is convergence, and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma is somehow at the center.

title: Debit Card Fees to Fall, but Will Consumers Benefit?
description: After weeks of back-and-forth debate and heavy lobbying by banks and retailers, the Senate voted Wednesday against delaying a cap on the swipe fees that stores must pay for the processing of debit card purchases.

title: On Limits and Leaps
description: Tom Friedmans column today focused on Paul Gildings new book, The Great Disruption: Why the Climate Crisis Will Bring on the End of Shopping and the Birth of a New World. The column and the cited comments from Gilding gave the impression of planetary overload, but a critical clause from Gilding was easy to miss and is worth highlighting here (my italics):

title: Who Made Californias License Plate?
description: California has been having a lot of problems lately, but despite the budget, gas prices and the fear of earthquakes, the Golden State can still conjure romantic notions of endless summer: surfing in the Pacific, camping in Redwood, taking the archetypal road trip down a coastal highway. Driving is a large part of Californias culture, and typographically speaking, the bold red script on the states license plate seemingly embraces the happily casual and free-spirited notions commonly associated with the West Coast.

title: 24 Hours in New York Sports
description: Mike Tanier's mission: to cover six major New York sports events in a span of 24 hours.

title: Suspicion and Disunity Impede Central Americas Effort to Fight Drug Violence
description: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador  The nations of Central America agree on one thing: They cannot by themselves combat the drug and organized crime violence that is making the region among the worlds unsafest.

title: The Balanchine Way, Imprinted
description: On Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater five teenage girls from the School of American Ballet, dancing to Tchaikovsky, each extended a leg toward the audience above hip height. Then, keeping the legs high in that position, they all began to fall forward off balance toward the audience. They didnt actually fall, of course, but, before they brought the legs down, they had transferred much of their weight in its direction. It was easy for the audience to feel the suspense involved in the moment of extension and then the audacity involved in that transfer of weight: those girls were aiming those legs straight at us.

title: Paul McCartney to Perform at Yankee Stadium
description: Sorry, Queens, but youve had plenty of opportunities to feature the Cute Beatle, now its time to let the Bronx host him for an evening: Paul McCartney will play his first concert ever at Yankee Stadium on July 15, Live Nation Entertainment said on Wednesday. Mr. McCartney, the pop musician whose work in Wings is perennially overshadowed by his time with another popular British rock outfit, has some familiarity with New York ballparks, having served as the inaugural performer at Citi Field as in 2009, and as a surprise guest when Billy Joel closed down Shea Stadium in 2008; Mr. McCartney also played at Shea Stadium in 1965 as part of that beloved band whose name momentarily escapes us. (No, not the Rolling Stones, the other guys.) A statement from Live Nation said Mr. McCartneys performance at Yankee Stadium can safely be predicted to feature some nearly three hours of the worlds best loved and most known music, with hits, deep cuts and surprises spanning his unrivaled career, including the 2008 album Electric Arguments that he released under the name the Fireman. With a top ticket price of $279.50 for this show, Mr. McCartney will hopefully throw in Band on the Run or Let It Be, too.

title: Chinese Truck Driver Sentenced to Death Over Homicide
description: BEIJING  An ethnic Han truck driver who killed an ethnic Mongolian herder with his truck last month, sparking Inner Mongolias largest protests in 20 years, was sentenced to death on Wednesday by a court in Xilinhot, the area of Inner Mongolia where the incident occurred.

title: Houston to Manage Knicks New Development League Team
description: The Knicks announced an affiliation partnership with the Erie (Pa.) Bayhawks of the N.B.A. Development League on Wednesday, with Allan Houston to serve as the teams general manager as well as continuing his role as assistant general manger of the Knicks.

title: Weiners Seat Could Be Scrambled in Redistricting
description: There is much speculation about whether Representative Anthony D. Weiner will remain in Congress or resign his seat. But there is a politically expedient solution for Democrats if they want to show him the door: Neuter his district in the redistricting process, which will require New York to lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House of Representatives.

title: Night at the Caravanserai
description: Yo-Yo Ma led Silk Road Ensemble in a cultural blend of music and dance to open the season Tuesday night at Central Parks Summerstage.

title: Headphones That Fit Different Needs, and Ears
description: IN this day of cloud computing and virtualization, its important to remember that satisfying feeling of holding a well-built, overengineered object in your hands; to be in touch, literally, with a things thingness.

title: That Chlo Sevigny Look
description: Chlo Sevignys resort collection for Opening Ceremony, shown yesterday evening at the St. Patrick Youth Center in SoHo, exuded a nostalgic, teenage spirit  and even included pieces made in collaboration with the storied skate brand Vision Street Wear. Its hard to encapsulate my inspiration because there are so many different looks, but I think its just like, sexy girl you see walking down the street in a cool outfit, Sevigny said. A lot of eyelet, a lot of leather, playing with the hard and the soft, the good and bad inside of us all. The hairstylist Thomas Dunkin, who used Sebastian Potion 9 for a soft, natural, 80s skater girl vibe, spared the models hair from heat tools (good thing, as the center was not air-conditioned). The makeup artist Lottie Stannard applied M.A.C. Coffee Eyeliner haphazardly  topped off with loads of black mascara  and M.A.C. Blush Cream in Laid Back. Im really into a blush on the eyelid and on the high of the cheek, Sevigny said. The singer of Cocteau Twins used to do that  really pink eyelids. It added a little romance to the hard kind of street-edge clothes.

title: Hearing the Voice of the Horse Whisperer
description: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. Shes confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

description: Charles Isherwood with a preview of the 2011 Tony awards.

title: Artists Decorate Palazzos, and Vice Versa
description: VENICE  When it comes to dense, out-of-control concentrations of contemporary art, there is nothing like the Venice Biennale. With its big central exhibition, its ever-rising number of national pavilions and the scores of collateral shows organized in museums, galleries and palazzos all over the city, the Biennale never stops. It is a cornucopia of recent artistic endeavor, endlessly amplified by Venice itself, which remains one of the most culturally layered, artful and art-filled places on earth.

title: Visuals
description: Before the personal computer, one way to pick out graphic designers in a crowd was from the pieces of colored adhesive film, like Cello-tak or Rubylith, stuck to their clothes. Most of the designers I knew back then yearned to rid themselves of messy cutting and pasting. So in 1984, when the Macintosh was introduced and became a design tool, they enthusiastically embraced desktop-computer design. Today, though, many designers are proud to engage in dirty handwork. Young and old designers alike are employing revered methods of making art and design by hand, especially in silk-screen print-making. Having clothes stained with ink and paint is now a status symbol.

title: Comics
description: Gilbert Hernandez is one of the great craftsmen of modern comics, the writer and artist of elegant, fiery, carefully controlled graphic novels like Palomar and Luba. Over the past few years, though, hes been doing his best to break away from (or at least expand on) that highbrow reputation with a series of short, pungent thrillers whose conceit is that theyre adapted from B movies starring one of his recurring characters: the tragic, top-heavy bombshell Fritz Martinez.

He alluded to the place in one of his pieces.

As the statuesque French chanteuse Yanna Avis sang Cole Porters great ode to the City of Light, You Dont Know Paree, on a recent evening, a composite view of the city as imagined by Balzac, Zola and of course, Porter himself, flickered in my imagination. Until youve lived a lot, and loved a lot, and lost a lot, you dont know Paree, go lyrics that Ms. Avis, a soign international beauty, sang with a wry understanding.

title: New Move to Condemn Syria in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS  Britain and France circulated a revised draft resolution at the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that would condemn the Syrian government for using force against its own civilians, but would scrupulously avoid a call for military action or any sanctions against the Syrian government.

title: Low Cost and Hi-Fi: Building a Player
description: Back when my music was on vinyl or CD, I had a stereo in the living room where my music-loving friends would gather to listen, chat and argue. But now that I, like most of the world, buy digital downloads, my music resides on my main computer. So when my friends come by, we end up awkwardly crowded around the computer in my office, clicking on songs. This is not gracious entertaining.

As director of the skating school at Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, Mr. Corbett, 64, coordinates lesson programs for aspiring skaters from age 3 until death, his way of saying that, with the proper instruction, anyone can learn to skate. title: Thursday: Do as Drer Did
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Solvers frequently comment on a constructors use of the rare letters seen in crossword puzzles, particularly J, Q, X and Z. In fact, this usage has even been given a nickname. A puzzle with a plethora of these letters is described as Scrabbly. title: 36 Hours in Bologna
description: VIBRANT, independent and home to one of Europes oldest universities, Bologna is a dynamic counterpoint to more popular, touristy cities like Rome and Florence. About 50 miles north of Florence, the city is as famous for its cuisine as it is for its fiery left-leaning politics. Market stalls brimming with asparagus and fava beans, specialty shops selling cured meats, and osterias serving fresh pasta with the citys signature rag (known as Bolognese in the rest of the world) offer compelling reasons to linger. And then there are architectural masterpieces like the church of Santo Stefano and the iconic Due Torri (Two Towers). Grittier than in most of its northern counterparts, Bolognas politics  the last mayor, Flavio Delbono, resigned when it was alleged that he was using public money on his mistress, and now residents are waiting to see if the new mayor, Virginio Merola, will make good on his promise to spruce up the city center  somehow only adds to the excitement of a visit here.

title: Just How Much Is a Tony Worth?
description: Every year, Broadway producers with musicals struggling to fill theaters to capacity every night place their financial hopes on the Tony awards. But just how valuable is winning a prestigious Tony? And how much does the publicity  and the broadcast television showcase for the musical numbers on CBS  help the runners-up? FiveThirtyEight, a blog devoted to helping readers of The New York Times cut through the clutter of this data-rich world, decided to find out.

title: Uncommon Threads | Sophia 203
description: With their refined silk embroidery and unironic butterfly and heart shapes, Sophia 203 belts, necklaces and flower-child headbands feel very Yves Saint Laurent by way of Williamsburg. Sophia Edstrand, the designer behind the label, is from Sweden but her C.V. has a very French accent: she studied fashion design in Paris, worked as a salesgirl at Colette  It was supposed to be for pocket money while I was a student, but I spent it all on shoes, she says gleefully  then did a 10-year stint as the creative assistant to the Parisian jeweler Marie-Hlne de Taillac. Edstrand now splits her time between Paris and Jaipur, India, where she moved six years ago and where her one-year-old line is produced by traditional craftsmen. The embroidery thats done here is unbelievable, Edstrand says. When I showed one of my pieces to Manish Arora  the New Delhi designer whos known as the John Galliano of India  he couldnt believe it. And people here are not afraid of color. Neither is Edstrand, who named the line for her favorite Pantone shade, a bright fuchsia. Lampshades, childrens wear and bridal pieces are coming up next, and Edstrand is happy to undertake custom orders. She claims she had no thoughts of YSL when she was designing her pieces but is happy to report that Stefano Pilati has already bought one of her heart belts. Im inspired by happiness and lightness, she says. Thats really where the collection is coming from.

In his investigation, Danny Hakim of The Times reviewed thousands of state records and court documents and interviewed current and former employees at nine state-run institutions that house the developmentally disabled. He found that supervisors at these institutions have tolerated physical and psychological abuse, knowingly hired unqualified workers, ignored complaints by whistle-blowers and failed to investigate credibly cases of abuse and neglect.

From now through August, American films will again be almost all male, almost all the time (the occasional decorative gal pal notwithstanding) as this years boys of summer  the Green Lantern and Captain America, Conan the Barbarian and Conan OBrien  invade the multiplex, seizing media-entertainment minds and your dollars.

title: Captured: A New York Minute, or One in Havana
description: In a photograph by Elliott Erwitt, New York City, 1949, we behold, from behind, Augustus Saint-Gaudenss bronze sculpture of a nude Diana. Drawing her bow, she seems to be aiming at the silhouetted figure of a man far away down a long hallway. In this, like so many of Mr. Erwitts images, the light humor thinly veils poetic profundity. A modern cipher of a man is about to get his comeuppance from a mythical divinity: Diana, the virginal huntress, the sight of whom makes men fall prey to the hounds of their own lust. As the sex scandals reported almost daily in the news media attest, many powerful men have suffered, metaphorically, the fate of that unlucky voyeur Actaeon.

title: Reality vs. Reality: NBC Tops Fox
description: In the ratings battle of reality shows on Wednesday, NBCs Americas Got Talent outperformed Foxs So You Think You Can Dance by a wide margin, lifting the network to No. 1 on the night. According to Nielsens estimates, 12.3 million viewers tuned in for the two-hour installment of Americas Got Talent from 9 to 11 p.m., while So You Think You Can Dance drew 7.1 million from 8 to 10. NBCs Minute to Win It garnered a meager 4.7 million at 8, but NBC still averaged more viewers over all for the night than second- place Fox. CBS was third with repeats of Undercover Boss (4.4 million), Criminal Minds (5.7 million) and Blue Bloods (6.2 million). ABC finished fourth, earning 4.4 million for back-to-back reruns of The Middle in the 8 p.m. hour, followed by repeats of Modern Family at 9 and 9:30, which also drew 4.4 million. At 10, an ABC 20/20 special exploring the allure of reality television lagged well behind in its time slot, attracting just 3.6 million viewers.

The clothes were largely inspired by 1960s and 70s French cinema, but a few looks, like this kicky, pleated dress with its matching Vespa helmet, would look at home on Coppola herself, as she tools around Pariss Sixth Arrondissement.

title: Weekend Miser
description: The fourth annual Bike Parade takes off from Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens on Saturday, with cycle-centered festivities throughout the day. Children can get ready to roll in Hallets Cove Playground (Vernon Boulevard and 30th Avenue) from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. at a bike swap organized by Recycle-a-Bicycle. The city Transportation Department will provide helmet fittings and giveaways, and Bike New York will talk safety. At noon the Free Style Arts Association, a group commissioned by communities to build interest in the arts, helps host a bike-decorating workshop that continues until the parade leaves the park at 3. The celebration ends with a reception in Queensbridge Park. (Free; Long Island City; 718-956-1819, Ext. 12, socratessculpturepark.org.)

title: UCB Pays $34 Million and Pleads Guilty in Epilepsy Drug Fraud Case
description: The drug maker UCB has agreed to pay more than $34 million and pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor for illegal promotion of Keppra, an epilepsy drug, for headaches and pain, according to a court filing unsealed on Thursday in Washington.

title: Budget Talks Heat Up as Deadline Nears
description: With time growing shorter, lawmakers and White House officials involved in budget talks tied to the debt limit said on Thursday that they would meet at least three times next week to try to close in on an agreement.

title: A Painters Menagerie of Birds and Beasts Comes Back to Life
description: The painter Robert Winthrop Chanler enjoyed spending his inheritance from his Astor ancestors in the 1910s and 20s by giving parties and maintaining a zoo and a plant conservatory at his Manhattan town house near Gramercy Park.

title: Kenneth Arrow Was Here
description: Some readers ask why my argument that relatively centralized systems work better for health care than the free market isnt an argument for government ownership of everything.

title: Knocking, Twitching, Buzzing, Rasping
description: In most rock songs the landmarks are standard ones: the beat, the riffs, the lyric. Radian, an Austrian instrumental trio that played Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night as part of a rare United States tour, sets most of those aside. Its music features sounds that are more often treated as glitches. Instead of melodies there are buzzes, thuds, creaks, high-pitched electronic hums or crackles of static. Silence too. Theres no predicting when an element that had been consistent will suddenly disappear. Radian replaces landmarks with potholes. It makes for a bumpy, mesmerizing ride.

title: Dance Listings for June 10-16
description: Dance

title: Go West, Wide-Eyed Easterners
description: The setting of a Pullman sleeping car departing Grand Central in spring 1914, bound for the Pacific Coast, evokes thoughts of adventurous pre-Depression train travel, when crossing the country was as much an endurance test as a glamorous jaunt. It suggests East Coast sophisticates leaving behind their cosmopolitan yet insular world to enter a landscape that opened their horizons in ways both physical and figurative.

title: A Collection of Classics With a Cuban Touch
description: The Ballet Nacional de Cubas short season, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, also concludes the Si Cuba! Festival, which has brought all things Cuban to the city for several weeks now.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for June 10-16
description: Classical

title: Somalia Extends Government; Premier Fired
description: JOHANNESBURG  After months of feuding, Somalias bickering leaders on Thursday agreed on a compromise that extends the transitional government for one more year but, at the same time, led to the dismissal of the popular prime minister.

title: Newt
Ford Cancels Minivan Plan for Hybrids and Plug-Ins
description: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company has canceled plans to re-enter the minivan market in the United States. Instead, Ford said on Thursday that it would introduce a smaller, five-passenger hatchback version of the minivan that it was going to build and offer it only as either a hybrid or plug-in hybrid.

title: Signature Theater to Open New Home With a Celebration of Fugard
description: Signature Theater Company has chosen the celebrated South African playwright Athol Fugard as the focus of its first year in its new 74,000-square-foot home, known as Signature Center, which will open in February 2012, the theaters leadership announced on Thursday.

title: You Can Feel Her Pain (Just Dont Ask Questions)
description: The tantalizing thing about Finding Sarah, the Duchess of Yorks six-part voyage of self-discovery beginning Sunday on OWN, is that not even Oprah Winfrey can pin her down.

title: A Comrade by Accident, a Seeker by Design
description: You dont say much, says the man who flirtatiously sidles up to Joy, the young heroine of Lisa Sees latest novel. He has a smile thats warm and embracing. He leaves Joy dumb with wonder and astonishment. And he has a question for Joys father: How many more pretty daughters have you left across China? Perhaps the question is impertinent, but this is a man who can say whatever he wants to: Joy is fielding a come-on from Chairman Mao.

title: Dogonomics
description: If this doesnt convince Congress that theres an unemployment crisis, I dont know what will.

title: An Inopportune Sex Scandal; the Republican Field of Candidates Gels; Addressing the Economy During the Elections
description: An inopportune time for a Democratic sex scandal while the Republican field of presidential hopefuls starts to gel. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Jackie Calmes, Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman, lead writer of the 538 Blog Nate Silver and national political correspondent Jeff Zeleny join Sam Roberts in New York. join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: With NBCs Finish, the Big Five Complete Upfront Sales
description: NBC on Thursday afternoon became the fifth of the five big English-language broadcast television networks to complete the sale of commercial time ahead of the 2011-12 season in what is known as the upfront market.

title: Questions Amid the Wreckage of Gingrichs Campaign
description: It doesnt require any deep thinking to determine that when virtually all of your most senior advisers suddenly decide to quit your campaign  as happened to Newt Gingrich on Thursday afternoon  your bid for the presidency isnt off to the best start. Although Mr. Gingrich is insisting  at least for the time being  that hell remain in the race, betting markets now give him just a 1-in-200 chance of winning the Republican nomination.

title: Lady Liberty Extends Her Family Tree
description: PARIS  For the last century or so, people wanting their own Statue of Liberty settled for a knockoff, like the version that looks down from a hotel rooftop in Pristina, Kosovo, or the copy in the bar of a bowling alley in Warrington, England. Now those with a preference for authenticity (and the means to indulge it) can buy the closest thing possible  a bronze cast made from the plaster sculpture that Frdric-Auguste Bartholdi used to create the famous monument.

title: Book of Tonys: Anything Goes?
description: WITH 14 nominations, will The Book of Mormon sweep the Tony Awards on Sunday night or come close to the record of 12 wins by another megahit musical, The Producers? Can Americans beat the British in a passel of play and acting categories? Can anything sink the U.S.S. Sutton Foster? And will it be gags or grudging respect on the CBS broadcast for ineligible-but-not-inconsequential Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark?

title: Maqbool Fida Husain, Indias Most Famous Painter, Dies at 95
description: Maqbool Fida Husain, an artist whose modernist reinterpretations of mythic and religious subjects made him Indias most famous painter and, in recent years, a target of right-wing Hindu groups, died on Thursday in London. He was 95.

title: Just Like Us
description: Stand-up comedians have been straying into documentary film territory for some time now, with both Chris Rock and Bill Maher finding the form useful for airing pet peeves. The latest to cross that border is Ahmed Ahmed, the Egyptian-American comic whose Just Like Us is a laudable if lightweight argument for broader minds and thicker skins.

title: Field Testers of Mini E Bonded With Cars, Study Finds
description: Given the brief amount of time that contemporary electric vehicles have been on the road, broad studies reflecting E.V. drivers user experiences are rare. But the coming findings of a yearlong survey by the University of California, Davis Plug-in Hybrid and Electric Vehicle Research Center reveals that drivers of a particular E.V., the Mini E, are an overwhelmingly contented lot.

title: Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer
description: Take the animated adolescent flourishes of Scott Pilgrim vs. the World and apply them to a hyperactive childs imagination, and you have an idea of the texture of Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer, John Schultzs rambunctiously exuberant film featuring Megan McDonalds popular childrens book character.

description: Marianne Boesky

title: CHRIS KRAUS: Films
description: Real Fine Arts

title: ALWAYS THE YOUNG STRANGERS
description: Higher Pictures

title: AMELIE VON WULFFEN: This Is How It Happened
description: Greene Naftali

title: 167th Street, The Bronx, 2:57 P.M.
Three Friends, Each on a Journey
description: The scent of perfumed suds hangs heavily over Bride Flight, a 130-minute fictionalized quasi-epic inspired by an actual contest known as the Last Great Air Race. The winner of the roughly 12,000-mile flight from London to Christchurch, New Zealand, in October 1953 touched down 41 minutes ahead of its closest rival. The movie incorporates vintage newsreel footage of the plane leaving London on a bumpy journey nicknamed the Bride Flight because many of the passengers were Dutch brides-to-be fleeing a country devastated by World War II.

title: Winter and Davidson Are Doubly Honored
description: A decade ago, the Missouri School of Journalism and the National Press Photographers Association parted ways, ending what had been the jointly administered Pictures of the Year contest. Sometimes, however, they still see eye to eye.

title: Five People Shot on Boardwalk in Brighton Beach
description: 11:30 p.m. | Updated For the latest updates, read the news article from Fridays paper.

title: A Rural Struggle for Subsistence, Rooted in Dignity
description: The title of Uruphong Raksasads Agrarian Utopia evokes the romance of rural toil, and also the political ideal, present in various Western back-to-the-land movements, of life lived close to the soil. And the films bucolic rhythms and stunning vistas of the Thai countryside give it a sometimes-idyllic quality. One of its subjects, whose long hair, plaid shirts and pointy beard give him the aspect of a hippie philosopher, espouses what sound like variations of locavore and organic-farming ideas.

title: Shimmying Into Shape
description: As 1920s New Orleans jazz played recently in an East Village studio, a buxom dancer began a sultry dance. She wore black fishnets, a leotard and cherry-dotted bloomers. She had on sparkly lipstick, a boa and high heels  all in vivid red  as she led nearly a dozen women in a bumping-and-grinding class called Flirting With Burlesque.

title: Activision Takes Different Approach to Mobile Gaming
description: You would be hard pressed to find anyone in the gaming world who wont agree that Activision is the hottest game developer in the world. The company has surpassed its own video game sales records several times over. Earlier this year Activision made over $650 million in just five days from the sale of its latest hit, Call of Duty: Black Ops.

title: Tony Awards Preview
description: Patrick Healy talks about what to expect in the upcoming Tony Awards show.

title: Yes, No, Yes. Vanuatu Clarifies Position on Abkhazia
description: MOSCOW  The south Pacific nation of Vanuatu, which has engaged in an on-again-off-again relationship with the separatist government in Abkhazia, released a video early Friday seeking to clear up the confusion. In a brief statement, Foreign Minister Alfred Carlot said that Vanuatu has, in fact, recognized Abkhazia as a sovereign nation.

title: Limns Spiritual Heights and Depths
description: Jos Limns Missa Brevis had its premiere 53 years ago, and it can take a bit of time and concentration to sink into its religion-infused depths today, especially for the agnostically inclined. (I cannot speak for the atheists out there.) It is worth the effort, however, at least it was on Wednesday evening at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, when the Limn Dance Company performed the work with intensity and palpable joy.

title: Trouble Ahead: Director Falls for Leading Lady
description: Voltaires observation Illusion is the first of all pleasures is the tag line of Monte Hellmans grandiloquent neo-noir, Road to Nowhere. The dangerous temptation to embrace impossible dreams is also addressed in Tom Russells title song, a gloomy stylistic mash-up of Dylan, Springsteen and Cash. Row, row, row your little dreamboat violently back upstream, Mr. Russell sings in the sepulchral tone of a dour country prophet warning of inevitable doom.

title: A Date With Bill Clinton, for a Donation
description: If you could meet any historical figure, who would it be and why? If its former President Bill Clinton, you might just get your chance.

title: A Kind of Orthodoxy Built on Improvisation
description: The Vision Festival, a hand-sewn New York institution now in its 16th year, presents avant-garde jazz as a form of religion, complete with saints and sacraments, a clergy and a congregation. The sheer range of music gathered under its umbrella  detailed compositions as well as top-to-bottom improvisations, in all manner of instrumental lineups  suggests a house policy of ecumenicalism. On some nights, though, the festival organizes itself around a single artist, yielding fully to his doctrine. (Its usually a he.)

title: A New Church Organ, With Vocal Celebration
description: You must really love music to have come out tonight, Dennis Keene, the artistic director of Voices of Ascension, said on Wednesday evening, greeting the audience after a day of temperatures in the high 90s with little relief yet in evidence.

title: Shortage Forces VW to Cancel Back-Up Cameras
description: Volkswagen will be unable to offer rearview cameras in several models due to ongoing parts shortages caused by the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan. Autoblog broke the story after citing a blog post by a Volkswagen dealer on Thursday, and The Times confirmed the news with Volkswagen of America.

title: ISABELLA KIRKLAND: Nova
description: Feature Inc.

title: Q. and A. With Alex Brown
description: Alex Brown, a regular contributor to The Rail, answered questions about his book, Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy.

title: Alone in the Wilderness and the Spotlight
description: The Frick Collection has long since mastered the art historical meet and greet. Last spring Rembrandt, seen in a late self-portrait, received fans in the Fricks skylighted Oval Room.

title: 2 Pairs of Sharp Elbows On White Tablecloths
description: In contrast to Roger Cormans 1967 freakout, The Trip, no hallucinogens are harmed in the Michael Winterbottom comedy of the same title, a British road movie laced with lacerating laughs and starring Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon. Mr. Coogan does, in fact, smoke a joint, lighting up in the same house where Coleridge wrote Dejection: An Ode and indulged in opium, the soporific that enslaved him in humiliation and debasement. Mr. Coogan has made a career partly by riffing on narcissism and hes in fine self-loving form, as is Mr. Brydon. For one man, the humiliation of choice here is fame (with a debasement chaser), while for the other its his incessant vocal mugging. Both give you a contact high.

title: Wi-Fi Set to Expand to 19 More City Parks
description: Free Wi-Fi service will be made available in 19 more city parks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday in East Harlem, which would more than double the number of parks with Wi-Fi.

title: The Implications of Assisted Suicide
description: Ezra Klein writes that he didnt find the arguments in my Jack Kevorkian column persuasive, but I think our views arent actually all that far apart. Heres his critique:

title: Richard Bove Does an About-Face on Goldman
description: Richard X. Bove, one of the most bearish stock analysts covering Goldman Sachs, has had an about-face on the firms role in the credit crisis.

title: The Pleasures and Perils of Creative Translation
description: The first modern French novel I read  the one that introduced terms like avant-garde and surrealism to my tongue  was Les Enfants Terribles, by Jean Cocteau. I thrilled to the extravagant antics of Paul and Elisabeth, brother and sister, soon to be sleeping partners, in the Room they share with teenage friends. Life in Cocteaus Paris is the Game, with its own rules or no rules, a state peculiar to the spirit on the threshold between infancy and adolescence. All lovers of this slim novel seek to unlock the secret door leading from their own room to the Room on the Rue Montmartre. When I open it now, it is my cleareyed 20-year-old self in Scotland who begins to read, as much as the weathered, bespectacled me of almost four decades on.

title: Up Front: Lydia Davis
description: On our cover this week, Lydia Davis reviews John Ashberys new translation of Rimbauds Illuminations.

title: Rimbauds Wise Music
description: Some associations with the name Rimbaud are very familiar: the highly romantic photograph taken a few months after he first settled in Paris, already at 17 the dedicatedly bohemian artist, with his pale blue eyes, distant gaze, thatch of hair, carelessly rumpled clothes; the startling, much interpreted declaration Je est un autre (I is someone else); the fact that he produced a masterly, innovative and influential body of poetry while still in his teens; that he stopped writing around age 21 and never went back to it, engaging thereafter in various sometimes mysterious commercial and mystical enterprises in exotic locations, including a period of gun-running in Africa (and, oddly, an attempt to enlist in the United States Navy).

title: The Four-Story Jigsaw Puzzle
description: Q. In his family history, my father, William H. Zinsser, writes that his cousin August Zinsser moved his mansion, brick by brick, from West 58th Street and 10th Avenue to 14 West 68th Street. Can you find a picture of the old house in its previous location?

title: Mavericks Win Game 5, 112-103
description: LeBron James went missing again in the fourth quarter, and the Mavericks were too much team to handle for the Big Three in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday.

title: Battle for Libya | June 9, 2011
description: A fire was seen at the Rixos Hotel, where foreign journalists are staying in Libyas capital, Tripoli.

title: Google in Talks to Buy Admeld for $400 Million
description: Google is in discussions to buy Admeld, a display advertising company, for around $400 million, according to three people briefed on the negotiations.

title: A Peephole Perspective on Tiny Worlds
description: TWO years ago David Revere McFadden, chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design in New York, found himself thinking a lot about dioramas. He was installing a show that included work by Thomas Demand, known for slightly creepy photographs of rooms that look realistic but are actually fabricated with colored paper. How reality is defined is one of those questions that has plagued human beings since the beginning of culture, Mr. McFadden said. I suddenly thought maybe there are other artists out there working in the same vein but on a smaller scale.

title: Vancouvers Circumspect Superstars
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On the ice, Henrik and Daniel Sedin, the twin forwards for the Vancouver Canucks, can rack up points as few others can. But outside of Canada and their native Sweden, not many people recognize them.

title: The Night the Music Died. Really.
description: Chamber music concerts rarely elicit reactions more raucous than polite applause, but last Sunday, an artistic melee more appropriate for a Metallica show broke out at The Royce Gallery in San Francisco after a heckler interrupted a viola performance.

title: Picking Up the Citys Garbage Is a Sweet Deal, and a Monopoly
description: Garbage is, obviously, a dirty business. But for Recology, the outfit that has had a monopoly on handling San Franciscos detritus for the past 80 years, it is one sweet gig. And one the company would very much like to keep.

title: A Real Statue of Liberty
description: A French art dealer will seek to sell bronze casts of the Statue of Liberty.

title: One Arm
description: Photos from the new stage production of a Tennessee Williams screenplay.

title: Georgia Threatens To Abandon Russia Talks
description: MOSCOW  Georgia said Thursday that it might withdraw from regular talks with Russia after uncovering what it said were Russian plots to plant bombs in Georgian territory. The talks, which are held in Geneva, have been the two countries main line of communication since their war in 2008.

title: Providing Warmth, Year Round
description: At the Springs General Store, a pine-shingled, two-story building that started life in 1847 as the areas post office and general store, the small-town atmosphere of East Hampton, from the days before the glittering hordes, is miraculously preserved.

title: Blagojevich Jury to Begin Deliberating in Retrial
description: CHICAGO  The fate of Rod R. Blagojevich, Illinoiss beleaguered former governor, who is accused of, among other things, trying to sell an appointment to the Senate seat that once belonged to President Obama, was in the hands of the jury on Thursday.

title: Nine Killed in Attack on Afghan Wedding Party
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Armed men attacked a wedding party in eastern Afghanistan Thursday, killing nine people including the groom and his father, local officials said. Five others were wounded.

title: Alabama: Tough Immigration Measure Becomes Law
description: Gov. Robert Bentley signed a tough immigration law on Thursday, and several civil rights groups said they would sue to stop it from taking effect. The law, which goes beyond an immigration enforcement bill Arizona adopted last year, requires public schools to determine the immigration status of all students starting in kindergarten and makes it a crime to knowingly give a ride in a vehicle to an illegal immigrant. It requires police officers to inquire about the status of anyone they stop if they suspect the person might be an illegal immigrant. Calling the law extreme, the Southern Poverty Law Center, the National Immigration Law Center and the American Civil Liberties Union said they were preparing a lawsuit.

title: The Wowing of a Practical Person
description: AFTER her graduation from dental school a decade ago, Maryann Riordan had two major goals: the first was to buy a dental practice; the second to buy an apartment.

title: How Tyrants Endure
description: WHY do certain dictators survive while others fall? Throughout history, downtrodden citizens have tried to throw off the yoke of their oppressors, but revolutions, like those sweeping through the Arab world, are rare.

title: Peter M. Lehrer
description: Mr. Lehrer, 69, is the chairman of Lehrer LLC, a construction consulting firm, and a board member of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center. He was a founder of Lehrer McGovern, the construction manager for the Statue of Liberty restoration. Bovis Ltd. bought a 50 percent stake in that company, creating Lehrer McGovern Bovis, and eventually acquired the rest.

title: College Fights Subpoena of Interviews Tied to I.R.A.
description: Boston College filed a motion this week to quash a federal subpoena seeking access to confidential interviews of paramilitary fighters for the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title: Exurb With Suburban Trimmings
description: WITH cul-de-sacs a hop, skip and short drive from major corporations, the town of Brookfield is in many ways a classic bedroom community. By that measure it has the look and feel of its Fairfield County neighbors.

title: The Reluctant Mormon
description: Politicians are trained from the time they mouth their first public lie to be reflexively certain about everything. So it was startling and certainly encouraging to hear Jon Huntsman sound less than convinced the other day about the God of his Mormon upbringing.

title: Sgt. Barney Longs for Home  and a Fight
description: Barely six weeks into their enlistment, the volunteers of the First Vermont Infantry had become bored with army life. Tedious daily drills and inspections had proved monotonous. Sunday services provided welcome relief from the exceedingly dull routine.

title: Director of National Counterterrorism Center Is Resigning
description: WASHINGTON  Michael E. Leiter, the head of the nations main counterterrorism center, is resigning after nearly four years in a job that has increasingly focused on detecting and thwarting smaller and more diverse terrorist plots.

title: A Gallery to Call Home
description: FOR years now, it has been the practice among some condominium developers to incorporate artwork into the design of their buildings public spaces, as an inducement to sophisticated buyers.

title: A Diplomat, He Isnt: Prince Philips Tongue Remains Sharp as Ever
description: LONDON  In a rare move by a man who appears to despise few activities more than speaking to the news media, Prince Philip recently agreed to cooperate in the making of a television documentary about his life. Although cooperate might be too strong a word.

title: More Luxury-Home Owners Opt for Short Sales
description: Glen Cove

title: Politicians Behaving Well
description: One reason many politicians behave badly these days is that we spend less time thinking about what it means to behave well. This was less of a problem in past centuries when leaders, teachers and clergy held detailed debates over what it meant to have good character.

title: 55-and-Up Complexes Shift Gears
description: WILLIAM COONS Jr. didnt sell a single house last year at Windermere Village, his development in Ellington, so the four sales since the start of 2011 strike him as impressive. His new sales strategy is clearly paying off.

title: Changes in Refinancing
description: REFINANCING your mortgage now is different from the last time you did it.
