title: Leonard B. Stern, Creator of Mad Libs, Dies at 88
description: Leonard B. Stern, an Emmy-winning writer, producer and director for television whose frantic search for an adjective one day led him and a colleague to create Mad Libs, the game that asks players to fill in blanks with designated parts of speech to yield comically ________[adj.] stories, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88.

title: Nothing Soft About This European
description: DALLAS  The suggestion that Dirk Nowitzki had overcome injury and illness to keep the Mavericks afloat in the N.B.A. finals did not impress Miamis Dwyane Wade.

title: Tracy Reese Celebrates Five Years in the Meatpacking District
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: After Nuclear Crisis, Japans Biggest Utility Faces Insolvency Risk
description: TOKYO  Far away from the battle to contain the nuclear crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, investors are increasingly edgy about a related issue: the fate of Tokyo Electric Power, the stricken plants operator.

title: A Pest in Bruins Black and Gold Gets Mad, and Gets Even
description: The Canucks do not possess the good-luck charms the Bruins have as they try to right themselves for Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals Friday in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: In Connecticut, Pondering the Loss of a Big Employer
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Dino Sakakini, owner of a restaurant here called Laylas Falafel, surveyed the dinner crowd on Wednesday night and sighed. Many of his patrons were still wearing security badges from the nearby headquarters of UBS, the Swiss banking giant, and Mr. Sakakini was contemplating what might happen to his business if, as now seems quite likely, UBS moves its sprawling trading floor to Manhattan.

title: Rule by Rentiers
description: The latest economic data have dashed any hope of a quick end to Americas job drought, which has already gone on so long that the average unemployed American has been out of work for almost 40 weeks. Yet there is no political will to do anything about the situation. Far from being ready to spend more on job creation, both parties agree that its time to slash spending  destroying jobs in the process  with the only difference being one of degree.

title: Yankees Consider the End of an Aura
description: In the lobby of the Cleveland Indians executive offices is a framed photograph of pitcher Fausto Carmona, covered in Lake Erie midges in the 2007 playoff game that changed everything for Joba Chamberlain. Carmona is focused, undisturbed by the swarm. The same conditions unraveled the Yankees Chamberlain.

title: Pakistan Orders an Inquiry After Troops Kill a Teenager
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan ordered an investigation on Thursday into the shooting death of an apparently unarmed teenager by paramilitary troops in the southern port city of Karachi. The shooting, which was captured on video and broadcast on national television, has led to protests and has been condemned by political parties and human rights groups.

title: Aceves Displays a Versatility The Yankees Wish They Had
description: With Joba Chamberlain apparently needing season-ending Tommy John surgery and other Yankee relievers already out of action, the teams bullpen is a shell of what it was supposed to be. Making matters worse, one possible remedy has instead become a valuable component of the Boston Red Sox pitching staff.

title: Oakland Mayor and Gang Policy Mix Uneasily
description: An Alameda County judge is expected to decide this month whether to restrict the movements of people suspected of being gang members in the violent Fruitvale neighborhood of Oakland.

title: Its a Scandal, Sure, but Hardly a Reason to Undermine the Will of Voters
description: It takes one kind of brazenness for a man to send lewd pictures of himself to women he knows only through a few on-line chats.

title: Gov. Cuomo and Public Pensions
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo campaigned for office vowing to reduce the ruinous growth in New York States public pensions, and on Wednesday he offered a strong set of proposals that would also rein in New York Citys skyrocketing costs. Although unions howled, such sacrifice is essential to preserve the states and the citys most essential services. It is also fair that New Yorks public workers  long cosseted by Albany  share more of the burden.

title: Ally Is Said to Delay Its I.P.O.
description: Ally Financial, the former financing arm of General Motors, plans to delay its $5 billion initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

title: Out of Prison, Into a Vicious Circle of Debt
description: On Tuesday, I wrote about the Clapham Set, a Boston program that works with recently released prisoners. It asks judges to waive their court fees if the prisoners complete an academic course and work with a coach who helps them get jobs and services they need to turn their lives around.

title: Could It Happen Here?
description: The deadly outbreak of food-borne illnesses in Germany may seem a distant threat, especially since that strain of E. coli bacteria has never caused an outbreak here. Dont get complacent.

title: New Yorkers Try to Beat the Heat
description: As temperatures rose to a high of 97 Thursday, city dwellers took to the beaches, fountains and shady areas for relief.

title: Budgeting for Insecurity
description: House Republicans talk tough on terrorism. So we can find no explanation  other than irresponsibility  for their vote to slash financing for eight antiterrorist programs. Unless the Senate repairs the damage, New York City and other high-risk localities will find it far harder to protect mass transit, ports and other potential targets.

title: Prize Horses Slower, and Maybe Thats Good
description: Animal Kingdom, a horse who had never even competed on dirt, won the Kentucky Derby on the first Saturday in May and stamped himself the leader of his 3-year-old class. His time for the mile-and-a-quarter race, though, was an ordinary 2 minutes 2.04 seconds. Two weeks later, Shackleford, who finished fourth in the Derby, held off Animal Kingdom to win the shorter Preakness Stakes in 1:56.47, the slowest winning time in that race since 1993.

title: Egypts Economy Slows to a Crawl; Revolt Is Tested
description: CAIRO  Egypts economy, whose inequities and lack of opportunities helped topple a government, has now ground to a virtual halt, further wounded by the revolution itself.

title: What They Think in Massachusetts

description: THE advertising tradition of subjecting products to torture tests dates back to at least the 1950s, when the crooner Vaughn Monroe starred in commercials where both an RCA Victor radio and an unnamed competing brand were dropped from the top of a ladder, and only the RCA Victor radio remained in one piece.

title: New Ring Straddles Two Visions
description: The Ring of the Nibelung, Richard Wagners monumental, four-part opera cycle chronicling the battle between gods, heroes and monsters over an all-powerful, magical ring wrought out of a mystical hoard of gold, is operas answer to extreme sports.

title: The Cultural Calculation: Museum Fees
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced last week that it planned to raise its admission price to $25 from $20. Though the price is only recommended (you can pay a penny and get in, as the museum hates to see newspapers write, and as newspapers love to keep writing), the announcement has occasioned an outpouring of sentiment on the Web and elsewhere about the cost of museumgoing. Do sizable admission prices, even suggested ones, discourage lower-income visitorship? (Of course.) Should museums that receive taxpayer money charge for admission? (A lot of people say no, even though many museums receive relatively little in the way of public subsidies.) Do museums have a kind of moral obligation, like libraries, to be free? (Museum directors are divided on the subject. Some, like Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Met, point out that almost all cultural goods come with a price. Philosophically, what is it about a work of art that makes it mandatory that it should be available for nothing? he has asked.)

title: Friday: Elaborate Spectacles

Conceived by Tennessee Williams, who specialized in angels in exile, Ollie first appeared in a 1944 short story. title: Challenge the Leader
description: Until recently, I worked for a small nonprofit that, among other things, runs an international leadership program for high school students. I know I would. Do you agree? A. K.,NEW JERSEY

title: A Mind of Their Own
description: Susan Dominuss article on the Hogan twins, Krista and Tatiana, and their family was sensitive and insightful. Throughout, Dominus suggests the under-explored relationship among philosophy, spirituality and science. She does so without ever losing sight of these extraordinary little girls in all of their humanity. Most especially, the author is content with leaving questions unanswered. She acknowledges that there is much we dont know. The girls provide the opportunity to revel in the questions, the mystery, that motivate great scientific discovery and artistic innovation.

title: Entering Darkness
description: Last month I went to a particularly cavelike theater (the basement walls, outside the bathrooms, were covered with synthetic stone) to see Cave of Forgotten Dreams, Werner Herzogs 3-D documentary about cave paintings. The film is a rapturous tour of the Chauvet cave in southern France, a dramatic pocket of rock that was discovered, in 1994, to contain the oldest known paintings in the history of the world: portraits, up to 32,000 years old, of bison, mammoths, reindeer, lions, bears and woolly rhinoceroses  the improbable megafauna of southern France during the last ice age.

title: The Getaway Car

We live in Seattle, and in the Pacific Northwest, collegeland, as my daughter calls it, is centered in New England and New York, where most of her immediate friends will be going in September.

title: Sticker Shock and Awe
description: Saturday night, Las Vegas. In this mecca of extreme retail, shops remain open as late as midnight, like fancy bodegas, because even a craving for Balenciaga ballet flats should have the option of satisfying itself on demand. While overall consumer spending still hasnt recovered from the recession, there are signs that luxury spending may be on the rise. High-end retailers (Tiffany & Company, Herms, Saks Inc.) have reported first-quarter gains. In America, analysts note, the wealthiest 2 percent of the population has been doing most of the buying. Where does this leave Las Vegas, purveyor of luxury for the masses?

title: The Perfumed Cuban
description: In three days, I saw, heard and ate things that you see, hear and eat only on a 3,280-mile Greyhound trip across the United States. I also smelled unusual things. Battle Mountain, a town in Nevada that The Washington Post once called the armpit of America didnt actually reek of rancid sweat. It smelled like clean desert air and the sweetness of boredom. If I close my eyes, I can smell the burritos they sell at 4 a.m. in Wendover, Utah, near the base where the pilots who dropped the atomic bombs were trained. They smelled like melted plastic. After this trip across 11 states, Im also familiar with the odor of the toilets at the station in Des Moines and the candied peanuts they sell outside the Port Authority in Manhattan, my final destination.

title: Going for Broken
description: We paddled canoe-style; I sat in the middle and Marie at the stern. The water was clean and cold and deserted. We circled an island. Dead branches washed up in piles along the banks, making intricate symmetrical reflections in the nearly still water. Nathaniel Hawthorne described a ride on the Erie Canal in 1835 as so tiresome. From our small, slow rowboat, I found it mesmerizing.

title: Whats Up, Doc? New Looney Tunes, With an Assist From Mel Blanc
description: Thats not quite all for the motion-picture career of the Looney Tunes, or for Mel Blanc, the versatile voice artist and comedian who helped bring to life the animated antics of Daffy Duck and Tweety Bird. Those speech-impeded cartoon characters, along with Sylvester the Cat, Elmer Fudd, Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner are set to return in a new series of 3-D computer generated shorts that will use some vocals previously recorded by Blanc, and which will begin appearing with Warner Brothers movies in the fall, the studios animation division said.

title: Pensionscare
description: Via Andrew Leonard, the rise in stocks since the financial crisis has made the financial position of public employee pension funds much better:

title: Add Audacity To Understatement, And Stir In Patience
description: TEARS gathered in the creases of Nikolaj Hbbes eyes, but he wasnt crying. Do you really suppose hes changed that much in the three years since he left New York for Copenhagen? He was shaking from laughter, and his laughter was directed at himself.

title: Hail the Amateur, Loved by the Crowd
description: THE crowd is taking over. Tasks that have traditionally been performed by highly skilled professionals are increasingly being outsourced to the masses, often with surprising results. And its not only production that is being crowd sourced. Judgments about the quality of that production, traditionally determined by experts, are also being turned over to the crowd. Champions of crowd sourcing claim that tapping the talents of the many, even the amateur or untrained many, can often meet or surpass the efforts of the expert few.

title: Friday Reading: Its a Sellers Market For Used Cars
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Snowmelt in the Rockies Just Isnt the Same
description: The summary of the new United States Geological Survey paper in Science Magazine was blunt. Over the past millennium, late-20th-century snowpack reductions are almost unprecedented in magnitude across the northern Rocky Mountains, it said.

title: Dispute Between Vietnam and China Escalates Over Competing Claims in South China Sea
description: BEIJING  Vietnam said on Friday that it would conduct live-fire naval exercises off its coast next week, a step that escalated a long-running dispute with China over territory in the South China Sea that both nations claim.

description: POUL RUDERS: PIANO CONCERTO NO. 2, BEL CANTO, SERENADE ON THE SHORES OF THE COSMIC OCEAN

title: West-Eastern Divan Orchestra
description: TCHAIKOVSKY: SYMPHONY NO. 6; SCHOENBERG: VARIATIONS FOR ORCHESTRA (OP. 31)

title: A Reunion of Sorts: Two Pieces of Unpublished Austen Novel Are Both in New York
description: Beginning on Saturday the two manuscript parts of the unfinished and unpublished Jane Austen novel known as The Watsons will not be reunited, exactly, but will be closer theyve been in almost 100 years  just 35 blocks or so from each other. The first part of the manuscript, some 12 pages, was sold during World War I to benefit the Red Cross, and now belongs to the Morgan Library & Museum. The rest, 68 pages which had been in private hands in England until recently, is going on display for a week at Sothebys before being shipped back to London, where it will be auctioned off in mid-July.

title: Unforgivable Behavior, Except When Its Not
description: Lying publicly about something like this is unforgivable and he should resign.  Tim Kaine, former chairman, Democratic National Committee, on Representative Anthony D. Weiner.

title: Golly Gee, By Jove!
description: Just one of my periodic reminders: quite a few otherwise reasonable comments have to be rejected because they contain obscenities. I know thats the way all of us !@#$%^& talk these days, but this is a Times blog.

title: G.M. Recalls Nearly 47,500 Cadillac SRX Crossovers to Repair Faulty Curtain Air Bag
description: General Motors is recalling about 47,500 of its 2011 Cadillac SRX crossovers in the United States because an air-curtain air bag may not deploy in a crash, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The action is part of a North American recall that affects roughly 50,500 vehicles.

title: Afghan Leader Seeks Pakistani Help in Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan arrived in Islamabad on Friday for a two-day visit, which was being viewed as an effort to ensure Pakistani help in the peace talks he has initiated with the Taliban.

title: Indias Way: Jim Yardley Responds to Readers on Development in Gurgaon
description: I want to thank everyone for all the thoughtful comments about the Gurgaon story. India is one of the most fascinating assignments in the world, if occasionally a vexing one, given its complexities and contradictions. In the Indias Way series, we hope to examine how India works  and doesnt work. We want to look at how it has grown, examine the unique ways Indians are trying to move their country forward and also explore the challenges ahead.

title: Assisted Living or a Nursing Home?
description: Like so many adult children, Catherine Hawes confronted The Promise. You may have experienced this fraught conversation, too: Your elderly parent grasps your hand and pleads, Promise me youll never put me in a nursing home.

title: Just One Look | 3.1 Phillip Lim Resort Collection
description: Phillip Lims Resort collection is based in utility rather than fantasy, designed for what he describes as the artificial nature we create for ourselves in our urban environments.

title: The View From Behind the Betting Windows
description: Elizabeth Minkel started taking bets at Saratoga in 2003. She still moonlights as a parimutuel clerk, but she spends most of her time working as a production editor and books blogger for The New Yorker.

title: Fair or Not, James Needs a Title to End the Daily Hounding
description: Dallas

title: Stocks Plunge Amid Fears That Global Economy Is Slowing
description: Investors anxious about the outlook for global economic growth sent stocks sharply downward on Friday as the Dow closed below 12,000 for the first time since March.

title: Fountain Is Reopening, but Not to Splash In
description: The new Whale Tail Fountain in the heart of New London, Conn., will reopen in the next few days, but it will now be used as a true fountain, and children will no longer be allowed to splash around in its gently gushing waterfall.

title: Security Checks on Boaters Disrupt Idyllic Life on the Hudson
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  For Bill OBrien, summer had meant the bliss of the Hudson River ever since he went out fishing for stripers as a boy. But last year, after he was stopped once too often by law enforcement patrol boats with armed officers, he decided he had had it. He sold his 22-foot jet boat, convinced that a once-restful afternoon on the Hudson was just becoming too stressful to enjoy.

title: Your Own Facts
description: Just Google it! has become a common cyber-snobbish response to questions that seem too trivial to merit a human conversation. But is it really an answer? Now that more and more Internet sites are tailoring their services to the idiosyncrasies of individual users, queries for climate change, stem cells and even pizza may yield different outcomes for different people. This may be an era when we are increasingly entitled to our own facts  but should we also be entitled to our own search results?

title: Negative Online Data Can Be Challenged, at a Price
description: THE Web is like an elephant  it never forgets, and if let loose it can cause a lot of trouble.

title: Fill-In | June Events in History
Tracy Morgan Apologizes for Anti-Gay Comments
description: 8:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Spain Approves Measure to Free Up Labor Market
description: MADRID  The Spanish government approved Friday measures intended to reduce chronically high unemployment by introducing more flexibility in labor relations, despite failing to get support from employers and unions for the changes.

title: Paul Watson Recalls Civil Wars Whale Wars
description: .Heres a short second segment of the interview I conducted last week with Paul Watson, the leader of the Sea Shepherd campaign that cut short Japans Southern Ocean whale hunt this year. (Part one is here.) He describes a book he is writing about the first real whale war, one that long predated his effort and the Whale Wars television series.

title: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary
description: HEART disease remains the No. 1 cause of death in the United States, killing more than 800,000 people each year, and accounting for one in three of all deaths. It is no wonder, then, that screening for heart disease is a routine part of just about every physical exam given in this country.

title: As Ally Delays Offering, How Have G.M. and A.I.G. Done?
description: In deciding to delay its planned initial public offering, Ally Financial is citing adverse market conditions.

title: Exploring the World of Travel Options
description: Whether you are trying to find the best time to travel to a favorite spot or have no destination in mind, a little-known travel tool, Kayak Explore, can help you find the best flight deals to hundreds of cities across the globe.

title: Joe Drapes Belmont Stakes Picks
description: The New York Racing Association oddsmaker Eric Donovan set the morning line odds, and Joe Drape lists the selections in order of preference for Saturdays 143rd running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Jerusalem Outings Go Beyond the Biblical
description: CASBAH-LIKE alleys lined with stone houses wound upward toward hills cloaked in pine and cypress trees. Hand-painted signs beckoned visitors to the shops and studios of jewelers, potters and other artisans. Just past a popular brunch spot with a packed terrace, Christian pilgrims from Russia, Poland and the United States gathered around a spring where Mary and Elizabeth, the mother of John the Baptist, were said to have met.

title: Storm Claims a Venerable Catalpa Tree
description: Thursday nights storm, in addition to forcing the cancellation of the Black-Eyed Peas concert in Central Park, uprooted and knocked down Dave Thoms catalpa tree. It had stood in front of Mr. Thoms house on West 217th Street in Inwood since at least 1934, where it appears, manicured into a delightful umbrella shape, in the city tax photo below.

title: After 30-Year Hiatus, the Return of the IndyCar Doubleheader
description: On Saturday night, Texas Motor Speedway will host the Firestone Twin 275s, the first IndyCar doubleheader since June 28, 1981, when Rick Mears swept two 125-mile races at Atlanta. Saturdays two 114-lap, 275-kilometer (171 miles) races replace the Firestone 550, which traditionally is held at the Fort Worth track at this time of year.

title: Giant Rat Will Miss Tonys Red Carpet After Deal Is Reached With Stagehands
description: The Broadway stagehands union will not have a picket line by the red carpet at the Tony Awards on Sunday evening, after reaching an agreement on Friday morning with the managers of the awards festivities to allow union workers to stage the carpet, according to representatives of both sides. The union and the Tony ceremony managers had been in a public standoff over the last 36 hours, with the clock ticking to set up the red carpet.

title: In Germany, Watch Out for Communion!
description: During the swine-flu crisis of 2009, I was living in Germany. I remember bicycling to work down Friedrichstrasse, one of Berlins main arteries, passing all the newsstands lined up outside convenience stores. The headlines of Bild, Germanys best-read and most hysterical tabloid, were printed in such large type that I could take in the days news as I biked by. Often I would see one rather ugly word: SCHWEINEGRIPPE!!!

title: Call It a Night, or Wait Out the Rain?
description: As Ben Shpigel reported in Fans at Stadium Who Waited Had Plenty of Time to Dry Off, the Yankees expected C.C. Sabathia to throw his first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night two hours before he eventually did, at 10:32 p.m.

title: Out and About in Jerusalem
description: An artists colony, an Arab-Israeli town, a hike in the forest and some great food.

title: Monetary Calvinball
description: I was trying to come up with a way to describe Raghuram Rajans latest on why interest rates should go up despite high unemployment and quiescent inflation  but Mike Konczal saved me the trouble.. As Mike says, its Calvinball  making up new rules on the fly to justify whatever you, for some reason, want. And todays column was about that reason.

title: World Food Supply: Whats To Be Done?
description: In a long article on Sunday and a string of posts on the Green blog this week, The Times has given readers a large body of reporting and analysis on the global food situation, including the risk to the food supply from climate change. I would like to end that run of coverage by pointing concerned readers toward the best thinking out there that tries to answer this question:

title: Big Deal | An Update on the Apthorp
description: Like most apartment hunters, Steven M. Goldman knew he was going to have to do some homework on the building he chose.

title: Where Private Borrowing Led to Public Debt
description: FIVE years ago, a survey of the euro zone would have shown two star countries. They were growing rapidly and running government budget surpluses. Their national debts were low. Other countries sought to emulate their success.

title: State Farm Tweaks Campaign to Compete With Rivals
description: What hath Geico wrought?

title: Joe Liebermans Plan to Make Health Care Worse and More Expensive
description: So Joe Lieberman is proposing that we raise the Medicare eligibility age. Thats a truly cruel idea; as it happens, I know several people who are hanging on, postponing needed medical care, hoping that they can make it to 65 before something terrible happens. And if I know such people in my fairly sheltered social circles, just imagine how widespread such stories must be.

title: Electric, if Not Electrifying: Cars for Short-Range Commutes
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: Qaddafi Writes to Congress
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has written to members of Congress thanking them for criticizing President Obama last week over his involvement in the NATO-led military campaign in Libya.

title: For Gay Aspiring Politicians, a Workshop on Campaign Strategies
description: PITTSBURGH  As a gay person running for the City Council in Houston, which already has a lesbian mayor, Josh Verde figured he would have no trouble talking to voters about his sexuality. Then he came here, to a boot camp for openly gay candidates, and promptly flubbed his lines.

title: Did J.F.K. Lose Berlin?
description: On Aug. 13, 1961, Robert H. Lochner drove to the eastern sector of Berlin. A radio director in the citys American sector, Lochner used a hidden tape recorder to capture stories of families who were suddenly trapped in the East by the decision to build the Berlin Wall. Thousands had been fleeing each week, threatening the Communist states viability. Now Lochner watched as an elderly woman timorously walked up to one of the transport policemen and inquired when the next train was due for West Berlin. He never forgot the officers contemptuous response: That is all over. You are all sitting in a mousetrap now.

title: Baking a Better Breadstick
description: On the popular television show Glee, the ultimate prize for a great performance is a trip to a restaurant called Breadstix. And in the real world, breadsticks are a main attraction at restaurants like the Olive Garden, and even pizza delivery services have gotten on the breadstick bandwagon.

title: U.S. Weighs Cancer Risk of Styrene and Formaldehyde
description: WASHINGTON  Government scientists are expected today to declare styrene a likely human carcinogen, a move that manufacturers have long feared. Styrene is used to make those ubiquitous white foam coffee cups and food containers and is widely used in building materials.

title: Russian Officer Jailed for Chechen Murder Is Killed
description: MOSCOW  A former Russian tank commander who was paroled early after being jailed for the murder of a young Chechen woman was shot to death in central Moscow on Friday in what the police said was probably a contract killing.

title: Despite Crackdown, New Video Emerges of Defiant Protesters in Syria
description: Last Updated | 6:58 p.m. As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Liam Stack report, even as the Syrian military moved to take control of a strategically important town near the Turkish border on Friday, protesters took to the streets in other parts of the country.

title: Breaking Up Morgan Stanley
description: Analyst Brad Hintz has a solution for Morgan Stanleys flailing stock price: Send the company to the chop shop.

title: The Unhappiness Project
description: Its hard to think of a less privileged creation than the second novel. When we admire a writers debut, its like falling in love across a crowded room; we are seduced by a part that we have mistaken for the whole. And when the follow-up reveals, as it must, a more complex picture than we at first believed we saw, our feelings are mixed. And so Dean Bakopouloss second novel, My American Unhappiness, is already at a disadvantage; if you liked his first one, you can be certain only that this one wont be the same.

title: A Critics Take on the Mortgage Modification Program
description: The Treasury Department announced penalties on Thursday against three of the nations largest banks for what it said was poor performance in the governments main foreclosure prevention program.

title: Good When He Needed to Be Great
description: The N.B.A. finals have become the LeBron James microscope, all powers of examination trained almost solely on him. Dirk Nowitzki as heroic leader? Dwyane Wade playing through pain and proving himself the Biggest of the Three? Jason Terry backing up his big talk with a crucial shot? In a real basketball world, those are all valid developments, but in Jamess basketball world, they are reduced to background noise.

title: Belmont Awaits Its Annual Return to Glory
description: If the last couple of years are any indication, about 50,000 fans will show up at Belmont Park on Saturday to watch the running of the 143rd Belmont Stakes, the premier race on the New York State calendar.

title: The Golden Age of the Secretary
description: In 1977, the group Women Office Workers held a contest for secretaries, inviting them to name the most ridiculous personal errand theyd ever run. As Lynn Peril tells it in Swimming in the Steno Pool, her light, wry history of the secretarial profession, the winner was a woman whose boss asked her to take pictures of him before, while and after he shaved off his moustache. The runner-ups task was to pick up her bosss wife and newborn baby from the hospital.

title: Its Hot, and These First Graders Are Bothered
description: Beware the fury of a first grader scorched.

title: Saudi Arabia, Defying OPEC, Will Raise Its Oil Output
description: In the wake of an unruly OPEC meeting, Saudi Arabia has decided to go it alone and raise production substantially in the coming weeks to meet rising global demand.

title: Ellen Williss Pioneering Rock Criticism
description: Woodstock was a rip-off. Creedence Clearwater Revival eclipsed the Rolling Stones. Bob Dylan struggled with identity. Janis Joplin was not so much a victim as a casualty. As the first pop critic for The New Yorker, Ellen Willis wrote deeply original commentary on the music that defined a generation. She wrote about landmark figures and events in prescient, unpredictable ways. She wasnt so much cranky  others pioneered that rock-crit stereotype  as she was rhapsodic, a fan who could be vociferously vexed by self-indulgent albums and overpriced shows. So vexed, eventually, that in the 1980s she turned her formidable analytical and literary skills to matters of (to Willis at least) greater weight: feminism, global politics, freedom.

title: Strahan Joins Same-Sex Marriage Campaign
description: Michael Strahan, the former Giants defensive end, has joined the quest to legalize same-sex marriage in New York.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Big Apple Barbecue Block Party will have 16 pit masters from across the country at Madison Square Park (Madison Avenue between 23rd and 26th Streets) once again this Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Plates of food are $8. There will be live music and cooking demonstrations throughout the two-day event. One note: go early, since some vendors often run out of food. On Friday, a preview party at the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues), from 6 to 8 p.m., includes food, drinks and films. Tickets for that party are $100 online. If youd rather watch the pit masters setting up and smoking meats between 7 and 9 p.m., Blue Smoke will serve some food and drinks during a V.I.P. party that costs $250 per person but includes a FastPass for two allowing access to an express lane (those passes are sold out otherwise) and $100 for food and drinks. Proceeds from the event benefit the Madison Square Park Conservancy.

title: You Look Great and Other Lies
description: MY friend sat down and ordered a stiff drink. I didnt think of her as the stiff-drink kind. An hour later, after our spouses drifted off into conversation, she leaned over the table. I need your help, she said. My sister has a brain tumor. I dont know what to do.

title: The Constitution After 9/11
description: At 11 oclock on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, David K. Shipler experienced what he describes, immodestly if not inaccurately, as a moment of extreme clarity. While most of us remained glued to our television sets in a post-traumatic daze, Shipler evidently sought nobler ground. His thoughts turned to the first 10 amendments of our nations Constitution. There go our civil liberties, he recalls thinking.

title: Squeezing 4-Wheeled Masterpieces Into the Museum
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: 16 Automobiles Worth a Spot in a Museum
description: THESE are the 16 cars in the Allure of the Automobile exhibition at the Portland Art Museum:

title: A Novel as Big as America
description: Near the end of his vast new historical novel, A Moment in the Sun, John Sayles describes a street performer who built an elaborate house of tiles on his little table, balancing one upon the other till the structure was almost up to his chin. Spectators bet against the master architect and his precarious creation, but he keeps adding tiles and winning wagers. This performer is, of course, a stand-in for Sayles himself, who has also built an elaborate house of tiles and managed, against all odds, to keep it standing. The book opens in 1897, the year of the Klondike gold rush, and closes in 1903, the year after the Philippine-American War ended, and in between it takes the measure of America on the brink of the 20th century.

title: Notes From the Underground | Macao Madness
description: The word on the street is that no one ever leaves Macao Trading Co. sober. The restaurant cum lounge is a haven for all manner of cool kids and gourmet-food chasers, and the management loves to get the customers sauced and smiling. As a no-holds-barred celebration of this mentality, the lounge, in collaboration with a performer who goes by the name Calamity Chang, hosts an annual Drunken Dragon Festival, where for five hours a completely free open bar and passed hors doeuvres menu attract a cast of hundreds costumed in either 1940s colonial or Chinese attire. At the most recent incarnation of the event, several burlesque performers took over the main room, which was packed with revelers and covered in a blanket of confetti. And yes, the snake is real. A smaller version of the madness, Drunken Dragon Nights, is held weekly, downstairs at Macao, and features live burlesque performances. Go tomacaonyc.com.

title: Lessons From Jane Austen
description: In 1990, William Deresiewicz was on his way to gaining a Ph.D. in English literature at Columbia University. Describing that time in the opening pages of his sharp, endearingly self-effacing new book, A Jane Austen Education, Deresiewicz explains that he faced one crucial obstacle. He loathed not just Jane Austen but the entire gang of 19th-century British novelists: Hardy, Dickens, Eliot . . . the lot.

title: The Idea of Germany, From Tacitus to Hitler
description: Why is there a Germany? Part of the answer goes back to a battle fought in A.D. 9 in the treacherous marshes and dense thickets of Teutoburg Forest, near modern Osnabrck. As described by the Roman historian Tacitus, three Roman legions led by Quinctilius Varus had crossed the Rhine from Gaul, intent on incorporating the vast area known as Germania into the empire. They were ambushed and annihilated by German tribes under the command of a warrior named Arminius. It was one of the worst military disasters the Romans ever suffered. Some years ago, archaeologists discovered the site of the battle; the debris field was a mile wide and 15 miles long. Caesar Augustus, it is said, roamed the hallways of his palace, crying, Quinctilius Varus, give me back my legions! Henceforth, the Romans pretty much wrote off the area east of the Rhine and north of the Alps. The line of demarcation survives to this day as a cultural divide  beer versus wine, butter versus oil, Germanic versus Romance.

title: A Memoir of Self-Destruction and Therapy
description: Emma Forrests memoir, Your Voice in My Head, is part of a literary tradition that began long before Susanna Kaysens girlhood was interrupted or Elizabeth Wurtzel got her first Prozac prescription. Indeed, on her books first page Forrest invokes the patron saint of mentally ill beauties with bad taste in men, as she describes how, at 13, she began making regular pilgrimages after school to the Tate in London, to visit Millaiss portrait of the drowned Ophelia. I believe that she infected me, she writes. I was afraid . . . that I saw in her my own destiny.

title: Sleeping With the Gestapo
description: William E. Dodd was an academic historian, living a quiet life in Chicago, when Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed him United States ambassador to Germany. It was 1933, Hitler had recently been appointed chancellor, the world was about to change.

title: Beach Retreat, Baggage Included
description: Ah, family. Isnt it satisfying to leave your own briefly behind to drop in on another  and see how thoroughly they bungle it all up? This is the pleasure of Maine, J. Courtney Sullivans second novel, which delves into the secrets and simmering emotions of one dysfunctional family over the course of a single summer month.

title: Alaska Releases Palin E-Mails
description: [live_updates]

title: Senator Criticizes S.E.C. Over Response to SAC Inquiry
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley chastised the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday for failing to detail how it handled nearly 20 referrals of suspicious trading at a major hedge fund, the latest salvo in an escalating face-off between the Iowa Republican and the commission.

title: Crosses That Bear the Past
description: IF you are suffering from a surfeit of repressed emotions, why not pay a visit to Midtown Manhattan? The steaming summer heat gives you the perfect excuse to blow your cool with all the unprintable expletives your heart desires.

title: Caucus | The Gingrich Campaign Implodes
description: June 10, 2011 - Michael D. Shear on what's left of the Newt Gingrich campaign. Also, Jim Rutenberg previews the release of thousands of pages of Sarah Palin's old emails.

title: Appropriated Landscapes in Ulm
description: Ulm, a small German city on the Danube, entered the contemporary photography scene with last years opening of the Walther Collection, a small museum founded by Artur Walther, a native of Ulm and former Wall Street banker. Mr. Walthers collection of about 1,100 works from the late 19th to the early 21st centuries is noteworthy for its Chinese and African photographs.

title: On the Erie Canal
description: Dana Spiotta joins Sebastio Salgado and J. J. Sullivan in this weeks issue.In her review of Spiottas novel Eat the Document, about two radicals on the lam, Michiko Kakutani credited her with erecting an elliptical narrative filled with musical leitmotifs and searing, strobe-lighted images of contemporary life  a narrative that immerses us, headfirst, in the chaos and incongruities of the American scene while goading us into a melancholy contemplation of the countrys penchant for discarding the past.

title: A Father With Regrets
description: Friday, Steph asked to hear from parents who regretted having children. Most of you assured her that parents rarely regret the children they have, but sprinkled amid the many comments were a few that were starkly sad. Most of those were from mothers, and they were about the added price women seem to pay  in sleep, income, ambition, time, status  when they have children.

title: Still Cute, but Now Sunny as Well
description: TESTED 2012 Fiat 500C

title: Far Beyond the Clothes
description: Elegance seemed to go viral in the photographs of George Hoyningen-Huene. A Russian migr in Paris in the 1920s, and a baron at that, Huene produced an exquisite quality of longing  or was it remoteness?  in the pages of French Vogue, where he was chief photographer in the most glamorous of 20th-century decades. You might say that Huene (pronounced HEW-neh) sealed the deal between modern-thinking couturiers and photographers, seducing us with light and classical forms. Afterward, nothing seemed the same. In her review of a 2001 exhibition that brought together Huene and his great friend Horst, the critic Vicki Goldberg noted the two Hs influenced almost everyone else.

title: Erik Larsons new best-seller; Emily Gould on Your Voice in My Head, the new memoir by Emma Forrest
description: This week: Dorothy Gallagher on Erik Larsons new best-seller, In the Garden of Beasts; Emily Gould discusses Your Voice in My Head, the new memoir by Emma Forrest; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Paperback Row
description: A GREAT UNRECORDED HISTORY: A New Life of E. M. Forster,  by Wendy Moffat (Picador, $20.) Between 1905 and 1924, E. M. Forster (1879-1970) published five novels, including Howards End and A Passage to India. Moffats perceptive biography explores the 46 years of relative silence that followed, drawing a picture of a sensitive, influential novelist whose homosexuality explained much, but certainly not all, of his mystery.

title: Editors Choice
description: SISTER,  by Rosamund Lupton (Crown, $24.) In Luptons novel, which is both tear-jerking and spine-tingling, a free-spirited sisters death  perhaps it was murder  forces a highly conventional woman to examine the truth of their relationship.

title: Inside the List
description: TIME TRAVELER: David Eagleman, who hits the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 14 with Incognito: The Secret Lives of the Brain, is the kind of guy who really does make being a neuroscientist look like fun. His experiments tend to involve things like dropping people off amusement park thrill rides (to measure the way time seems to slow down during near-death experiences) and hanging out in the studio with Brian Eno and the drummer from Coldplay (to see how professional timekeepers stay precisely on the beat). He wears hip ankle boots and designer jeans while dashing between TED talks and his lab at Baylor. In his spare time, Eagleman has even written an acclaimed collection of speculative short stories, Sum: Forty Tales From the Afterlives, that will be staged as a full opera in London next year. Hes also getting some traction with his efforts to start a new quasi-religious movement called Possibilianism, which aims to move beyond the dueling certitudes of traditional religion and atheism to explore radical what-ifs about the universe and human consciousness. One story in Sum, for example, considers the possibility that life on earth may be just a brief, pleasurable vacation from our true existence as gigantic beings doing the heavy lifting of holding up the cosmos. (If you are thinking of dying, Alexander McCall Smith wrote in the Book Review in 2009, this book may not exactly increase your peace of mind.)

title: Cleaning Up an Online Reputation
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, takes note of the women who received Representative Anthony Weiners texts to make the point that their names will be forever linked to his in any online search. Yes, this is a high-profile example, but Paul says that all sorts of people can be negatively branded on the Web, even if they did nothing wrong.

title: Video: Gingrich Campaign Implodes; Palin E-Mails Released
description: Michael D. Shear on the next steps for the Newt Gingrich campaign. Also, Jim Rutenberg previews the release of thousands of pages of Sarah Palins old e-mails.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Slice of Sales-Clerk Life
description: Paying for It, the memoir about prostitution by the cartoonist Chester Brown, has had to share the hardcover list with a lot of superheroes. But this week it is joined by Life With Mr. Dangerous, by the cartoonist Paul Hornschemeier, the fictional, slice-of-life story of Amy Breis. It is No. 6 on the list this week.

title: Perpendicular to Brunch
description: ON a recent Sunday, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was bustling at midday. You couldnt move on the main drag of Bedford Avenue, between the people milling, the sidewalk vendors selling, and the groups jockeying for position in the sport of brunch. Day-trippers from Manhattan were headed for Smorgasburg, the food extension of the Brooklyn Flea; a line had formed outside Blue Bottle Coffee over on Berry Street; and the sign-up sheet at Egg, the little breakfast place on North Fifth Street, was oversubscribed.

title: At Video Game Convention, a Crowded Field of Winners
description: LOS ANGELES  For anyone involved with the video game industry, surviving the E3 convention is an annual rite of passage. Many of the tens of thousands of developers, journalists and PR people here find themselves attending up to 16 hours of meetings each day for four or even five days straight, giving the whole thing the feeling of summer camp meets the Bataan Death March. In a good way. After all, were talking about video games.

title: Croatia Given Conditional Approval to Join E.U. in 2013
description: LONDON  After six arduous years of talks on its bid for European Union membership, Croatia was told Friday that it should be able to join in 2013, but that its efforts to combat corruption and reform its judiciary will be monitored in the meantime in case they slip.

title: Twitters Secret Handshake
description: CHARLIE SHEENS meltdown took many forms: a cocaine-fueled rampage in a New York hotel room, an erratic radio rant, a vulgar one-man comedy tour. But his biggest contribution to current culture may have been more subtle. With a simple Twitter phrase, #winning, known in the parlance of social media as a hashtag, Mr. Sheen underscored one of the newest ways technology has changed how we communicate.

title: Thousands Flee in Sudan as North-South Clashes Grow, U.N. Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The northern Sudanese military is on a house-to-house hunt for opposition forces in the embattled city of Kadugli, near Sudans disputed internal border, as intensifying clashes are forcing tens of thousands of people to flee, United Nations officials said on Friday.

title: Expanding the Cultural Realm in Singapore
description: ON a balmy Saturday evening last summer in the Dhoby Ghaut neighborhood of Singapore, a few hundred people  residents and in-the-know tourists  stood or sat in rows of plastic chairs taking swigs of Tiger Beer retrieved from an ice-filled inflatable kids pool.

title: Restaurant Report: Two One Two Bar and Grill in Mumbai
description: Over the last few years, the Mumbai dining scene has been bombarded with hip openings competing for attention from a group of increasingly well-heeled residents. While the ambience at these restaurants might be buzzing, the food doesnt necessarily impress. The upscale Italian bote Two One Two Bar and Grill, which opened just over a year ago, is different: although the glamour set has already descended here, the draw is decidedly on the menu.

title: Hollywood Comeback Trail
description: A COMEBACK has been underway in Hollywood  that famous glamour-meets-grit area of Los Angeles  for over a decade now. But over the last few years, the revitalization has moved eastward along Hollywood Boulevard or, as movie fans know it, the star-paved Walk of Fame. Most of the recent renewal has been concentrated around Hollywood and Vine, perhaps the citys most famous intersection. While souvenir shops and tattoo parlors are still part of the areas kitschy charm, they now share sidewalk space with high-class hotels, refined bars and restaurants and even a new Trader Joes outlet.

title: Its Back to Nature at Rustic Spas in Quebec
description: A SOFT summer rain stippled the surface of the lake. As I toweled off my racer-back Speedo after a chilly swim, I spotted a muskrat busy building a nest beneath the willows. As campsites go, this clearing 30 miles northeast of Quebec City in the foothills of the Laurentian Mountains offered tranquillity. Except it wasnt a backcountry destination  it was a spa with a wild streak.

title: Fork by Northwest
description: To eat in and around Seattle, isnt merely to eat well. It is to experience an exhilarating sense of place.

title: Letters: Off-Season Summer
description: To the Editor: Re Traveling Off-Season, in Summer (Practical Traveler, May 29): If you go to Greece and avoid Athens and the popular islands, there are a lot of other lovely places to visit on the mainland that will remind people of what the islands were like 30 years ago. The less popular islands are also great. Small hotels can be very affordable and quite nice. You could easily spend $100 or less a day for off-the-beaten-path but still nice lodgings. Spend a little more and it would be even nicer, with hardly any company. Joseph Coates

description: Aaron Goldberg and Guillermo Klein

title: Aiming for the Fences With Our Belmont Picks
description: The Rails contributors welcome TWO guest pickers, Joe Torre and Mark Shapiro, for this years Belmont Stakes. Torre managed the Yankees from 1996-2007 and is now the executive vice president of baseball operations for Major League Baseball. Shapiro was the general manager for the Indians from 2001-2010 and is now the teams president. Torre has long been involved with horse racing, owning the 2010 Derby contender Homeboykris, who finished 16th. Maybe thats a good sign for the Indians (34-26), who open a four-game series tonight against the Yankees (33-27) at Yankee Stadium.

title: Italian Neorealism in Softer Hues

title: No Charges Are Brought in Kahlo Case

The Mexican trust that owns the copyright to Kahlos work says that the works are fakes and last year asked prosecutors to investigate.

title: Answers About Abuse in State-Run Institutions, Part 2

In his investigation, Danny Hakim of The Times reviewed thousands of state records and court documents and interviewed current and former employees at nine state-run institutions that house the developmentally disabled.

title: Just One Look | Helmut Lang Resort
description: It should surprise no one that Helmut Langs resort collection was dominated by macabre hues of gray and black. The asymmetrical lines of this silk dress follow the natural curvature of the body; it takes its inspiration from Jan Kempenaerss photographs of the Yugoslavian monuments known as Spomeniks. How silk can be modeled after concrete is as much a triumph of drapery as it is of ideological sculpture.

title: Ailey Dance Camp Coming to Newark
description: AileyCamp, a full-scholarship summer day camp with classes in dance technique for urban students, will come to Newark this summer. The announcement was made by officials at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Newark public schools and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The six-week program will be held at the Newark Arts High School, from July 5 to Aug. 12 for 100 middle-school students ages 11-14 from Newark schools.

Rey Pamatmat follows the same routine: Wake at 5 a.m., then two hours of ashtanga yoga followed by two hours of playwriting, before heading from Jackson Heights, Queens, to the East Village and his day job as a database manager at the Public Theater. He usually hits the sack at 10 p.m.  a lifestyle with which he has no complaints, he said, other than one: He has craved more time for writing.

title: Ristretto | On the Rocks
description: I became hooked on cold-brew coffee after working a construction job in New Orleans more than 10 years ago. It was strictly a regional thing then, everywhere in the Big Easy and nearly impossible to find elsewhere  you could find cold-brew concentrate in the supermarket, but most of the people I knew were given mayo jars full of the dark, dense liquid by an aunt or a grandmother. In the following years, I became a proselytizer for cold-brew coffee, gaining converts for a steep-and-strain method that seemed counterintuitive until you tried it.

title: First-Base Umpires Must Keep Eyes, and Ears, Open
description: A common exercise at umpire clinics is to blindfold students and have them call close plays at first base. Its not a frivolous thing. The idea is to teach the students to use their ears as an umpiring tool, to listen for the separate sounds of the foot on the bag and the ball in the glove  a thud and a pop, as the veteran major league umpire Mike Winters described them.

title: Woman Found Dead at Bonnaroo
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  A woman has been found dead at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, as the Associated Press reported, and was confirmed by the festivals organizers. The Coffee County Sheriffs office confirmed the death of a 32-year-old women from the Pittsburgh area this morning, and according to Sheriff Stephen M. Graves, the woman was found dead at her camp site by friends at 11 p.m. on Thursday, the opening night of the four-day festival. The state medical examiner will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death, according to the A.P. report. Her name has been withheld pending notification of her family.

title: Jorge Semprn, Who Blurred Line Between Novel and Memoir, Is Dead at 87
description: Jorge Semprn, a Spanish writer whose novelistic memoirs (or memoirish novels) drew on his experiences as a French Resistance fighter, concentration camp survivor, Communist organizer and Communist dissident, and who wrote distinguished screenplays for Alain Resnais, Costa-Gavras, Joseph Losey and other directors, died on Tuesday at his home in Paris. title: A Voice Actor Shows His Face and Hits the Road
description: JON BENJAMIN knows that you may well be unimpressed by his face. After all, youve probably never seen it, though his distinctive voice is familiar to viewers of the two animated series on which he currently plays the title roles, FXs Archer and Foxs Bobs Burgers. That rich, deep, deeply annoyed baritone seems at odds with the impish, bearded actor sipping soup in a downtown restaurant on a recent rainy afternoon. After fans meet him, he said, they often complain online that his looks didnt live up to their fantasies. To read peoples disappointment is really great, he said, laughing. His voice is so wonderful! But then they meet me, and its awful.

title: Playing Up the Music in That Musical

Rise Above 1, the first single from the cast album of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, was due for release in less than a week; it wasnt finished. Nor were the rest of the songs for the album, which arrives on Tuesday. Thats also the official opening night of the musical, with its songs by Bono and the Edge from U2. Its long, torturous run of Broadway previews has been  as a self-conscious new song lyric puts it  a $65 million circus tragedy. In separate interviews Bono and the Edge described the experience the same way: humbling.

So for this editors note on an issue filled with spectacular pictures, I asked the photography department to pick a few images they loved that did not make the print edition of our Voyages in America special issue. title: Concern About Stockpiles Pushes Corn to Record
description: Corn hit a record near $8 a bushel on Friday, on signs that global inventories would drop as bad weather slashes acreage in the United States, the worlds top producer, and demand rises for livestock feed and ethanol. Worldwide stockpiles will be 111.89 million metric tons before the 2012 harvest in the Northern Hemisphere, the Agriculture Department said Friday. That was down from 129.14 million forecast in May. Prices have more than doubled in the last year.

title: Judge Says Case Against Goldman Trader Will Proceed
description: Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors, failed in his bid for a dismissal of a lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission. While Judge Barbara Jones of United States District Court in Manhattan did narrow some of the claims in her decision on Friday, she said the S.E.C. had met its burden that Mr. Tourre had violated a law meant to prevent fraudulent sales of securities. The S.E.C. initially sued Mr. Tourre in April 2010, saying he had defrauded investors by not disclosing that the Paulson & Company hedge fund had helped pick the underlying securities for a collateralized debt obligation and planned to bet against them. Goldman and the S.E.C. agreed to a related $550 million settlement.

Then there is the minced chicken flatbread, which includes Thai basil, a soy reduction and Spanish Manchego cheese. Perhaps the ultimate marriage of East and West is the miso Caesar salad, with white miso and white anchovy fillets in the dressing.

Jaczko, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the subject of a harsh new investigative report from his own agency, finds himself in the cross-fire of a 30-year political battle over disposal of radioactive waste from the nations nuclear power plants and weapons program.

description: The Dallas-Miami series is proving just about as popular as last years Boston-Lakers finals. The average viewership through the first five games on ABC is 16.08 million, down slightly from 16.15 million last year. Game 5, which was won by Dallas on Thursday, generated 18.3 million viewers, down from last years 18.7 million.  Cappie Pondexter scored 21 points, including the winning jumper with 8.1 seconds left, to give the Liberty an 81-80 road victory over the Indiana Fever. Plenette Pierson added 13 points for the Liberty (2-0), which won after squandering an 18-point lead in the second half. (AP)

title: TimesCast | Secretary Gates Warns NATO
description: Defense Secretary Robert Gates issues a sharp warning to NATO in his final address.

title: Critics Fume Over Intensity of News Coverage for Palins Messages
description: News organizations mobilized teams of reporters and even recruited online volunteers to scan more than 24,000 pages of e-mails from Sarah Palin that were released on Friday, prompting some critics to accuse the news media of overkill at best and vigilantism at worst.

title: TimesCast | Sifting Fact From Fiction
description: New videos of Syrian security forces have surfaced online that contradict official government accounts.

title: At Picnic for Black Mormons, No Sign of Churchs Biased Past
description: COTTONWOOD HEIGHTS, Utah  On Christmas Day in 1964, the day before Darius A. Gray was to be baptized as a Mormon, he learned that the church would not allow a black man, like him, to be in the priesthood.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,450 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,599 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Opposition Is Split on How to Reshape Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  The protesters, arrayed in the tens of thousands under a blazing sun, pumped their fists in unison as they stood on the hot tarmac on Friday and chanted triumphantly, The people, at last, have defeated the regime!

title: A Slaughterhouse in Brooklyn, and Misery Next Door
description: For decades now, the pattern has been the same: New York City factories fall prey to the hunger for offbeat places to live, and once-gritty industrial neighborhoods like SoHo, TriBeCa, Dumbo and the meatpacking district are transformed into enviable residential enclaves.

title: Massachusetts: Six Seals Are Found Shot to Death
description: Six gray seals have been found shot to death in recent weeks on Cape Cod beaches. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is investigating, but it is unclear whether the seals were shot at sea or on land. Five were shot in the head, said Todd Nickerson, a special agent for the agency. A sixth was discovered on Friday and was still being analyzed, the International Fund for Animal Welfare said. All were discovered on beaches between Dennis and Chatham. New Englands seal population has been growing, and some fishermen have complained that the animals damage their nets and eat too many fish. Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, anyone who hurts or kills seals can face up to $100,000 in fines and a year in prison.

title: N.A.A.C.P. on Defensive as Suit on Charter Schools Splits Groups Supporters
description: In some ways, it seems like a natural cause for the N.A.A.C.P.: students  many of them poor, most of them black  treated as second-class citizens when the public schools they attended had to share buildings with charter schools. A lawsuit filed last month by the N.A.A.C.P. and the United Federation of Teachers described children having to eat lunch so early it might as well be breakfast, and getting less exercise because gym hours were evenly divided between the schools despite big differences in their enrollment sizes.

title: Cuomo Seeks Tougher Laws for Texting While Driving
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, joining officials in other states who have sought steep penalties for phone-wielding motorists, said on Friday he would introduce legislation to crack down on drivers who text, post on Twitter or otherwise distract themselves with handheld electronics while at the wheel.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Minnesota: F.B.I. Identifies Suicide Bomber
description: Federal authorities have identified a Minnesota man as one of the suicide bombers in an attack in Mogadishu, Somalia, on May 30. The man, Farah Mohamed Beledi, 27, was identified using his fingerprints, the F.B.I. said. Last summer, Mr. Beledi was charged with terrorism offenses in Minneapolis for joining the Shabab militant group in Somalia. The attack at a peacekeeping base in Mogadishu killed three people. The F.B.I. is seeking to identify a second suicide bomber in the attack.

title: Saturday: Attempt to Enter Dead Space
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Id like to personally thank Gary Cee for restoring my faith in myself as a solver. Not only was todays puzzle much easier for me than yesterdays Patrick Berry grid  quite a statement for a Saturday puzzle to begin with  but Mr. Cee was kind enough to include a snippet from the Rudyard Kipling poem Gunga Din that made me feel like I was a better, um, person for having attempted it.

title: Zimbabwes Mugabe Faces Pro-Democracy Push From Powerful Neighbor, South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG  As heads of state from across southern Africa meet here Saturday to wrestle yet again with Zimbabwes intractable crisis, the countrys 87-year-old strongman, Robert Mugabe, is facing a new reality: a strong and very public pro-democracy line from the regions most powerful country, South Africa.

title: Drug Bust
description: Friday marks the 40th anniversary of one of the biggest, most expensive, most destructive social policy experiments in American history: The war on drugs.

title: Computer Studies Made Cool, on Film and Now on Campus
description: NEW HAVEN  When Keila Fong arrived at Yale, she had never given much thought to computer science. But then last year everyone on campus started talking about the film The Social Network, and she began to imagine herself building something and starting a business that maybe, just maybe, could become the next Facebook.

title: Well, Its a Start
description: The New York State comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, has proposed an excellent way to clean up the costly and tainted campaigns for his powerful job. He has submitted a bill that creates the states first voluntary public campaign financing system, which would apply only to his office. To clean up Albanys muck, the state needs a much broader system. But this is a start.

title: Bonnaroo: Days 1 and 2
description: The Bonnaroo festival in Manchester, Tenn., which draws 80,000 rock fans for four days, kicked off on Thursday.

title: Remember Microsoft?
description: Steven Ballmer is going through a rough patch. Not only did the influential hedge fund manager David Einhorn call for him to step down from the top job at Microsoft, to give someone else a chance, Microsoft stock jumped right after he said it.

title: A Family Mourns as Bathers Return to a Beach
description: Beachgoers in bathing suits and the patter of residents speaking Russian: Brighton Beach on a hazy Friday in June.

title: Lottery Numbers
Weiner Confirms He Sent Private Messages to Girl, 17
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner said on Friday that he exchanged at least five private messages on Twitter this spring with a 17-year-old Delaware girl who became an admirer of his after hearing him speak during a high school trip to Washington.

description: More Photographs

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.
