description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Photo Replay: June 10
description: A look at the day in sports, from Rafael Nadals defeat to a glimpse of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Redistricting by Citizens Has Test in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Republicans and Democrats are battling across the country for advantage this year in drawing new Congressional and legislative districts in every state, based on new census data. California set out to do it differently, with an independent citizens commission, approved by voter initiative, designed to be insulated from the push-and-pull of partisan politics, a development that unsettled many elected officials here.

title: Lawyers for Guantnamo Detainees Allowed to See Leaked Files
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has eased restrictions preventing lawyers representing prisoners at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, from reading the classified files about their clients that were leaked to WikiLeaks and then made widely available on the Internet.

title: With Passion, Yankees Show Indians Theyve Had Enough
description: It all may have come a few days too late. But after a three-game sweep at the hands of the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees on Friday night finally displayed the sort of intensity and emotion  and generally strong play  that they had so lacked in an otherwise feckless week.

title: The First Shall Be Last: Recovering From a Financial Crisis
description: Tables rank European countries on economic growth, government budget surpluses or deficits and outstanding national debt.

title: Luongo and Canucks Turn the Tide
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  After four games and another two periods on Friday night, the hometown Canucks and the Boston Bruins entered the final period here deadlocked, two wins against two wins, 0-0 in Game 5. With two goaltenders near perfect and two offenses far from it, the final 20 minutes promised to shift these Stanley Cup finals in one direction.

title: Ethnic Protests in China Have Lengthy Roots
description: DAMAO BANNER, China  The Mongol nomads who have ranged across these blustery grasslands for millenniums have long had a tempestuous relationship with their Han Chinese neighbors to the south. Genghis Khans horseback conquerors overran Beijing in 1215, and Qing dynasty armies returned the favor four centuries later.

title: Bloggingheads: Being a Black Academic
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the position of the black public intellectual.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Hubris and Tension Reign at East Dillon
description: We are covering the final season of Friday Night Lights according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

title: Patrick Leigh Fermor, Travel Writer, Dies at 96
description: Patrick Leigh Fermor, the British writer whose erudite, high-spirited accounts of his adventures in prewar Europe, southern Greece and the Caribbean are widely regarded as classics of travel literature, died on Friday at his home in Worcestershire, England. He was 96.

title: With Abstentions, Iowa Questions Political Role
description: WASHINGTON  For decades, Iowa has served as the official kickoff for the presidential campaign, providing the first real test for candidates hoping to win their way to the White House.

title: Norman Redlich, Ex-Dean of N.Y.U. Law School, Dies at 85
description: Norman Redlich, a quiet luminary of the New York legal community who pioneered the pro bono defense of indigent death row inmates and who, as a staff member of the Warren Commission, helped develop the so-called single-bullet theory to explain how President John F. Kennedy was killed by a lone gunman, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: As Ex-Aides Speak Out, Gingrich Continues Bid
description: Newt Gingrich vowed on Friday to campaign for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination on his own terms, saying he would do whatever it takes to remain in the race despite the exodus a day earlier of nearly his entire senior staff.

title: Chamberlain Looks Ahead to Recovery After Surgery
description: What seemed inevitable is now official. Joba Chamberlain will have season-ending Tommy John surgery next Thursday, with the procedure to be performed by Dr. James Andrews, the renowned orthopedic surgeon, in Pensacola, Fla.

title: Toxic Coal Ash Spill in Tennessee
description: A coal ash pond ruptured and sent a billion gallons of toxic sludge across 300 acres of East Tennessee.

title: Bonnaroo: My Morning Jacket, on Main Stage for First Time
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  Live, with its simple song forms blown up to cathedral dimensions, the Kentucky band My Morning Jacket can suggest so many different sources that at least in print it looks ridiculous: Pink Floyd (in all eras), Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Rolling Stones, the Grateful Dead, Television, Prince, the early Paul McCartney solo records and Bob Dylans Nashville Skyline, which more than any other source seems to have given Jim James, the bands singer, his voice. That voice is soft and big and throaty; tonight at Bonnaroo, in a two-hour set that just ended (I write this at 10:15 on Friday night), he stuck his tongue halfway out on the loudest and highest falsetto notes.

title: One Festival Under Lil Wayne
description: This is what I came here for, right here, said a college boy next to me. It was a little after 2 a.m., and Lil Wayne had just cued the beginning of Im Single, his narcotic, spectral slow jam from last year. The fan rapped every word loudly, twice as loud as Lil Wayne did, but with the exact inflections. Dozens of college boys around him were doing the same thing. They all looked different, but had the same purpose.

title: The Weekend Word: Relevance
description: Todays Times

title: Small-Business Regulation Bill Gets (and Loses) a Vote
description: Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the top Republican on the Senate Small Business Committee, finally got the vote she sought for legislation that would make sweeping changes to federal rule making by requiring more deference to small-business interests. She lost, largely on party lines.

title: Rise and Shine, Little Raccoon
description: Awakening from a hot days nap. Wednesday, Riverside Park. Click to enlarge.

title: Deutsche Banks Chief Casts Long Shadow in Europe
description: FRANKFURT

title: Dancing With the Stars, Belmont Style
description: Molly Jo Rosen has been involved with thoroughbred racing from coast to coast: from Churchill Downs to TVG to Smarty Joness personal assistant to managing a major New York racing operation. She now runs Community Communications at GradeOneRacing, finds future superstars at 2yoSales.com, and serves her blend of pony punditry on her blog, Focused Filly.

title: Thoughts on Voodoo
description: With Tim Pawlenty  who was supposed to be a sensible Republican  going all-in for high voodoo, I thought its worth pointing out that at the moment theres a pretty good case that there is a kind of Laffer curve in which more is less and less is more. Namely, theres a good case that fiscal stimulus right now would actually improve the long-run fiscal situation, while fiscal austerity makes it worse.

title: Afghan Civilian Deaths Set a Monthly Record, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations announced Saturday that May was the deadliest month for Afghan civilians since it began keeping count in 2007  most likely a reflection of intense fighting, as militants seek to show they can stand up to the surge in American forces and try to undermine the government of President Hamid Karzai as it prepares to start taking over security.

title: Can Ticketmasters Builder Now Unseat It?
description: FREDRIC D. ROSEN has winked through Steely Dan, blinked through Neil Diamond and nodded through the Rolling Stones.

title: News Outlets Pounce on Palin E-Mails
description: News organizations that pored over nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday focused on her selection as Senator John McCains running mate in 2008, her relationship with the media and her style of governing.

title: Woods Is Out, but Always on the Mind
description: In the absence of Tiger Woods, the United States Open has seldom been more open than it will be, starting Thursday, at Congressional Country Club outside Washington.

title: Cause of the Yips Is Debated, but the Effect Isnt
description: Among the many embarrassments golf can dole out, missing a short putt may be the worst. The stroke starts with a twitch of the hands and a flip of the wrist, and then the ball lips out of the cup or skitters wide of the hole. And sometimes, with recreational golfers, the ball does not move at all because they have bounced the putter over it.

title: A Coveted Souvenir (Hair No Extra Charge)
description: In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasnt stopped going to the races since. That is when she isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Protests Challenge Japans Use of Nuclear Power
description: TOKYO  Beating drums and waving flowers, protesters in Tokyo and other major cities rallied against the use of nuclear power on Saturday, three months after a devastating tsunami set off a nuclear crisis.

title: I.M.F. Reports Cyberattack Led to Very Major Breach
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund, still struggling to find a new leader after the arrest of its managing director last month in New York, was hit recently by what computer experts describe as a large and sophisticated cyberattack whose dimensions are still unknown.

title: For James, Once Again, a Star Turn as Houdini
description: LeBron James is the N.B.A.s Harry Houdini, with a touch of wrestlings Gorgeous George.

title: Taking Your Feelings to Work
description: WHEN I graduated from college in 1977, the world was still neatly divided into two spheres: work and everything else. Work was supposed to be a hyperrational realm of logic, filled with timetables, organizational charts and returns on investment. It was only outside of work that emotions  so dangerously ill-defined and unpredictable  were supposed to emerge.

title: A Few (Middle) Seats Still Available
description: A pie chart that categorized the source of complaints to the Haggler would leave a gluttons slice for the airlines. Tales of doomed luggage, missed connections and fare disputes are legion, as are service reps and gate agents who say that they would love to help, if only they could.

title: The Power of the Pets
description: To the Editor:

title: The Class of 2011
description: Word usage in 40 speeches given at graduations this year.

title: Variety: Spiral With a Reason For Being
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  A reader asked me the other day about different methods for solving, and todays Spiral puzzle by Will Shortz made me wonder: Do you start from the inside, working out, or do you start from the exterior of the spiral? Do you fall into the a little of both camp, as the instructions suggest? How about blindfolded, just to set yourself an extra challenge?

title: The Annuity Question
description: To the Editor:

title: As Arizona Fire Rages, Officials Seek Its Cause
description: SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz.  There is no yellow police tape ringing the huge wildfire raging along Arizonas eastern flank, but the torched forest is a crime scene nonetheless.

title: Azerbaijan and Armenia Meet to End Land Dispute
description: MOSCOW  The foreign ministers of Azerbaijan, Armenia and Russia met behind closed doors here on Saturday, as international mediators ratcheted up the pressure for a breakthrough in the long conflict over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.

title: Agassis Post-Tennis Career Is Anything but Restful
description: PARIS  Andre Agassi has retired from tennis, but is hardly retired from the work force. At 41, he has announced his goal, in conjunction with a Los Angeles-based investment firm, to finance the construction of as many as 75 charter schools in the United States in the next several years.

title: Car Bombings and Shooting of Family Kill 11 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Twin car bombs ripped through a crowded neighborhood of restaurants and peanut vendors in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul on Saturday, and unidentified gunmen killed a teacher and his family in the central part of the country. At least 11 people were killed in the attacks.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Hurricanes, Serial Killers, Murder and Nazis
description: Erik Larson, the author of The Devil in the White City, has had four books on the hardcover nonfiction list.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Back in the Top Spot
description: Charlaine Harriss Dead Reckoning is one of five books over the past year to spend three or more weeks at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list.

title: The Worry Meter May Overlook Some Warning Signs
description: WHILE market risks appear to be climbing  stocks have lost ground for six consecutive weeks as the economy seems to have hit another soft patch  most traditional gauges of volatility show no noticeable jump in market anxiety.

title: Residents Flee as Syrian Forces Bombard Town
description: CAIRO  Syrian security forces bombarded the restive northern town of Jisr al-Shoughour for a second day Saturday with withering tank and helicopter fire as frightened people struggled to escape, residents reported.

title: Somalis Kill Mastermind of 2 U.S. Embassy Bombings
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Fazul Abdullah Mohammed, Al Qaedas leader in East Africa and the mastermind of the American Embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, was killed in a late-night shootout at a security checkpoint in Mogadishu, Somalias capital, Somali and American officials said Saturday.

title: The Sickness Beneath the Slump
description: THE origins of the current economic crisis can be traced to a particular kind of social epidemic: a speculative bubble that generated pervasive optimism and complacency. That epidemic has run its course. But we are now living with the malaise it caused.

title: Got an M.B.A.? Great, but I Prefer Uncommon Sense
description: This interview with Byron Lewis Sr., the chairman and chief executive of the UniWorld Group, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Out of Cuba, With a Suitcase
description: MY family emigrated from Cuba when I was almost 7, after the failed Bay of Pigs mission. We had a nice life in Cuba. My father worked for the Coca-Cola Company, and wed spend weekends at our beach house. But my parents didnt support Fidel Castro and wanted safe passage out of the country at that point.

title: Two New Web Sites Aim to Connect Travelers
description: Two new Web sites aim to make traveling a more social event. Both sites  triptrotting.com and igottaguide.com  combine travel with elements of social media, connecting members based on common interests.

title: Preview: U.S. vs. Panama
description: The United States could clinch a top-two spot in Group C with a victory over Panama in the Concacaf Gold Cup at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., Saturday night (8 p.m., Eastern, FSC/TeleFutura) and a Canada tie against Guadeloupe in the opening game of the doubleheader.

title: When Two-Thirds Isnt Enough
description: ITS one of the great anomalies of our ownership society: shareholders own companies, but executives can easily slap them down. The hired help, in other words, holds the cards.

title: Guard That Password (and Make Sure Its Encrypted)
description: FOR a pretty strong password, think 10. If your password contains 10 characters, you should be able to sleep well at night  perhaps for 19.24 years.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: Sean Penn, the actor, and Ozzie Guillen, the manager of the Chicago White Sox and a native of Venezuela, have been feuding over the actors support of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela.

title: Eritrea Detains Four Antipiracy Contractors
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Eritrea, a secretive and often testy nation in the Horn of Africa, has accused four British security contractors who are working for an antipiracy company of espionage, sabotage, terrorism and acts of invasion.

title: You Bring an Idea, and Theyll Do the Rest
description: BETSY RAVREBY KAUFMAN is a lot of things  a freelance television producer, a former anchor, a wife and mother, a resident of Houston. One thing she is not, she insists, is an inventor.

title: No Middle Ground in Relievers Commitment to Helping
description: When the San Francisco Giants needed a player to speak to the crowd before their game with the Los Angeles Dodgers on April 11, the choice was obvious. It would not be a star, but a journeyman left-handed middle reliever. It had to be Jeremy Affeldt.

title: A Guide to Palin E-Mail Notes
description: When The Times began posting nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday, we asked readers poring over them to highlight noteworthy and interesting messages. Our thanks to the hundreds of you that have done so since then. Here is a listing of the notes that weve made, based on Times research and your suggestions:

title: In Race or Behind the Scenes, Women Cement Their Gains in the Industry
description: This Triple Crown season has been rife with story lines, many involving women. Rosie Napravnik posted the highest finish by a female jockey in the Kentucky Derby  ninth with Pants On Fire. Kathy Ritvo, recovering from a heart transplant, trained Mucho Macho Man for all three legs of this grueling series.

title: Suburban Hip Is Where Its At
description: No one knows how things will end in the busted love affair between Manhattan and the wandering bankers of UBS. Fifteen years ago, the Swiss bank jilted Manhattan for the fresh face and roomy digs of Stamford, Conn. Now, it appears some aspiring masters of the universe are balking at working outside New York City and UBS is pondering coming back home, like the ending of a weepy Meg Ryan romance.

title: Husband Retraces Grete Waitzs Swift Footsteps
description: Jack Waitz said he probably should not have eaten so much before Saturdays race. But he could not help it. Delis had been a tradition for him and his wife, Grete, on their visits from Norway.

title: Weiner Agrees to Get Treatment as Calls for Resignation Intensify
description: Defying forceful demands for his resignation, Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York said on Saturday that he was entering a psychological treatment center and seeking a leave of absence from the House to deal with a pattern of reckless online behavior with women.

title: Days of a Dynasty Are Only a Memory for a Distinct Race
description: So much can happen in a mile and a half. And it can happen fast. Its enough to humble owners and trainers and jockeys, knowing that the Belmont Stakes can be lost right after the clang of the bell at the opening of the gate.

title: The Mets Bat Whisperer
description: PITTSBURGH  Whenever he receives a new box of bats, Carlos Beltran takes each bat out, holds it to his ear and raps it, gently but convincingly, with the base of his hand, his head cocked, one eye shut, concentrating like a virtuoso tuning his violin.

title: Carmona Says He Didnt Mean to Hit Teixeira
description: The Yankees were convinced that the Cleveland right-hander Fausto Carmona intentionally hit Mark Teixeira in the second inning of Friday nights game, an 11-7 Yankees victory. Carmona left Yankee Stadium without speaking to the news media, and on Saturday morning he offered his account of the pitch that sparked a benches-clearing incident and a shouting match between the managers.

title: No Guide to Survive a Political Scandal
description: There is no more wince-inducing time for a Washington politician than the moment that a sex scandal bursts into public view. But Representative Anthony D. Weiners fate notwithstanding, the truth is that they are not always politically fatal.

title: When It Comes to Scandal, Girls Wont Be Boys
description: WASHINGTON  There was a collective rolling of the eyes and a distinct sense of Here we go again among the women of the House of Representatives last week when yet another male politician, Representative Anthony D. Weiner, confessed his terrible mistakes and declared himself deeply sorry for the pain he had caused in sexual escapades so adolescent as to almost seem laughable.

title: Technology and the Political Sex Scandal
description: In 1791, while serving as secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton began an affair with Maria Reynolds, being blackmailed by her husband for several years to allow it to continue. When a muckraker exposed the affair and the cover-up, Hamilton turned to the communications technology of the day to defend himself, publishing a pamphlet in which he argued that he had never abused any public resources.

title: Blaming Sprouts Again
description: European officials have finally identified bean sprouts as the likely culprit in a deadly outbreak of E. coli poisoning, the latest in a series of outbreaks traced back to tainted sprouts.

title: Something Has Been Missing in October
description: Baseball fans had reason to be envious of the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. last week. Each sports championship series stood at 2-2 after four games. The World Series has not been tied 2-2 since 2003, when the Yankees played the Florida Marlins.

title: An Airlift, Family by Family, Bolsters Cubas Economy
description: HAVANA  Alejandrina Hernndez packed only light clothes and a makeup bag when she flew here from Miami this spring. As always, she kept her baggage to a minimum.

title: Clementes 3,000th Hit Was Muted Milestone in Ambivalent City
description: When Derek Jeter reaches 3,000 career hits, he will achieve more than a milestone. At that moment, Jeter will match the career hit total of Roberto Clemente, the Hall of Famer who stands forever as the greeter to the club.

title: Bayler Teal Was South Carolinas Talisman
description: When South Carolina won the 2010 N.C.A.A. Division I baseball championship, the universitys first mens title in more than 100 years of athletic competition, Coach Ray Tanner thanked three people, posthumously.

title: McEnroe-Borg 1980: A Great Match Endures
description: Bjorn Borg was conspicuously absent from last weekends French Open final when Rafael Nadal defeated Roger Federer and tied Borgs record six singles titles in Paris. But Borg is conspicuously present in a new HBO documentary he shares with his longtime rival John McEnroe.

title: Another Vettel Pole, and Another Thought on Schumacher
description: MONTREAL  Sebastian Vettel scored pole position in his Red Bull in Montreal today, but since he has done that at most of the races this year, Id rather talk about other things.

description: MONTREAL  Sebastian Vettel scored pole position in his Red Bull in Montreal today, but since he has done that at most of the races this year, Id rather talk about other things.

title: Dying to Tell the Story
description: Islamabad, Pakistan

title: E. Coli Fallout: My Salad, My Health
description: The Greek salad I ordered at a business lunch in the Netherlands near the German border two weeks ago was served up with a dilemma. Are you sure you want to eat that?  look at the cucumbers, my Dutch dining companion pointed out, ominously.

title: The Quiet Corner of the Mideast (Surprise)
description: WASHINGTON  In the Arab democracy movement, there is a dog that has not yet barked. And whether or not it does  and how loudly  is causing a lot of heartburn among American policy makers.

title: New Curb, No Ban, On Hits to the Head
description: Last week the N.H.L.s general managers fired the latest salvo in the rear-guard action they have fought over the last season and a half.

title: From a Twitter Photo to Treatment
description: FRIDAY, MAY 27: A sexually suggestive photograph is sent to a young woman from the Twitter account of Representative Anthony D. Weiner. It is quickly deleted.

title: After a Stroll, Luongo Is Immovable
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  In this hockey-mad city and throughout Canada, fans have been perplexed by the uneven performance of Roberto Luongo, the Canucks veteran goalie and Vezina Trophy nominee. His games in the Stanley Cup finals have been endlessly scrutinized, dissected and discussed. After two miserable showings in Boston last week, he entered Game 5 against the Bruins on Friday under the microscope once again.

title: The Mayors Go-To Man on the Council
description: After giving his victory speech and plunging into the audience to shake hands with supporters, Rahm Emanuel climbed back onto the stage at his election-night party in February. Chicagos next mayor then noticed someone he had to return to floor level to greet.

title: Qaddafi Forces Shell Rebels Near Misurata
description: CAIRO  Forces loyal to Col. title: It May Look Like a Scone, but Its Job Training

So his job counselor recommended the 12-week job-training course at Blue Sky Bakery, a Lincoln Park cafe known for its delectable scones  and for creating first jobs for young people who need them most.

Officials were bracing for high winds, projected to pick up in the afternoon, that would test the containment efforts after a two-day reprieve from harsh weather.

title: The Uncertainty Tax
description: If you want to understand why the unemployment rate has been stubbornly lodged around 9 percent, a good place to start is with the eye-popping mortgage statistics released last week by the economic analysis firm CoreLogic: 38 percent of homeowners with second mortgages are underwater. They borrowed against the value of their homes, and they now owe more than their houses are worth. The total number of underwater homeowners in America, with first and second mortgages, is a stunning 22.7 percent. In Nevada alone, 63 percent of all mortgaged properties are worth less than the owners paid; in Arizona 50 percent, Florida 46 percent, Michigan 36 percent and California 31 percent.

title: Handicapping the Obama-Boehner Golf Summit
description: MIAMI  On the first tee, President Lyndon B. Johnson often warned his golfing partners, One lesson youd better learn if you want to be in politics is you never get out on a golf course and beat the president.

Together with Jess Gaspar, Ed wrote a paper 15 years ago arguing that contrary to what many people were saying, the Internet and all that wouldnt undermine the agglomeration forces that support places like Manhattan; if anything, agglomeration would increase. title: 30 Seconds With David Feherty
description: A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Fehertys half-interview, half-improv weekly show, Feherty, will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Fehertys 2002 novel, A Nasty Bit of Rough. Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.

Closer inspection revealed a cacophony of fungi spread out across an old tree stump  one mushroom growing singly like a shelf, others in trumpet-shaped clusters, and a few as large as pancakes. Each had that lovely speckled pattern fanning out across the cap.

Then theres the sheer size of it. Not only does Will Shortz want us to break our brains, they reason, he wants us to suffer. This might be the puzzle we have to leave to our children in our wills.

title: Missouris War Within the War
description: On June 11, 1861, at St. Louiss sumptuous Planters House, two Army officers met with Missouris governor and former governor, the latter now commanding the state militia, in the governors suite. The meeting, called to discuss Missouris role in the unfolding Civil War, was anything but cordial. For the first half hour, the governors, Claiborne Fox Jackson and Sterling Price, insisted their state, though still a part of the Union, remain neutral, and that, in exchange for disbanding the state militia, the federalized German home guard be disbanded as well.

title: Rooftop Seating, for Everyone
description: Some hotels have exclusive rooftop bars, open only to guests and V.I.P.s, but at Above 6 at the 6 Columbus hotel, across 58th Street from the Time Warner Center, the approach is more democratic. The bar, a casual aerie perched high above Columbus Circle, welcomes hotel guests and the general public on a first-come-first-served basis  patrons need only ask at Blue Ribbon Sushi in the lobby to be let up in the elevator to the roof. Open for just two months, the spot, which does not serve food but supplies wasabi peas free upon request, is already popular with neighborhood residents, office workers and diners waiting for a table downstairs when the restaurant bar is full. On Wednesday, the crowd included two friends from the television business chatting with each other and the patrons at the adjacent table.

title: In the Park and Then the Wig

Now she is appearing on Broadway as the haughty, overbearing Mrs. Evangeline Harcourt in the Tony-nominated revival of the Cole Porter musical Anything Goes. Most Sundays revolve around the matinee; today, though, there is none because of the Tony Awards.  Ms. Walter, 70, lives in an Upper West Side brownstone with her husband, the actor Ron Leibman, and their black Lab, Reggie; they also own a house in Pound Ridge, N.Y., where they plan to make an early getaway this weekend.  ROBIN FINN

title: Bonnaroo: Day 3

title: Red Chain Reactions Against the Sky

Leaning forward, one knee bent with her hands pressing into her lower back, she faces an industrial landscape where water towers and a panorama of rooftops dot a hazy horizon. She stares at it, and it stares back: a frontier of open space, freedom and possibility.

With three bands on the bill  Medeski Martin & Wood, Josh Roseman and the King Froopy All-Stars, and Jim Blacks AlasNoAxis  there were innumerable on-the-fly decisions about timbre and color, rhythm and counterrhythm. Each set was impressive in its own way, but there was continuity among them.

title: Philosophy as an Art of Dying
description: It happens rarely, but when it does it causes a commotion of great proportions; it attracts the attention of all, becomes a popular topic for discussion and debate in marketplaces and taverns. It drives people to take sides, quarrel and fight, which for things philosophical is quite remarkable. It happened to Socrates, Hypatia, Thomas More, Giordano Bruno, Jan Patocka, and a few others. Due to an irrevocable death sentence, imminent mob execution or torture to death, these philosophers found themselves in the most paradoxical of situations: lovers of logic and rational argumentation, silenced by brute force; professional makers of discourses, banned from using the word; masters of debate and contradiction, able to argue no more. What was left of these philosophers then? Just their silence, their sheer physical presence. The only means of expression left to them, their own bodies  and dying bodies at that.

title: Super 8 Surprises Viewers and the Box Office
description: A mix of science fiction suspense, coming-of-age drama and Spielbergian wonder proved to be a winning formula, giving Super 8  a better-than-expected opening weekend gross of $37 million and the No. 1 spot at the North American box office. The film, directed by J. J. Abrams, is one of the few summer releases that does not benefit from being a sequel or having a built-in fan base. In an effort to offset this handicap and spread some quick word of mouth Paramount Pictures held early screenings on Thursday and urged customers to tweet about the film. Private screenings were also held on Wednesday night for Twitter users with large numbers of followers. X-Men: First Class from 20th Century Fox held steady at second place with $25 million, dropping 55 percent from last weekends total, an above-average second-week showing for a summer blockbuster. That franchise reboot has accumulated a North American total of $98.9 million, according to Box Office Mojo, which tracks sales data. The Hangover Part II (Warner Brothers) was third with $18.5 million, proving the continued appeal of the misadventures of the Wolf Pack. In fourth place, Kung Fu Panda 2 (DreamWorks Animation, via Paramount) piled on another $16.6 million. At fifth place with $10.8 million, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (Walt Disney Studios) crossed the $200 million mark in North America. So far at this summers box office, ticket sales are up 13.5 percent compared with this stage in the season last year, but are still down 9 percent for the year so far.

title: Judy Garlands Career in 2 Retrospectives

There will also be a presentation of short films and rarities hosted by John Fricke, a Garland historian and author of the forthcoming Judy: A Legendary Film Career (Running Press, 2011). The retrospective will run from July 26 to Aug. 9 at the Walter Reade Theater; the Paley Centers Judy Garland: The Television Years, a comprehensive collection of highlights and performances from The Judy Garland Show, The Ed Sullivan Show and Tonight, will run from July 20 to Aug. 18.

title: Looking for Truth in All That Lying

title: Now Arriving | Orla Kiely

But the Irish-born, London-based designer makes much more than just mummy-friendly diaper bags. She also has home dcor and ready-to-wear lines, both of which feature cheerful graphics and mod silhouettes. And while its taken a while, London hipsters have finally lit upon her her clothing designs, which make references to the Chelsea girl charm of Mary Quant, Julie Christie and Jean Shrimpton. Thanks to bright young fans like Alexa Chung and Keira Knightley, Kiely is enjoying some well-deserved celebrity on her home turf. It helps, of course, that she has a bevy of cool girls working for her. Venetia Scott, the Marc Jacobs stylist-turned-photographer, shoots her ad campaigns, and Leith Clark, the Canadian editor of the British indie fashion magazine Lula, styles them. Her first American store is set to open in SoHo in September. In anticipation, Kielys hosting an event at the Ace Hotel tomorrow night. Chung will D.J. and Mercedes Heinweins short film about the fall collection, which was inspired by Tippi Hedrens wardrobe in The Birds, will be screened. Describing her recent success, which shes hoping to replicate in the United States, Kiely is as well mannered and ladylike as her neat blouses and primly tailored coats. Oh, gosh, Ive really just been enjoying it, she says. I hope Americans like the clothes, too.

title: Major Art Gift to Stanford
description: In an economically rough period when many university art museums seem to be in a position of retreat, Stanford University plans to announce on Tuesday that it will soon be a major West Coast presence in postwar art. The university is accepting a donation of works from one of the most important private collections of Abstract Expressionism. The group of 121 paintings and sculptures, owned by Harry W. and Mary Margaret Anderson, had long been expected to make its way to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which has been the beneficiary of the Andersons for many years. But the couple, known as Hunk and Moo, said in a statement that we have always been closely associated with colleges and universities, and in making this gift to Stanford we anticipate the students, the public and the entire art community will have the opportunity to fully engage the collection. The collection, which the Andersons began building in the 1960s, includes one of the last major Jackson Pollock drip paintings still in private hands, Lucifer, from 1947, when Pollock was making his transition from a more traditional style to his signature volcanic canvases. Several years ago dealers familiar with the painting said that the Andersons had turned down as much as $100 million for it. The collection also includes significant works by Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, Mark Rothko, David Smith, Helen Frankenthaler, Sam Francis and Philip Guston. Stanford said that by 2014 it expected to complete construction of a building to house the collection, which includes 86 artists in all, in styles including Abstract Expressionism and reflecting movements like Light and Space and Color Field painting.

Her decision was not unexpected, and it clears the way for what some political observers expect to be an extremely close race in 2012. Rob McKenna, a Republican who is the states attorney general, announced his long-anticipated candidacy last week. Representative Jay Inslee, a Democrat whose district includes parts of the politically crucial Seattle region, has signaled for months that he would run if Ms. Gregoire did not. The state, like many others, has been forced to make major spending cuts, including to schools and social programs, and the question is whether frustration with the its direction will be enough to overcome Democratic control.

What they wont show you, although every resident of the area knows about them, are the four towns  Arena, Shavertown, Union Grove and Pepacton  that were flooded in the middle 50s so that the reservoir could be constructed. title: Jordan: Protesters Clash With Police During Kings Visit to Tribal Town
description: Youths clashed with riot police officers during a visit by King Abdullah II to Tafileh, a long-neglected tribal area 125 miles south of the capital, in a rare outburst of anger surrounding a royal event. About 30 riot police officers were hurt and five police cars were burned. Youths in Tafileh had been protesting against corruption and had wanted to meet the king, left, a request that was denied. A government spokesman said the clashes occurred as people rushed to salute the king. In a nod to protesters the king pledged Sunday that in the future the government would be elected, rather than appointed, but he set no timetable for the change.

title: Venturi Remembers When He Was Hot Stuff
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Ken Venturi returned on Monday to Congressional Country Club, where 47 years earlier he won the United States Open while suffering from dehydration and heat exhaustion. The temperature at Congressional on Monday was a balmy 75, or about 25 degrees lower than when Venturi trudged through 36 holes on the final day of the 1964 United States Open to win by four strokes.

title: Pundit Under Protest
description: Ill be writing a lot about the presidential election over the next 16 months, but at the outset I would just like to remark that Im opining on this whole campaign under protest. Im registering a protest because for someone of my Hamiltonian/National Greatness perspective, the two parties contesting this election are unusually pathetic. Their programs are unusually unimaginative. Their policies are unusually incommensurate to the problem at hand.

title: Progress Claimed in Reporting Abuse at Group Homes
description: ALBANY  Roughly 40 percent of the allegations of physical abuse of the developmentally disabled at group homes and institutions in New York in recent months were not reported to law enforcement authorities, a senior state official said on Monday.

title: Pakistan: Suicide Bomber Attacks Bank, Leaving Two Dead and Puzzle Over Motive
description: A security guard was killed and three people were injured Monday afternoon when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a bank in Islamabad, police officials said. It was not clear why the bomber attacked a branch of a local bank, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. The police speculated that the bomber might have been trying to create panic or mistakenly thought the bank was foreign owned.

These billowing trousers under a simple top and a tight denim mini are mash-up worthy of a fashion hermaphrodite.

Watch for cameos from the newly minted Tony winner Nikki M. James and from Mr. Harris, who in his first run-through of the hot-off-the-presses number makes it look every bit as effortless as when he recited it for real.

title: Just One Look | The Row
description: If there is one thing Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen of the Row want you to take away from their resort collection, it is that theyre in the business of luxury. Just take this nautical mink coat and sheath dress (and supercute sailor striped socks). The collection is inspired by the gilded age in Europe. Embroidered floral tops and dresses, crisp checked Prince of Wales separates and jewels designed with Ileana Makri are reminiscent of the Belle Epoque. And in case you had a shred of doubt about how luxe they want to go, consider their handbags: classic totes, satchels and bags glow in rich tones of bright purple and neon green. Not to mention, a fox and mink snow white backpack.

title: Second Death at Bonnaroo Festival Is Reported
description: A man attending the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., over the weekend died on Sunday, officials told The Associated Press. Stephen M. Graves, the sheriff of Coffee County, said that Christopher William Yoder, 24, of Raleigh, N.C., had died of hyperthermia after he was airlifted from the festival to a hospital in Chattanooga. The sheriff told The A.P. that he was awaiting the results of toxicology tests. The organizers of the festival said in a statement, The safety of our patrons is our No. 1 concern, and we are deeply saddened by this.

title: Critics Picks Video: Un Chien Andalou
description: In this weeks Critics Pick, A. O. Scott looks at a slice of surreal life in Luis Buuel and Salvador Dals 1928 short film Un Chien Andalou. The film, which catalogs a variety of random, sometimes shocking scenes, was part of the Surrealism art movement, one that rebelled against order and coherence. Mr. Scott says that even now, 80 years later, the movie still seethes with creative, revolting imagery. Mr. Scott praises Mr. Buuels filmmaking, saying that he was among the first to discover that the language of cinema could proceed beyond the boundaries of sense and produce powerful and strange effects and emotions. Have you seen Un Chien Andalou? Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

The lockouts first victim, however, could be a former merchant seaman from Brooklyn who once worked on the Apollo lunar module but today lies inert in Room 12 at the Silverado dementia-care facility here.

title: Century-Old Immigration Debate Has Familiar Sound

title: For Franciscan Twins, Simple Lives Had Depth
description: ST. BONAVENTURE, N.Y.  They were like paired birds of Franciscan brown. If Brother Julian was gardening in front of the friary, Brother Adrian weeded in the back. If Adrian was driving the van, Julian sat by his side. Preparing the altar for chapel, chopping wood for kindling, exulting in ice cream at the Twist & Shake, the identical Riester twins were together, always.

title: The Costs of an Urban Diet
description: The city of Louisville, where six of 10 residents are overweight, has tried to deploy every municipal agency to put its citizens on a regimen of diet and exercise. Like other cities across the country, Louisville is receiving federal and private money to build bike paths and racks, sponsor community gardens and other healthy alternatives  all aimed at efforts to influence and change the habits of its residents.

title: Royal Ballet Names New Artistic Director
description: The speculation has been incessant, but on Tuesday morning the Royal Ballet in London put an end to the chatter about who will take over once its current artistic director, Monica Mason, steps down in July next year. It will be Kevin OHare, a former principal dancer with the Birmingham Royal Ballet who has been steadily making his way up the Royal Ballets hierarchy since his retirement from the stage in 2000. He joined as company manager in 2004 and became administrative director in 2009.

title: U.S. Students Remain Poor at History, Tests Show

title: Local Colors

Which might explain the appeal of a new collection of T-shirts by Local Knit, featuring the logos from Montauk institutions like Duryeas Lobster Deck, the Montauket and Paulies Tackle. Montaukers are snapping them up, as are weekenders. (Curbeds Lockhart Steele is a fan and ordered a Herbs Market shirt in beach plum with the slogan You Cant Beat Herbs Meat.) He has no self-reverential tattoos and his entourage consists of equipment guys who hang up his goalie pads. And its hard to gin up much dislike for a hockey player in the United States, where Luongos name recognition hovers somewhere around the Dodgers backup shortstop.

Smart decision, because its really a remarkable, unexpected story. It was adapted from Anands book, India Calling: An Intimate Portrait of a Nations Remaking, and presents a subtle picture of a new Indian ethos, best described by Anand this way:

The performances include operas, symphonic concerts, chamber music and recitals produced by the festival. They also include a huge slate of fringe events, concerts presented by musicians and ensembles from around the country who flock to Boston in hopes of being heard by an audience of enthusiasts as well as managers and concert presenters who are in town for the festivals starrier offerings. This years festival, the 16th, opened on Sunday and runs through next Sunday.

title: Nocturnal Voyages Through Many Eras and Textures
description: Strains of Bartok, Britten, Radiohead and Pink Floyd echoed through the musically omnivorous soundscape that unfolded in the first of two sets at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening, blurring genres and centuries into one enigmatic, continuous sequence.

title: Just One Look | Bally Resort
description: Ballys resort collection shows us how to do vacation, luxe Alpine style. A poplin and crepe de chine dress, like this one, is the go-to uniform for relaxing in St. Moritz. The collection has other sportif classics, like utility windbreakers and chic, cotton dresses. The lines recently introduced Moritz accessories line features perforated leather handbags and sporty perforated nappa leather handbags and slate blue sandals.

title: Lennys Sandwich Shops to Pay $5.1 Million for Wage Violations
description: The New York State Department of Labor has reached a $5.1 million settlement, its largest ever, with the chain Lennys: The Ultimate Sandwich for minimum-wage and overtime violations, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday.

title: When Everything Moves but the Subject
description: Easiest thing in the world, taking a picture of a building. Right? It doesnt blink. It doesnt turn its back. It doesnt duck out of sight. It just stands there, frozen. (O.K., leave the Milwaukee Art Museum out of this.)

title: Into the Crocodile Cave
description: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes from Madagascar, where he is studying cave fishes.

title: Just One Look | Nina Ricci Resort
description: Pretty, airy dressing is what Nina Ricci does best. And this resort season is no exception. The Ricci woman finds her classic summer look in pretty-in-pink ruffled suits, tight belted sheaths with horizontal ruching, floaty chiffon minis, belle poque gowns and this strawberry confection with marabou, which will make you look absolutely yummy.

title: Madewell, but Remade How Well?
description: FOR about five years, the brand Madewell has been rattling like rusty ironworks around the edges of my consciousness, producing vague and somewhat conflicting associations, like flannel shirt, rain boots and Alexa Chung.

title: Maison Premiere
description: 298 Bedford Avenue (Grand Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (347) 335-0446, maisonpremiere.com.

title: TimesCast | Surviving Inside Syria
description: June 14, 2011 - Sebnem Arsu crosses into northern Syria and speaks to desperate refugees fleeing Jisr al-Shoughour.

title: Inside Maison Premiere
Life With a Gay Ex-Husband. It Happens.
description: Not so long ago there was nothing funny about a wife discovering that her husband is gay.

title: Just One Look | Burberry Prorsum
description: Burberry Prorsum delivered a resort collection intentionally rooted in tradition but updated with color and pattern. There are electric yellow trench coats and orange leather ones. There are classic necessities like dusty rose bell-bottoms and high-waisted pencil skirts in turquoise leather. Prints that resemble African fabric make for chic little shirtwaist dresses. And beading around ankle and around the trim of a classic Burberry plaid hits the swoon button.

title: ABCs Rose Bouquet From The Bachelorette
description: ABCs latest two-hour installment of The Bachelorette delivered Monday nights largest audience as 7.8 million viewers tuned in to that reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The solid ratings were high enough to lift ABC to the top spot in prime time as the nights most watched network even though a repeat of CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (7.4 million) outperformed ABCs Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition (5.9 million) in the 10 p.m. hour. CBS ranked second over all with reruns of its sitcom lineup from 8 to 10, including Two and a Half Men (6 million) and Mike & Molly (6.3 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC ranked third, averaging 5.3 million viewers for its coverage of Game 6 of the National Hockey Leagues Stanley Cup Finals while Fox was fourth with a new episode of MasterChef at 9 (4.9 million).

title: When Whats Left of a Man Is Found in His Collections
description: W. David Hancocks Race of the Ark Tattoo caused a small sensation downtown about a dozen years ago, partly because of its intriguing conceit. Inside a flea market a man spun stories about his foster father, who had died, by randomly picking up the mans belongings and musing on them. It was a little bit of a gimmick but it worked.

title: Debate Coverage Brings CNN a Ratings Win
description: CNN pushed to the top of cable news ratings Monday night with its coverage of the debate in New Hampshire among Republican candidates for president.

title: TimesCast | From Guinea to New York
description: June 14, 2011 - Metro reporter Kirk Semple looks at the life long journey of Dominique Strauss-Kahn's accuser, from a childhood in Guinea to a job in a New York hotel.

title: Pandora Prices Its I.P.O. at $16 a Share
description: The online music service Pandora may not be profitable, but that hasnt discouraged investors clamoring for a piece of it.

title: Filling the Void Left by El Bulli
description: When the most influential restaurant in the world closes, who will step up to take the lead?

title: Just One Look | Vionnet Resort
description: Visits to India, Africa and Japan informed Vionnets 2012 resort collection. Color-blocked tunics and dresses in vivid combinations like purple and gold, and orange and white, were reminiscent of 1960s Courrges as well as of origami. And Vionnets reputation as a house famous for cut came through loud and clear: there were fluid, sensationally draped evening gowns; even a simple blue shirtdress had crisscross drapery on the bodice. Oh, and the jewelry. So chic.

title: Government Will Try to End Strike at Air Canada
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian labor minister introduced a motion on Tuesday that could legislate an end to a strike by Air Canadas airport customer service agents if a negotiated settlement proves impossible.

title: Ushering In Golden Age for Fans of Film
description: Nostalgia is frequently the default setting for movie lovers, who, even as they direct their eyes toward the screen, look back dreamily at a lost Arcadian time when the popcorn was crunchier and the films more substantial. New Yorkers are burdened with a similar feeling, the sense that back then  then being a vague moment sometime before now, when La Guardia was mayor and the Dodgers were in Brooklyn and men wore hats and action painters hung out at CBGB and the Dutch had not yet landed  was when things were really happening.

title: After El Bulli, Spain Looks Forward
description: EL BULLI, currently the most influential restaurant in the world, will serve its last dinner on July 30. The next morning, Spains chefs will wake up to a radically changed universe.

title: From a Season Aloft, High Hopes Linger
description: Have certain Balanchine steps and certain Balanchine roles ever been better danced than they were in the six-week season by New York City Ballet that ended on Sunday? The question makes the mind fly like an arrow to the tall, naturally grand, pale-blond Teresa Reichlen, the most compellingly unknowable and pure dancer that company has had since the departure of Kyra Nichols four years ago.

title: Chefs Assess El Bullis Legacy
description: I wrote an article that explores the effect of El Bullis imminent closing on Spanish cuisine, but its chef, Ferran Adri, has influenced cooking all over the world, especially in haute cuisine. I asked some American chefs (and one restaurateur) to assess the legacy of Mr. Adri and his cocina de vanguardia  the term he and others prefer over molecular gastronomy.

title: A Facebook App for the iPad (Just Not From Facebook)
description: Facebook has had a mobile app for some time, but iPad users have had to go without a native iPad app.

title: The Knife Rack Goes High-End
description: FOR years, a few privileged cooks have joined a waiting list to spend thousands of dollars for the carbon steel knives Bob Kramer makes by hand at his forge in Olympia, Wash. Two weeks ago the cookware chain Sur la Table began selling a signature line made to his specifications by Zwilling J. A. Henckels. Though the knives are priced as high as $349.95 for a 10-inch chefs knife, cooks quickly bought hundreds of them, with the chain selling about 20 percent of its inventory in 10 days, said Jacob Maurer, the vice president for merchandising for Sur la Table.

title: Resort Looks from Cline and Nina Ricci
description: There were so many resort presentations happening at Milk Studios on Monday that the building, which bumps up against the High Line park, began to feel like a department store. First floor: Marc by Marc Jacobs. Second floor: Cline, Nina Ricci, Erin Fetherston. Farther up were Lanvin, Givenchy and Pedro Loureno.

title: Facebook Hires Former White House Press Secretary Joe Lockhart
description: Facebook has hired Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary during President Clintons second term, to be its vice president of communications.

title: The Cook Who Couldnt Taste
description: ON a bright May morning at the Union Square Greenmarket, Molly Birnbaum came across a potted clump of rosemary. She squeezed a leaf of it between her fingertips, brought the invisible smear of scent to her nostrils and inhaled.

title: Postcards From the Resort
description: Oh my, arent designers taking the term resort a bit literally this season? I thought we were calling it pre-spring now.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Drink for Charity

title: New on Smith Street, Croissants and Cured Fish
description: Breakfast and lunch at Seersucker in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, have been discontinued. Why? Because Robert Newton and Kerry Diamond, the owners, have turned a century-old pharmacy a few doors away into Smith Canteen, a cafe. They left the wood shelves and trim, tin ceiling and tile floors and added counters and tables. The coffee and espresso dispensed from a marble bar is from Counter Culture, and the iced coffee is dynamite. Pastries, like whole-wheat croissants with spinach filling, start the day. By lunch, there are sandwiches like duck confit banh mi, salads and items like a sweet pea quiche. Many use Greenmarket ingredients.

title: Bamboo Pickles, With Grandmas Help
description: Carla Squires grew up making bamboo pickles with her grandmother Johnsie Walsh, who had a stand of bamboo behind her house in Wilkes County, N.C. I was the only grandchild who did it, she said. Then, about four years ago, she took courses in food science at North Carolina State University and began making the pickles in a commercial kitchen.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Juicers for a Cocktail Splash
description: For that quick splash of citrus juice, be it orange, grapefruit, lemon or lime, this new four-in-one juicer (above, left) designed by Quentin de Coster in the Netherlands for the Royal Delft Group, is the answer. It has two reamers, one for smaller fruit, one for larger, and sits securely on top of a glass or cocktail shaker. An internal channel directs the juice, not the seeds, into the glass. It is dishwasher-safe, but not suggested for use on stemware or delicate glassware because of the pressure needed for juicing.

title: Fedora
description: RECENTLY OPENED

title: Boehner Warns Obama on Libya Operations
description: House Speaker John Boehner on Tuesday warned President Obama that his administration would be in violation of the War Powers Resolution unless he seeks authorization from Congress for Americas military involvement in the NATO operations in Libya or the United States withdraws from those operations.

title: Bishops Wont Focus on Abuse Policies
description: Despite recent cases in which Roman Catholic bishops failed to report or suspend priests accused of child sexual abuse, the bishops head into a meeting in Seattle on Wednesday proposing no significant revisions to the abuse prevention policies they passed in 2002 at the height of the scandal.

title: Battle for Libya | June 14, 2011
description: Libyan rebels held a funeral for a comrade killed in clashes with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, and NATO dropped leaflets warning of helicopter airstrikes.

title: Russia Seizes Animal Parts
description: MOSCOW  The 26 elk lips were just the tip of the pile. The items the Russian customs agents reported seizing Tuesday were exotic even by the standards of Russias border with China, where wildlife smuggling is rampant: 1,041 bear paws, lynx fur, unspecified claw parts and five tusks from the extinct woolly mammoth.

title: Slump Still in Effect, Bay Returns to Bench
description: ATLANTA  For the fourth time in nine games, Jason Bay was left out of the Mets starting lineup Tuesday night, with the possibility of more time on the bench to come.

title: In Visit to Puerto Rico, Obama Offers (and Seeks Out) Support
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  President Obama came to this United States commonwealth on Tuesday and promised to stand by Puerto Rico no matter what residents decide about its future  statehood, independence or a continuation of the status quo.

title: One Voice or Many for the Taliban, but Pegged to a Single Name
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Will the real Zabiullah Mujahid, mouthpiece of the Taliban movement in Afghanistan, please stand up?

title: Suddenly, Jeters Not Fine
description: Im fine, Derek Jeter usually says when he is hit in the ribs or the hand by a pitched ball, or is suffering from a bug. Managers and teammates smile when he says hes fine.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,604 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Inside BAMcinemaFest
description: Images from some of the films playing at BAMcinemaFest, a Brooklyn festival that celebrates independent cinema.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Taste for Pad Thai, Then Criminal Court
description: The case could have been filed as an Upper West Side edition of Clue: the mezzo-soprano, in the frozen-food section of Trader Joes, with the open palm of her manicured left hand.

title: A Call for Lower-Key Debate on Debt Limit
description: Many of the nations top economic and political power brokers gathered on Tuesday for a conference aimed at a more sober conversation regarding the federal budget.

title: Philippe Petit: Wireless!
description: The famous tightrope walker has a new one-man show showcasing his other identities: juggler, magician, pickpocket, bullfighter, lock picker, motivational author.

description: I am a madman! Philippe Petit announced, and whos to disagree?
