title: California Judge Upholds a Ruling on Gay Marriage
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the ruling that struck down Californias ban on same-sex marriage, asserting that the judges 10-year relationship with another man did not disqualify him from deciding the case.

title: The Humanist in the Foxhole
description: Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Indictments Over 2009 Quake Cause Quite a Furor
description: MILAN  Seven members of an Italian commission that assesses major risks like earthquakes have been indicted on manslaughter charges here for not adequately informing residents of the potential danger posed by the seismic activity that shook the Abruzzo region for months before the fatal earthquake that killed 309 people on April 6, 2009.

title: Effort to End Tax Credit for Ethanol Fails in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate beat back a challenge to ethanol fuel subsidies on Tuesday in a demonstration of how the drive to cut the federal deficit can run headlong into a favored interest on Capitol Hill.

title: The True Cost of Tomatoes
description: Mass-produced tomatoes have become redder, more tender and slightly more flavorful than the crunchy orange cello-wrapped specimens of a couple of decades ago, but the lives of the workers who grow and pick them havent improved much since Edward R. Murrows revealing and deservedly famous Harvest of Shame report of 1960, which contained the infamous quote, We used to own our slaves; now we just rent them.

title: Candidates Show G.O.P. Less United on Goals of War
description: DERRY, N.H.  The hawkish consensus on national security that has dominated Republican foreign policy for the last decade is giving way to a more nuanced view, with some presidential candidates expressing a desire to withdraw from Afghanistan as quickly as possible and suggesting that the United States has overreached in Libya.

title: Obama in Old San Juan
description: San Juan, P.R.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Standards for Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title: A California Bankruptcy Court Rejects U.S. Law Barring Same-Sex Marriage
description: A bankruptcy court in California has declared that the 1996 law barring federal recognition of same-sex marriage is unconstitutional, increasing pressure against the law.

title: The G.O.P. Debate
description: Mondays Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire  full of historical error, economic obfuscation, avoidance of hard truths and even outright bigotry  was a feast for connoisseurs of political dysfunction. Desperate to avoid being outflanked on the right, the seven candidates tried so hard to outdo each other in finding fault with President Obama that they seemed to forget that they are competing for the same party nomination. By evenings end, they had melted into an indistinguishable mass of privatizing, tax-cutting opponents of Shariah law.

title: Wisconsin Court Reinstates Law on Union Rights
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for significant cuts to collective bargaining rights for public workers in the state, undoing a lower courts decision that Wisconsins controversial law had been passed improperly.

title: Arnold Palmers Grandson Makes the Open on His Own
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Sam Saunders, one of the qualifiers at the United States Open, was quietly practicing his putting Tuesday at Congressional Country Club when a fan tried to summon his attention.

title: Garmin Acquires a Rival Car Navigation Company
description: Selling car navigation devices is increasingly challenging these days because, after all, people can use their mobile phones to get directions free of charge.

title: Somalia: Prime Minister Refuses to Quit
description: The future of Somalias transitional government became even more uncertain on Tuesday after the prime minister, Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed, announced that he was refusing to resign, defying an agreement last week between Somalias president and Parliament speaker that included a reshuffling of the cabinet. Mr. Mohamed is popular among many Somalis and soldiers, and riots erupted last week when the president and the Parliament speaker said that Mr. Mohamed would be replaced. The president and speaker had bickered over whether to hold elections in August and agreed to a deal to extend Somalias weak transitional government for another year and to make changes in the cabinet. Mr. Mohamed says he will step down only if the full Parliament orders him to do so.

title: A Call to Shift Policy on Marijuana
description: Night court in Manhattan, Monday, 7:30 p.m.

title: Jeter Goes on Disabled List, Delaying Push to 3,000 Hits
description: Derek Jeter has paused his pursuit of history, landing on the 15-day disabled list Tuesday with a strained right calf, six hits short of 3,000 hits for his career.

title: Fatah and Hamas Leaders to Meet
description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president and Fatah party chief, and Khaled Meshal, the Damascus-based leader of the militant group Hamas, will meet in Cairo next week to try to finalize the makeup of a Palestinian unity government after lower-level talks ended Tuesday without a consensus, according to the official Palestinian news agency Wafa. Fatah, which dominates in the West Bank, and Hamas, which controls Gaza, signed a reconciliation agreement in early May. Fatah has nominated Salam Fayyad, the current prime minister of the Palestinian Authority government, to lead a unity government of independent technocrats. Hamas has rejected Mr. Fayyad as a candidate.

title: Banks Turn to Schumer on Patents
description: WASHINGTON  For years and much to their frustration, big banks have paid hundreds of millions of dollars to a tiny Texas company to use a patented system for processing digital copies of checks, making Claudio Ballard, the inventor of the system, a wealthy man and the bank industrys biggest patent foe.

title: Account Executive Is Antiquated. Consider Yourself a Catalyst.
description: A LEADING public relations agency is reorganizing its operations in another example of how the marketing communications industry is scrambling to adapt to the significant changes in consumer behavior, most notably the publics fast and fierce embrace of digital and social media.

title: In East Village, Harbingers of Spring Are Missing
description: For years, warm weather in the East Village has been heralded by an influx of young, tattooed visitors carrying backpacks and bedrolls and wearing clothes so stiffened with grit that they have come to be known in the neighborhood as crusties.

title: Canada: Drug Raids in Mohawk Areas
description: About 500 police officers conducted a series of drug raids at Mohawk communities in the Montreal area on Tuesday and detained about 50 people. The police said they were investigating a drug trafficking ring that dealt primarily in marijuana. Some of the raids were at reserves, which are comparable to reservations in the United States.

title: So No Ones Responsible?
description: With Justice Clarence Thomas writing for a 5-to-4 majority, the Supreme Court has made it much harder for private lawsuits to succeed against mutual fund malefactors, even when they have admitted to lying and cheating.

title: France: Guardian Suggested for Heiress
description: A specially appointed medical panel is recommending that Liliane Bettencourt, the elderly LOral heiress,be protected by a guardian because of her deteriorating health, according to the newspaper Le Monde. The panels members did not examine Mrs. Bettencourt, 88, the newspaper said, but based their opinion on her medical records.Her lawyer, Pascal Wilhelm, declined to comment Tuesday due to the current situation. Mrs. Bettencourts daughter, Franoise Bettencourt-Meyers, has asked for court-appointed guardianship; Frances highest appeals court will review the request to determine whether it can be imposed without Mrs. Bettencourts support.

title: Two Golfers Revisit a Memorable Masters
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Charl Schwartzel and Rory McIlroy completed their practice rounds Tuesday about 20 minutes apart  Schwartzel finishing first, followed by McIlroy. Two months ago, in the final round of the Masters, the order was much the same.

title: Albanys Duty to Stop Domestic Violence
description: There are just a few days left in the New York State legislative term, and there is a lot of important business left to do. We want to draw particular attention to two bills that would help protect victims of domestic violence. Both need to pass before lawmakers go home.

title: David C. Baldus, 75, Dies; Studied Race and the Law
description: David C. Baldus, whose pioneering research on race and the death penalty came within a vote of persuading the Supreme Court to make fundamental changes in the capital justice system, died on Monday at his home in Iowa City. He was 75.

title: Gay Marriage Bill Is One Vote Shy of Clearing State Senate
description: ALBANY  New York was on the cusp of legalizing same-sex marriage on Tuesday, after a second Republican state senator came forward to support the measure, leaving it a single vote shy of passage.

title: Bias and the Beholder
description: Stephen Jay Gould, a prominent evolutionary biologist, gained broad public attention for exposing how scientists biases can skew their research. In one celebrated case, he charged that a famous study of human skulls in the mid-19th century had been manipulated, probably unconsciously, to support racist notions.

title: Dr. James J. Rahal, 77, Virus Expert, Dies
description: Dr. James J. Rahal, an infectious-disease specialist who raised early alarms about the rise of drug-resistant bacteria in hospitals, and who emerged as a leading expert in the treatment of West Nile virus after the Queens community where he worked became the epicenter of a deadly outbreak in 1999, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: For Rubio, a Senate First
description: As far as Senate rituals go, Marco Rubio is old school, honoring the longtime Senate tradition of biding ones time before joining the more seasoned politicians in speaking out on the floor; learning the rules before getting in the game.

title: Lottery Numbers
Cutting the Deficit, Adding Jobs
description: WASHINGTON

title: Transfers Delay Release of Detainees, Report Finds
description: Despite assurances that they would curb the practice of transferring detained immigrants to distant detention centers around the country, federal immigration officials continue to move hundreds of thousands of people a year, impeding the detainees access to lawyers and extending their time in custody, a human rights organization said in a report released on Tuesday.

title: Vancouver Is Hoping to Avoid Replay of 1994
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The intersection of Granville and Robson Streets, the center of what is referred to here as the party zone, was a somber place Monday night. With about 30 police officers looking on, dejected fans in blue and green floated through downtown Vancouvers entertainment district unsure of where to go and what to do.

title: Justice Goes Global
description: You probably missed the recent special issue of China Newsweek, so let me bring you up to date. Who do you think was on the cover  named the most influential foreign figure of the year in China? Barack Obama? No. Bill Gates? No. Warren Buffett? No. O.K., Ill give you a hint: Hes a rock star in Asia, and people in China, Japan and South Korea scalp tickets to hear him. Give up?

title: A Slowdown for Small Businesses
description: In the latest sign that the economic recovery may have lost whatever modest oomph it had, more small businesses say that they are planning to shrink their payrolls than say they want to expand them.

title: Justice Department Accused of Reckless Technique
description: WASHINGTON  In a report issued Tuesday by two powerful Republicans in Congress, the Justice Department was accused of conducting an operation that allowed nearly 1,000 guns to flow illegally into Mexico, including two that were eventually found at the scene of the murder of an American Border Patrol agent.

title: Perry Speaks, but Avoids  Big Question
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas came to Manhattan on Tuesday night to address local Republicans, and in the process stoked speculation about his ongoing presidential deliberations.

title: A Hole in One Helps, but Mental Discipline Is Critical at Majors
description: BETHESDA, Md.  The only thing more difficult than winning one of golfs four major championships is winning them all.

title: Shuttles End Leaves NASA a Pension Bill
description: The nations space agency plans to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of the contractor that has supplied thousands of workers to the space shuttle program.

title: With a Game 7 to Go, Omens Take the Stage
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  One final game will decide who will lift the Stanley Cup, one game to decide the winner of one of the oddest, most contentious, culturally fascinating and entertaining finals in N.H.L. history.

title: College-Readiness Low Among State Graduates, Data Show
description: Heightening concerns about the value of many of its high school diplomas, the New York State Education Department released new data on Tuesday showing that only 37 percent of students who entered high school in 2006 left four years later adequately prepared for college, with even smaller percentages of minority graduates and those in the largest cities meeting that standard.

title: At Chase, Top Ranks Get a Big Shake-Up
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, removed the head of the banks consumer banking business and reshuffled several other top executives in the biggest shake-up of his management team since the financial crisis.

title: State Lawmakers Argue Over Rent Laws as Deadline Looms
description: ALBANY  Rent regulations that limit how much landlords can charge for more than one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs are set to expire at the end of Wednesday, and lawmakers on Tuesday were still debating whether to simply renew them or to make changes sought by tenant advocates.

title: Thriving Corporate Park Spurs Growth in Bronx
description: In 2001, when Joseph Simone, the president of the family-owned Simone Development Companies in New Rochelle, N.Y., bid $3.7 million at a state auction for a weedy 18.5-acre site in the Bronx, home to an abandoned residential treatment center, skeptics wondered what such a normally astute businessman could possibly be thinking.

title: Wednesday: Having Four Sharps
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Confession: Sometimes I have to look really, really hard to spot the words in words-hidden-inside-other-words themes. Todays puzzle, however, very kindly supplies the answers following the theme entries, and those answers also help to flesh out the theme itself.

title: 1 Radioactive Bite, 8 Legs and 183 Previews
description: There is something to be said for those dangerous flying objects  excuse me, I mean actors  that keep whizzing around the Foxwoods Theater, where the mega-expensive musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark has entered the latest chapter of its fraught and anxious existence. After all, if youre worried that somebody might fall on top of you from a great height, the odds are that you wont nod off.

title: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark
description: Photos of the Broadway musical at the Foxwoods Theater.

title: Squeezing Costs, Builders Take New Look at Prefab
description: PHILADELPHIA  A package arrived on a shabby north Philadelphia block in January 2010, wrapped in Tyvek and measuring 55 feet long and 16 feet wide. Inside was a kitchenette, a bathroom and two bedrooms. The only thing missing was the toilet bowl lid. Just six weeks  and 88 similar packages  later, the Modules at Templetown, a four-story student-housing complex of 80,000 square feet near Temple University here, had completely risen from its concrete foundation.

title: City Comptroller Is Asked to Curb Comments on Fraud Case
description: Seeking to prevent additional unauthorized disclosures about the continuing criminal inquiry into the citys troubled automated payroll project, the United States attorney in Manhattan has urged John C. Liu, the city comptroller, to make no more public statements about the case without first consulting investigators.

title: Camels Nose Under the Wheel?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Wal-Mart Workers Try the Nonunion Route
description: After numerous failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nations main union for retail workers has decided to try a different approach: it has helped create a new, nonunion group of Wal-Mart employees that intends to press for better pay, benefits and most of all, more respect at work.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Apples Hype Envelops Penney
description: Apples reality distortion field has enveloped J. C. Penney. The department store chain poached Ron Johnson, the man behind Apples stores, to be its eventual chief executive. The hiring helped lift J. C. Penneys market value by nearly a fifth, or $1.2 billion, before edging back a bit at the end of trading on Tuesday. It is true that Mr. Johnson also spent 15 years at the retailer Target, but Apples halo looks too wide.

title: Defense Cites Unforeseen Factors in Deutsche Bank Fire
description: Summarizing their theories of what caused the deaths of two firefighters battling a blaze in the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, two defense lawyers on Tuesday echoed what they said 10 weeks earlier during opening statements  that an artificially created smoke chamber, not a missing standpipe, was to blame.

title: Pakistan Arrests C.I.A. Informants in Bin Laden Raid
description: WASHINGTON  Pakistans top military spy agency has arrested some of the Pakistani informants who fed information to the Central Intelligence Agency in the months leading up to the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to American officials.

title: A Green Solution, or the Dark Side to Cleaner Coal?
description: LIANYUNGANG, CHINA  The six massive silos standing beside this industrial port in northeastern China hold seemingly contradictory promises: They could help improve the quality of Chinas polluted air, but they might also contribute to faster global warming.

title: Braves Wet Down the Infield, but They Cant Slow Reyes
description: ATLANTA  Ever since the Atlanta Braves moved into the National League East in 1994, and Bobby Cox started managing against his rival Bobby Valentine later that decade, the Braves and the Mets have engaged in fierce competition and creative gamesmanship.

title: To Be Good Citizens, Report Says, Companies Should Just Focus on Bottom Line
description: A new paper by an advisory firm that works with major corporations argues that companies would achieve more social good by simply focusing on the bottom line rather than social responsibility programs, double- and triple-bottom-line accounting and hybrid structures that have nonprofit and for-profit arms.

title: Relic of Saint Disappears From Its Case Inside Church
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.  When missing something, devout Catholics often turn to St. Anthony of Padua, the patron saint of lost objects. Now, parishioners here are turning to him to pray for the return of his own relic.

title: Southern Baptists Elect Black Pastor
description: The Southern Baptist Convention elected a popular black pastor as first vice president on Tuesday, a decision described by church leaders as historic and a prelude to his likely elevation to the presidency of the nations largest Protestant denomination next year.

title: Extent of the Wallow Fire
description: Raging through eastern Arizona and neighboring New Mexico, the Wallow Fire has become the largest in Arizonas history.

title: C.I.A. Building Base for Strikes in Yemen
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency is building a secret air base in the Middle East to serve as a launching pad for strikes in Yemen using armed drones, an American official said Tuesday.

title: Yankees Bats Fill Void With Whacks

The original book, written by Mr. Yankovic (who, in a rare career move, did not declare himself to be Weird on its cover) and illustrated by Wes Hargis, follows an 8-year-old boy named Billy as he considers grown-up career options, such as becoming a doctor, firefighter, giraffe milker or snail trainer. The When I Grow Up app, which is developed by the Web design company Bean Creative, offers interactive games and features based on the book, including the option to have Mr. Yankovic read it to you, and opportunities to practice some of Billys more fanciful future occupations, such as shaving a tarantula or massaging a gorilla. Mr. Yankovic said in a statement that when he was a child, I dreamed of one day helping to produce a cross-platform app that would be sold in the iTunes Store. He added: I was a very prescient kid.

So why was it that the good people behind an amfAR benefit at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night still felt the need to spice up their party with a bunch of freshly depilated hunks wearing only boxer briefs?

title: Scene City: The AmfAR Benefit
description: The benefit was filled with a celebrity cast, and many, many near-naked male models.

title: From the Venice Cup Trials, Subterfuge and a Big Swing
description: The 96-board match that chose the U.S.A.-1 Venice Cup world championship team last week in Detroit was won by Sylvia Moss, Judi Radin and Migry Zur Campanile of New York and JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif. They combined well for a game swing on the diagramed deal, Board 74.

title: Women Rule a Marathon of New One-Act Plays
description: Intriguing women populate Series B of the Ensemble Studio Theaters 2011 one-act play marathon. Their backgrounds may be diverse, but the shared depth and detail of their personal histories makes their stories spill beyond the frames of the short works in which they appear.

title: Just One Look | Alexander Wang Resort
description: Alexander Wang is todays sports authority. With the debut of his first swimwear collection  eight athletic cutout and scuba style suits  his resort line focuses on swimming, cycling and running. Super roomy jackets were inspired by cycling uniforms. There were hints of basketball in the intarsia-knit jersey-style tops, and the perforated pants were all about the track. And speaking of running, its worth hoofing downtown for those red, blue and yellow colored kicks.

title: Hitsville U.S.A.: Detroit Rolls in Without Cars
description: For baby boomers theres no more surefire party starter than Motown songs. That made Motown Meets NYC an easy concept for Summerstages annual fund-raising gala. Rain on Tuesday night moved the concert indoors, from Central Park to Roseland, where the New York Pops orchestra backed 1960s Motown stalwarts  Martha Reeves, minus the Vandellas, and Dennis Edwards from the Temptations  and other singers for songs from the Motown canon and beyond.

title: Homes for $590,000
description: A duplex condo in downtown Atlanta; a 1932 house in Fort Worth, and an brick 1872 farmhouse in Chanhassen, Minn.

title: A Danish Modern Twist Updates Classical Ballet
description: See Naples and then die? In the passage of his memoirs that describes his visit to Naples and his subsequent composition of his three-act ballet Napoli (1842), the Danish choreographer August Bournonville quotes the old motto. Since the highlight of Napoli is the stream of uninterrupted dancing in its third act, this is often performed by itself and is the exuberant conclusion of the quadruple bill with which the Royal Danish Ballet opens its weeklong engagement at the David H. Koch Theater. Unfortunately the three ballets that precede it are each in different ways so depressing that the evening seems to say Die, die, die, and then see Napoli.

title: What You Get for ... $590,000
description: ATLANTA

title: Faces on Film Add Humanity to the News
description: If there is one hard lesson weve learned since 9/11, it is the degree to which fear lurking just below the placid surface of everyday existence can poison the social climate. Fear of terrorism, fear of disease, fear of the Other, of the Unknown, is easy to instill and hard to dislodge. Instead of surrendering blindly to paranoia, one way of combating it is to confront the very things that scare us the most.

title: Giffords Is Released From the Hospital
description: TUCSON, Ariz.  More than five months after being shot point-blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said.

title: For Starters
description: Think graphics, think floral. Just dont think too hard.

title: Restaurant Shirts Gain Admission
description: THOUGH Robert Graham shirts are sold nationally in hundreds of stores, the label does not yet engender the kind of instant recognition that makes marketing people salivate.

title: Thousands Protest Austerity Measures
description: Thousands joined a nationwide strike in Greece as Parliament prepared to debate a second round of sharp cuts to government spending.

title: Even in Custody, Bahrain Activists Use Twitter to Protest
description: Three women who were arrested in Bahrain on Wednesday as they tried to stage a sit-in at a United Nations office turned to Twitter to explain and document their protest, continuing to file updates even after they were taken into custody.

title: The Tom and Jerry Problem
description: If the 2012 election were held in the newsrooms of America and pitted Sarah Palin against Barack Obama, I doubt Palin would get 10 percent of the vote. However tempting the newsworthy havoc of a Palin presidency, Im pretty sure most journalists would recoil in horror from the idea.

title: Dracula Lurks in Your Set-Top Box
description: Imagine pulling into your parking space and just hopping out, leaving the car idling all day while youre at the office.

title: White House Report on U.S. Actions in Libya
description: The Obama administrations defense of its Libya policy includes an argument that the president has not violated the War Powers Resolution.

title: A Lifetime of Roles, Sometimes Two at a Time
description: PERFORMING two of Shakespeares problem plays in repertory during the wilting summer nights, contending all the while with low-flying helicopters and errant raccoons, can be challenging.

title: Stage Scenes: John Cullum
description: Photos of some of the actors past performances.

title: Newly Released Books
description: The ties in this months new books  between sisters, first loves and family members, real and improvised  dont break. In some cases, however, the characters might have liked a little more give.

title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Immokalee, Fla.
description: Fifty years after Edward R. Murrow concluded his tenure at CBS with Harvest of Shame, an arresting expose of migrant field workers in rural Florida, CBS News correspondent Byron Pitts returned to Floridas tomato, bean and sugarcane fields for an update. In Harvest of Shame: 50 Years Later, Mr. Pitts found that, while wages have improved, the work  when it could be found  is just as backbreaking as it was in 1960. Juan Lopez, a 62-year-old tomato picker in Immokalee, said he gets up before dawn hoping to find work; in 2009 he said he earned $7,800 for a full year of work.

title: In Sydney, Finding Room to Grow
description: A couple combined their building with an adjacent one to create a modern spin on the Victorian-era town house.

title: Their Space Solution Is Found Next Door
description: SYDNEY, Australia

title: Summer Fashions
description: Looks for $100 or less.

title: Easy Summer Looks With Prices to Match
description: JACQUELYN ORTIZ scours her favorite cheap-and-chic fashion outposts once or twice a week to stock up on a seasons worth of flowing dresses, tank tops, sandals and tees. In the summertime I do a lot more shopping, said Ms. Ortiz, who works at an advertising agency in New York.

title: Talking Heady
description: David Carr, who wrote the magazines profile of Keith Olbermann, doesnt just report stories. Sometimes hes the one the camera is trained on. As The Daily Beast, Underwire andSlate report  yes, sometimes new media do speak the truth  Carr is the breakout star of Andrew Rossis new documentary, Page One: A Year Inside the New York Times. Asked about his role in the film, Carr told The Daily Beast:My daughter, when she saw [the film], she said, You look like a thug. . . . Idont like how mean I am in the movie.

title: Hacking Group Says It Brought Down C.I.A. Site
description: 7:05 p.m. | Updated  Adding background on denial of service attacks, update on availability of C.I.A. site.

title: A Tool to Help Secure Your Browser
description: Web browsers are top targets for hackers. Theyre abused in more than 90 percent of attacks meant to hit random Internet users (versus more targeted strikes), according to Kaspersky Labs. And more than half of those attacks exploit flaws in browser software and seek to install dangerous malware on computers.

title: Royal Danish Ballet at the Koch Theater
description: Royal Danish Ballet is performing a weeklong engagement at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: This Time, Rangers Wilson Doesnt Mind Short Porch
description: Four Texas pitchers were taking batting practice around 2:30 p.m. Wednesday, but only one of them was taking his left-handed hacks in a Dirk Nowitzki T-shirt: C.J. Wilson. The free spirit of the bunch, Wilson deposited a few balls into the second deck in right field  which, as he playfully mentioned to a reporter, is different from the upper deck.

title: Just One Look | Gucci Resort
description: In a well executed version of Gucci minimalism, Frida Giannini relied on gold to add a lustrous note to simple basics, like this shining pleated skirt. The collection was up to the minute in current trends, from color blocking (red, white and purple sheath dresses) to funky pattern-on-pattern suits. Other standouts: her python skirt, lam top and a black jumper with a medallion broach on the shoulder, all accented in gold, what else?

title: Finding Frames That Fit
description: The Times's Simone Oliver and Stephanie Rosenbloom get refreshing tips for selecting sunglasses.

title: Shopping for Alarm Clocks With Jonas Damon
description: The New York industrial designer shopped for interesting alarm clocks.

title: Jean Prouvs Designs Reinterpreted
description: Many design purists consider Jean Prouv one of the most important designers of the 20th century. The idea, then, that anyone would think to alter his classic furnishings amounts to sacrilege. Yet thats exactly what the Dutch clothing company G-Star Raw has done, with the blessing of Prouvs manufacturer, Vitra.

title: Pop! Goes the Chandelier
description: The designer Lindsey Adelman is best known for her bubbles, the hand-blown spherical glass shades she uses to build a wide range of light fixtures.

title: Sales at Frette, ABC Carpet & Home, Canvas and Safavieh
description: Upholstered chairs, sofas and sectionals are up to 44 percent off at the Safavieh Home Furnishings seating sale, through July 5 (the Chester sofa, originally about $5,600, is $3,134; the Easton chair, regularly $1,065, is about $600; the Tufted sofa, originally $5,725, is $3,206); 902 Broadway (20th Street); (877) 919-1010 or safaviehhome.com.

title: Take an Old Master to Your Next Picnic
description: This summer, you might be surprised by the faces staring back from the picnic blanket.

title: Traditional Meets Quirky in a Campana Brothers Cafe
description: The cafe at the century-old Municipal Theater of So Paulo reopened to the public this week, with furnishings by the Brazilian designers Humberto and Fernando Campana, as part of a two-year-long renovation of the entire theater.

title: Todd Oldham
description: Todd Oldham has been many things in his 49 years: fashion designer, television personality, interior designer, product designer, film director, photographer and writer, just to name a few. Ive had the greatest privilege of having a lot of adventures, he said. But Ive been moving away from doing things where success is hinged on my face being stuck on things. Its a happy transition.

title: Lost in Time and Words, a Child Begins Anew
description: TO this day it is hard for me to speak about possessing any real sense of a home, at least during my childhood and adolescence. Or, to put this idea more precisely: whatever sense of a secure home life, of belonging, that I once felt as a boy was whisked out from under my feet at a tender age.

title: Alarm Clocks
description: FOR more than a decade, the New York industrial designer Jonas Damon has been giving some serious thought to alarm clocks.

title: Bringing in the Big Fans
description: SOMEWHERE in modern America, there are people who do not like air-conditioning. But they are awfully hard to find. After studying home energy use for decades as the principal research scientist at the Florida Solar Energy Center, Danny Parker puts the number of air-conditioning heretics at 1 to 2 percent of the population.

title: A Father, a Daughter, a Collaborative Garden
description: The garden behind John Frys house in Westchester is inhabited by a dozen or more creatures created by his daughter, Leslie Fry, a sculptor.

title: Sowing Enchantment
description: KATONAH, N.Y.

title: A Murder in Diepsloot
description: As horrified and shaken as I am by Barry Bearaks article Watching the Murder of an Innocent Man, I am also grateful for it. We are too often inured to what we do not ourselves confront, and we need to be shaken from our complacency. Some of the comments take the familiar tack of dehumanizing the other, of casting the murder of this man as an act committed by savages. Well, as others have noted, we all have the potential to be savages, all of us.

title: The Hunt for the Right Shades
description: I thought about buying a pair of round sunglasses this summer. I pictured myself wearing sphere-shaped tortoiseshell shades with bright red lipstick for the entire summer, until I changed my look again for fall. But something has held me back from running to the nearest optical boutique with debit card in hand. Fear, rooted in vanity, had me questioning whether round frames are the look for me.

title: First
description: In Let Me Take Off My Tinfoil Hat for a Moment, Bill Keller muses on conspiracy theories and discusses why otherwise smart people fall for crackpot conspiracy theories. I read the article to see if Keller would include in his examples how in reporting the events leading to the Iraq war, otherwise smart people at The Times fell for the malicious crackpot conspiracy theory of the Bush-Cheney administration that Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction that threatened the United States. But alas, no. Millions of people here and abroad, though, saw through this particularly wacky notion, the consequences of which, in deaths, displacements and destruction, are far worse than the consequences of some poor guy believing he has the key to the J.F.K. assassination.

title: Piercing Cats Is Cruelty, Judges Rule
description: Piercing kittens to give them a goth appearance is cruel, a panel of Pennsylvania judges has ruled.

title: Restoring Life to Mountain Retreat Where Mao Napped
description: MOGANSHAN, China  The first to build and occupy European-style stone villas atop this bamboo-cloaked mountain were the foreign missionaries. Then came Big-Ear Du and other Shanghai gangsters looking for a getaway (or maybe hideaway). Later still, the big guns rolled in: Chiang Kai-shek and Mao Zedong.

title: Competing Ideas for Saving Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Public Library Buys Timothy Learys Papers
description: When the Harvard psychologist and psychedelic explorer Timothy Leary first met the Beat poet Allen Ginsberg in 1960, he welcomed Ginsbergs participation in the drug experiments he was conducting at the university.

title: A Protest by Saudi Women, Seeking the Right to Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Suspend Jockey After Incident in Belmont
description: New York racing officials suspended jockey Rajiv Maragh for seven days on Wednesday for careless riding in the Belmont Stakes, saying he compromised the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdoms chance to win the third leg of the Triple Crown.

title: From the A.C.L.U.: When Immigrants Are Detained
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Finance Reform in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlantas Wet Infield Has the Mets Attention
description: ATLANTA  In response to a request by the Mets, the umpiring crew for Wednesday nights game at Turner Field was notified by Major League Baseball to keep an eye on the condition of the infield, which was so boggy and wet Tuesday night that Jose Reyes slipped three times on it and fell twice.

title: In France, Sauciness Extends Well Beyond Food
description: One thing has to be made clear right from the start: To the French, seduction is about compliments, smiles and mutual pleasure, not locking someone in a hotel room and trying to force her to have oral sex.

title: Bruins Win the Stanley Cup
description: The Cup is coming back to Boston.

title: Social Media Help Keep the Door Open to Sustained Dissent Inside Saudi Arabia
description: AL KHOBAR, Saudi Arabia  When Manal al-Sharif posted a video of herself breaking the law by driving her own black S.U.V. around this hot, flat city and called for a collective protest on Friday, the government responded harshly: she was jailed for nine days.

title: Inside the Timothy Leary Archives
description: Selections from Learys papers, which have been acquired by the New York Public Library.

title: Judge Is Asked to Throw Out Bondss Obstruction Conviction or to Retry the Case
description: The lawyers for Barry Bonds have asked a federal judge to throw out Bondss obstruction of justice conviction or to retry that charge, arguing that Bonds was unjustly convicted of unauthorized rambling during his grand jury testimony in 2003.

title: Swisher Finds Himself in Strange Spot
description: With Derek Jeter on the disabled list with a strained right calf, Joe Girardi has been forced to shuffle the Yankees lineup. He moved Nick Swisher to the leadoff spot Wednesday night for the first time since 2008, when he played for the Chicago White Sox.

title: After the Scandal, More of the Same at the I.M.F.
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Exit Near, Gates Speaks Bluntly of U.S. Allies
description: WASHINGTONRobert M. Gates has 15 days left as secretary of defense  just ask him  and has become ever more unleashed from the constraints of the job.

title: Around Tornado Deaths, a Nagging Tale of Shelter Denied
description: CORDOVA, Ala.  Everybody in town heard about it.

title: In Berlin, Moved by Music, Place and Memory
description: Our view of reality is conditioned by our position in space and time  not by our personalities as we like to think. Thus every interpretation of reality is based upon a unique position. Two paces east or west and the whole picture is changed.  Lawrence Durrell, Balthazaar

title: Activists by Invitation
description: No one loves an activist judge. We know this because members of the Senate Judiciary Committee are forever denouncing judicial activism and warning of its hidden dangers. Last summer, when Sen. Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, became the first member of the committee to oppose Elena Kagans Supreme Court nomination, he explained that the nominee had endorsed, and praised those who endorse, an activist judicial philosophy.

title: News Office in Jordan Is Damaged in an Attack
description: JERUSALEM  The offices of the French news agency in the Jordanian capital, Amman, were attacked on Wednesday by about 10 men who broke windows and destroyed furniture, a day after several hundred people demonstrated against the bureau, accusing it of harming the kingdom through its dispatches.

title: Our Lefty Military
description: As we search for paths out of Americas economic crisis, many suggest business as a paradigm for cutting costs. According to my back-of-the-envelope math, top C.E.O.s earn as much as $1 a second around the clock, partly by cutting medical benefits for employees. So they must be paragons of efficiency, right?

title: California Lawmakers Close Budget Gap
description: LOS ANGELES  The Democratic-controlled Legislature passed a stopgap state budget on Wednesday to close Californias $10 billion deficit.

title: A Case for Reform at Japan Tobacco
description: The Childrens Investment Fund was humiliated when it brandished the sword of shareholder activism at Japans corporate shogunates in 2008. Now the London hedge fund is back with what appears to be an even more foolhardy campaign  to prod the Japanese finance minister to shake up Japan Tobacco. But this time around the embattled government may have enough to gain to push for corporate reform.

title: Watching the Detectives
description: Los Angeles

title: Children on Medicaid Shown to Wait Longer for Care
description: Children with Medicaid are far more likely than those with private insurance to be turned away by medical specialists or be made to wait more than a month for an appointment, even for serious medical problems, a new study finds.

title: Ahmadinejads Fall, Americas Loss
description: Washington

title: Still Writing, Regulators Delay Rules
description: Regulators overseeing financial reform are delaying many of the planned changes in the immense market for complex securities known as derivatives because they are running drastically behind schedule in writing their new rules.

title: The Smokies Light Show
description: Thousands of tourists are drawn every year to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park to witness the mating ritual of a species of fireflies that blink in beautiful synchrony.

title: Plane Crashes Into Hudson River
description: A US Airways plane that took off from La Guardia Airport landed in the Hudson River, but all the passengers and crew appeared to be safe.

title: Czechs, Disliking Role, Pull Out of U.S. Missile Defense Project
description: BERLIN  The Czech Republic announced Wednesday that it was withdrawing from plans to participate in the United States missile defense program out of frustration at its diminished role in the system, which was conceived as a deterrent against a potential threat from Iran.

title: Fireflies, Following Their Leader, Become a Tourist Beacon
description: ELKMONT, Tenn.  Lynn Faust remembers the old days of firefly season here.

title: Nice Work if You Can Get It
description: New Yorks legislators plan to go home for the rest of the year on Monday, even though they have not finished what the public pays them to do. If they were students, they would earn Fs for diligence. Here are crucial measures still on the Legislatures to-do list:

title: Stoudemire Offers Wisdom to James
description: Amare Stoudemire gave LeBron James some public relations advice on Wednesday.

title: Blue, Gray and Everything in Between
description: While the colors blue and gray are almost iconically associated with the opposing ground forces of the Civil War, early in the conflict many regiments reporting for duty on either side were much more colorfully attired. Some rebel troops wore blue, some northern troops wore gray, units on both sides sported every shade of red, green, black, white or even tartan, and uniform patterns were almost completely non-standardized.

title: After Delay, Iranians Launch a Satellite
description: Iran said it launched a satellite into orbit on Wednesday that Western aerospace experts said could be used for limited military reconnaissance and also to monitor crops and track damage from earthquakes, flooding and other natural disasters.

title: Scientists See More Deadly Weather, but Dispute the Cause
description: WASHINGTON  The United States experienced some of the most extreme weather events in its history this spring, including deadly outbreaks of tornadoes, near-record flooding, drought and wildfires.

title: Tigers Ace Is Also a Drawing Card
description: DETROIT  In the sixth full season of his major league career, Justin Verlander is the Detroit Tigers biggest drawing card, providing a reason for fans to climb into their cars and drive hundreds of miles from across the state and other parts of the Midwest to watch him on the mound.

title: Can Justice Be Bought?
description: Two years ago, the Supreme Court tried to bolster public trust in the nations justice system by disqualifying a state judge in West Virginia from a case that involved a coal company executive who had spent more than $3 million to help get the judge elected.

title: A Place to Laugh, Cry, Hide, Complain ... and Verify a Scorecard
description: BETHESDA, Md.  It is called the scoring tent, and there may be no other space like it in sports. Although it occasionally is a hut, trailer or clubhouse room instead, the scoring tent is always the way station just steps from the 18th green where all golfers report directly after a round at the United States Open or other golf championship.

title: Cuomo Gives Lawmakers Ultimatum on Rent Laws
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he would not let lawmakers leave the capital at the scheduled end of the legislative session early next week unless they had come to an agreement on how to extend the states rent regulation laws.

title: Unaffordable Roaming
description: In a plugged-in, hyperglobalized world, one might expect that our communications networks would allow us to roam widely, cellphones and tablets connected to the matrix, no matter the location. But when it comes to telecommunications pricing, globalization stopped at the border.

title: When Sporting Cultures Collide
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

title: Untold Stories of How Everyone Got Here
description: Border-guarding Minutemen and immigrant-pummeling politicians should get a grip on this countrys history at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum in New York Harbor. Exhibits are planned to tell the full story of the teeming masses, including African slaves, displaced Indians, modern globetrotters and Know-Nothing nativists.

title: Labor Talks Offer Signs of Optimism for the N.F.L.
description: Earlier this month, as the prospect of a shortened N.F.L. season loomed, so did the pessimism about the state of labor negotiations as owners and players awaited a critical court ruling in their fight over how to divide billions of dollars.

title: Bloggingheads: Debt Ceiling Showdown
description: Daniel Drezner, left, of ForeignPolicy.com and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic discuss the fight over raising the debt ceiling.

title: Concern for Money, Not Safety, Was Behind Deutsche Fire, Prosecutor Says
description: The deaths in 2007 of two firefighters during a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan were caused by the actions of contractors working inside the building, a prosecutor repeatedly told jurors on Wednesday.

title: Nuclear Plant Safety Rules Inadequate, Group Says
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  Nuclear safety rules in the United States do not adequately weigh the risk that a single event would knock out electricity from both the grid and from emergency generators, as an earthquake and tsunami recently did at a nuclear plant in Japan, officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday.

title: Nuclear Plant, Left for Dead, Shows a Pulse
description: HOLLYWOOD, Ala.  Spider webs line the 50-story cooling towers, parts have been amputated for the scrap value of their nickel or copper, and the control room still has analog dials at Bellefonte 1, a half-built nuclear plant here that was shelved 23 years ago.

title: In a Harlem Basement, Beneath the Stars
description: After our Tonys romp, where we spent Sunday night nestled on a staircase with Joel Grey, in a phenomenally expensive hotel suite with a Bono and a Broderick  the air scented with scads of Diptyque candles so costly we estimate that each intake of our breath was worth at least $7, we have a confession: Nocturnalist was on a bit of a high.

title: Human Rights Watch Film Festival
description: Images of some of the films appearing in the festival, which runs June 16-30.

title: Where Others Have Gone Without Success, J.C. Penney Goes Again
description: Trying to redefine itself, Sears Holdings introduced a flurry of concepts when its new chairman, Edward S. Lampert, took over.

title: Ex-Spy Alleges Bush White House Sought to Discredit Critic
description: WASHINGTON  A former senior C.I.A. official says that officials in the Bush White House sought damaging personal information on a prominent American critic of the Iraq war in order to discredit him.

title: Learning to Navigate in the Citys Rough Waters
description: Kevin J. Walsh is three years into the 12-year training program  five years as an apprentice and seven as a deputy pilot  required of a full branch pilot, licensed by the state and federal government to board vessels offshore and navigate them into port through the devilish traffic and currents of New York Harbor. In essence, a pilot takes over for the captain of the ship, whether its a vacation cruise liner or a tanker with hazardous cargo. Mr. Walsh, 28, a 2005 graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, N.Y., is one of 14 apprentices with Sandy Hook Pilots on Staten Island. He lives in Point Pleasant, N.J., with his wife, Jacquline, a hairstylist, and their 19-month-old daughter, Willa.

title: For Police in the Bronx, a Ticket-Fixing Investigation Stirs Up Fear and Anger
description: A new policy intended to combat ticket-fixing in the Bronx requires that police officers hand their summonses to desk sergeants. But some officers are apparently taking the requirement a step further: they wait to watch the sergeant electronically scan those tickets, and even resist orders to return to patrol until they have seen the entire transaction.

title: Labor Coalition Is Divided Over Financial Rescue Plan
description: Members of New York Citys powerful municipal labor coalition met on Wednesday to discuss a financial rescue package that could prevent thousands of teachers from losing their jobs.

title: Thursday: Let Off Some Steam
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Earlier this week, we saw the debut of a young new constructor named Alex Vratsanos, who graduated from high school on the same day his puzzle was published. Today, just to make us all feel even older, we get to do a puzzle by someone who has mastered the art of crossword construction, but cannot drive himself to the store to pick up the newspaper in which it appears.

title: Drug Is Harder to Abuse, but Users Persevere
description: BROCKTON, Mass.  Michael Capece had been snorting OxyContin for five years when a new version of the drug, intended to deter such abuse, hit the market last summer. The reformulated pills are harder to crush, turning instead into a gummy substance that cannot be easily snorted, injected or chewed.

title: Top Agency Officials Knew of Disputed Gun Program
description: WASHINGTON  Knowledge of Operation Fast and Furious, a controversial border security strategy that allowed guns to be shipped illegally into Mexico in an effort to track them to drug cartels, went to the top of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, according to evidence released on Wednesday at a House Oversight Committee hearing.

title: At Congressional, a Few Players Dare to Talk About Fun
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Four competitors rocking out on the eve of the 111th United States Open in a new music video may, or may not, rival the impact of the Chicago Bears Super Bowl Shuffle from Super Bowl XX, but the slickly produced spoof has lightened the atmosphere of a traditionally staid week.

title: In Case You Missed It, the 2014 World Cup Just Started
description: Less than a year after Spain lifted the World Cup trophy in South Africa, and nearly three years to the day before the next one begins in Brazil, the 2014 tournament quietly began on Wednesday with the first qualifier.

title: Rep. Giffords Released From Houston Rehabilitation Center
description: TUCSON  More than five months after being shot point blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said.

title: Journeymans Long Trail Takes Him to Bronx
description: In need of a starting pitcher on Thursday afternoon, the Yankees will turn to a former outfielder with 3,810 at-bats over a 15-year minor league career and only four innings of work pitching in the majors, all in 2008.

title: Pakistans Chief of Army Fights to Keep His Job
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is fighting to save his position in the face of seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, according to Pakistani officials and people who have met the chief in recent weeks.

title: American Retailers Try Again in Europe
description: PARIS  On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Champs-lyses was packed with people enjoying this citys most famous boulevard  window shopping, sipping wine at sidewalk cafes and strolling toward the river with ice cream cones.

title: At Empire State Building, a Feud Over a Virtual Tour of New York
description: It is pretty much compulsory on any tourists to-do list. You ascend to the 86th-floor Observatory of the Empire State Building and soak in the big city in all its dizzying splendor, and probably get dizzy yourself.

title: Coughlin Takes In a Ballgame
description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said the N.F.L. lockout had left him feeling disoriented because of the absence of practices and routine preparations typically associated with the run-up to the season. But he got close to players on Wednesday night.

title: Separate Bills Focus on Two Pieces of Immigration Puzzle
description: WASHINGTON  For many lawmakers in Congress, the immigration issue has become too hot to touch, especially with presidential campaigns starting up and voters, burdened with persistent unemployment, in a volatile mood. But competing bills introduced this week, one by Republicans and another by Democrats, show small but consequential steps on immigration that leaders on both sides think they might accomplish in coming months, before electoral politics overwhelm the debate.

title: Wisconsin: Law Curbing Unions Is Back in Court
description: Several unions filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday to block a law that limits collective bargaining rights for public workers in the state. A day earlier, the Wisconsin Supreme Court reinstated the law, overruling a lower courts decision to halt it because it had been passed improperly. The unions, which represent teachers and state and city workers, say provisions of the law violate the Constitution by singling out only some public workers and not others.

title: Massachusetts: Ex-Speaker Guilty of Taking Kickbacks

The waterfront  with views of wide, tentacled Narragansett Bay  is still Newports soul, and the estates along Bellevue Avenue havent lost their Gilded Age glamour. title: Living the Good Lie
description: Denis Flanigan isnt hiding anything. A 42-year-old psychotherapist in Houston, he has a straightforward manner that meshes nicely with his no-nonsense buzz cut and neatly clipped goatee. Unlike many mental-health professionals, Flanigan puts personal items on display in his office, including a photo of his partner, who is attractive, and male. For his patients amusement he has on hand an S-and-M Barbie as well as a Tickle Me Freud doll. (Its so, so . . . wrong, Flanigan told me, in a tone that signaled he believed it was exactly right.) Flanigans no-secrets policy extends to his Web site, where he writes that he has frequently been asked to speak on the gay and lesbian experience and mental health, transgender concerns and body-modification issues. A member of the American Psychological Association, Flanigan has also served as Mr. Prime Choice Texas, winning a contest designed for men 40 years or older who represent the masculine aesthetic embraced by the leather/Levi/uniform/fetish community. In his own words, he identifies as a militant homosexual.

title: Need a Kidney? A Skull? Just Bring Cash

Many of the real-life examples he cites in this chilling volume cannot help but remind the reader of a horror movie, or of Kazuo Ishiguros devastating dystopian novel Never Let Me Go (2005), in which we learn that a group of children are clones who have been raised to donate replacement body parts.

I, by contrast, know almost nothing about how The New York Times works.

In any case, the film, directed with bounce and snap by Mark Waters, stands as a comeback of sorts for Jim Carrey, who mugs and prances and does funny voices and manages not to be upstaged by a half-dozen flightless birds. The birds  real gentoo penguins with computer-enhanced abilities  honk, defecate and waddle around Manhattan while Mr. Carreys Popper, at first vexed and then beguiled by the creatures, tries to deal with them, his job, his children and the state of his soul.

title: Broadways Next Stanley Kowalski: Blair Underwood

The television actor Blair Underwood (The Event, L.A. Law) is known to be popular with the ladies. Plus he is a great actor, the theater producer Stephen C. Byrd said on Thursday. One plus one plus one. And even better news is, this role is a great fit for him.

title: The Songs Of Prince, Faithfully Reimagined
description: Meshell Ndegeocello outlined a catalog of social and natural disasters at one point in her sold-out show at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. You turn on the telly and every other story/Is tellin you somebody died, she sang in her deep-shadow vocal register, a notch or two above a murmur. The tune was Sign o the Times, by Prince, rearranged for upright bass, pinging keyboards and hazy rhythm. The overhaul affected everything but melody and lyrics, amplifying the bitterness in the song.

title: ESPNs Bill Simmons
description: Those of us who remember Bill Simmons from his Boston Sports Guy days cant possibly love him as much now as we did then. Back then, he really was one of us  just another fan  and his fatalistic tone was perfect for the awful Boston sports scene of the late 90s and very early 2000s. Jonathan Mahler would have done well to mention that the unprecedented success of Boston sports franchises over the last decade did a lot to boost Simmonss profile, particularly in the mid-2000s; I wonder whether a Cleveland Sports Guy or a Buffalo Sports Guy would have had the same success. In fact, I wonder whether a Cleveland Sports Guy, just as witty and clever as Simmons, has been writing for a tiny audience for years and is seething about living in a town that has arguably the most depressing sports scene in America.

title: Moving On Simply by Moving Out
