This weekend, Susan Rethorst: Retro(intro)spective, programmed by Ms. Ring, concludes the series with two new works  208 East Broadway Part 3: Over and Out, which was shown for the first time on Tuesday evening and 208 East Broadway Part 4: Sold, a performance installation that will be presented on Saturday afternoon.

title: Wheelies: The Normalcy Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Piano Tour of Schoenbergs Career
description: My only intention is to have no intentions, Schoenberg wrote in 1909, the year he composed his landmark Three Piano Pieces (Op. 11), no formal, architectural or other artistic intentions (except perhaps of capturing the mood of a poem), no aesthetic intentions.

title: In Mahlers Chamber, a Radical Departure
description: How often do you encounter a program of chamber music named for Mahler? Only one Mahler chamber work has survived in the literature; or rather, part of a work. What we call the Piano Quartet in A minor  written around 1876, when Mahler was 16  was intended as the first movement of a larger piece, otherwise represented by only 24 bars of a scherzo.

title: Anthony Weiner Resigns
description: At last, there was a dignified moment in the decline and fall of Anthony Weiner.

title: Norah ODonnell Leaves NBC for CBS
description: CBS announced Thursday that it had hired Norah ODonnell, the long-time Washington-based correspondent for NBC News, as its new chief White House correspondent.

title: Pawlenty Goes After Romney
description: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Four days after declining to criticize Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, during a Republican presidential debate, Tim Pawlenty acknowledged his flub in a Twitter message on Thursday.

title: Andrea Catsimatidis and Christopher Cox
description: RICHARD NIXON could never have scripted it  that it would take a Democrat to help his avowedly Republican oldest grandson fall head over heels in love.Yet that is what fate had in store in April 2008 for Christopher Nixon Cox, then 29 and working for Senator John McCains presidential campaign.

title: The Caveat to Early Preference Polls
description: As polls measuring voters preferences in the 2012 presidential election abound, one finding is important to note at this early stage in the campaign to help put them into context: the large majority of voters, including Republican voters, are simply not yet tuned in.

title: Merciless Congressional Takes Toll on Former Champions
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Ernie Els, the 1997 United States Open champion, and Jim Furyk, who won in 2003, were having pretty good outing Thursday at Congressional Country Club until a few measly holes ruined everything.

title: A Plea From South Kordofan State, Sudan
description: This week, Sudanese airstrikes near Kadugli and Kauda in Southern Kordofan have made access for reporters to the contested area all but impossible. The following email is from a South Sudanese humanitarian worker who is trapped in a United Nations Mission in the Sudan (UNMIS) camp, which is apparently surrounded by Sudanese forces. It seems to be consistent with other reports that have trickled in throughout the last few days.

title: The Unsung Queen of the Colonial Revival
description: THE Museum of the City of New Yorks new exhibition, The American Style: Colonial Revival and the Modern Metropolis, covers the energetic movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries to restore the homespun virtues of the 18th.

title: Lawmakers Seek Assurances on Bank Regulations
description: Financial regulators sought to reassure lawmakers that they could coordinate with global officials and still maintain industry competitiveness as they rewrote Wall Street oversight rules.

title: Making the Switch to Rentals
description: ELIZABETH

title: Reunited by Kia, and Ready for Adventure
description: Kia Motors America is getting the old gang together again.

title: Paying Off Your Mortgage Early
description: JUST because you own a home doesnt mean you have to keep carrying a mortgage  about a third of American homeowners dont, according to the Federal Reserve.

title: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Voluntary Disclosure Form
description: A summary of evidence to be used against Dominique Strauss-Kahn provides insight into the early hours of his arrest.

title: Q & A
description: Security Concerns Over Broken Buzzer

title: Stephen M. Ross
description: Mr. Ross, 71, is the chairman, chief executive and founder of the Related Companies in New York, which is best known for the Time Warner Center. Among the companys latest projects is the development of the 26-acre Hudson Yards.

title: Court Papers Detail Strauss-Kahns Statements After Arrest
description: About 15 minutes after police detectives from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pulled Dominique Strauss-Kahn off a Paris-bound flight, he told them he had diplomatic immunity, according to a document filed by prosecutors on Thursday.

title: Truth Behind Watergate Uncertain, Even With Technology
description: A high-tech attempt to plug the mysterious 18 -minute gap in the Watergate tapes turned up a tantalizing clue, the National Archives and Records Administration said Thursday, but ultimately proved inconclusive in solving the scandals most intriguing questions: What did President Richard M. Nixon know, and when did he know it?

title: Take Mugwort and Call Us in a Week
description: Dragons blood incense, musky and sweet, burns from an altar. The rich smoke wafts across an 18th-century Bible and through shimmering peacock feathers, mingling in midair with hundreds of allies: roasted dandelion root, Irish moss flakes, horny goat weed, astragalus.

title: Ecoexistence Project
description: A Palestinian and an Israeli engineer crossed borders and barriers to work together on establishing a sustainable future for their joint environment.

title: Use Twitter? Always Remember These Three Things
description: Congressman Anthony Weiners resignation on Thursday was triggered by a Twitter mistake last month that he admitted making.

title: Pakistani Journalists Threatened After Filming Police Shootings
description: As Pakistani officials investigate two cases of extrajudicial killings caught on video, both cameramen report that they have been threatened for having recorded the incidents.

title: Alternative Worlds Where Even McMansions Are Tiny
description: In the age of the flat screen, a show about the diorama sounds charmingly nave. The word itself conjures benign images of hobbyists with tweezers and sixth graders with shoeboxes.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Grill? Check. Flip-flops? Check. Vernon Reid, founder of Living Colour? Check.

title: Allergic to Homework and Possibly Smitten
description: Someday every overprivileged, misunderstood high school boy who has ever come of age in New York will have his own movie, and one good thing about The Art of Getting By is that it brings that day, the day we can move on to other matters, a little closer. Another good thing about the movie, written and directed by Gavin Wiesen, is Emma Roberts, who plays the protagonists beguiling and elusive soul mate. She did similar duty in Its Kind of a Funny Story  also rising above its above-averageness  which makes you wonder when she will get a coming-of-age story for herself.

title: Long Dead, Yet Somehow Vaguely Alive
description: PHILADELPHIA  After a while, you get used to the trappings of death: the vacant, hollow stares; prongs of teeth protruding from desiccated gums; the shriveled flesh pulled like dried leather over jutting joints. And theres a dreadful uniformity in those signs, whether you look at the remains of a 500-year-old dog that was found in 1953 in a peat bog in Germany or at an 800-year-old embalmed child from Peru who had been interred in a crunched and compact crouch.

title: Intruders at the Window, and Then a Nightmare
description: The money shot in the Spanish horror thriller "Kidnapped" lasts only a split second, but you are not likely to forget it. What looks like a hunk of chopped meat with wet marbles stuck into it is actually a bashed-in face.

title: Up Front: Stacey DErasmo
description: Before Stacey DErasmos first novel, Tea, came out in 2000, she worked for seven years in the late 1980s and early 1990s as a senior editor at The Village Voice Literary Supplement in downtown New York.

title: Loud Music, Clean Living
description: The ambition of Ten Thousand Saints, Eleanor Hendersons debut novel about a group of unambitious lost souls, is beautiful. In nearly 400 pages, Henderson does not hold back once: she writes the hell out of every moment, every scene, every perspective, every fleeting impression, every impulse and desire and bit of emotional detritus. She is never ironic or underwhelmed; her preferred mode is fierce, devoted and elegiac.

title: Wrapped Up
description: Images from the new Mummies of the World exhibition at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

title: Battle for Libya | June 16, 2011
description: Libyan government minders took foreign journalists to the scene of a bombing hours after a NATO strike in Tripoli.

title: Derby Champion Has Leg Injury After Belmont
description: The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom, who was bumped and nearly unseated his jockey in the opening strides of the Belmont Stakes, has a minor injury to his left hind leg.

title: House Tour: Southampton, N.Y.
description: An interior designer finds a Hamptons getaway that doesnt need to be rebuilt. And its next to a horse farm.;

title: House Tour: Southampton, N.Y.
description: WHAT Four-bedroom house.

title: Life in the Big House: The Danish Experience
description: For a mild-mannered movie critic the Danish prison drama R, set in a maximum-security penitentiary, raises inescapable personal questions: Could I survive in such a brutal environment, and if so, how? I should add that R is far from the most harrowing prison film ever made. And life inside Horsens State Prison, the Danish institution, now closed, where the movie was filmed with a cast that includes former inmates and guards, isnt as hellish as the situation behind bars is portrayed in American movies, some of which are so gory they qualify as prison porn. But it is awful enough.

title: Long Memory or Short, Boston Fans Savor Success
description: BOSTON  To Brittany Shepard, life without a Boston sports championship every year or two is like the days before text messages and Twitter: a bygone era she simply cannot fathom.

title: Banished in California, Dance Event Edges East
description: LAS VEGAS  The Electric Daisy Carnival drew nearly 160,000 people to the Los Angeles Coliseum last year for a two-day outdoor extravaganza of electronic music and dazzling visual displays.

title: Caution Needed in Changing Share Disclosure Rule
description: A new plan to ease a disclosure rule that has been burdensome for private companies like Facebook gets it only half right. Tweaking, rather than gutting, the current requirements would be a better way to balance companies accessing capital with investor protection.

title: Young Lords and Ladies of the Dance
description: Girls may do it in wigs, and boys may do it in secret, but Irish dancing  if the documentary Jig is any indication  is nothing if not exhibitionist. Tracking eight international aspirants on their pogoing path to the 2010 Irish Dancing World Championships in Glasgow, this programmatic entry in the tykes-and-trophies genre has too much on its plate and not nearly enough on its mind.

title: Plenty of Seats, but Only One Behind the Wheel
description: My stepfather has asked me to accompany him and my mother to the airport two hours away, and then drive their car back. He insists on driving to the airport because he is a nervous passenger. But I dont feel safe when he drives. He goes too fast and has had accidents in the past. Ive explained my concerns to my mother, but she wont get involved. How can I ask him to slow down and be more careful? Hes thin-skinned, and I dont want him to blow his stack. But Im not risking my life just to keep him happy.

title: Meatless Mondays Catch On, Even With Carnivores
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Friction between the health-and-eco-minded hippies who came here for a Rocky Mountain High in the 1970s and the superwealthy second-homers who followed from the intersection of Hollywood and Hedge Fund is an old story here at 8,000 feet.

title: In Brooklyn, Pushing Back Against a Redevelopment Plan
description: Battle for Brooklyn, a documentary about the unending mess that is the Atlantic Yards project, is unabashedly slanted and as a result will probably be dismissed by those it portrays unflatteringly. Thats unfortunate, because this film should be discouraging and dismaying for people on all sides of the project, for what it says about oversize expectations and missed opportunities.

title: Partisan Politics, Public Frustration
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Suspect Need Miranda Warning? It May Depend on Age, Justices Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court issued four decisions in criminal cases on Thursday, including one ruling that a suspects age must be taken into consideration in deciding whether to issue Miranda warnings.

title: Seeking a Balance: Part-Time Doctor and Mom
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Schools in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: How China Behaves
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sound of (Experimental) Music
description: Hows this for pedagogy? I teach so that you wont be able to write music. Thats Schoenberg quoted by his student John Cage in Jacqueline Cauxs film The Colors of the Prism, the Mechanics of Time. As for Cage, what interests him most, he says in an archival interview (in French), are the ugliest things, because in the end we realize that theyre not ugly at all, but life itself.

title: Day After in Vancouver: Dissecting a Failed Run
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The first question on the minds of Vancouver Canucks fans Thursday morning was: what went so terribly wrong in the Stanley Cup finals?

title: My Dinner With Prince Philip
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Urge Cuomo to Alter Same-Sex Marriage Bill
description: ALBANY  Several Republican senators in New York are urging Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to consider changing his proposed same-sex marriage bill to better protect religious institutions, addressing a concern that has emerged as one of the bills chief obstacles as the legislative session comes to an end.

title: Venus Williams Loses
description: Venus Williams lost to Daniela Hantuchova, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2, in the quarterfinals of the Eastbourne tournament in England. She was playing her first event in five months since retiring with hip and abdominal injuries during the Australian Open. Williams said she was headed to Wimbledon with plenty of confidence as she targets a sixth title. I played a lot of matches here, spent a lot of time on the court, Williams said. Its not the best luck today, but I feel good about my preparation. (AP)

title: Sleazy Charm, Bloody Ends
description: The past few years have offered impressive European accounts of celebrated career criminals. There was Olivier Assayass sprawling Carlos, the story of Ilich Ramrez Snchez, the international killer called Carlos the Jackal, and Jean-Franois Richets Mesrine: Public Enemy No. 1 and Mesrine: Killer Instinct, about the French gangster Jacques Mesrine. Matteo Garrones dispassionate, corrosive Gomorrah recounted the enterprises of the Camorra, the Neapolitan Mafia.

title: Gates Stresses the Importance of Ties With Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and the nations top military officer said on Thursday that it was critical for the United States to maintain ties with Pakistan despite growing anti-Americanism in the Pakistani military and the worst relationship between the two countries in years.

title: Delivering a Lawyer Within 15 Minutes (Soda Extra)
description: The wheels of justice tend to be slow, but arrests can happen with lightning speed  and what happens next can be crucial. In searches, seizure and interrogation, things can go badly wrong.

title: The Best Unknown Park in America
description: CHINLE, Ariz.  On the floor of Canyon de Chelly, what pops up in three dimensions of desert light are the remains of 900-year-old stone apartments, the graveyard of peach trees cut down by Kit Carsons Indian killers, and sandstone walls that drew the cameras of Edward Curtis and Ansel Adams.

title: France: C.E.O. of Nuclear Company to Be Replaced
description: One of the most prominent female executives in France was pushed out of her job on Thursday when the French government said it would replace Anne Lauvergeon as chief executive of Areva, one of the worlds largest nuclear power companies. Areva, which she created in 2001 in a merger of other nuclear companies, is majority-owned by the state. Ms. Lauvergeon, 51, will be succeeded by Luc Oursel, also 51, who had headed Arevas nuclear reactor business before becoming chief operating officer. Her departure at the end of the month caps a struggle with Henri Proglio  a favorite of President Nicolas Sarkozy  who runs the state electric utility, an important Areva customer.

title: Umenyiora Says Giants Broke Contract Pledge
description: Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora, in a coming affidavit that will become part of the N.F.L. players antitrust lawsuit against the league, says General Manager Jerry Reese did not make good on a promise to renegotiate his contract or to trade him to another team before last season.

title: RIM Profit Falls Below Estimates
description: OTTAWA  After reducing its profit forecast seven weeks ago, Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry, turned in earnings results on Thursday that were even worse than analysts lowered expectations.

title: Arguing, Again, Over Terrorism Trials
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and the top Republican in the Senate, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, traded barbs on Thursday about whether terrorism suspects captured on American soil should be prosecuted in regular civilian court or sent to Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to face trial before a military commission.

title: The Spanish Police Arrest a Mubarak Associate
description: Madrid  Hussein Salem, a close associate of former President Hosni Mubarak who has been accused of corruption and squandering public money, was arrested on Wednesday by the Spanish police, Europa Press, a Spanish news agency, reported late on Thursday.

title: Call Off the Global Drug War
description: Atlanta

title: For Weiners Successor, Perhaps, Lame-Duck Status
description: So, who wants to be a lame-duck freshman?

title: Utilities Turn to Mergers as Demand for Power Slows
description: Even as the number of tablet computers, electric vehicles and Internet data centers multiply rapidly, electricity demand is barely growing. Low-power processors, smarter manufacturing plants, rooftop solar panels and other technologies are keeping a lid on electricity use.

title: Side Effects of Arrests for Marijuana
description: The Bloomberg administration says that by arresting more than 350,000 people for having small amounts of marijuana since 2002, the police have helped drive down serious crime  and that the consequences for the people locked up have been minimal.

title: Workers Swarm Trenton on Benefit Changes
description: Thousands of angry government workers swarmed New Jerseys Capitol on Thursday and some were briefly arrested, one day after Gov. Chris Christie and legislative leaders agreed to sharply increase the contributions public employees must make into their health insurance and pensions plans.

title: Making the Most of His Moment
description: As he sat hunched in front of his nameplate-less dressing stall late Thursday morning, looking away from the posh Yankees clubhouse and into a rack of assorted field wear, Brian Gordon could not have envisioned a day as eternally gratifying as the one that was about to unfold.

title: Facebook Readies an iPad App, Finally
description: Facebook had its application for the iPhone ready right when the Apple App Store opened in July 2008. But more than a year after the iPad went on sale, there is still no official Facebook app for it.

title: Hockey Hangover Turns Into Riot Embarrassment
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Canadas grand obsession, hockey, led to great national embarrassment when the defeat of the Vancouver Canucks set off one of the countrys worst episodes of rioting in recent decades.

title: A Schizophrenic, a Slain Worker, Troubling Questions
description: Across Massachusetts, many are asking the timely but uncomfortable question of whether continual budget cuts played a role in the death of a mental health worker.

title: Pinnacle Thats Not Out of Reach for the Regular Guy
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Michael Tobiason Jr. always wears black socks when playing golf. Ryan Nelson has caddied for himself. Chris Williams catches fish with his bare hands.

title: Same-Sex Marriage Opponents Frustrated in N.Y. Lobbying
description: ALBANY  The Rev. Duane R. Motley, a Baptist minister, stood in a marble hallway in the Capitol on Thursday, frustrated. Behind the closed door, all of the Senate Republicans were meeting with one of the states most prominent supporters of same-sex marriage, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But Mr. Motley, a leading opponent of same-sex marriage, could not get the same audience.

title: Epistemology and the End of the World
description: In the coming weeks, The Stone will feature occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

title: Hows the Weather?
description: LATELY, the Sun has been behaving a bit strangely. In 2008 and 2009, it showed the least surface activity in nearly a century. Solar flare activity stopped cold and weeks and months went by without any sunspots, or areas of intense magnetism. Quiet spells are normal for the Sun, but researchers alive today had never seen anything like that two-year hibernation.

title: A Schizophrenic, a Slain Worker, Troubling Questions
description: BOSTON  Last November, Yvette Chappell found herself increasingly anxious that her 27-year-old son, Deshawn James Chappell, was spiraling downward into deep psychosis. He was exhibiting intense paranoia and calling late at night to complain about deafening voices in his head.

title: Those Manly Men of Yore
description: WHAT was he thinking? Thats the question columnists, talking heads and my (mostly female) friends have been asking about Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York, who announced Thursday that he would resign, just over a week after admitting hed sent sexually explicit photographs and messages to women over the Internet.

title: At Bronx High School, Field Is 20 Yards Short of Being a Home
description: For decades it has been an inconvenience bordering on embarrassment. Herbert H. Lehman High School, with an enrollment of more than 4,000 students in the Bronx, has never played a home football game simply because its field, at 80 yards, is too short for regulation contests.

title: Transit Agency Weighs a Digital Upgrade for Aging Subway Cars
description: New York City Transit is looking for a way to bring some of its older subway cars into the digital age.

title: Miranda Rights for Middle Schoolers
description: In the landmark Miranda case, the Supreme Court ruled that the Constitutions guarantee against self-incrimination required that police warn criminal suspects about their right to remain silent and to have a lawyer present when they are taken into custody for questioning.

title: Extra Vitamins? A Great Idea, Except in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN  For the last seven years, Marianne Orum has owned a narrow store in a charming street in the heart of this Danish capital.

title: Bidder for Share of Mets Sheds Light on the Process
description: On Friday, May 20, just six days before the Mets disclosed they had come to an agreement with David Einhorn to buy part of the team, Ray Bartoszeks accountant received a call from Terry Morris at Allen & Company, the firm retained by the Mets to facilitate the sale.

title: East Tennessees Unruly Unionists
description: When the East Tennessee Convention reconvened on June 17 in Greeneville, a small town near the North Carolina border, the Union-minded delegates assembled on what was technically Confederate soil  though nothing in their defiant tone acknowledged the fact.

title: China: Media Coverage of a Study Embarrasses Party
description: A media storm over corrupt officials is embarrassing Chinas Communist Party as it prepares to celebrate its 90th birthday on July 1. The news coverage has focused on a study circulating on the Internet claiming that corrupt officials have fled the country with more than $100 billion since the mid-1990s, mainly to the United States. It is unclear who wrote the 71-page study, which is marked internal material but has no author, letterhead or other identifying features. It was reported to have been posted on the Web site of the Peoples Bank of China. It remains online, but not on the banks Web site.

title: Wuerffel Found to Have Disorder
description: The last time Danny Wuerffel was in Birmingham, Ala., it was 2002 and he considered his trip serious business. Dr. James Andrews, the noted orthopedic surgeon, was examining Wuerffels shoulder, which he had injured while playing quarterback for the Washington Redskins.

title: Public Gardens Turn on the Charm
description: IF you are still bummed by the endless 2011 winter and sunless spring, heres a way to put your blues away: Get out into a public garden. They weathered many tough months too, but theyve recovered, are full of color and ready to charm. In mid-May I toured Western and Central Connecticut, visiting gardens of varying size, style and spirit. Here are five favorites.

title: Pretty in Petals
description: Four public gardens in Western Connecticut offer something for everybody.

title: The Rewards of Renewal
description: In Self-Renewal, a landmark book on how societies innovate, John W. Gardner wrote that the task for every new generation was not to stand a dreary watch over the ancient values but to face the bracing truth that it is their task to re-create those values continuously in their own behavior, facing the dilemmas and catastrophes of their own time. Society, he added, was not like a machine that is created at some point in time and then maintained with a minimum of effort; a society is being continuously re-created, for good or ill, by its members. This will strike some as a burdensome responsibility, but it will summon others to greatness.

title: Concern for Vast Social Services Database on the Citys Neediest
description: New York City has spent the past 18 months developing a database on four million residents, most of them the citys neediest, which officials say will enhance social services but which advocates for the poor say could put their privacy at risk.

title: Little Consensus on the Candidates
description: After the chicken salad sandwiches were handed out and people had their fill of A.B.O. (Anybody but Obama) jokes, the Republican Women of Madison got down to business.

title: Assessing the Field
description: Wednesday nights meeting of the Sandown Republican Committee was a lesson in New Hampshire traditions: painstakingly scrutinizing presidential candidates and fanatically rooting for Boston sports teams.

title: Who Is James Johnson?
description: Most political scandals involve people who are not really enmeshed in the Washington establishment  people like Representative Anthony Weiner or Representative William Jefferson. Most scandals involve spectacularly bad behavior  like posting pictures of your private parts on the Web or hiding $90,000 in cash in your freezer.

title: Young Chicagoans With Varied Opinions
description: About a mile from President Obamas 2012 re-election headquarters, a crowd of young Republicans was swelling at an Irish bar. If Republicans in Democrat-ruled cities like Chicago sometimes sound lonely and gloomy, particularly with a hometown Democrat in the White House, they were anything but that now.

title: Many Choices in the G.O.P. Field
description: The Republicans who bellied up to the bar at a trendy restaurant here Wednesday for an evening of drinks and politics agreed on neither the beverages they sipped nor the presidential candidates they backed. But as the servers took order after order, and as the drinks fueled spirited conversations on the fledgling presidential campaign, one thing was clear: nobody felt as though they lacked choices.

title: A Sneaky Attack on Clean Water Rules
description: Congress often kills or delays federal regulations it doesnt like by simply denying agencies the money they need to carry them out. This spares Congress from actually debating the regulation on its merits.

title: Among the Dead
description: The Spoon River Project is performed amid the gravestones of Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Libya and the War Powers Act
description: It would be hugely costly  for this countrys credibility, for the future of NATO and for the people of Libya  if Congress were to force President Obama to abandon military operations over Libya. However, Mr. Obama cannot evade his responsibility, under the War Powers Act, to seek Congressional approval to continue the operation.

title: Magazines Host Parties, and Introduce Some Brands
description: AS traditional media become increasingly willing to try the nontraditional, magazines are exploring ways to promote themselves and brands sold by their advertisers.

title: For Syrian Refugees, Shelter of a Precarious Sort
description: KHIRBET AL-JOUZ, Syria  Hundreds of displaced Syrians were gathered at a makeshift refugee camp in a plum orchard near the Turkish border on Thursday, growing increasingly anxious after Syrian security forces attacked two nearby towns.

title: City Reduces Chronic Absenteeism in Public Schools
description: At Public School 309 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, students wear necklaces with colorful pendants, each marking a month in which they did not miss a day of school. At P.S. 75 in the South Bronx, a row of young adults welcomes students each morning as they walk in the door. Some 40,000 city children got daily automated wake-up calls from Magic Johnson and other celebrities to remind them to show up for class, and City Hall offered prizes like baseball tickets and gift certificates.

title: Lottery Numbers
Plan for Hydroelectric Dam in Patagonia Outrages Chileans
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A white gas mask hanging from her neck, Paula Baados strode side by side with 30,000 other marchers through this capital one recent Friday, a determined look on her face.

title: Lockout II: In N.B.A., the Effects Are Instant
description: They are holding meetings, swapping proposals, rhetoric and suspicious glances, and pursuing a labor deal that could stabilize the N.B.A. and avert a costly lockout. But the lockout, in so many ways, is already in effect.

title: Worries Grow About Breadth of Debt Crisis
description: The tumult in the European monetary zone is spreading concern among investors of a broader crisis in financial markets from Ireland to Spain.

title: Friday: Hunter With Rough Hair
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Ah, Fridays. Based on the mail I get, I would have to say that reactions to the late week puzzles vary widely. There are those of you who avoid the trickier grids like the plague, only venturing into the early week puzzles for fear of defeat at the hands of those evil themeless constructors. There are also quite a few of you who only do the late week puzzles because they are the only ones that pose a real challenge to you. Still some of you, who shall remain nameless, do only the Saturday grid blindfolded, using only every third down clue, mentally translating everything into Latin while reciting the whole of Shakespeares works backward. Whatever works for you, is my philosophy.

title: Wall Street Braces for New Layoffs as Profits Wane
description: Wall Street plans to get smaller this summer. Faced with weak markets and uncertainty over regulations, many of the biggest firms are preparing for deep cuts in jobs and other costs.

title: For Collins, Facing Angels Doesnt Mean Much Now
description: ATLANTA  On Friday, for the first time since he left the Anaheim Angels in 1999, Terry Collins will get a chance to manage against his old team.

title: A Tough Day for Farmers as Lawmakers Look for Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  The House approved large cuts in food aid for the poor and various agriculture programs on Thursday after a steely weeklong debate that pitted Democrats against Republicans, and farm-state members against those within their own party who vehemently oppose certain types of farm aid.

title: Narcotics Detective Faces Perjury Charges
description: The narcotics detective had testified that while sitting in his unmarked car, he saw a man selling crack cocaine along Bronx Boulevard.

title: Weiner Wont Speak at High School Commencement
description: Anthony D. Weiners alma mater confirmed Thursday that it had canceled his speech at its graduation because of the scandal surrounding his sexually explicit communications with women.

title: Attorney General and Senator Clash on Where to Try Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and the top Republican in the Senate, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, traded barbs on Thursday about whether terrorism suspects captured on American soil should be prosecuted in regular civilian court or sent to Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to face trial before a military commission.

title: Conflicts Imperil Future Khmer Rouge Trials
description: BANGKOK  As it prepares to open its most complex and significant case, a United Nations-backed Cambodian tribunal trying former Khmer Rouge leaders has been torn by conflict over what critics are calling interference by the Cambodian government and inaction by the United Nations.

title: Architect, 82, Dies Weeks After Being Robbed and Beaten
description: A Manhattan architect who designed a piece that is featured in the Museum of Modern Arts permanent collection died on Thursday, less than a month after he was robbed and beaten on the Upper West Side, the authorities said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,452 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,606 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Catholic Bishops Uphold 2002 Sex Abuse Policy
description: The nations Roman Catholic bishops voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to retain their policies on sexual abuse by clergy members with only minor revisions, disregarding victims advocates who had called for a more substantial overhaul.

title: Keeping Score: Single. Double. Triple. Reyes.
description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: Tip of the Week: Using Search Engines for Higher Math
description: The ability of search engines to calculate basic arithmetic right in the search box is well known, but some can handle higher math as well. Both Bing and Google can perform trigonometric functions like sine, cosine and tanget when the sin, cos and tan operators are typed into the search box. For example, typing sin 45 degrees and hitting the Enter key brings a result of 0.707107  with no digging around for a calculator. Microsoft has a full list of mathematical operations that work with Bing here; a similar list for Google is here.

title: The Very Quiet Revolution
description: At the end of Lebanons 15-year civil war, in 1990, Beiruts downtown was an apocalyptic scene of rubble and weeds, inhabited by squatters in skeletal buildings and bored soldiers moving among sewage-filled craters. The rare splash of color came from the blue advertisements for a billboard company that read: What do our boards have in common with the C.I.A.? Theyre both all over the place. In the two decades since then, Beirut has become a monument to globalism, home to Louis Vuitton, Chanel and the priciest hotels, the power of capitalism concealing but never really healing the wars scars. Among the chrome-and-glass buildings downtown stands a grand statue of Riyadh al-Solh, a founder of modern Lebanon, looking like a fat and happy pasha. And beneath that statue, in a patch of bare sand he calls the Square of Change, sits a lonely man named Tony Daoud.

title: Storyseller
description: Amanda Hocking, the star of self-publishing, was sitting in the front seat of her Ford Escape earlier this spring when she spotted a messenger delivering flowers to her home in Austin, Minn. She watched her best friend and roommate, Eric Goldman, get the door.

title: The Video Explorer
description: About five years ago, a prodigious young French filmmaker named Vincent Moon reinvented the music video. Filming in an intimate cinma vrit style in odd locations, mostly around Paris, Moon created dozens and dozens of raw, enigmatic clips that stripped away everything but the performer and the song. He put musicians in awkward situations, and the results were magnetic. He set up the band Phoenix, already fairly famous at that point, as buskers in a sea of tourists outside the Eiffel Tower; the National sat crammed elbow to elbow around a picnic table in the South of France; Yo La Tengo played a Troggs cover amid squealing schoolchildren in Montmartre. But it was the clip of Arcade Fire  10 of them, strings, horns, xylophone, guitar  packed into an elevator and singing, with the rip of magazine pages for percussion, that came to represent Moons innovative new oeuvre. A combination cool-hunter and documentarian, Moon proved its possible to reinvent an old, tired format (the music video) using the very thing (the Internet) that supposedly killed it.

title: How My Mom Discovered Crack
description: It was 1985. I was 12 and standing next to my mother in a police station in Greenwich Village. She was a pretty red-haired gal in her late 30s, but the three police officers she was talking to werent looking at her. They were looking at the bag of crack vials she had in her hands, confused about what they were. I wasnt confused. We had a lot of crack vials in our apartment at that point. Hundreds of them. My brothers and I played with them in Washington Square Park. We carried them around in our pockets the way other kids carried marbles.

title: Lights Out
description: To put Andrew Rices Bulb In, Bulb Out in perspective: More than 100 years ago, Robert Louis Stevensons Plea for Gas Lamps grieved the passing of the evening lamplighter and ranted against the horror of electric light. The word electricity now sounds the note of danger. . . . A new sort of urban star now shines out nightly, horrible, unearthly, obnoxious to the human eye; a lamp for a nightmare! Such a light as this should shine only on murders and public crime or along the corridors of lunatic asylums, a horror to heighten horror. To look at it only once is to fall in love with gas, which gives a warm domestic radiance. Technologies past are always warmer than the harsh, cold, high-tech future, even in the 19th century.

title: Doctors Order
description: I have a chronic medical condition, which is being treated with injections every other week. The drug has a potentially deadly side effect that can occur without warning, after years of symptom-free doses and days after an injection. The treatment for this side effect is epinephrine, which I carry with me as a precaution. My doctor recently announced that after each injection, I must wait 30 minutes before leaving the clinic. There is no reason I would be able to use an Epi-pen after 30 minutes but not before, but he says, These are new guidelines from the manufacturer, and I wont allow you to be dosed unless you agree to comply with them, here and now. Is this a textbook example of coercion? Thinking that term might be hyperbole, I looked up various definitions, many of which apply. P. C., NORWELL, MASS.

title: Underneath Every Hoarder Is a Normal Person Waiting to Be Dug Out
description: In 1947, Erich Fromm, a humanist, psychoanalyst and philosopher, developed a theory of character that divided people into five orientations, mostly determined by their relationship to stuff. He characterized four of these  the receptive, exploitive, hoarding and marketing orientations  as part of the having mode, which is focused on consuming, obtaining and possessing. (The fifth orientation was productive, which focuses on experience and human connection.) Fromm specifically linked the hoarding orientation to the Protestant work ethic and the American merchant middle class and argued that this orientation is characterized by, among other things, being constipated and squinty.

The lateness of the hour was not so unusual: the Boston Early Music Festival, which presented the concert, has always offered late- night performances, and the concept has taken root elsewhere too (at Lincoln Center, for example, which has offered refreshing late performances, particularly after Mostly Mozart concerts, in recent years).

Of course, baseball was still segregated then. The Reds took great pains to highlight the irreproachable ethnicities of their newest employees: yes, they were Cuban, but they were purebred Spaniards, without so much as a trace of African blood.

title: How Hitler Could Have Won
description: How did the Wehrmacht, the best fighting force, lose World War II? The reader seeking the answer to this question, posed by Andrew Roberts in his splendid history, will be treated to a brilliantly clear and accessible account of the war in all of its theaters: Asian, African and European. Robertss descriptions of soldiers and officers are masterly and humane, and his battlefield set pieces are as gripping as any I have ever read. He has visited many of the battlefields, and has an unusually good eye for detail as well as a painterly skill at physical description. (His nearly perfect sense of terrain and geography is marred only by his regrettable conflation of Russia with the Soviet Union, which leads to confusion about battlefield locations, German war aims and Soviet casualties.) He is just as much at home at sea as on land; from Midway to El Alamein his prose is unerringly precise and stirringly vivid. It is hard to imagine a better-told military history of World War II.

title: The Central Park Jogger Case Revisited
description: In the wake of the 1989 rape and near-fatal beating of a 28-year-old white woman named Trisha Meili (known to many as the Central Park jogger), and after the arrests, confessions and eventual convictions of one Latino and four African-American teenagers for the crime, the media relentlessly asked: How did this happen? In her slim but ambitious book, The Central Park Five: A Chronicle of a City Wilding, Sarah Burns tackles this same question, but with a changed referent. This, rather than signifying a horrific gang rape in New York Citys bucolic backyard, here signifies a preventable miscarriage of justice that put five Harlem teenagers behind bars for a crime they didnt commit. Each of the boys  Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Korey Wise and Raymond Santana Jr.  served between 7 and 13 years. Their convictions were vacated in 2002 by the New York State Supreme Court, after a confession and DNA analysis linked a serial rapist, Matias Reyes, to the crime.

description: FOR some parents, an engraved pen set just wont cut it as a graduation present. It seems so insubstantial, so unoriginal. Anyway, the kid will just lose it. So how about a New York apartment?

title: Paradoxical Storytelling for Children
description: A tiger lies on the parquet floor of a deserted room, telling lies to a newly awakened stone statue: Long ago, the tiger says, he had a family, but he was shot and stuffed with straw, and glass baubles were sewn where his eyes had been. Later, however, he says he was made in a factory out of artificial fibers. Which story is true?

title: A Beachcombers Guide to Growing Up
description: Sometimes things dont happen exactly the way you want them to happen. In this gentle tale of growing up, 9-year-old Alice Rice learns that even though shes growing older, life is seldom about achieving perfection. She senses this in the very first paragraph of the story, by Kevin Henkes, a Newbery Honor winner and Caldecott medalist, as her family crosses the bridge that connects the Florida mainland to the island they visit every winter. Alice, who ordinarily enjoys being suspended between two worlds, suddenly feels strange. Her breath caught high in her chest and she became light-headed. It seemed as though there wasnt enough air in the car.

title: Violent Clashes as Thousands Protest in Cities Across Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of protesters poured into the streets in the suburbs of Damascus, Syria, and in three of the countrys five largest cities on Friday, in a weekly show of defiance that came days before President Bashar al-Assad was expected to address Syrians for the first time in two months. Activists said at least 19 people were killed and dozens wounded.

title: Saudi Women Defy Driving Ban
description: Updated | 3:15 p.m. Although random acts of women driving were reported in major cities across Saudi Arabia on Friday, the protest against the longstanding ban appears to have been smaller than initially anticipated after the Saudi government imprisoned a main organizer for nine days last month.

title: Shorts Sale
description: If you can buy just one pair of shorts this summer, try slim-fitting chinos in either khaki or navy. When youre ready to branch out, consider a more adventurous print, like these from Sunny Sports. Youd be surprised how well batik, ikat, baja and nautical stripes integrate into your exist- ing warm-weather staples.

title: Little Frogs, Big Family
description: Poky puppies may take the prize in the charm category in Picture Book Land, but the natural spring in a young frogs step has its own special appeal for newly mobile toddlers. With growing confidence in their ability to go where they please, 2- and 3-year-olds begin their first, tentative experiments in independent exploration, suddenly deciding one day to check out the far side of the playground, for example  though typically not before first making sure that Mom or Dad is keeping a weather eye on their adventure.

title: Fresh From Europe, a Japan-Built Wagon
description: AS the world has grown smaller, Americans have acquired tastes that were once foreign. Soccer, si. Sushi, yum. The Euro-style sport wagon? Forget it.

title: Bookshelf: Farm
description: HOGWASH!  By Karma Wilson. Illustrated by Jim McMullan.  40 pp. Little, Brown. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

title: Graphic Book Best Sellers: Wonder Woman and Zombies
description: At No. 1 on the hardcover list this week is Wonder Woman: Odyssey, in which the superheroine wakes up to find that someone has altered her past. She sets out  in a new costume  to find out what went wrong. This is the first half of the journey, written by J. Michael Straczynski and illustrated by Don Kramer. About halfway through the story, Mr. Straczynski departed to work on a sequel to Superman: Earth One, an interpretation of the Man of Steels origin for todays audience. The first installment of that story hit No. 1 in our hardcover list in November. Phil Hester, who took over the Wonder Woman story, has two installments in Odyssey that were helped along by the original writers notes. Of course, theyll likely be more tinkering with the Amazing Amazons origin in September when DC Comics restarts the majority of its superhero series with new number ones.

title: An Unvarnished Critique of Your Finances
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the experience of having his financial life examined by eight wealthy men, all members of an investment club called Tiger 21.

title: Archbishop Calls Gay Marriage Bill an Ominous Threat
description: ALBANY  Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, who has been a low-key presence during the debate over same-sex marriage in the state, called in to a capital radio talk show Friday morning to warn that the proposed legislation posed an ominous threat to society.

title: All Those Online Videos, Still Chasing an Audience
description: DRUMBEAT would be too strong a word. But in recent months theres been a steady patter of news indicating a fresh urgency in the world of original Web series: projects involving high-profile filmmakers, additional rounds of financing, redesigned and expanded video-sharing sites.

title: Because Its There
description: For 150 years, the road up Mount Washington in New Hampshire has challenged man, beast and machine.

title: Montreal Toasts Gaultier
description: The crowd is ecstatic! shouted the fashion historian Valerie Steele. She was referring to the more than 2,000 fans at Tuesdays preview opening of The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk, the designers first major solo exhibition, at the Montreals Muse des Beaux-Arts. (It opens to the public today.) The guests had lined up for hours in front of the museum to catch a glimpse of the show and, with luck, of the man insiders call fashions enfant terrible. That proved nearly impossible; every room was packed, with visitors struggling to reach a bar or a faraway friend.

title: Sax and Cicadas  An Interspecies Jam
description: [April 27, 1:45 p.m. | Update | Bug Music, David Rothenbergs book and CD on insect sounds and human communication and music is out and getting much deserved attention.]

title: The I.P.Nos
description: The one-day pops usually associated with initial public offerings are looking more like one-day fizzles.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: American Historian
description: David McCullough first appeared on the hardcover nonfiction list in 1977. This week, his Greater Journey sits atop the list for the second week in a row.

title: Paperback Row
description: HALF A LIFE: A Memoir,  by Darin Strauss (Random House, $13.) At 18, Strauss was behind the wheel when his Oldsmobile struck and killed a fellow high school student in suburban Long Island. In his subtle yet wrenching book, Strauss, the author of Chang and Eng (2000), explores memory, guilt and coming-of-age after a life-altering event.

title: Ann Patchetts Amazon Wonder Drug Novel
description: Ann Patchetts most characteristic subject is the hell turned unlikely paradise, a kind of reverse Lord of the Flies in which a group of strangers, shipwrecked into a disaster beyond their imagining, manage nonetheless to create a peaceable habitat where love and decency prevail. Patchetts best-selling 2001 novel, Bel Canto, opened with a botched terrorist operation in a South American country, after which an American opera diva, a Japanese industrialist, a French ambassador, various Russian businessmen and their Marxist-Leninist guerrilla captors turned their long captivity into a peculiar sort of idyll. State of Wonder, Patchetts eighth book and sixth novel, is no less multinational in its cast of characters, or high-stakes in its plot.

title: Young Love in Little Russia
description: Magic and magical thinking are the means by which the innocent can acquire power. This accounts for the appeal not only of the Harry Potter books but of adult-minded novels like Michael Chabons Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay. Now Haley Tanners first novel, Vaclav & Lena, takes the figure of the young magician and mixes it with a second magical device, the mutual love of a young boy and girl.

title: Inside the List
description: WOMAN IN BLACK: When Ann Coulter last appeared on the hardcover nonfiction list in 2009, with Guilty: Liberal Victims and Their Assault on America, some commentators asked whether the conservative attack dog had lost a bit of her sales bite. Guilty spent six weeks on the list  an enviable showing by most standards, but a decline from the mark set by Godless (12 weeks), Treason (13 weeks) and Slander (15 weeks).

title: When Women Lost the Vote
description: Iwonder how todays advice columnists might handle a query John Dunton received in 1691. A London printer and bookseller, Dunton was the great-granddaddy of all agony aunts and uncles. He had offered to answer questions from readers of his periodical, The Athenian Mercury. Someone asked him what a man should do if his mother and his sweetheart were in equal peril at the same time. Which one should he save? Dunton suggested that we esteem it more generous, were it possible, to die himself than lose either. Gallant Mr. Dunton appears nearly halfway through Mary Beth Nortons suggestive if idiosyncratic new book, Separated by Their Sex. He is a villain in the story, since Norton assigns him the role of defining women as suited to the soft glories of home life and men as strivers in the public world. His chivalry was part of a larger effort to keep the fair sex away from political power. Or so it seems.

title: David Mamets Right-Wing Conversion
description: This is an extraordinarily irritating book, written by one of those people who smugly believe that, having lost their faith, they must ipso facto have found their reason. In order to be persuaded by it, you would have to be open to propositions like this:

title: The Pseudoscience of Hysteria
description: Readers who cant identify Jean-Martin Charcot as the name of the French neurologist whose 19th-century experiments with hypnosis influenced Sigmund Freuds theory of neurosis may yet recognize the work he conducted at the Saltptrire Hospital in Paris. Photographs and illustrations of Charcots patients, all women suffering hysteria, remain in currency today, 140 years after they were made, if more as curiosities than as clinically valuable documents. Once seen, these images  of, for example, a woman wearing little more than a tangle of bed sheets, her eyes rolled up into her head in either ecstasy or delirium, or fixed on the invisible object of her amorous supplication  are not easily forgotten, let alone dismissed. Poses classified as passionate attitudes, they have the disquieting aspect of pornography masquerading as intellectual inquiry.

title: Story of a Jazz Age Murder
description: Even by the standards of a time when some dozen major New York area newspapers competed for scoops and sensations, the 1927 murder trial of Ruth Snyder and her lover, Judd Gray, was a huge story. The pair, who murdered Snyders husband, embodied the sort of colorful contradictions that reporters love  and that novelists are hard-pressed to better.

title: Im O.K., Youre a Psychopath
description: Do psychopaths enjoy reading books about psychopaths? In his engagingly irreverent new best seller, The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through the Madness Industry (Riverhead, $25.95), the journalist Jon Ronson notes that only about one in 100 people are psychopaths (there is a higher proportion in prisons and corporate boardrooms), but he wonders if this population will be overrepresented among readers of his book. After all, people do enjoy learning about themselves, and psychopaths in particular have an enhanced sense of their own importance. And they might like what Ronson has to say. He approvingly quotes experts who argue that psychopaths make the world go around. Despite their small numbers, they cause such chaos that they remold society  though not necessarily for the better.

title: Malcolm X: Criminal, Minister, Humanist, Martyr
description: His aura was too bright, the poet Maya Angelou said of her first meeting with Malcolm X. His masculine force affected me physically. A hot desert storm eddied around him and rushed to me, making my skin contract, and my pores slam shut. Malcolm X had that same sort of bone-deep, visceral impact on America. He got under everyones skin  either in the sense that he seeped into your pores and transformed you the way the great love of your life does, or in the sense that he annoyed or scared the living hell out of you. There is no middle ground with Malcolm. If you hate him or distrust him, you should consider giving him another try: officers assigned to monitor the wiretaps on his phones sometimes ended up being flipped, because close listening led them to believe that his programs and philosophies were sensible and righteous and that law enforcement agencies should not have been working against him at all. And while Malcolms ideas changed America, his life journey has captivated us even more. He went from a petty criminal and drug user to a long-term prisoner to an influential minister to a separatist political activist to a humanist to a martyr. Throughout his life he continually grew upward, unafraid to challenge or refute what he believed, giving hope that any of us can rise above even our deepest convictions to become better people.

title: Escaping Hitler, Cracking Up in L.A.
description: The not unimportant but somewhat undervalued writer Heinrich Mann (1871-1950) and his second wife, Nelly Kroeger-Mann, 27 years younger and socially several rungs lower, had suspenseful lives during the great emigration  or cultural diaspora  of the Hitler years, and years of exile thereafter. This could make for a wonderful book if the author exercised sufficient self-control rather than showing off in various ways, and kept the work reasonably concise. Unfortunately, Evelyn Juerss House of Exile is not, or not quite, that book.

title: Editors Choice
description: ILLUMINATIONS,  by Arthur Rimbaud. Translated by John Ashbery (Norton, $24.95.) Besides his early absorption of Rimbauds poetry, Ashbery brings to this resourceful translation a long and deep familiarity with French life, language and culture.

title: What Physics Owes the Counterculture
description: What the Bleep Do We Know!?, a spaced-out concoction of quasi physics and neuroscience that appeared several years ago, promised moviegoers that they could hop between parallel universes and leap back and forth in time  if only they cast off their mental filters and experienced reality full blast. Interviews of scientists were crosscut with those of self-proclaimed mystics, and swooping in to explain the physics was Dr. Quantum, a cartoon superhero who joyfully demonstrated concepts like wave-particle duality, extra dimensions and quantum entanglement. Wiggling his eyebrows, the good doctor ominously asked, Are we far enough down the rabbit hole yet? All that was missing was Grace Slick wailing in the background with Jorma Kaukonen on guitar.

title: Life of a Psychohistorian
description: For many years, Robert Jay Lifton has been recognized as a leading psychohistorian, or as he prefers to define his vocation, a historically minded psychiatrist. Psychohistory is the field of inquiry that explores the psychological motives of individuals and groups of historical actors, as well as the psychological impact of historical events. Lifton is perhaps best known as the author of Death in Life: Survivors of Hiroshima, published in 1967, which received a National Book Award. In that book, he described how the hibakusha, those residents of Hiroshima who survived the atomic bomb on Aug. 6, 1945, lived with deep and shameful feelings of being inwardly poisoned by their experience, as well as an embittered sense of special knowledge that set them apart from those who had not witnessed the horrors of the attack.

title: Final Curtain
description: Back in the golden age of British detective fiction, the New Zealand author and theater producer Ngaio Marsh set the bar for backstage mysteries with Enter a Murderer (1935), distinguished by its realistic theatrical settings and strong dramatic themes. Dame Ngaio still rules, but Peter Lovesey carries on in her honorable tradition with STAGESTRUCK (Soho Crime, $25), a brilliantly conceived and smartly executed mystery set in the hallowed Theater Royal of Bath.

title: Big Deal | All Units Are Unique, Some Uniquely So
description: Real estate brokers often describe the properties they market as unique. (Roughly 99.9 percent of the time.)

title: Suburbia, but Not the Cookie-Cutter Kind
description: ADRIENNE NATRILLO and her husband, Javier Gomez, moved to Berkeley Heights, N.J., from Connecticut four years ago because the town was 15 miles from her office in East Hanover and had houses they thought were much better buys than those in nearby communities.

title: Scuffle in the Nest
description: Things get a little rough between Pip, the young hawk above Washington Square Park, and his father, Bobby.

title: Why Huntsman Should Be Taken Seriously
description: As youve probably heard, Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former Utah governor and the Obama administrations ambassador to China for the last two years, is set to enter the Republican presidential field on Tuesday. Youll be able to read more about Mr. Huntsman  a lot more  in my Times Magazine piece about him, which should go online Monday. (Hows that for a coincidence?)

title: Habitats | Clinton Hill, Brooklyn
description: Jenny Salomon, an artist, lives in a magnificent restored brownstone that often functions as a de facto exhibition space.

title: Adopted by a Brownstone
description: BACK in 2007, when Jenny Salomon and her longtime boyfriend began house-hunting in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, the two seemed poised on the brink of a golden future together.

title: U.C.L.A. Freshman Cantlay Shoots 67 at U.S. Open
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Patrick Cantlay, who just finished his freshman year at U.C.L.A., has plenty to be proud of after finishing his second round at the United States Open.

title: Weekend Fare
description: After two decades as a mainstay restaurant in SoHo, Peter Hoffmans Savoy, 70 Prince Street (Crosby Street), closes  on Saturday. An $85 five-course menu will be served. True to its reputation as a leader in the farm-to-table movement, Savoys last meal will have dishes based on ingredients available at the Greenmarket. The first seating is at 6 p.m. Reservations at (212) 219-8570.

title: The Caucus | Politics and Social Media
description: June 17, 2011 - Megan Liberman and Ashley Parker discuss social media in politics, and Nicholas Confessore reports as New York lawmakers debate gay marriage.

title: Video: Politicians and Social Media
description: Megan Liberman and Ashley Parker discuss Anthony D. Weiner and the future of social media in politics. Also, Nicholas Confessore reports as New York lawmakers debate same-sex marriage.

title: In Panama, a Respite for People and Pelicans
description: I WOKE with the sun and the roosters. The clouds on the horizon hung over the Panama mainland  just 12 miles away, across the wide-mouthed Bay of Panama  in dusty, caramel-colored bands. It was Fat Tuesday on Taboga Island. The night before, sulfurous firecrackers mixed with the sea air as an elaborately dressed Carnival Queen was carried through town to the rolling drums of a marching band. But now San Pedro, a brightly painted tangle of houses woven with footpaths, was still and quiet. At the beach, small waves came ashore like a series of tiny sighs. The only action was in the sky, where brown pelicans made their morning commute, traveling in uneven V-shaped constellations as they hunted fish from above.

title: A Tour of Taboga, Panama
description: Less than an hour from Panama City by boat, Taboga has long called to Panamanians, who descend on the island on weekends.

title: Umenyiora Says He Would Welcome Return to Giants
description: The comments by Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora about General Manager Jerry Reese in an affidavit that will become part of the N.F.L. players antitrust case against the league seemed as if it might signal the end of the players relationship with the team.

title: Old Cars Still Stars at Beverly Hills Auction
description: Hollywood filmmakers have been treating cars as disposable props for more than a century. Cars, like everything else in a movie, serve the story, and if that means they must be destroyed in the process, so be it. Even the cars that survive filming are treated poorly; they often pile up on studio back lots after their moments of cinematic glory and sit until theyre weathered down to scrap.

title: A Frog Endangered, But Extinct No More
description: A Las Vegas native thought to have been extinct for decades is alive and living in Arizona.

title: U.S. Open Replay: Day 2
description: Rory McIlroy had five birdies and an eagle (and a double bogey) to take a commanding lead Friday at Congressional Country Club.

title: Obama vs. Boehner: Tee-Off Time
description: WASHINGTON  In 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson used a round of golf as an opportunity to persuade senators to vote for the Civil Rights Act. On Saturday, President Obama will hit the links with House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio with another divisive issue  increasing the national debt limit  hanging over them.

title: Is Sarah Palin Running for President?
description: Is Sarah Palin running for president?

title: Fewer Rewards for Debit Card Holders
description: Change is in the air for rewards programs linked to debit cards, like those that let users bank airline miles with each purchase. For the 8 or so million Chase Continental debit card holders, this will mean no more miles.

title: The Barbershop 2.0
description: Julien Farel has teamed up with Hommage, a Parisian luxury mens face-care brand, on Hommage Atelier, a ritzy new venture that combines your local barbershop with an upscale Manhattan grooming salon. It sits on the penthouse floor of Farels 605 Madison Avenue building, where for the past 10 years he has built a reputation for cutting and styling womens hair.

title: Just the Essentials
description: In a week, I told myself, Lady Gagas vintage Versace studs (seen in her new Edge of Glory video) will be history. If that. Never be afraid to dream, she tweeted to her followers, but I had already unfollowed, like a skiff breaking from its moorings. Goodbye!

title: Man Found With Suspicious Materials in Virginia
description: A Marine Corps reservist who was found in Arlington National Cemetery overnight after it had closed, and then ran from approaching federal parks police was arrested on Friday, the authorities said.

title: Bruno Asks Appeals Court to Spare Him Another Trial
description: A year and a half after he was convicted of corruption charges, Joseph L. Bruno, once one of the most powerful men in Albany, was in a courtroom in Manhattan on Friday fighting to avoid a new trial.

title: Bookshelf: Farm
description: New picture books about farms and farm animals.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: MOTHER-OF-THE-GROOMS GUEST LIST

title: Angels Visit Stirs Up Memories of Randolphs Ouster
description: The Los Angeles Angels will be at Citi Field on Friday for the start of a three-game series against the Mets, three years to the day since Willie Randolph was fired as Mets manager while the team was on the West Coast playing a series against  you guessed it  the Angels.

title: AARP Is Open to Cuts for Social Security Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  AARP, the powerful lobby for older Americans that has been seen as one of the leading opponents of Social Security benefit cuts, said on Friday that it was open to modest reductions in benefits for future recipients.

title: Cold Pea Soup
description: Mark Bittman reaches back into the Minimalist vault to share one of his favorite recipes, a simple soup made with fresh ginger snap peas.

title: June 19  25
description: Art

title: A Swirl of Influences in a Psychedelic Haze
description: JUST over a week ago the rapper and singer Theophilus London took the stage at the Brooklyn Museum in a custom-made navy jacket with gold buttons lining the sleeves  Buttons is so swag, he had tweeted earlier  and loads of gold jewelry (he favors what he calls old lady jewelry), as well as a signature cap and sunglasses. This was his warm-up outfit, for the sound check; for the show he donned a sequined sweater and hat.

title: With Botox, Looking Good and Feeling Less
description: THE GIST Using Botox decreases a persons ability to empathize with others.

title: Letters: Crowd-Free Colorado
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, Bargain Summer Trips Free From Crowds (May 29): Winter Park and the Grand Valley offer fabulous golfing on three stunning mountain courses. Dwight Eisenhower thought this valley, the headwaters of the Colorado River, to be the best fly-fishing in the country. Many agree. The southern entrance to Rocky Mountain National park is a few miles away. If you want an authentic Colorado experience for a family, rent a pontoon boat on Grand Lake then take the kids to the rodeo. You can ride at Devils Thumb Ranch or the Y.M.C.A. of the Rockies; all are within a few miles of the resort. There are several top-notch restaurants where you can enjoy creative food in a casual environment. Leave your mink coat at home.

title: Back to Provence
description: THE difference, for the traveler, between a first and repeated visit is crucial. To go back is not to go. Yet old, familiar places retain a kind of magic, and all the more so when the memories are shared. For our 40th wedding anniversary year, my wife, Elena, and I returned to the place where our marriage began: the South of France. We planned to visit old haunts, the area wed once called home. Then, we had had all the time in the world; now we could spend a week. Too, theres a difference between 20-somethings living on a shoestring and tourists of a certain age who stay in fine hotels.

title: Restaurant Report: ING, in Chicago
description: In Chicagos Fulton Market meatpacking district, the hot restaurant of the moment is Next, where the chef Grant Achatz will change the entire concept behind the menu every three months. Instead of reservations, the owners are selling nonrefundable tickets to dinner, offered, in order, to potential diners who have signed up online. Those who tire of waiting for notification might consider heading just two doors down to iNG, the latest project from Homaro Cantu, Chicagos other cutting-edge chef.

title: Blood, Sand, Sherry: Hemingways Madrid
description: IN the Legazpi neighborhood of Madrid, a vast complex of early 20th-century buildings of ornate stone and brick sits near the banks of the Manzanares River. For most of the 20th century, the Matadero Madrid, as the compound is known, was the citys main slaughterhouse; its robust stench lingered far beyond the high stone walls surrounding it and deep into the working-class neighborhood nearby.

title: California Houses as Celebrities in Themselves
description: PERHAPS the most clichd Los Angeles tourist activity is the curbside ogling of celebrity homes. But take away the famous residents, and Los Angeles is still the ultimate showplace of American dream houses. With legions of architects and Hollywood set designers equally adept at building a Southern plantation or a medieval Transylvanian castle, its no wonder that some streets are lined with English Tudors and Mexican haciendas that somehow look more authentic than anything youd find in Chichester or Chihuahua.

title: In Omaha, From Train Yards to Playground
description: The deserted rail yards of the NoDo neighborhood in Omaha have given way to a thriving arts and commercial district.

title: Finding Hemingway in Madrid
description: The modern version of Hemingways Madrid is an old-school itinerary of bars, bullfighting arenas and restaurants.

title: Back to Provence
description: Exploring the south of France.

title: Canadas Loss, Red Bulls Gain
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe spoke with his inimitable candor when he was asked how he felt about Dwayne De Rosarios return to the club after Canada was eliminated on Tuesday from the Concacaf Gold Cup.

title: House Republicans Question Obamas Use of Autopen
description: President Obama does any number of things that annoy or downright enrage House Republicans, often in the context of constitutionalism. Now a handful of them, many freshmen who ran on platforms of strict constitutional adherence, are unhappy that the president used a so-called autopen to sign legislation extending the U.S.A. Patriot Act, and have written him a letter demanding that he re-sign the bill.

title: Identifying Looters and Lovers in Vancouvers Riot
description: The Stanley Cup Final has spawned a lot of Internet buzz since Wednesday night  but almost no one is talking about hockey.

title: Gingerly, Medvedev Seeks a Little Distance From Putin
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  With the countrys next presidential election scheduled for March, the incumbent, Dmitri A. Medvedev, complicated the riddle at the center of Russian politics by delivering a speech on Friday that implied criticism of his predecessor and presumed rival for the job, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

title: From Devastation in Japan, Vital Data
description: The earthquake in Japan earlier this year was massive and devastating, but it also provided researchers with an unprecedented amount of data, thanks to Japanese investment in earthquake-monitoring technology.

title: Avoiding the Misery of Remodeling by Choosing the Right Contractor
description: WHEN we lived in London, we bought a Victorian home that hadnt been touched since the 1970s. In fact, the electrical wiring was so tangled and potentially dangerous that several qualified electricians declined to work on it.

title: Summer Diamonds
description: Known for her deft use of exuberantly colored gems, Irene Neuwirth, a California jeweler, is making waves with her first diamond collection. These beachy chic turquoise, mint chrysoprase and diamond earrings are $28,000 at Barneys New York.

title: Barbour Tells Republicans Not to Obsess Over Perfect Candidate
description: NEW ORLEANS  A presidential hopeful no more, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi reprised his role as an elder statesman of the Republican Party and urged activists on Friday not to obsess over finding a perfect candidate, but focus on rallying around a contender who can defeat President Obama.

title: From Retro Glamour to the Librarian Look
description: JILL SCOTT, 39, a Philadelphia native, has won three Grammys for her R&B, soul and spoken-word recordings. With 5 million records sold worldwide, the singer and occasional actress will release her fourth studio album, The Light of the Sun, on Tuesday. Her corresponding Summer Block Party tour begins July 28 at the Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y.

title: In the Town of Phil Campbell, a Gathering of Phil Campbells
description: PHIL CAMPBELL, Ala.  Phil Campbell, a writer from Brooklyn, is in love with this little three-stoplight town. So is Phil Campbell from Wisconsin. And Phil Campbell from England.

title: Golf Fans Reluctant to Surrender Their Lifeline to the World
description: BETHESDA, Md.  At each entrance to the United States Open this week, there is a sign listing the items fans cannot bring onto the grounds of the Congressional Country Club.

title: Acura TSX Sport Wagon
description: Americans shy away from station wagons, but the 2011 Acura TSX Sport Wagon deserves to be considered by anyone looking at an S.U.V.

title: Big Movies Coming in Short Packages
description: DEB SHOVAL is overjoyed that her movie, AWOL, will be shown as part of the Palm Springs International ShortFest in California this week, even if she hasnt had time to think about it lately. After all, the crops are in.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $8,500,000
description: A West Village town house that sold for $8.5 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com and brokers who confirmed the closing price.

title: Give a New Yorker a Chicken
description: If youre interested in taking a step away from the big (and often overwhelming) picture and remembering all the little things people are doing to improve our food system, consider Exhibit A: Just Food, a nonprofit that does terrific food justice work in New York City, is gearing up for a fifth year of its City Chicken Project, which brings egg-laying hens, necessary coop-building equipment, and training to urban gardens and schools in underserved neighborhoods.

title: Ferguson in France
description: Craig Ferguson took his Late Late Show to Paris for a week of shows as Le Late Late Show Avec Craig Ferguson.

title: Want to Call Your Senator? Advocates Make It Easy
description: When New York State Senator Joseph P. Addabbo Jr., reversed course earlier this week and supported legislation that would legalize same-sex marriage in the state, he said that what had changed were the number of people contacting him asking him to vote for the bill. As was reported in The Times on Monday:

title: Joseph Loseys Dark Hall of Extramarital Mirrors
description: The Romantic Englishwoman

title: More on Sunspots and Sushi Choices
description: A couple of pieces in The Times relate to ongoing coverage here of the causes and consequences of variations in solar activity and the issues raised by the burgeoning human appetite for sushi-bound fish, particularly bluefin tuna.

title: Just One Look | Theyskens Theory Resort
description: Theyskens Theorys ability to flirt with the notion of romantic and fluid dressing  we can thank Olivier Theyskenss time at Nina Ricci and Rochas for that  is changing the definition of downtown cool. Hence the cutout yet flowing shirtdress paired with loose slacks. For the labels first resort collection, color entered the game, like these camouflage pants and updated boots. There were also hits of neon blue lining messenger bag straps, along with coral hues brightening up blouses, blazers and trousers.

title: Wear Resort Now | Full Body Prints

Either way, this is one trend that can be activated right now with a pair of printed mini shorts, like the cotton ones from Etoile Isabel Marant ($225; go to net-a-porter.com), and an equally busy tank top from your closet. Just remember to stick to the same palette. Or, you could revive that printed onesie you were hoping never to wear again. Courage, girl.

Since I had challenged myself to eat every olive I could this summer in an effort to appreciate what so many of my friends love in them, that left me with 10.
