title: The Minimalist: Cold Pea Soup
description: This Minimalist recipe comes from July 2001, an age of relative innocence (and youth!), or so it seems to me now. The column was on weeknight entertaining, made possible by a menu of make-ahead dishes, including white bean and garlic dip, green salad with fresh mild herbs and hazelnut oil, pured fresh pea soup, salmon with cherry tomatoes en papillote, and coeur  la crme (that creamy French concoction thats often chilled in heart-shaped molds and served with fresh fruit). Of these, only the salmon and dessert strike me as dated  the former because salmon no longer seems nearly as good and guilt-free as it did a decade ago, and the latter because these days I rarely indulge in desserts that are 80 percent full-fat dairy and 20 percent sugar, as coeur  la crme is.

title: A Surprise on Fox

But ratings for that Fox reality show were modest, according to Nielsens estimates. The network finished in third place, garnering 6.3 million viewers for So You Think You Can Dance at 8 p.m. and 3.4 million at 9 for a rerun of Glee. CBS led with repeats of CSI (7.3 million) and The Mentalist (8.1 million) from 9 to 11 after reruns of The Big Bang Theory (6.7 million) and Rules of Engagement (5.6 million) at 8 and 8:30. ABC was third, averaging 5.8 million for Wipeout reruns from 8 to 10, but 3.5 million viewers at 10 for a repeat of Rookie Blue. NBC lagged in fourth, drawing 2.3 million in the 10 p.m. hour for Love Bites.

title: Vaclav & Lena
description: Here, I practice, and you practice. Ahem. AH-em. I am Vaclav the Magnificent, with birthday on the sixth of May, the famous day for the generations to celebrate and rejoice, a day in the future years eclipsing Christmas and Hanukkah and Ram - adan and all pagan festivals, born in a land far, far, far, far, far, far, far distance from here, a land of ancient and magnificent secrets, a land of enchanted knowledge passed down from the ages and from the ancients, a land of illusion (Russia!), born there in Russia and reappearing here, in America, in New York, in Brooklyn (which is a Borough), near Coney Island, which is a famous place of magic in the great land of opportunity (which is, of course, America), where anyone can become anything, where a hobo today is tomorrow a businessman in a three-pieces-suit, and a businessman yesterday is later this afternoon a hobo, Vaclav the Magnificent, who shall, without no doubt, be ask to perform his mighty feats of enchantment for dukes and presidents and czars and ayatollahs, uniting them all in awestruck and dumbstrucks, and thus, one day in the future years, be heralding a new era (which is a piece of time) of peace on earth. Ladies and gentlemans, I give you, I present to you, I warn you in advance of his arrival, so that you may close your eyes or put your hands on your face if you are afraid, Vaclav the Magnificent, Boy- Magician.

Reading these intertwined stories of men and women searching for sex, love and themselves in the heady, indulgent atmosphere of San Francisco in the 1970s is like dipping into an inexhaustible bag of M&Ms, with no risk of sugar overload. The stories  of ardent friendships and surprising liaisons, startling family secrets and scandalous crimes  keep piling up and tumbling together, and somehow too much is never enough.

title: The Central Park Five
description: The day it happened, Wednesday, April 19, 1989, Raymond Santana, Jr., walked over to the Taft Houses in East Harlem to visit a friend. Raymond, whose family had moved to New York from Puerto Rico before he was born, lived with his father and grandmother in an apartment building on 119th Street, a few blocks north of the project, but he often hung out in the courtyard of the Taft Houses, where some of his friends lived. At fourteen, he was of average size  about five six and 130 pounds  with curly hair and small features. He was well liked at school, where his good sense of humor made him popular with girls. Even though there were always kids playing sports around the neighborhood, especially basketball and football in local school yards and the decrepit project courtyards, Raymond was more interested in drawing. He took art classes and spent a lot of his free time sketching.

The work, which recasts the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro along the lines of a Bach Passion, has been a lightning rod for controversy and protest since its premiere in 1991. When you have dinner, they will still be there. And when you go back to work after the weekend. And she wants you to know that they have good reasons to exhibit some form of insanity.

title: Three Men Are Indicted Under Drug Kingpin Law
description: Three men who the authorities say played key roles in a major cocaine trafficking ring that has been operating in East Harlem for about a quarter-century have become the first to be indicted in Manhattan under New York States two-year-old law known as the kingpin statute, the district attorney announced Friday.

title: This Sunday: Even More Appealing Than Washboard Abs
description: One of the advantages The Times Magazine has over its competitors is that our print edition comes tucked into the newspaper, and we are therefore liberated from playing celebrity musical chairs with our cover. However, this also means we miss out on the opportunity of watching our magazine fly off the newsstand (to the extent that ever happens with any magazine anymore). We never get that rock-solid indication of a covers popularity. Instead, we have to rely on anecdotal feedback in the form of reader mail, Twitter feeds and Web sites like Coverjunkie (which we love, by the way; thank you for your support).

title: World Bank Is Withholding $70 Million as Afghans Try to Resolve a Scandal
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A World Bank-managed trust fund is withholding $70 million in incentive money from the Afghanistan government after it failed to reach an agreement with the International Monetary Fund over the Kabul Bank scandal by a key deadline that quietly passed last week.

title: Bachmann Accuses Obama of Secret Medicare Plan
description: NEW ORLEANS  Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, the latest candidate to join the Republican presidential campaign, suggested Friday that President Obama secretly wanted Medicare to go bankrupt so retirees would be forced to enroll in the new national health care law.

title: Senate Inquiry Promised in Case of War Critic
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat and chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said Friday that the panel would investigate accusations that the White House of President George W. Bush sought to have federal intelligence officials collect damaging personal information on a prominent critic of the Iraq war in order to discredit him. In a brief statement, Mrs. Feinstein said, Depending on what we find, we may take further action. She was responding to an article in The New York Times on Thursday in which a former senior C.I.A. official said the Bush White House sought to direct intelligence officials to collect sensitive information on the critic, Juan Cole, a University of Michigan professor and Middle East expert. The Central Intelligence Agency has denied the accusations and said agency officials never provided any derogatory information to the White House about Mr. Cole.

title: Towers With Babels Diversity, but a Much Happier History
description: This being June, weddings and proms are colliding at Terrace on the Park banquet hall in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, and doing so with a particularly Queensian flair.

title: Turkey: Aid Ship Wont Join Flotilla
description: Technical problems will keep a Turkish humanitarian aid ship that was the target of a fatal raid by the Israeli military last year from joining a flotilla that is set to leave for Gaza next week, the pro-Palestinian charity that owns the boat announced on Friday. The charity, the Humanitarian Relief Foundation, said the decision was not the result of political pressure from the government. Nine people were killed in the raid on the ship, the Mavi Marmara, straining ties between Turkey and Israel. The new flotilla is expected to challenge Israels blockade of the Gaza Strip this month. Israeli military officials warned Thursday that they would use force if necessary to prevent boats from breaking the blockade.

title: Short Trial May Decide if Dodgers Are Sold
description: The Dodgers ownership situation, and perhaps the teams future, gained some clarity Friday in a divorce settlement reached by Frank and Jamie McCourt. The judge overseeing the divorce scheduled a one-day trial on Aug. 4 to determine if the team will remain solely Frank McCourts or will be sold as a community property asset.

title: China: Maritime Force Is Beefed Up
description: China is bulking up its maritime surveillance operations, according to a report on Friday in China Daily, the official English-language newspaper. The force will grow to 15,000 people from 9,000 by 2020, the report said. By 2015, the aviation branch of the force, which is officially civilian, will have 16 aircraft, and by 2020, its sea patrol fleet will have 520 vessels.

title: California: Woman Arrested in Relics Disappearance
description: The parishioners of St. Anthonys Catholic Church in Long Beach may well think their prayers have been answered. Police officials say they recovered a nearly 800-year-old relic of St. Anthony  the patron saint of lost objects  from the home of Maria Solis, who they say stole it from the church on Monday. Rico Fernandez, a spokesman for the Long Beach Police Department, said officers used surveillance video from a nearby business to identify Ms. Solis, 41, who was arrested on burglary charges. Mr. Fernandez said that the relic appeared to be undamaged and was promptly returned to the church on Thursday, but that officers were still questioning Ms. Solis. The relic had been on rare display for Mass last Sunday, and church officials realized early Monday that it had disappeared from its glass case.

title: Walk This Way: The Punk Tour
description: Enough already with the jazz. Its all over the city this month, what with the Blue Note Jazz Festival, the Undead Jazzfest and the Vision Festival: flitty, formless music that makes me want to bang my head against some bathroom porcelain. I had to go see Jake Szufnarowski and John Joseph to restore my heavy-punk-metal-thrashing-garage-acid-hard-rock soul.

title: Bill Haast, a Man Charmed by Snakes, Dies at 100
description: Bill Haast figured he had handled more than three million poisonous snakes over the years, and he had the hands to prove it.

title: Wild Man Fischer, Outsider Musician, Dies at 66
description: Wild Man Fischer, a mentally ill street musician who became a darling of the pop music industry in the 1960s and as a result enjoyed four decades of strange, intermittent and often ill-fitting celebrity, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 66.

title: Mayors See End to Wars as Fix for Struggling Cities
description: BALTIMORE  While states are seeing their tax collections begin to rise again, much to the relief of budget-battered officials, the nations cities are having a far rougher time, with many losing state and federal aid just as the burst housing bubble is belatedly driving down property taxes.

title: United States: Federal Court Drops Charges Against Bin Laden
description: A federal judge in Manhattan formally dismissed charges against Osama bin Laden on Friday that were originally brought more than a decade ago. A first indictment, for conspiracy to attack United States defense installations, was filed in 1998 when the authorities were considering a plan to capture and try him in New York. Later indictments charged him in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan ordered the dismissals at the request of federal prosecutors in Manhattan, who filed papers citing proof of Bin Ladens death. Charges remain open against other Qaeda figures, including Ayman al-Zawahri, who has succeeded Bin Laden as the groups leader.

title: A Black Cultural Tradition and Its Unlikely Keepers
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  After the shish kebab and blueberry pie, as dusk calmed the Lowcountry heat, the dinner guests gathered around Park Doughertys table prepared to sing. They clapped hands in one rhythm, beat their feet against the floorboards in another, and lifted their voices into a song that had been passed down to them through generations and in defiance of a rigid racial divide.

The man, identified as Yonathan Melaku, 22, a Marine Corps reservist from Alexandria, Va., ran from federal parks police officers and was arrested, officials said. Investigators initially said his backpack contained suspicious materials, though they later determined nothing was explosive, said Chris Allen, a spokesman with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The authorities searched his car, found in a wooded area near the Pentagon, but did not find anything suspicious, Mr. Allen said.

It left him a long eagle putt, but he had avoided a dangerous bunker, found a narrow opening and seemingly put some pressure on his young playing partner, Rory McIlroy.

title: When Snoopy Landed on the Moon

That connection is the subject of To the Moon: Snoopy Soars With NASA, now on view at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: Little League and Dim Sum
description: John C. Liu, 44, New York Citys feisty and ambitious comptroller and the first Asian-American to win a major elective office in the city, has at times been at odds with the Bloomberg administration. But on Sundays, Mr. Liu says, auditing, fraud-busting and the mayor are the last things on his mind. Its a time for Little League and maybe a dim sum outing in Flushing, Queens, where Mr. Liu, a former actuary, arrived from Taiwan at age 5. He still lives there with his wife, Jenny, 43, a director at the New York Power Authority, and their son, Joey, 10.

Schuyler Grantof the Kula Yoga Project, a founder of the event, Wanderlust Yoga in the City, made in situ additions to the yoga canon, suggesting, Reach your heart to the water, and encouraging participants to try handstands on the forgiving grass.

Part of a deeply tanned foursome, he was soon holding court on the restaurants crowded outdoor deck, administering margaritas to his guests from an icy carafe.

Then last month it added a fifth bubbly, the nonvintage Cuve Carnaval ($27), providing an option for consumers who like sweetness.

description: THE space at 51 Bank Street in New Milford has seen restaurants like Arrivederci and Cucina 51 come and go. But the current occupant, Lucia Ristorante, may be here to stay, judging by the full house, the moderate prices and, most persuasive of all, the freshly made dishes that emerge from a highly competent kitchen.

title: The Treaty and the Law
description: Humberto Leal Garca Jr., a Mexican citizen who faces execution in Texas next month, has petitioned Gov. Rick Perry for a six-month reprieve. He is asking for a stay under a vital international law, the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, which requires that foreign nationals who are arrested be told of their right to have their embassy notified of that arrest and to ask for help.

The lists lead to an important question. Can you actually read at the beach? Or do you merely hold a book before your face as a blind for better beach-watching?

title: Out of Fashion
description: The black beret is out. Ten years after it became standard gear in the United States Army, it has been replaced by the patrol cap as the default head gear for soldiers wearing combat uniforms, CNN reports. Soldiers had complained that the wool beret was hot, hard to adjust and took two hands to put on. Soldiers who were already wearing berets, and who will continue to wear them  like Special Forces, airborne troops and Army Rangers  were not happy either. They thought that having every soldier wear a beret diminished the work they had done to earn theirs. The decision by Gen. Martin Dempsey, the Army chief of staff, reverses a policy laid down by a predecessor, Gen. Eric Shinseki. The patrol cap looks like a baseball cap, but with a flat, not rounded, top. Soldiers wearing their dress uniforms will still wear berets, but by reducing the number they will need from two to one, the Army will save $6.5 million.

Toler, 45, will be there for the anniversary. She is in her 12th season as the Sparks general manager and has built two championship teams.

title: You Might Remember This
description: In 2007 I posted an animated portrait of my son Busters first years called You Wont Remember This. You Wont Remember This Either, covering the toddler years but featuring my younger son, Oscar, followed in 2009. This new film continues the series and features Buster from ages six to 10. While these films portray childhood, the perspective is parental. If Buster had made this film it would be all baseball, and the actual point of view, looking up at grownups twice his size, would surely feature more chins and nostrils. The angle might seem a small thing, but it can alter the feeling in subtle ways. Looking at children, our perspective is angled down and as they look up, we see eyes, those big ones, looking up like lasers. And, like every portrait, these films are double portraits, simultaneously reflecting the sensibility of who made them as well as who they picture.

title: Clarence Clemons, Springsteens Soulful Sideman, Dies at 69
description: Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist in Bruce Springsteens E Street Band, whose jovial onstage manner, soul-rooted style and brotherly relationship with Mr. Springsteen made him one of rocks most beloved sidemen, died on Saturday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69.

title: Well Behind the Leader, an Exciting Tournament Takes Shape
description: BETHESDA, Md.  A crowd of more than 35,000 came out to watch the third round of the United States Open on Saturday at Congressional Country Club. They lined the fairways and tees and encircled the greens 10 deep.

title: Taymor Calls New Spider-Man Much Simpler
description: LOS ANGELES  In her first public comments about Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark since the opening of the $70 million Broadway musical, the director Julie Taymor on Saturday described the new show as much simpler than the version she created before being fired in March. Speaking to a conference of theater leaders here, she also tacitly criticized her former producers for drawing ideas from audience focus groups.

description: Rory McIlroy continued his dominance on Saturday, setting a 54-hole record for the United States Open and extending his lead to eight strokes.

description: Four people were killed on Saturday afternoon when a small plane crashed on its approach to an airport runway in Westchester County, the authorities said.

title: The Obstinacy of Error, Interest Rates Edition
description: Brad DeLong reposts something he wrote two years ago about interest rates; it was, I think, at least in part a followup to my slightly earlier post on liquidity preference and loanable funds. Brad and I both believe that the story of interest rates in this crisis is both remarkable and under-appreciated.

title: Kicking the Eurocan
description: The reaction of European leaders and institutions to the Greek crisis is a sight to behold. Essentially, it boils down to the fact that default would be very inconvenient, both as a practical matter and in terms of prestige. Therefore default must not be considered a possibility, even though it has long been obvious that non-default is not an option.

title: Music Festival Takes to Pragues Islands
description: The islands of Prague will be pulsating with music and pounding with dancing feet during United Islands, a free international music festival that is held on islands in the Vltava River from June 23 to 25.

title: Three Grown-Ups and a Baby
description: We only come to intimately know a handful of families in a lifetime. Theres the one we were raised in, and the ones we form on our own. Thats not a large sample size, which often leaves us wondering if the way we do things is normal. When we get glimpses here and there of how other families work, we crane our necks toward those for hints of what happens behind doors that arent ours.

title: Early Music Festival: Weighing the Costs
description: BOSTON  You would hardly know it, given the number of performances the Boston Early Music Festival and its related fringe festival have fielded this year, but this successful, 30-year-old celebration of early music has been fighting the effects of the economic downturn just as other arts organizations have. Financial support from foundations, corporations and individual donors has not quite recovered. But Kathleen Fay, the festivals executive director, said that the situation has improved greatly since the last festival, in 2009.

title: NATO Admits Missile Hit a Civilian Home in Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  NATO acknowledged Sunday that an errant missile had destroyed a civilian home in the Libyan capital in the early morning, saying it may have killed civilians. It was the alliances first such admission in the three-month-long campaign of airstrikes against the military forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: How Do You Engage Your Customers?
description: At TerraCycle, consumers can interact with our business in two crucial ways. First, they can send us garbage (postage paid), and for each piece of waste they collect, we typically give 2 cents to the charity or school of their choice. Today, more than 21 million people in the United States are actively involved in our collection programs, and theres another 2 million participating outside of the United States. The second way to interact with TerraCycle is for consumers to buy the products that are made from the waste weve collected. These products are typically available at major big-box stores, including Wal-Mart and Target.

title: Green Lantern Fizzles at the Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  An all-hands-on-deck effort by Warner Brothers to turn Green Lantern into a box office superpower fizzled over the weekend.

title: Struggling to Stoke Economic Growth in Greece
description: ATHENS  A few months after Greece was seized by its debt crisis, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou had a grand idea to revive growth: sun-drenched islands would be dotted with solar panels and wind turbines to transform the country into a green economy, attracting badly needed investments and creating hundreds of thousands of new jobs.

title: Divided on Premier, Palestinians Cancel Meeting
description: GAZA  In a blow to Palestinian unity efforts, a meeting in Cairo planned for this week so that the leaders of the two main factions could announce a new government has been called off for lack of agreement on a prime minister, Palestinian officials said Sunday.

title: Our Man in Milan
description: Joe Jonas has 2,132,660 Twitter followers, a new solo album, a growing fan club among the fashion cognoscenti and a posse of devoted teen faithful who wait, like pilgrims at Lourdes or extras in Sofia Coppolas Somewhere, every day outside the Principe di Savoia hotel for a glimpse of this pop divinity.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed, the American-educated  prime minister of Somalia, resigned Sunday after weeks of pressure to abide by a deal between two other top officials that extends Somalias wobbly transitional government for another year.

title: McIlroy Cruises to U.S. Open Victory
description: BETHESDA, Md.  During the first three days of the 111th United States Open, Rory McIlroy moved through the cheering galleries with a boyish smile and the occasional laugh, a young man playing near-flawless golf and enjoying the walk on the lush grounds of Congressional Country Club.

title: Boeing to Decide This Year Whether to Revamp or Replace 737 Jet
description: PARIS  Boeing will decide this year whether to revamp its popular 737 jet with more fuel-efficient engines or to develop a new single-aisle jet, an executive of the company said on Sunday.

title: Williams Returns to Wimbledon With Title to Defend and Ground to Make Up
description: LONDON  According to Serena Williams, her fearsome serve has not yet made the trip across the Atlantic Ocean, but she was definitely here Sunday: reflecting, joking and even yanking off her sneakers at one point to show a small group of American reporters the scars on her feet that symbolized her year of living dangerously.

title: Some Early Stumbles by Niese Leave the Mets With Few Opportunities to Recover
description: After a sputtering beginning to the season, Jon Niese seemed to finally be finding his footing on the rubber, winning five of his last six decisions for the Mets before his start Sunday at Citi Field.

title: Grieving, From Asbury Park
Debate Swirls Around Research Showing Lung Problems for Returned Troops
description: As a teenager in northern New York, Gary Durham ran cross-country and hiked the Adirondacks high peaks. In Army basic training, he did two-mile runs in under 13 minutes. But after a yearlong deployment to Iraq with the 101st Airborne Division in 2003, he says he started gasping for air while just mowing the lawn.

description: According to Hegel, history is idea-driven. According to almost everyone else, this is foolish. What can idea driven even mean when measured against the passion and anguish of a place like Libya?

title: Bargains on Flash Sale Sites Serve a Long-Range View
description: FLASH sale Web sites, a thriving e-commerce trend to promote limited-time sales, started as a way for brands to unload excess inventory in a controlled, high-end place. But now they have become something else: a way to advertise and find new customers, many of whom visit the sites of the brands and buy full-price merchandise soon after the sales.

title: Two Women Love One Man, Worthy of Neither
description: Lee Martin, a 2006 Pulitzer Prize finalist for The Bright Forever, about a 9-year-old girls disappearance in rural 1970s Indiana, specializes in tautly written, unsettling novels that reveal the evil secrets lying just beneath the seemingly banal surfaces of American small towns. Quakertown, his first novel, took place in the titular African-American community in 1920s Denton, Tex.; the fictional Mount Gilead, Ill., was the setting for 2008s River of Heaven.

title: Beer. Nachos. Arena. Ballet?
description: LONDON  The idea was to bring the ballet to the masses, so it was perhaps inevitable that the masses would bring nachos, beer and hot dogs to the ballet.

title: Taymor Tries to Reclaim a Reputation
description: LOS ANGELES  Breaking her silence about Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the Broadway musical from which she was fired in March, Julie Taymor tacitly criticized her former producers on Saturday afternoon for relying on audience focus groups and said that the rise of Twitter and blogs for instant theater criticism was damaging to shows.

title: Elena Bonner, Widow of Sakharov, Dies at 88
description: Elena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident and human-rights campaigner who endured banishment and exile along with her husband, the dissident nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, died Saturday in Boston. She was 88.

description: Even as Al Jazeera English continues its battle for broader cable distribution in the United States, it is reaping a growing audience in Los Angeles on a broadcast channel.

description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Katy Perry shrewdly polled her sold-out audience  at least 85 percent female, young and eager to scream  at Nassau Coliseum on Friday night. She asked who had just graduated from college, high school and junior high, and junior high won, decisively. title: An Obsessive Killer Is Revealed in a Stylish Whodunit
description: Early on in The Killing, the American adaptation of a Danish thriller that has had a talked-about run on AMC, an unusually creepy funeral director guides a pair of bereaved parents through the retail dimensions of his mortuary. Mitch and Stan Larsen have lost their 17-year-old daughter, Rosie, to a deranged act of violence and stare achingly into the bottom of an expensive coffin they cannot afford. Trailing the couple as though they were shopping for hatchbacks, the undertaker offers that the object of their attention is a beautiful choice for a young girl. He goes on to instruct the Larsens on how their child should look for her interment, discreetly relishing the thought of her corpse in a pretty dress.

title: Afghanistan Veteran, Afghan Sounds
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Though the experienced arts administrator Thomas W. Morris is the official artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival, much of the artistic planning for this innovative annual four-day event is turned over each June to a rotating music director, who organizes the programs. This summer that artist was the soprano Dawn Upshaw, and not surprisingly she devised diverse and adventurous offerings.

title: An Orphan, a Libertine and the Walking Dead
description: ST. LOUIS  The Opera Theater of St. Louis is a small, hardy institution not averse to risk. Its choice of John Adamss Death of Klinghoffer, which opened triumphantly on Wednesday, was only the latest proof. Founded in 1976 and modeled after the Santa Fe Opera, another seasonal company, the theater earned its renown by championing opera in English, including standard works sung in translation, and by offering premieres and unusual, important revivals among its steady supply of user-friendly chestnuts.

title: Captive to Politics and Radical Poetry
description: After a pair of critically lauded independent documentaries, Street Life and Ghost Town, Zhao Dayong turns to fiction in his new feature, The High Life. His subjects are the same  the rootlessness and avarice that afflict contemporary China, and the agonies of self-expression in a country that limits speech and effaces identity. His storytelling skills, however, are not at the same level in this awkward mash-up of what feel like two completely different movies.

title: Great Time for a Perfect Read
description: The 60-board match that chose the U.S.A.-2 dOrsi Senior Bowl Cup world championship team this month in Detroit was won by Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla.; Larry Kozlove of Louisville, Ky.; Peter Boyd of Darnestown, Md.; Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va.; Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y.; and John Schermer of Seattle.

title: A Booed Winehouse Cancels Shows
description: Only weeks since checking out of an alcohol rehabilitation program, the British pop star Amy Winehouse, right, canceled part of her European tour after strange behavior during a performance on Saturday night in Belgrade, Serbia. During the concert, which one Serbian newspaper called the worst in the history of Belgrade, Ms. Winehouse was booed as she mumbled and stumbled her way through her performance, The Associated Press reported. A spokesman for Ms. Winehouse said that she would return to London after agreeing with management that she cannot perform to the best of her ability.

title: New Group Lineup Features Rabe Play
description: The world premiere of a play by David Rabe is among the New Groups productions for the 2011-12 season, the theater company announced. An Early History of Fire, a coming-of-age story set in the 1960s and directed by Jo Bonney, heralds Mr. Rabes return to original theater production after an eight-year absence. The Off Broadway New Group company previously collaborated with Mr. Rabe on a revival of his 1984 play, Hurlyburly. Other coming productions include Russian Transport by Erika Sheffer and Burning by Thomas Bradshaw (The Bereaved). Both plays will be directed by the companys artistic director, Scott Elliott (Marie and Bruce).

title: Love Does in Fact Die
description: The London production of Love Never Dies, the sequel to Phantom of the Opera, will close on Aug. 27 after running for a little more than a year, BBC News reported. Andrew Lloyd Webbers troubled musical received poor opening reviews, underwent numerous rewrites and was ultimately met with a tepid reception at the box office. Although it was nominated this year for seven Olivier awards, including best new musical, it won none. The Sydney Morning Herald recently reported that Mr. Lloyd Webber would prefer to bring the better received Australian version to Broadway in the future, instead of the West End version.

title: Genetic Basis for Crime: A New Look
description: It was less than 20 years ago that the National Institutes of Health abruptly withdrew funds for a conference on genetics and crime after outraged complaints that the idea smacked of eugenics. The president of the Association of Black Psychologists at the time declared that such research was in itself a blatant form of stereotyping and racism.

title: A Daily Deal Site Aimed Squarely at Gay Men
description: Like millions of people, Mario Correa wakes up every morning to an in-box full of offers and deals. But most of the time, he just isnt interested. As he puts it, he doesnt want to learn to knit, go on a Segway ride, get my varicose veins removed or take a mommy-and-me yoga class.

title: A Wild Man-Child by Way of the Bolshoi Tears Up the Met Stage
description: The Bolshoi Ballet star Ivan Vasiliev, still in his early 20s, is just what you want a Russian male dancer to be: powerful, ardent, engaging and a bit on the wild side. Even without matinee-idol looks, he has loads of physical charm. His smile is happy, his dark brown hair is none too tidy, theres a mischievous glint in his eyes, and hes virile without having completely shaken off his boyishness. Vast though the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House is, he makes it look much too small for comfort when he tears around it. His jumps are out of all proportion to his medium height.

But HBOs adaptation of George R. R. With exceptions like True Blood, which is based on Charlaine Harriss vampire novels (though how closely Im not sure, as a non-fan of the show and books alike), few of the major cable dramas have been adaptations of existing stories. From Al Swearengen to Walter White to Stringer Bell, the great characters of televisions dramatic golden age have sprung from the imaginations of TV writers, rather than the printed page.

Apologies to Raf Simons, who proved himself a master of postmodernist sartorial play in his collection for Jil Sander, but critical consensus was Christopher Baileys flip-flop luxe look at Burberry Prorsum might go over better with the accidental billionaire generation.

title: Hobbit Cast Adds Evangeline Lilly, Dame Edna and Sherlock Holmes
description: If your natural inclination is to spell the word color using the letter u, theres a good chance you have just been cast in Peter Jacksons ever-expanding film adaptation of The Hobbit. In a Facebook post published over the weekend, Mr. Jackson announced that his two-movie version of that J. R. R. Tolkien fantasy novel would feature Evangeline Lilly, a Lost alumna; Barry Humphries, the comedian best known for his garish alter ego, Dame Edna Everage; and Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays the title character on the television series Sherlock.

title: McQueens Voodoo Rock n Roll
description: (Three hours later and in a warehouse across the city, Sarah Burton, the Alexander McQueen designer, gave a gleeful laugh when told of the Kray brothers reference. Previewing her show, the first for the label since she designed the wedding dress for Catherine Middleton, she pointed out that it, too, draws on the English 1960s, that inexhaustible mine of style. Its rock n roll, with stripes and checks, a very McQueen shoulder and fuller trousers, Ms. Burton said, adding that the special jet embroidered pieces, a distinctive McQueen touch, were also rock n roll, but voodoo rock n roll.)

title: Battle Waged Over Real Estate Gossip on the Web
description: A Web site, now defunct, that claimed to expose the underbelly of the Manhattan real estate market by reporting on bad broker behavior, abusive landlords and run-down apartments quickly became a forum for bitter accusations against landlords, brokers, real estate industry co-workers and even roommates.

title: Curtain Down Heads Up: Advice for Broadway Producers and Casting Directors
description: Readers had a lot to say about two recent theater-related articles, one that explored the line between success and struggle on Broadway and another that took a close look at the challenging work of Broadway casting directors.

title: British Store Sells Old New York Dont Walk Signs. Only 975.
description: Consider the Dont Walk sign, that lost classic of the New York streetscape. It is a yin-yang traffic signal, a functional poem  Dont Walk/Walk  inside an iconic yellow box. It is to Martin Scorseses midcentury Manhattan what the gas lamp is to Edith Whartons gilded age.

title: The Lights Are On Again at Montes in Gowanus
description: Its been 105 years since Angelo and Angelina Monte opened the Brooklyn landmark once called Montes Venetian Room, known for its murals of Venice, and its Rat Pack clientele. Now, after having been closed for more than two years, new owners, Tina Esposito and her husband, Dominick Castelvetre, have refurbished the restaurant, but without the murals. They were gone when we took over, Ms. Esposito said. But except for a new marble top, theyve left the bar room alone, just cleaning and brightening it.The menu is less focused on traditional parmigiana dishes, offering more authentically regional Italian fare. The chef, Salvatore Zapparata, is a native of Sicily.

At the Milwaukee Mile last weekend, Franchittis equalizing performance left no doubt that IndyCar had a genuine, ratings-boosting rivalry on its hands.

title: Beatles Tribute Rain Will Dry Up on Broadway

Rather than splitting into separate tribute shows for Wings and the Plastic Ono Band, Rain will embark on a national tour through 2012. (Productions in Singapore and Johannesburg are scheduled for this summer as well.) The Broadway production, which opened at the Neil Simon Theater in October, will have played 8 previews and 341 regular performances when it closes.

On Sunday, to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the brand, close to 1,200 Chevrolets descended on the town.

title: Asia Society Plans Exhibition of Ai Weiwei New York Photos
description: Long before he was a star of the international art world and a target of the Chinese government, the artist Ai Weiwei was at the center of an obscure group of Chinese cultural emigrs in the East Village, a community that he documented in some 10,000 photographs in the decade that he lived there, from 1983 to 1993. Now, while Mr. Ai remains under detention in China, without formal charges, the Asia Society is preparing to open an exhibition of 227 of his New York photographs. They show not only important East Village events like Wigstock and local characters like Allen Ginsberg, but also humble gatherings in Mr. Ais Third Street apartment featuring people like the artist Xu Bing, the filmmaker Chen Kaige and the composer Tan Dun, all now major Chinese cultural figures who were then toiling in immigrant obscurity.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Tim Blett, senior partner and senior vice president at Doner, Southfield, Mich., who had been the head of the agencys office in Newport Beach, Calif., is stepping down and selling his interest in Doner back to the agency. Three executives at the office are assuming his duties: Brian Born, senior vice president and creative director; Henni Sanft, senior vice president and director for planning and research; and Peter Watkins, senior vice president for brand leadership. Mr. Bletts departure leaves two remaining partners at Doner: David DeMuth, president and co-chief executive, and Rob Strasberg, co-chief executive and chief creative officer.

title: Milan Top 5 | Burberry Prorsum
description: There was an air of the exotic in Christopher Baileys great Burberry Prorsum collection. Brightly colored tribal prints covered jackets and camp shirts, while coats sprouted woven raffia collars and trim. Lace-ups with jute and ethnic-inspired fabric insets and woven totes perfect for an open air market completed this global nomads look.

When photographers have had nearly 100 years to perfect the shot of, say, the Taj Mahal, how do you improve on shots so classic they have become clich?

They have trapped it in a tiny groove on a clear plastic chip, with just its nose sticking into a channel. Pheromones  signaling chemicals produced by other worms  are being pumped through the channel, and the researchers have genetically engineered two neurons in the worms head to glow bright green if a neuron responds.

title: Hoping to Survive This Round. Literally.
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  On the rim of a rock quarry in the blistering June heat, three people are huddled in spacesuits with metallic jet packs on their backs, worrying aloud about which jet pack is about to be turned on. Five camera operators are sprawled around them, capturing every groan and sigh and exhortation to God.

title: The Complete Pentagon Papers
description: Forty years after the New York Times published the leaked Pentagon Papers, the National Archives has released them in their entirety.

title: Young and Old, With No Particular Place to Go
description: Death steals quietly into a Greenwich Village apartment, like morning sunlight gradually suffusing a darkened room, in 4000 Miles, a funny, moving new play by Amy Herzog that opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street. Beneath the plain-wrap surface of this drama about a grandmother and grandson sharing a few weeks of casual cohabitation lies a quiet meditation on mortality. But its hardly a downer: Ms. Herzogs altogether wonderful drama also illuminates how companionship can make life meaningful, moment by moment, in deaths discomforting shadow.

title: Keyboard Speaks Louder Than a Microphone
description: On Sunday evening Shea Stadium, a performance space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, had the feel of a dorm party in its dwindling hours. Young people sat on lumpy couches, barely talking to one another, lost in their own reveries. Onstage a series of performers came and went, though at any given time there were as many people smoking and chatting on the balcony as were loosely gathered near the stage to watch.

title: For Artists, Growing Up Is Still Hard to Do
description: A coming-of-age tale about struggling artists in the big city, Next Thing You Know is a sort of Rent for the Organization Kid generation.

title: A Festival Brings the Obscure to the Fore, With a Global Touch
description: BOSTON  You might expect an early-music festival to celebrate the settled canon, with programs devoted to, say, Josquin and Dufay Masses, Bachs Brandenburg Concertos, Mozarts Requiem and other repertory high-water marks, in interpretations that reflect the latest notions of period style.

title: For One Fan of McIlroy, a Major Payoff
description: This weekend 22-year-old Rory McIlroy cruised to a United States Open title, becoming the youngest Open champion since Bobby Jones in 1923. The incredible performance - he finished 16-under par, eight shots ahead of the runner-up, Jason Day - included 12 records. And it also sparked comparisons to Tiger Woods as the sport seeks a young superstar for a future that may not feature the dominant Woods the world grew accustomed to.

title: Viewers Still Drool for Frosting Fantasies
description: By any logical standard, say the collapse of Hollands tulip bubble in 1637 or Mrs. Fields filing for bankruptcy in 2008, cupcake mania should surely by now be waning.

title: Thaw in a Players Dispute With the U.S.T.A.
description: WIMBLEDON, England - Two unseeded Americans who traveled thousands of miles from home faced off on opposite sides of the net at the All England Club on Monday. The match was anti-climactic compared to a controversy involving the losing player, Donald Young, 21, of Atlanta.

title: Working With Whimsy Fit for the Philharmonic
description: Among the many novel ideas implemented at the New York Philharmonic since Alan Gilbert took the reins as its music director in 2009, one has come to loom larger than all the rest. Le Grand Macabre, a musically unorthodox, wickedly funny absurdist opera by Gyorgy Ligeti, represented a substantial risk when the Philharmonic mounted a series of performances of it at Avery Fisher Hall in May 2010, imaginatively and resourcefully staged by Doug Fitch, a designer and director with whom Mr. Gilbert had worked in opera houses.

title: A Vision Glimpsed Through the Window, and Its Consequences
description: See whats outside! Last weekend you could go from the Metropolitan Museum of Arts exhibition Rooms With a View: The Open Window in the 19th Century to two theatrical depictions of (sometimes open) windows in the 19th century: Tom Stoppards play Arcadia and August Bournonvilles ballet La Sylphide. The recent revival of Arcadia at the Ethel Barrymore Theater closed on Sunday; from Friday to Sunday the Royal Danish Ballet gave four performances of La Sylphide at the David H. Koch Theater.

description: One current and three former speakers of the House are scheduled to gather together Friday in Lexington, Ky., to pay tribute to another member of their illustrious fraternity  Henry Clay.

description: The freshman class of House Republicans has offered to sacrifice vacations to keep Congress perpetually in session for the next 18 months, which would prevent President Obama from appointing officials while Congress is not in session.

title: Baseball Commissioner Rejects Dodgers TV Deal
description: Bud Selig, Major League Baseballs commissioner, rejected a proposed cable television deal by the Los Angeles Dodgers on Monday. That scrambled the teams financial future and voided a divorce agreement reached Friday by Frank McCourt, the Dodgers owner, and his wife, Jamie, who wants the team to be declared half hers.

title: Pizza From Scratch
description: Melissa Clark proves that making pizza at home is easier than you may think.

title: Planners Want to Enliven Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn
description: The City Planning Department on Monday proposed a commercial rezoning of upper Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, the famously unscenic stretch of flats-fixed joints and auto body shops that has lately sprouted a collection of blocky apartment buildings.

title: Open Continues International Players Domination
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  For all the well-deserved hoopla attending the transcendent United States Open performance by Rory McIlroy, a 22-year-old from Northern Ireland, his record-setting victory at Congressional Country Club on Sunday did not come without some cautionary notes for the game.

title: Pizzeria-Quality Pies at Home
description: There is nothing like pizza fresh out of a brick oven. That thin-yet-chewy crust blistered to perfection was one of those things I thought was utterly impossible to reproduce at home  until I met Andrew Feinberg.

title: Mr. Peanut Gets Back in the Peanut Butter Business
description: Take cover, Peter Pan. Be choiceful, all you choosy moms who choose Jif. A dapper legume who had bowed out of the peanut butter market some decades ago is returning.

title: A Cumin, Ginger and Sweet Pea Kind of Day
description: WE all want to believe in the myth of one-stop shopping, but the truth is, you wont find everything you want at a regular supermarket. More to the point, life would be a lot duller if you could.

title: Milan Top 5 | Prada
description: An ingenious AstroTurf green with a grid of electric blue foam cube seats set the perfect scene for Pradas Summertime show. Whimsical cartoon-printed 50s-style camp shirts and floral pants and golf bags made it clear that Miuccia Prada was serious about her leisure time. Though tough to choose, my favorite look was a mismatched tattersall sports jacket and trouser worn with a ghillied golf shoe. Country club clothes with a sense of humor.

title: Whats Your Favorite Food-Hunting Ground?
description: In this weeks City Kitchen, well take a spin through Curry Hill to pick up some fragrant Indian staples for the pantry, along with a cauliflower, for a one-pan vegetable dish that delivers pungent, citrus-laden herbs and spices.

title: Man Turns to Crime for Prison Health Care
description: As if conjured up by a presidential speechwriter to star in an anecdote about Americas dysfunctional health insurance system, James Verone, an unemployed 59-year-old with a bad back, a sore foot and an undiagnosed growth on his chest, limped into a bank in Gastonia, N.C., this month and handed the teller a note, explaining that this was an unarmed robbery, but shed better turn over $1 and call the cops. That, he figured, would be enough to get himself arrested and sent to prison for a few years, where he could take advantage of the free medical care.

title: Hawk Cam | One Readers Family Portrait
description: Not much news today from the 12th floor of Bobst Library at New York University, where Pip the hawk is expected to take flight any day now. But in the increasingly wide world of Hawk Cam spinoffs theres this: a family portrait of Bobby, Violet and Pip sporting the school colors, courtesy of chatroom regular Cheryl Ann Kingstons new Pip at NYU blog.

title: Ex-Tunisian President Found Guilty, in Absentia
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A Tunisian court sentenced the countrys ousted president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, and his wife, Leila Trabelsi, to 35 years in prison and a fine of roughly $66 million after a trial in absentia for embezzlement and misuse of public funds, state news media said Monday night.

title: A Tech Entrepreneurs Plan for Grilled-Cheese Sandwiches
description: Jonathan Kaplan, who created the Flip video camera and sold it to Cisco Systems for $590 million, surprised a lot of people when he announced that his next start-up, the Melt, would make grilled-cheese sandwiches.

title: Protests Aside, Yemens Leader Has His Followers
description: SANA, Yemen  Out of the ancient, ornate mud brick buildings and across the narrow alleyways where barefoot children play, a chant emerges frequently in the old walled city here in the capital. Seemingly at random, someone will raise his voice to announce: The people want Ali Abdullah Saleh!

description: A family protected its home from the rising flood waters in the Mississippi Delta, but its farming legacy is not as secure.

description: YAZOO CITY, Miss.  Sitting on a boat, in a driveway on dry ground in the middle of a flood, a man can get to thinking about his place in the world.

title: Belarus: European Union Imposes New Sanctions
description: The European Union on Monday imposed additional sanctions on Belarus in response to the governments crackdown on opposition groups and independent media. Officials condemned the imprisonment of about two dozen opposition figures for participating in an antigovernment protest last December. The sanctions apply to three major companies linked to the government, a prominent arms exporter, a judge and two prosecutors, a union spokeswoman said.

title: Witnesses to Sunrise Over the Strip
description: The economic news in the morning newspaper was grim this past weekend: another uptick in the unemployment rate for Las Vegas, to 12.4 percent from 12 percent. Room occupancy rates on the Strip are stagnant. There were tables to be had at some of the fancier restaurants around, and empty spots at craps tables at the Cosmopolitan, the hot new casino, during what should have been a prime hour.

title: With Xboxs New In-Game Advertising, Engagement Is the Goal
description: Users of Microsofts popular Xbox Kinect gaming console will soon be able to use voice and motion commands to interact with advertisements while they are playing their favorite game or watching a video.

title: France: Ex-Minister Held in Sexual Abuse Inquiry
description: The French police took a former government minister into custody on Monday for questioning about accusations of sexual assault by at least two women employees. The former minister, Georges Tron, resigned May 29 over allegations that he persuaded women who worked in the town hall where he was mayor into letting him massage their feet, which turned into groping. The women came forward, inspired, they said, by the New York hotel chambermaid who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former director of the International Monetary Fund, of attempted rape. Mr. Tron was reportedly confronted by three women during the questioning, Agence France-Presse reported. He has not been charged in the case.

title: Rules to Stop Overfishing
description: To the Editor:

title: Wanted: Hygienist (and Her Gangster Pal)
description: BOSTON  Catherine Greig, a former dental hygienist, is thin and blond with well-kept teeth  or at least she was before she went on the lam. Now the F.B.I. is hoping the public will provide more help finding her so it can solve a case that has stumped the agency and fixated Boston for years.

title: Is Voting Speech?
description: At the first tenure meeting I ever attended, a candidate for promotion was approved by a single vote, and it turned out that one of my colleagues in the majority had gotten mixed up and believed he was voting for someone else. (It was a very large department.) The decision stood because, it was said, a vote is a vote and the motivations behind it, including having been motivated by a mistake, were not to the procedural point. Voting was, by definition, a one-time affair, and if misgivings or second thoughts or the fact of confusion were enough to warrant a revote (I now know who she is; lets do it again), there is logically no place to stop and the departments business could never get definitively done.

description: MILWAUKEE

description: HARWICH, Mass.  Summers arrival, usually cause for celebration on Cape Cod, has been dampened this year by a grim question: Who is killing the gray seals?

title: FIFA Power Broker Is Out After Years of Whispers
description: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad  Jack Warner commands headlines nearly every day in this Caribbean nation, known simply by his first name in his highly visible if conflicting roles as energetic public servant and now disgraced soccer power broker.

title: Court Issues Split Ruling on Poors Right to Counsel
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday gave a complicated answer to the simple question of whether poor people facing jail time for failing to pay child support are entitled to court-appointed lawyers.

title: Flooding Brings Worries Over Two Nuclear Plants
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  As record floodwaters along the Missouri River drench homes and businesses, concerns have grown about keeping a couple of notable structures dry: two riverside nuclear power plants in Nebraska.

title: Mayors Call for a Quicker End to Wars So Money Can Be Used for Needs at Home
description: The resolution that the United States Conference of Mayors passed on Monday calling on President Obama and Congress to speed up the ending of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan was not nearly as strong as the one it passed 40 years ago, calling on President Richard M. Nixon to withdraw all American troops from Vietnam within six months.

title: Joining the Crowd and Standing Apart
description: Carlyle will soon join the crowd  but try to stand apart from it. The private equity firm is preparing to join its rivals Apollo, Blackstone and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts as a publicly listed company. Carlyles unique structure could be its best hope of arguing the tough case that profits from investing, or carried interest, as it is known in the industry, should be worth more than investors currently think.

title: Bonus Cuts, Pay Raises, Then Layoffs
description: Its hardly surprising that Wall Street is bracing for layoffs. The European debt crisis is rocking the markets. New regulations are crimping bank profit centers. And smaller bonuses are sending other compensation costs soaring.

description: BLOOMBERG has begun a major marketing effort for its television operation in a bid to persuade business executives to see the company as more than just a maker of the terminals that are popular on trading floors.

title: Vote of Confidence Is Only the First Step for Greece
description: If the Greek government can win a crucial vote of confidence Tuesday night, paving the way to passing austerity measures into law this month, it will also win an immediate infusion of cash that will tide it  and the rest of Europe  over for now.

title: Health Law in a Swirl of Forecasts
description: The debate over the effects of the federal health care law on employer-provided insurance has been intensifying in recent weeks, with controversial polls and consultants contradicting one another about whether employees will benefit or lose coverage by 2014.

description: Jeff Sharlet, left, of Dartmouth College and Amy Sullivan of Time discuss anti-Muslim sentiment in American politics.

title: Wal-Mart Case Is a Blow for Big Cases and Their Lawyers
description: With the dismissal of a sex-discrimination lawsuit brought on behalf of 1.5 million women who have worked at Wal-Mart, the Supreme Court on Monday significantly tightened the rules for how a large group of individuals can join together to sue a company for alleged harm done to them.

title: Legislature Still at Odds Over Cuomos Top Issues
description: ALBANY  The annual legislative session sputtered into overtime on Monday night with no visible progress on critical elements of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos ambitious first-year agenda, while legislative leaders battled behind the scenes on a host of contentious issues.

title: Germany Debates New Life for a Behemoth of the Nazi Era
description: PRORA, Germany  Three years before the outbreak of World War II, Adolf Hitlers lieutenants ordered the construction of what was portrayed as a remarkable perquisite for the toiling masses of the Third Reich  a vacation complex along the Baltic coast with 10,000 sea-view rooms in eight identical six-story blocks of steel-reinforced concrete, each one the length of five football fields.

title: In New Jersey, Bill Advances on Public Workers Benefits
description: TRENTON  A central piece of Gov. Chris Christies agenda moved to the brink of becoming law on Monday, when a bill requiring government workers to pay much more for benefits, while limiting their bargaining rights, passed two crucial tests.

description: OMAHA  Two days into the College World Series, California-Berkeley already finds itself in the losers bracket, one loss from elimination.

description: SALT LAKE CITY  A drive along mountain-lined Interstate 15 here shows why Senator Orrin G. Hatch is considered a hero in this region nicknamed the Silicon Valley of the nutritional supplement industry.

title: Orrin Hatch: An Industry Champion
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch repeatedly defended the dietary supplement industry, which has a major presence in his home state of Utah, from new regulations.

description: BEIJING  The chairman of the Libyan oppositions executive board, Mahmoud Jibril, will visit Beijing for talks on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Chinese Foreign Ministry announced on Monday, in the latest sign that China is hedging its bet on the survival of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis government in Tripoli.

title: Warner Resigns, Cutting Short Ethics Inquiry
description: Jack Warner, who for nearly three decades was a powerful but polarizing figure in regional and international soccer, resigned his positions as the vice president of FIFA and as the president of Concacaf on Monday. In response, FIFA closed an ethics inquiry that had accused him of bribery and said the presumption of innocence is maintained. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: In Iran, a Brotherhood of Doctors and Patients
description: Few doctors anywhere in the world have done their country a greater service than the Iranian brothers Arash and Kamiar Alaei. Kamiar, who is 37, is currently living in Albany, N.Y., where he is working on a doctorate in public health. Arash, who is 42, is a resident of Tehrans notorious Evin prison  where until recently, Kamiar lived as well.

title: Moving Beyond Its Feisty Roots, Hudson River Park Group Focuses on Fund-Raising
description: The nature lovers and community activists who founded Friends of Hudson River Park in 1999 never shied from a fight; years earlier, they even helped kill Westway, the superhighway planned to run down the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Scores of U.S. Strikes in Libya Followed Handoff to NATO
description: WASHINGTON  Since the United States handed control of the air war in Libya to NATO in early April, American warplanes have struck at Libyan air defenses about 60 times, and remotely operated drones have fired missiles at Libyan forces about 30 times, according to military officials.

title: Smart Power Setback
description: So far, few politicians have embraced my plan for a Marshall Plan Tax. The idea is that every time a think-tanker, op-ed writer or retired senator calls for a new Marshall Plan or a moonshot-type initiative to solve a social problem, they would have to pay a tax of $50. Within a few months, wed have enough money to pay for an actual new Marshall Plan.

title: Bankings Moment of Truth
description: Capital matters. Let me put that another way. The current fight over additional capital requirements for the banking industry, eye-glazing though it is, also happens to be the most important reform moment since the financial crisis broke out three years ago. More important than the wrangling over Dodd-Frank. More important than the ongoing effort to regulate derivatives. More important even than the jousting over the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

title: Uranium Mine Moratorium Extended at Grand Canyon
description: The federal government on Monday extended for six months a moratorium on new uranium mining claims in a million-acre buffer zone around the Grand Canyon as it awaits the conclusions of a study of potential environmental harm to the region.

title: Tuesday: Limo-Riding Sorts
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Stop me if youve heard this one before. A young woman walks into her high school class (shes too young to walk into a bar, so I changed it), sits down at her desk and pulls out a crossword puzzle. Despite her teachers bid to maintain her attention, shes more interested in doing that puzzle.

title: Wal-Mart Wins. Workers Lose.
description: Wal-Mart Stores asked the Supreme Court to make a million or more of the companys current and former female employees fend for themselves in individual lawsuits instead of seeking billions of dollars for discrimination in a class-action lawsuit. Wal-Mart got what it wanted from the court  unanimous dismissal of the suit as the plaintiffs presented it  and more from the five conservative justices, who went further in restricting class actions in general.

title: Man Shot in Brooklyn Shop; Police Kill Gunman
description: A pair of police officers shot and killed a gunman on Monday minutes after he walked into a Brooklyn auto shop and opened fire on a man in an apparent feud, the police said.

title: Chilean Court Blocks Plan for Patagonia Dam Project
description: A Chilean appeals court on Monday suspended a plan to build five dams and hydroelectric plants in the countrys Patagonia region.

title: The Sun Is the Best Optometrist
description: WHY is nearsightedness so common in the modern world? In the early 1970s, 25 percent of Americans were nearsighted; three decades later, the rate had risen to 42 percent, and similar increases have occurred around the world.

title: Police Suspect That Drugs Were Goal of Killer on L.I.
description: The Suffolk County police commissioner said on Monday that investigators seeking the killer of four people at a Medford pharmacy would plead for help from pharmacists and doctors who might have recently come into contact with a person expressing an urgent need for painkillers.

title: Politically Tied Lawyers Win Jobs Handling Foreclosures in the City
description: In 2009, a judge in Manhattan had a lucrative appointment to hand out: oversight of a diamond district building that was drifting into foreclosure.

title: Despite Setback, Plaintiffs to Pursue Wal-Mart Cases
description: Wal-Mart has spent 10 years fighting claims that it discriminated against female employees, and by many accounts, it has improved its hiring and promotion policies for women during those years.

title: Murder Rate and Fear Rise in Puerto Rico
description: LOZA, P.R.  As people strolled past the Alambique liquor store here recently, the puddle of blood and the bullet-shattered storefront behind it scarcely merited a glance. Yet another young man had been shot. Yet another tally would be added to the record books.

title: Obama to Announce Plans for Afghan Surge Pullout
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama plans to announce his decision on the scale and pace of troop withdrawals from Afghanistan in a speech from the White House at 8 p.m. Eastern time Wednesday evening.

title: Potential on Display, Nova Dismantles Powerful Reds
description: CINCINNATI  The Cincinnati Reds are the highest-scoring team in the National League, and they play in a ballpark that yields home runs by the bushel. One of their left-handed sluggers, Joey Votto, is the reigning most valuable player. Another, Jay Bruce, is among the league leaders in homers.

title: Upending Anonymity, These Days the Web Unmasks Everyone
description: Not too long ago, theorists fretted that the Internet was a place where anonymity thrived.

title: Doing Right by the Poorest Countries
description: Ten years ago in Doha, Qatar, the worlds leading trading nations began the so-called development round of trade negotiations, billed as an effort to open markets in rich countries to the exports of the worlds poorest nations to help them rise out of destitution.

title: Hypocrisy, Locked and Loaded
description: If Congressional Republicans are really intent on getting to the bottom of an ill-conceived sting operation along the border by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, they should call President Felipe Caldern of Mexico as an expert witness.

title: Elena Georgievna Bonner, a True Human Rights Activist for 40 Years
description: On Jan. 22, 1980, shortly after I arrived in Moscow as a reporter, but before I met him, Andrei Sakharov was arrested and flown to internal exile in Gorky, a city closed to foreigners (now called Nizhny Novgorod). The operation was a stunning show of the Soviet states paranoia about a mild man who did nothing more than publicly criticize its human-rights violations. All the traffic around Sakharovs apartment on Chkalova Street was halted and phones in the neighborhood turned off as if armed dissidents were out there ready to defend him.

title: Immigrants Sue Over Loss of Green Cards
description: A class-action lawsuit was filed against the State Department in federal court in Washington by immigrants from more than 20 countries who say officials mishandled the annual lottery of permanent resident visas. After notifying more than 20,000 foreigners this year that they had won the permanent visas, known as green cards, the State Department canceled them, saying a computer glitch had tainted the process. The immigrants, who are all living legally in the United States, had waited years for the green cards and were bitterly disappointed to have them granted and then taken away.

title: As Secession Nears, Sudan Steps Up Drive to Stop Rebels
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Sudanese Army and its allied militias have gone on an unsparing rampage to crush rebel fighters in the Nuba Mountains of central Sudan, bombing thatch-roofed villages, executing elders, burning churches and pitching another region of the country into crisis, according to United Nations officials and villagers who have escaped.

title: TimesCast | Ruling for Wal-Mart
description: June 20, 2011 - The Supreme Court throws out a class-action discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart, saying 1.5 million women could not unite their collective cases.

title: Sudan to Pull Troops From Abyei and Allow Peacekeepers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Sudanese government has agreed to pull its troops out of the flashpoint Abyei area and allow Ethiopian peacekeepers to come in, the result of a deal signed Monday that could ease tensions along Sudans disputed north-south border.

title: Ethnic Killings by Army Reported in Sudanese Mountains
description: PARIENG, Sudan  Underneath the wisp of shade he now calls home, Hamed El Bardi is a leader of a lost community. With more than 100 of his fellow Nubans huddled in the backyard of a county office in this southern Sudanese village, Mr. El Bardi tabulates newcomers and tries to figure out what to do next.

title: California: Beating Suspect Jailed for Parole Violation
description: The suspect in the beating of a Giants fan at Dodger Stadium on opening day was sent back to prison on Monday because of a parole violation. The parole board ordered Giovanni Ramirez, 31, suspected of being a gang member, to spend 10 months behind bars after the Los Angeles police found weapons in the home where he was living when he was arrested in the beating case on May 22. The parole revocation comes as the police have struggled to put together a case against Mr. Ramirez, who has been in custody since his arrest and remains the primary suspect but has not been charged. The parole board declined earlier this month to hold Mr. Ramirez on charges related to the beating for lack of evidence.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Nokia Unveils a New Smartphone, but Not a Product of Its Microsoft Deal
description: ESPOO, Finland  Late last year, the Apple iPhone became the best-selling device at Finlands leading mobile operator, a highly embarrassing situation for Nokia, the struggling mobile phone maker that has long been Finlands corporate standard-bearer.

title: Battle for Libya | June 20, 2011
description: The Qaddafi government made new charges that a NATO airstrike had killed civilians, including children, when it hit an estate belonging to Khoweildi al-Hamidi, a former military officer.

title: The Mouth That Roared Begins a New Countdown
description: Keith Olbermann returned to cable television on Monday mad as hell and pointedly madder than other self-described liberal anchors on his former channel, MSNBC.

title: A. Whitney Ellsworth, First Publisher of New York Review, Dies at 75

title: Who Made That Big Brown Bag?
description: I cant walk down the street anymore without seeing someone with a canvas tote. They have become the default choice for the environmentally conscious and have also provided fertile ground for graphic designers, illustrators and other creatives. I think I have at least 10 of them but only one of which I actually purchased. They just keep appearing either as gifts or freebies, which makes me wonder how earth-friendly they actually are if enough people have similar tote-bag-to-person ratios to my own. A couple years ago, Dimitri Siegel wrote an article on the Design Observer blog about this phenomenon and noted, Just as the remarkable efficiency of the plastic bag ended up making it a menace to the environment, graphic designs ability to generate options and choices may turn a sustainable idea into an environmental calamity. It seems that sustainable design is not limited to just the materials that are used but also to the endurance of the design itself.

Theres a pioneer fur trader, too, a man who negotiated with the Lenape Indians to move them out of central Indiana and lost his Lenape Indian wife and children in the bargain. And lets not forget the 20th-century philanthropist who envisioned a living museum that would reflect the history of his state; his gift of that museum to a nearby college that had other priorities led to 21st-century courtroom battles and, ultimately, to the museums recent independence. Now teams of interpreters and facilitators and costumed Indianians lure more than 220,000 visitors a year to this endearingly strange place.

description: Before Jeremy Kost became a Polaroid-snapping phenom, he was working a day job as a manager for an Internet company in Washington. I started taking pictures at the big parties I was throwing with Ed Bailey and John Guggenmos, but I eventually felt I had outgrown that city, says Kost. He had already flirted with New York nightlife during business trips, and in 2006 he quit his Web job, moved to New York and began taking party photos full time. The result has been an oeuvre of Warholian portraits showing off his favorite nocturnal denizens. His first hardbound monograph, Its Always Darkest Before Dawn (PowerHouse, $50), contains his typical club pictures, but blown up and and methodically assembled to show graphic detail. The book features a selection of cropped photographs and Polaroid collages (the result of a collaboration with Sam Shahid, a former creative director of Calvin Klein).

In his work with avant-garde composer-improvisers (John Zorn) and the indie-rock intelligentsia (John Darnielle) he often engages his instrument with an ear tilted toward possibilities. The same is even truer in his own work, especially within the last five years.

Translation? The cropped suit, nipped and trimmed from the leg to the sleeve, never looked so cool. Wear a facsimile now, before the weather turns brutal.

As such, it is an oasis of psychological complexity among the bells and whistles of the Comic Book Theater Festival, which is currently stuffing the Brick Theater with no end of chintzy superhero outfits.

title: Victorian Goddesses, a Real Wife and a Sour Marriage
description: Most people who have read about the great Victorian art critic John Ruskin remember two things about him: that he was sued by Whistler and had to pay a farthing in damages, and that he was unable to consummate his marriage to Effie Gray because, knowing the female body only from paintings and classical statuary, he was appalled by the sight of her pubic hair.

title: Violence Continues in Syria, Activists Say

title: The End of AfPak
description: Remember how after 9/11, Osama bin Ladens attacks on us could be linked to almost anything, from shopping habits to the rediscovery of Western values to carbon-pricing schemes? Something similar appears to be happening with Bin Ladens death. Jihadism sure isnt what it used to be. After 10 years, it seems, the time has come to go home. Troops are and will be coming back to the United States from Iraq and Afghanistan. The military budget will be cut. The outgoing secretary of defense feels able to openly mock NATO because, presumably, he thinks he can afford to  because it doesnt matter all that much. The global war on terror is being downgraded from Armageddon to something more out of Leviticus: a tricked-out police action, just as John Kerry, in this magazine, always said it should be. On Sunday, Helene Cooper and Mark Landler reported that American success in the counterterrorism campaign would seem to bolster arguments for a swift withdrawal from Afghanistan. By Tuesday morning, they were reporting that President Obama would announce his withdrawal plans on Wednesday. Meanwhile, a Harris poll revealed that 51 percent of Americans and 54 percent of Britons believed the death of Bin Laden meant it was time to bring troops from their countries home.

title: Design Miami/Basel Wrap-Up
description: Last week professionals, collectors and amateurs of all things art flocked to Basel for the 42nd edition of Art Basel, the worlds top contemporary art fair. While the main fair was received with mixed reviews (too crowded, confusing layout, not enough outstanding pieces), an entirely different tune was sung over at Hall 5 of Basels venerable Messegelnde, where only a day earlier Design Miami opened the doors to its annual sister fair, Design Miami/Basel, a satellite fair specializing in collectible design. There was a noticeable excitement in the air as this was the first Design Miami/Basel under the new directorship of Marianne Goebl. Her debut did not disappoint: a record 43 exhibitors showing everything from 20th-century classics to contemporary designers, intelligent design collaborations with corporate sponsors (take note, Art Basel V.I.P. lounge), a great bookstore (courtesy of doyoureadme?! from Berlin) and a well-curated series of talks (full disclosure: I moderated one of them). Design Miami/Basel may keep flourishing thanks to the cross-pollinating effect from the neighboring art fair(s), but judging by the increasingly educated and design-passionate public, it seems that the fair could very well stand on its own if it had to.

title: Angela Bassett Will Star Opposite Samuel L. Jackson in The Mountaintop

title: Pairings: Edible Cocktail
description: The classic rum drinks, most of them made with spirits that are aged briefly, if at all, are well-suited for summer sipping. They are beautiful at bolstering fresh fruit combinations, made with citrus, mango and melon, without intruding notes of woody intensity. Good cachaas perform similar magic. A thoroughly non-classic use for agricultural rum or cachaa is the edible cocktail that El Bulli was recently serving as a first course. Sticks of sugar cane are marinated in mojito and caipirinha baths and stuck into a bowl of crushed ice. Diners would pick them up and chew the cane to get the cocktails essence. Once I was home, I tried it with sticks of pineapple core and a mixture that suggested both drinks. My guests were happy, so I checked it with Ferran Adri, who gave his enthusiastic approval in an e-mail: Fantstica tu idea!!! Were going to try it!

He also addressed the Senate on Tuesday, saying Italys economic future depended on the longevity of his coalition, whose mandate expires in 2013. Rejecting opposition calls for his resignation, he said a government crisis would be madness when Italy needed to focus on growth.

title: A New Cheesemonger for the Flatiron District

title: No Food Safety in These Numbers
description: Im eager to cover some curious and less depressing topics here  did you know Asian multi-millionaires are cornering the market on first-growth Bordeaux?  and equally eager to stop throwing mind-numbing numbers around. But as long as those pesky Republicans keep attacking the food supply for low-income people and food safety for all of us, and as long as most Democrats put up toothless defenses instead of actually trying to make things better, I gotta pay attention. If we needed further evidence that the party of family values only values wealthy families, we have it now; when these guys say women and children first, they mean first to throw overboard.

title: China: Military Ties With India Resume
description: China and India have restarted military-to-military relations, nearly a year after India froze exchanges because of a visa dispute related to territorial claims, according to a report on Tuesday in the newspaper China Daily. An eight-member Indian military delegation arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a six-day visit. The head of the delegation is the head of a counterinsurgency unit deployed in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir.

title: Indian Company Under Scrutiny Over U.S. Visas
