A new world order has unfolded, with nerds ascendant.

title: The Presidents Debt-Ceiling Strategy
description: Theres been a lot of discussion on liberal blogs (see Matt Yglesias, Jonathan Chait, Kevin Drum, Greg Sargent, and Chait again) about whether President Obamas decision to go along with the Republican insistence on tying a deficit reduction package to the debt ceiling vote constitutes a blunder or a deliberate strategy  whether hes a bad negotiator whos let the Republicans hold him (and the American economy) hostage to their demands for spending cuts, or a clever moderate whos using the debt ceiling to force his own base to live with painful deficit choices.

title: An Accidental, Experimental Masterpiece
description: I was walking, recently, with my physical body through a physical bookstore when  somewhere between the giant display of e-readers, the Blu-ray wing, the Wi-Fi cafe and the looming tower of interactive language software  I stumbled across an actual, physical book that stopped me cold.

title: Showcasing Lower Manhattan as 9/11 Anniversary Nears
description: In advance of the 10th anniversary of 9/11 and the opening of the 9/11 Memorial on Sept. 12, NYC & Company, the official marketing, tourism and partnership organization for New York City, is encouraging tourists to visit, dine, shop and stay in the downtown area.

title: A Clean Balance Sheet for a Corporate Asset
description: AS Chrysler emerged from bankruptcy in 2009, the reorganized Fiat-controlled automaker reasonably concluded that it needed to improve the minivans that had been corporate mainstays for a quarter-century.

title: The debut of the 'The Mechanic Muse' column; Andrew Delbarco on "Mightier Than the Sword" by David S. Reynolds; bestseller news
description: This week, Kathryn Schulz and Alex Star on the debut of the Book Review's new column, The Mechanic Muse; Andrew Delbanco discusses "Mightier Than the Sword: Uncle Tom's Cabin and the Battle for America" by David S. Reynolds; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: UBS Hires New Head of Hedge Fund Distribution
description: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse  Getty Images A UBS branch in Bern, Switzerland.

title: The Rules: Version Franaise
description: In De la Sduction (On Seduction), the French philosopher Jean Baudrillard defined his subject as the mastery of the symbolic universe. His point was that in contrast to political power, which involves the mastery of the real universe, seduction is a deft manipulation of rituals and codes, a never ending game that seducer and seduced play for its own sake, delighting in its elegant formulas and subtle challenges. Understood in this way, seduction is less a means to sexual conquest than an end in itself, an exquisitely refined form of social interaction. As the celebrity intellectual (and self-styled sducteur) Bernard-Henri Lvy has put it: Civilization is seduction. What separates man from the animals is seduction.

title: A Digital Helping Hand for Scholarly Work
description: Digitally savvy academics have been struggling to reconcile new media with traditional scholarly publishing, which is painfully slow and generally locked behind paywalls or unavailable online. One answer has been offered by the Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media at George Mason University, which on Wednesday unveiled PressForward, a new open access platform for online scholarship.

title: Its All About Holding Hands and Stitching Hems
description: When Sutton Foster won the Tony Award for best actress this month for her performance in Anything Goes, she began her acceptance speech by thanking the usual suspects: co-stars, teachers, director, boyfriend. It wasnt until she thanked her dresser, though, that Ms. Fosters composure broke, and the waterworks started.

title: Go Daddy Expected to Be Sold to Buyout Firms
description: 6:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Robert Lipsyte: Skeptic in the Press Box
description: A 19-year-old aspiring novelist and native New Yorker just out of Columbia University, Robert Lipsyte had never bought a copy of The New York Times until he decided to look in the classifieds for a summer job before graduate school. He found one at the paper itself, as a copy boy in the sports department in 1957, though he had little interest or experience in sports. In junior high, he was a self-described nerd and became a particular target of the bullies because I compulsively talked back and was too fat to run away afterward.

title: Handicapping the Republican Field: Part II, the Wild Cards
description: I mentioned last week that Id thought wed seen the emergence of a relatively distinct top tier of Republican candidates, consisting of Mitt Romney, Tim Pawlenty, Rick Perry and Michele Bachmann. Having taken a deeper look, I am more confident in that claim  Id posit that there is a better than an 80 percent chance that the nominee will be one of those four people.

title: A Primer on Pakistan
description: During the regime of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, it became the policy of the United States to help spread Sufi Islam in Pakistan. A Sufi council was formed and a few seminars and some musical concerts were held; a Sufi University is still being worked on. Meanwhile, Sufi shrines have been attacked all across Pakistan. Many Pakistanis now believe Sufis to be the allies of American intelligence operatives, a belief only strengthened by the recent Raymond Davis affair, in which a Central Intelligence Agency contractor was detained in the killing of two Pakistanis.

title: Cengage in National Geographic Deal
description: Cengage Learning, a private-equity-backed education company, agreed on Friday to acquire National Geographics digital and print school publishing unit.

title: The Story of the Mole
description: A very nice dermatologist called me about the small growth on my fathers ear, which he had biopsied. He left a phone message asking me to call him at home (over a holiday weekend! I liked this guy already). His message said that more removal needs to be done.

title: Campaigning for Change in Mexico
description: Jorge G. Castaeda was long involved in efforts to end the 70-year dictatorial reign of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) over Mexico. In 1988, he supported the presidential ambitions of Cuauhtmoc Crdenas, who probably won the election that was officially called for the PRI candidate Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Crdenas decided to contest local races across Mexico, and in 1989 Castaeda traveled to the town of Tepoztln as an election observer. As he recounts in Maana Forever? it became obvious that the PRI was tampering with the ballots in this election as well, and Castaeda urged the local cardenistas to put up a fight.

title: Jets Will Hold Training Camp in New Jersey
description: Citing the uncertainty of the N.F.L. lockout, the Jets said they would hold their training camp this year in Florham Park, N.J., and not at SUNY Cortland, where it has been held the past two years.

title: Up Front: Introducing The Mechanic Muse
description: The literary critic Hugh Kenner, who died in 2003, is best known for his intimate studies of Ezra Pound, T. S. Eliot, James Joyce and their contemporaries. Unlike many advocates of these authors, Kenner was also a technology enthusiast; he celebrated the Wright brothers flight as the first great act of American modernism and even attempted to translate a passage of Samuel Beckett into the Pascal programming language.

title: What Is Distant Reading?
description: Ars longa, the ancient saying goes, vita brevis. Art is long, life short, and the problem is intensifying. As the literary ars lurches exponentially more longa  accommodating the printing press, Gravitys Rainbow, Google Books  our collective TBR pile towers ever more vertiginously overhead. Which raises a question: What are we mortal beings supposed to do with all these books?

title: Chinese History, Straight From the Source
description: Beginning of the Great Revival (called The Founding of the Party in China)  a companion piece to The Founding of a Republic from 2009  is a lavish, sprawling mosaic, spanning Chinese history from 1911 to 1921 and concluding with the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party. (Filmed for the partys 90th anniversary, Revival had a colossal release at home; the State Film Commission sought at least 30 million viewers.) Its principal focus is the May Fourth Movement, which sprang from failed government efforts to wrest Shandong Province from foreign control at the Paris Peace Conference of 1919, resulting in student riots in Beijing.

title: Preparing to Be Torn
Overlooked Vancouver Video Shows Kissing Couple Was Knocked Down by Riot Police
description: As journalism in the Internet age starts to seem more and more like a remix of the 1966 film Blow-Up, reporters have discovered video shot during a riot in Vancouver, British Columbia, last week that shows exactly what happened just before a news photographer snapped a beguiling image of a man kissing a woman in the middle of a street filled with riot police officers.

title: The Death Camp Pharmacist
description: If memory serves, the great Italian poet and novelist Cesare Pavese once made the Archimedean claim that, given a place to stand and a pivot, he could write about anything. The mediocre German-Romanian poet and novelist Dieter Schlesak (may Paveses ghost forgive me for mentioning him in the same paragraph) makes the same point ex negativo. To wit, with nowhere to stand and no pivot, he can make nothing happen. The Druggist of Auschwitz, his so-called documentary novel, is neither document nor novel. It is that depressing thing, a very bad book on a very terrible subject.

title: The Rise and Fall of Pseudonyms
description: When the venerable tradition of the pseudonym is discussed, it is often in reductive terms. The other day, someone said to me, There are three reasons why authors use pen names, right? and went on to cite them: Women writing as men. Writers with dirty secrets to hide. Highbrow writers slumming it in trashy genres. Its true that each of those motives is historically common, but there are many others.

title: Inside the List
description: HOT WAR: Tom Clancy is back at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list with his latest thriller, written with Peter Telep. Against All Enemies  no relation to the counterterrorism expert Richard Clarkes 2004 nonfiction best seller of the same name  recounts the exploits of a former Navy Seals member and C.I.A. paramilitary officer named Maxwell Moore, who survives an attack on an American ship off the coast of Pakistan only to find himself doing battle with the Taliban on the United States/Mexican border.

title: Editors Choice
description: TEN THOUSAND SAINTS,  by Eleanor Henderson (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Hendersons fierce, elegiac novel follows a group of friends, lovers, parents and children through the straight-edge music scene and the early days of the AIDS epidemic.

title: Paperback Row
description: YOUR FACE TOMORROW: Volume Three  Poison, Shadow and Farewell,  by Javier Maras. Translated by Margaret Jull Costa (New Directions, $16.95.) In the final volume of Marass disquieting novel, his narrator  hired by MI6 in London as an expert translator or interpreter of people  peers into the territory of torture as he returns home to Madrid to both spy on and protect his own family.

title: Testing the Conscience of a Village Under the Nazis
description: All novelists are godlike. Sovereign creators of worlds they populate with beings wrought from something less than dust and rib, they set events in motion and determine their consequences. The situation is less ideal than it sounds: omnipotence can be a dreary limitation. Thats why the best novelists are also childlike. Bent over impalpable dollhouses, moving their lips while they rearrange the furniture and figures, they give themselves over to such deep play that their stories read less like a premeditated imposition than obedience to the whispered suggestions of the universe.

title: Paris Top 5 | Dries Van Noten
description: Always a Paris highlight, Dries Van Noten delivered a beautiful, carefully considered show. Cabana stripes turned on their side in airy nylon trenches, blousons, pants and wide-legged shorts worn over loose leggings gave an elegance to the athletic inspiration weve been seeing this show season. But it was the beautiful proportions of the elongated, trim double-breasted jacket with the loose shorts and leggings that took the prize.

title: The Impact of Uncle Toms Cabin
description: No less an authority than Leo Tolstoy included Uncle Toms Cabin on his short list of examples of the highest art flowing from love of God and man. Fifty years later, James Baldwin called the same book a very bad novel full of excessive and spurious emotion. What goes on here? The question belongs in the present tense because it is by no means settled.

title: A Frontier Schoolhouse Story
description: In the spring of 1916, two society girls from Auburn, N.Y.  Smith graduates who, having already done a European tour, were iffy about charity work but picky about husbands  found by chance the answer to the question of what to do with themselves. A lady whod come for tea mentioned a friend who had a brother, a Princeton man, who was looking for two college-educated women to teach at a schoolhouse hed built with his neighbors in the Elkhead Mountains of Colorado. Instantly, both knew they wanted to go. One of them, Dorothy Woodruff, was the grandmother of Dorothy Wickenden. And in Nothing Daunted, Wickenden has painstakingly recreated the story of how that earlier Dorothy and her friend Rosamond Underwood embarked on a brief but life-changing adventure, teaching the children of struggling homesteaders. Mining a trove of letters as well as oral histories and period documents, including an autobiography published by their employer, Farrington (Ferry) Carpenter, Wickenden lets their tale of personal transformation open out to reveal the larger changes in the rough-and-tumble society of the West  a back story, as she aptly puts it, to Americas leap into the 20th century.

title: Deer Tick as Deervana
description: Melena Ryzik goes to Brooklyn Bowl to catch Deer Tick, an alt-countryesque indie rock band, perform as Deervana, a Nirvana tribute band.

title: From Lisbon, Visiting the Storied City of vora
description: MANY day trips and overnight stays  especially to outlying towns and cities in southern Europe where weekend hours for shops and tourist sites can seem almost whimsical  often do little more than whet ones appetite to return for a proper visit. But, at less than two hours by car from Lisbon, an overnight visit to the storied Portuguese city of vora and the surrounding area packs a lot into relatively little time.

title: Exploring vora
description: An overnight visit to a storied Portuguese city packs a lot into relatively little time.

title: Hsker Ds Propulsive Liberation
description: It was early 1983, probably, after the Everything Falls Apart EP presaged Hsker Ds departure from hard-core punk and before the Metal Circus EP made it official. Just a gig at a crummy club near CBGB, and late  after 1. There werent a dozen onlookers, but Hsker Ds two early records were knockouts, and that Minneapolis trio never came east, so there we were. From our booth in back the music sounded terrific: headlong and enormous, the guitar unfashionably full, expressive and unending, with two raving vocalists alternating leads on songs whose words were hard to understand and whose tunes werent. Another half-dozen curious fans drifted in. And then, halfway through, the guitarist passed into some other dimension. When he stepped yowling off the low stage, most of us gravitated closer, glancing around and shaking our heads.

title: Steven Tylers Warp Speed Memoir
description: Calling Steven Tyler an incoherent loudmouth is like describing James Brown as a guy who moved around a lot. Tyler has devoted his improbably long musical career to testing the limits of incoherence, loudness and his mouth. From his 1970s glory days as the jive-talking lead singer of Aerosmith to his unlikely TV success as a judge on American Idol, hes always delighted in babble for its own sake. In his words, hes been 61 Highwayed and I did it my wayed; Little-Willie-Johned and been-here-and-goned; million-dollar riffed and Jimmy Cliffed; cotton-picked and Stevie Nickd. What he lacks in lucidity, which is just about everything, he makes up for with garrulous charm. As Laurence Sterne says of Yorick in Tristram Shandy, he has big sails but not an ounce of ballast.

title: Curing the Pelvic Headache
description: The appeal of conversion stories often depends on descriptions of the darkness before enlightenment: we enjoy learning in detail about the presalvation misery, debauchery or sinfulness. The more detail, the better. The English novelist Tim Parks understands that principle. In his urbane, droll, weird yet far from charmless account of the pain and misery suffered by his body in general, and by his bladder, prostate, penis and related bits in particular, the conversion is from a cerebral, anxious, hunched-over and compulsively verbal kvetch (not his term, but the literal squeeze makes the Yiddish word seem appropriate) to something resembling the opposite.

title: Taking Literary Revenge on Joseph Conrad
description: The best lines in The Secret History of Costaguana were written by Joseph Conrad. Harsh, maybe, but such is the treatment that its Colombian author, Juan Gabriel Vsquez (The Informers), invites  with crafty masochism  in this postmodern literary revenge story.

title: The Trouble With Common Sense
description: The popularity of the Mona Lisa is an illusion. As Duncan J. Watts explains: We claim to be saying that the Mona Lisa is the most famous painting in the world because it has attributes X, Y and Z. But really what were saying is that the Mona Lisa is famous because its more like the Mona Lisa than anything else. In other words, we are trapped inside a hall of mirrors of our own devising. We think the Mona Lisa is famous because of its traits, but we think those traits are significant only because they belong to the Mona Lisa, which we know to be famous. Ditto Shakespeare? Yes. When an incredulous English professor asked him whether he believed Shakespeare might just be a fluke of history, Watts indicated that he meant exactly that.

title: Love and Real Estate in South Asia
description: Anuradha Roys first novel opens with the image of a house, a Roman-looking affair with tapering pillars that seems to float down a river in flood. First its veranda goes under and then its windows, until the rooms look drowned and the building itself appears to leave its moorings. The imagination of disaster is never far from these pages, and though this house will finally stay on its foundation, it does get swamped by a monsoon-swelled river, and with consequences that are bitter indeed. That waterfront property is only one of the three houses in which Roys narrative is played out  each of them bedraggled, each living on after its time, and none of them a proper home.

title: The Great Gatsby: The Next Generation
description: When readers met Pamela Buchanan in the pages of The Great Gatsby, she was about 2 years old. As Daisy Buchanans Daughter opens, she is in her 80s, waiting for a birthday call from President George W. Bush, during which she intends to blow her brains out to protest the Iraq war. While waiting, she blogs. Through a suicide note that eventually becomes an autobiography almost perfectly contemporary with the American Century, we learn that Pam has been many things: rich mothers regret, successful author, war correspondent, diplomats wife. She was on the beach at Normandy, saw Dachau liberated and knew the Kennedys.

title: Cambodia After Year Zero
description: In the preface to Cambodias Curse: The Modern History of a Troubled Land, Joel Brinkley recalls his first encounter with Cambodia. Brinkley was reporting for The Louisville Courier-Journal from a refugee camp near the Thai border in 1979, in the aftermath of Pol Pots reign. As they tell of years of horror and misery, Brinkley wrote, their faces are expressionless and dull . . . as if theyre talking about a dull day of work. Their tales end with a nodding acknowledgment of the death of their nation and culture. Brinkley, who later worked for The New York Times, finds little has changed in the 32 years since then. As the title suggests, his book is an unabashed plea to refocus international aid and diplomacy on a suffering people. It is also an attempt to hold some of those responsible for that suffering accountable  but not all.Cambodia lost a quarter of its population under the Khmer Rouge. For many, survival meant 14-hour days of backbreaking work, often on little more than a cupful of rice or a smattering of gruel. You could be killed on the least suspicion you sympathized with the Vietnamese. The effects of this period have proven hard to shake.

title: Does Coaching Win Championships?
description: What the heck? Why havent we been doing this more often in the past?Dom Starsia, mens lacrosse coach, University of Virginia

title: Ahead of U.N. Vote, Effort to Restart Mideast Talks
description: JERUSALEM  Intensive efforts are under way to stave off a Palestinian bid for United Nations membership in September, with diplomats trying to lure Israeli and Palestinian leaders back to negotiations on the basis of President Obamas formula of a state based on the 1967 lines with mutually agreed land swaps.

title: A Prep School Confronts the 60s
description: In the opening chapter of Carolyn Cookes Daughters of the Revolution, two young men go kayaking off the coast south of Boston. It is 1963 and both men are graduates of the Goode School, a redoubt of WASP privilege. One of them, Archer, comes from money and the other, Heck, comes from moderate means and continues to struggle. Heck packs sandwiches for them both in hopes that Archer wont suggest they eat at a restaurant; when the weather turns bad, he notices that Archer has helped himself to the only life jacket in the boat. Issues of entitlement become a matter of life and death.

title: Inside the Churchill Clan
description: Like his mother, Jennie Jerome, and his cousin-by-marriage Consuelo Vanderbilt, Winston Churchills Aunt Lily Hammersley was an American heiress whose fortune, it was hoped, would assist in bailing out the Churchill clans ever shaky finances. Hurriedly wed and brought to England as the newest Duchess of Marlborough, Lily arrived at Blenheim, the familys vast, dilapidated country seat. The first thing that confronted her, Mary S. Lovell writes in The Churchills, was a life-size nude of Lady Colin Campbell, her husbands former mistress and divorce co-respondent, painted by Whistler, which hung in the dukes dressing room. The canvas soon thereafter disappeared from art history. It is widely assumed that Lily had it burned.

title: For a Few Developers, Its Hammer Time
description: LOUIS FOUNDOS didnt think he would have a problem selling out his new condominium project last fall. It was a renovated building in East Harlem with everything a first-time buyer might want, including granite countertops, dishwashers and washing machines in every unit. It was just a few blocks from the subway, and plenty of new development was under way in the neighborhood.

title: Wozniacki Is Waiting for a Major Breakthrough
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The ball dropped from the sky Friday as Caroline Wozniacki was trying for the second time to convert a match point against Virginie Razzano. Was it the plague of Court 2 descending on another top womens player put in its path?

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Bounty of Buffy
description: Theres only one new book on our lists this week and that honor goes to Volume 8 of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, which lands at No. 1 on our softcover list this week. The series, published by Dark Horse Comics, was presented as Season Eight, a look at the adventures of Buffy and her friends as if the television series had continued. The first issue of the series had orders of more than 110,000 copies. The series also made some news when Buffy had a brief affair with a fellow (female) slayer. Season Eight lasted 40 issues. The concluding storyline, issues No. 36 through 40, is collected in Volume 8. All of issue No. 36 is available on the Dark Horse site.

title: The Italian Potboilers Master Chef
description: IN 1949 the cognoscenti of the film world were focused on Vittorio De Sica, Roberto Rossellini, Luchino Visconti and the other Italian directors who had been gathered together under the banner of neo-realism.

title: Connecticut Budget Is Upended as State Workers Reject Deal
description: HARTFORD  Connecticuts state workers, in voting results announced on Friday, rejected a deal meant to produce $1.6 billion in labor savings over two years, blowing a gaping hole in the state budget, raising the likelihood of thousands of layoffs and threatening chaos in a state that has largely avoided the rancorous labor issues seen elsewhere.

title: Leasing a Car? It May Have Hidden Value
description: The common wisdom is that its more expensive to lease a car than to buy one. But the recent rise in used-car prices may provide a lucrative opportunity for those with leases to come out ahead of the game.

title: The Great Unknowns
description: Well, that was fast. The N.B.A. draft decelerated from 60 to zero in what seemed like a few seconds. One minute it was all sweetness and light, hope and change, kids with shiny new jerseys. The next it was devoid of top-level talent, hindered by teams afraid of the future, the last step before labor Armageddon. And while all that might be true, it was also true before the draft started, so it was fascinating to watch the perception pivot on a dime without anything actually changing.

title: Schools Out, Forever
description: JUST dont cry. That has been Sister Nora McArts mantra. She has been unflappable in her 42 years at St. Martin of Tours Elementary School in the Bronx, braving the gang fights, racial unrest and crack wars that were waged outside the school and convent in the Crotona neighborhood. No matter the mayhem, she had to be calm for the children.

title: Obama Seeks to Restart Budget Talks
description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet separately on Monday with the Democratic and Republican Senate leaders in an opening bid to restart budget talks on addressing long-term debt reduction and clear the way for a necessary vote on raising the nations debt limit.

title: Dwyane Wade in the Front Row
description: Dwyane Wade, the Miami Heat guard, was in the front row on Friday at Yves Saint Laurent, as friendly as he could be. He chatted with Bruce Pask, the mens fashion editor of The Times Magazine, about what he likes to wear, and about his visit to the Milan and Paris shows. I loved the splashy effect of his scarves against his light blue suit.

title: The Last Days of St. Martin of Tours
description: St. Martin of Tours, a Catholic school in the Bronx, closed this week after serving the community for 86 years.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Spymaster
description: Collectively, Tom Clancys novels have spent more than seven years on the hardcover fiction best-seller list, and all but one  The Hunt for Red October  reached No. 1.

title: LulzSec Hackers Make Enemies Online
description: Lulz Security, the hacking group that has been on a spree lately, might think its antics are hilarious. But some others in the hacker world are sick of its games.

title: The Wheels Wedding Album
description: Wheels recently used the occasion of a Ford scions wedding, from which groom and bride fled to the reception in a 1965 Mustang convertible, to invite Wheels readers to submit photos of their wedding-day getaway vehicles.

title: Preferring Boys to Girls
description: China isnt the only country where parents have a distinct preference for baby boys rather than baby girls. Americans prefers XY to XX in their offspring, too  and have wanted boys rather than girls for the last 70 years.

title: Winklevosses Pursue New Legal Avenue Against Facebook
description: A day after Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss said they would drop plans to appeal a case against against Facebook to the United States Supreme Court, the twins, along with their partner Divya Narendra, told a federal court in Massachusetts that they would pursue separate claims that Facebook suppressed evidence when the parties were in settlement talks in 2008.

title: Harrison Returns With His Temper, Not His Game
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The greatest opportunity of Ryan Harrisons professional tennis career was slipping through his fingers, as evidenced by the racket skidding onto the court.

title: Videophiles | Xeno & Oaklanders The Staircase
description: Just when you thought winter was finally over, a cold front suddenly hits. The new video for The Staircase, by the synth pop group Xeno & Oaklander, which makes is United States premiere on The Moment today, epitomizes the cool aesthetic of the underground minimal electronics movement. The video has the quality of a Xerox, reproduced over and over, blown out and dark, and induces a sense of something lost. Sean McBride and Miss Liz Wendelbo, the duo behind Xeno & Oaklander, along with other members of the Wierd Records label, have been largely credited with the revival of minimal wave here in New York. Taryn Waldman of Boxmotion, who directed the The Staircase, and Patrick Stroub, its cinematographer, make references to Roman Polanskis film Repulsion, as a slip of a woman, Xeno (Wendelbo), climbs the stairs of a claustrophobic 19th-century Brooklyn tenement building, seemingly unaware that the object of her affection and of her voyeurism, Oaklander (McBride), is right next to her. (Xenos stark, wintry eyes come courtesy of the master retoucher Pascal Dangin, known in fashion circles for his work for Annie Leibovitz, Patrick Demarchelier, Steven Meisel, Steven Klein, Craig McDean and others.) Alienation, disconnection, damage? Oh, city life!

title: Living In | Audubon Park
description: Residents of Audubon Park in Washington Heights hope that Columbia Universitys northward expansion will increase demand.

title: Big C or Small Business, TV Promotions Get Creative
description: The proliferation of new series on television is particularly noticeable in the summer, when cable channels pour on the premieres. That means a flood of advertising and marketing campaigns to promote all those shows.

title: Naturalist Perched Here
description: ONE can imagine how John James Audubon, the renowned naturalist and illustrator of Birds of America, might have reacted to the idea: his own name, being used to promote the very development that would transform the rambling woodlands of his beloved Washington Heights estate into a densely populated urban district. But that is precisely what happened, according to Matthew Spady, a longtime resident and magpie collector of historical facts about the area.

title: Time for a Change
description: We were sitting at a communal table at the Sonoma Farmers Market when the couple next to us laid their baby on the table and changed his diaper. They also gave a loud play-by-play for delighted family members in the vicinity. A week before, a father across the aisle from me on an international flight changed his babys diaper on the food tray. I lost my temper on the plane, but said nothing at the farmers market. What should I have said?   Ricky S., San Francisco

title: Energy Rivals Court Southern Union
description: June 24, 2011 - A takeover battle for control of the Southern Union Company could create world's largest natural gas pipeline. DealBook analyzes the pros and cons of the competing bids.

title: Evolution of the Boxes: Five Generations of Chrysler Minivans
description: BOX-SHAPED vehicles have been rolling around the fringes of the automotive world for at least a century. Credit for creating the modern minivan, and making it a fixture of family transportation, goes to Chrysler, though fans of the Volkswagen Microbus and Corvair Greenbrier may argue the point.

title: Photo Replay: June 24
description: The day in sports included table tennis in Shanghai and a prediction by an elephant that Germany would win Sundays opener of the Womens World Cup. (An octopus, however, picked Canada.)

title: Lost Cities, Found Anew
description: A 10-day expedition sets out to trace the path of the explorer Hiram Bingham to the Incas most sacred city.

title: As Wedding Roles Evolve, Here Come the Flower Men
description: CLAIRE HACKNEY and Bobby Smith made two playful touches to their wedding in 2008 in Boylston, Mass. First, as gifts for the wedding party they gave puppets made to resemble each attendant.

title: Bulgers Arrest Stirs Memories for One Victims Family
description: BOSTON  To Patricia Donahue, James (Whitey) Bulger was more than a crime boss on the lam: he was the man who destroyed her family.

title: Big Deal | Sloane Mansion Sold to Fertilizer Tycoon
description: The lone bidder for the troubled Henry T. Sloane mansion won the property for about $40 million at a foreclosure auction on Wednesday.

title: Google Confirms F.T.C. Antitrust Inquiry
description: Google confirmed on Friday that the Federal Trade Commission had opened an antitrust investigation into its core search and advertising business.

title: Inside the Southern Union Takeover Battle
description: The takeover battle for control of the Southern Union Company could create worlds largest natural gas pipeline. DealBooks Adrienne Carter and Michael J. de la Merced analyze the pros and cons of the competing bids.

title: A Conservatives Case for a Gas Tax
description: Awhile back, I had a brief e-chat with the conservative columnist Charles Krauthammer, a self-described global warming agnostic, about his longstanding push for a gas tax (with payroll taxes cut to compensate).

title: The Caucus Click: Seersucker Thursday
Green Jobs Attract Graduates
description: WHEN the anchorman Howard Beale uttered his famous vituperations in the 1976 film Network (Im as mad as hell, and Im not going to take this anymore!), he was a grizzled, alcoholic veteran of the television rat race, at the climax of a long, slow boil.

title: Rock-Climbing Stars to Clamber in Central Park

description: BRUSSELS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France said on Friday that criticism by the departing United States defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, about European support for operations in Libya had been motivated by personal reasons and was grossly unfair.

title: Grasping Climate Change at a Garden-Plot Level
description: One of the first places where Americans may notice the impact of climate change is in their own gardens and backyards, their most common point of intersection with the natural world.

title: Following the Rich
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan considers the various surveys and analyses done of and for the rich. He says all the time and money put to looking at the wealthy, particularly when most people are feeling anything but wealthy, raises questions about the value of the information. Could anything from the various reports help others?

title: New Haydn Recordings by Philharmonia Baroque
description: HAYDN: SYMPHONIES NOS. 88, 101, 104

title: The Last Days of St. Martin of Tours
description: Forty years ago this month, David Gonzalez walked down the aisle of the Church of St. Martin of Tours in the Crotona neighborhood of the Bronx, clutching his eighth-grade diploma from the parish school. For the past few weeks, Mr. Gonzalez, now a reporter for The New York Times, has been back at St. Martins, this time to perform one of the Roman Catholic Churchs works of mercy: Burying the dead.

title: Syrian City Crushed in 1982 Rises Up Again
description: As protesters rallied again across Syria on Friday, activists reported a large protest in the center of Hama, Syrias fourth-largest city, where a rebellion was brutally crushed in 1982, during the reign of Hafez al-Assad, the current presidents father.

title: Talent for Punctuating Classics With Surprises
description: It is heartening to see a young, energetic group like the Knights become, in effect, the resident orchestra for the free summer concerts at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park.

title: 13 Hours of Sounds and Psychedelia
description: Listeners at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center had to jump out of the way as the Asphalt Orchestra, a brainchild of Bang on a Can, snaked its way through the large crowd at the annual Bang on a Can Marathon on Sunday. The orchestra, an ebullient, avant-garde marching band that blends performance art with inventive new works and funky arrangements, offered a version of Frank Zappas Zomby Woof by Peter Hess (the groups tenor saxophonist); an arrangement of Bjorks Hyper-Ballad by Alan Ferber; and Goran Bregovics exuberant Champagne.

title: Cold-Blooded Dinosaurs As Warm as Humans
description: By studying the chemical composition of dinosaur teeth, scientists have determined that some sauropods had body temperatures as warm as those of mammals.

title: Southern Union Says Williams Bid $30 a Share in January
description: Southern Union has not tipped its hand yet on whether it will abandon its $4.2 billion sale to Energy Transfer Equity in favor of a $4.9 billion cash proposal from the Williams Companies.

title: Trends: Super Whites
description: Bright white evokes field sports and science labs. The look, in monochrome, turns up in the collections of Comme des Garons, Yves Saint Laurent and Givenchy.

title: Citizen Kushner
description: ON a recent Monday evening, Jared Kushner, the 30-year-old publisher of The New York Observer, was holding court in the grand ballroom at the Harmonie Club on East 60th Street. The occasion marked the newspapers annual 100 Most Powerful People in New York Real Estate issue, and many in attendance were city fixtures, people whose names appear on donor plaques and ballots, not on movie marquees: the developer Richard LeFrak, New York Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman, the public relations wizard Howard Rubenstein.

title: Virgins, Pimps and Other Facts of life
description: The dancers in The White Room, Jennifer Mullers new evening-length work, arent identified with character names or descriptions, but its not too difficult to sort out their agendas. This story of innocence and corruption shifts among characters including a virginal woman in white (Hsing-Hua Wang), a cartoonish kingpin (Pascal Rekoert), an ominous pimp (Gen Hashimoto) and an imposing woman who takes Daphne du Mauriers Mrs. Danvers out of Manderley (Susanna Bozzetti).

title: A Hard Rain Begins to Fall on Lives in Gulfport, Miss.
description: With The Play About My Dad, Boo Killebrew attempts a daunting juggling act: telling multiple accounts of Hurricane Katrinas assault on her hometown, Gulfport, Miss., and recounting the dissolution of her parents marriage and her rapprochement with her father, a doctor called to action when the storm hits. She largely pulls it off, though detours intermittently threaten the balance.

title: Everybody Outside With the Deep Fryer
description: RECENTLY, I acquired an electric deep fryer. It worked a little better than a pot of oil on the stove, but it didnt make deep-frying any less of a messy, smelly affair.

title: N.Y. Gay Marriage Bill Gains Key Votes
description: ALBANY  Thirty-three state senators have publicly declared they will support legalizing same-sex marriage, all but assuring passage of the measure which will make New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples can wed.

title: Growing Up With Two Icons
description: I ORDERED a Greek salad, followed by cheesecake. She went for split-pea soup and a bagel, with a fountain Diet Coke. Jenny Lumet, told she could pick a place for lunch, chose the Metro Diner, on Broadway at 100th Street, near her home. Im kind of a diner girl, she said.

title: Weekend Fare for June 24 to 26
description: Lincoln Ristorante hosts a negroni workshop Saturday from 3 to 4:30 p.m. The restaurants wine director, Aaron von Rock, will talk about the drinks history and guests can enjoy happy hour with hors doeuvres from chef Jonathan Bennos summer menu. The class is $50 per person. Reservations can be made online through the restaurants Web site. Lincoln, 142 West 65th Street (Broadway); (212) 359-6500.

title: Whats Left in Joplin
description: A little over a month ago, the photographer Andrew Moore was just beginning his next project in Omaha, Neb. But when a tornado hit Joplin, Mo., he called Kathy Ryan, our photo director, and suggested that he make the five-to-six-hour drive to the area to take some pictures of the aftermath for the magazine. One of them was published as last weeks Look feature.

title: Reviewing the 2011 Chrysler Town & Country
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the 2011 Chrysler Town & Country, which Chrysler historically has positioned as the choice of the luxury-minded minivan buyer. As Ms. Jensen notes, however, the automakers upmarket aspirations have not always translated to the final product.

title: Photos of the Moment | Kris Van Assche
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#915", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: TimesCast | Congress Votes on Libya
description: The House rejects a measure to authorize American operations in Libya but it refuses to cut financing.

title: A Troubling Mutual Fund Case; Juggling Multiple Jobs; Putting More People to Work; the Oil Market and Bailing Out Greece
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with Gretchen Morgenson on a troubling mutual fund case, Phyllis Korkki and Hannah Seligson on juggling multiple jobs, and Robert Frank on how to put more people to work. Also, Mr. Sommer discusses the oil market and bailing out Greece.

title: On the Street | Wedding Season
description: The reign of the Cinderella wedding dress continues, although the simplicity of the recent London royal wedding may soon have an effect.

title: Mothers Cultivate Their Gardens in Burkina Faso
description: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 Win A Trip winners and are currently traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. Noreens fourth post is from Burkina Faso.

title: Grilled Shellfish With 'Barbecue' Sauce
description: Mark Bittman cooks fresh clams on the grill, and a sauce to go with them.

title: The Minimalist: Grilled Shellfish With Barbecue Sauce
description: Clams, mussels and oysters offer the lazy summer cook an advantage: theyre enclosed in perfectly sealed pots, Mother Natures very own pressure cooker. With a bit of heat from the grill, shellfish literally steam themselves and then pop open, ready for consumption, with virtually no effort required on the part of the griller.

title: Executive Unbound?
description: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of The Atlantic and Reihan Salam of National Review debate the limits of presidential power.

title: Scenes from Undead Jazz Festival
description: Images from the music series.

title: TimesCast | Gay Pride Weekend
description: June 24, 2011 - With a vote looming, organizers prepare for this weekend's Gay Pride parade.

title: Everything Is Obvious, Once You Know the Answer
description: Chapter 1: The Myth of Common Sense

title: Photos of the Moment | Walter Van Beirendonck
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#85", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Born This Way: On a Farm
description: O.K., Im a sucker for overalls; have been ever since that great American classic of town-and-country life, Green Acres. Junya Watanabes free-spirited collection, presented in a garden, featured loose-fitting overalls with Wellies, scrap-patch shirts, plaid shorts and waxed cotton utility jackets. I dont know if he was appealing to the music festival crowd or the farm-to-table movement or just some dudes in Brooklyn, but his timing couldnt be better.

title: Conservative Group Rolls Out Major Ad Campaign
description: Crossroads GPS, the conservative independent group founded by Karl Rove, will spend $20 million on a national television advertising campaign aimed at framing the national debate on jobs, the economy and the national debt, a spokesman said.

title: In Brooklyn, the Rats Move Out Before the Nets Move In
description: Residents living in the shadow of the Atlantic Yards arena project in Brooklyn shared horror stories on Thursday evening about cohabiting with rodents, and in the telling the rats seemed to grow to Godzilla-like proportions.

title: Lauren & Michael
description: In this homemade video, Michael Camarinos recalls being impressed that Lauren Mavroudis could tee off.

title: F.D.A. Urges Less Use of Anemia Drugs
description: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators said on Friday that three drugs that had been widely used to treat anemia in both kidney and cancer patients were so dangerous to the heart that doctors should consider avoiding the medicines altogether in some patients and using less of them in others.

title: Wrapped in Paper, Gifts From the Earth
description: IS there anything better than a steaming new potato? I doubt it. Not to be confused with small potatoes or little boiling potatoes (which, dont get me wrong, are wonderful), real new potatoes are freshly dug, perishable and heavenly. Theyre showing up now at farmers markets, probably the best place to find them unless you have a gardener friend willing to share.

title: A Stronger Net Security System Is Deployed
description: A small group of Internet security specialists gathered in Singapore this week to start up a global system to make e-mail and e-commerce more secure, end the proliferation of passwords and raise the bar significantly for Internet scam artists, spies and troublemakers.

title: Chic in Review | Versace to the People
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Liane & Xin
description: In this homemade video, Dr. Liane Young and Xin Gao recall meeting at a mixer at a Boston nightclub.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 24
description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Summers Here. Have a Potato.
description: In this weeks City Kitchen, an ode to a seasonal delight, freshly dug new potatoes, coming soon to a farmers market near you. Nothing better. Of course you can boil them, but baking them in parchment with garlic and herbs shows off their ethereal sweetness. Count on at least half a pound per person  there wont be leftovers. By the way, theyre bound to go with whatever youre having for the Fourth.

title: Plans for Festivities Move Ahead as Gay Marriage Vote Looms
description: This weekends gay pride festivities in New York City are unfolding as the State Legislature lurches toward a vote on same-sex marriage. Organizers are preparing for anything from violence to public outbreaks of euphoria, depending on the outcome.

title: Meghan & Pip
description: In this homemade video, Pip Decker and Meghan Kober hail a cab and recall how they met at a mutual friend's wedding in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Creating an Adolescence for the Ages
description: WHEN it comes to the teen movie, as with many well-defined genres, familiarity is often part of the point. But a pair of new American indies  Terri (opening Friday) and The Myth of the American Sleepover (opening July 22)  show that the conventions of the high-school film provide a useful shorthand even as they present room for nuance and complication. Terri, a character study and unlikely buddy movie named for its outsize protagonist, tackles the evergreen subject of adolescent alienation. Drifting from one slumber party to another, Myth borrows the night-in-the-life structure associated with two classics of the genre, American Graffiti and Dazed and Confused.

title: Interview: Azazel Jacobs
description: The director Azazel Jacobs discusses his offbeat coming-of-age film "Terri."

title: Expedition Leads ABC to Second Place
description: Expedition Impossible, a new reality show on ABC from Mark Burnett involving teams of contestants traveling through Morocco and competing for money, got off to a solid if somewhat subdued start on Thursday, attracting seven million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The premieres audience was down slightly from ABCs show at 8, Wipeout (7.4 million), but higher than the networks Rookie Blue at 10 (5.9 million). For the night, ABC finished runner-up to CBS and its lineup of repeats, including CSI (7.7 million) and The Mentalist (8 million). Fox was third with an elimination episode of So You Think You Can Dance at 8 (6.3 million) and a rerun of Glee at 9 (3.2 million). NBC and repeats of its comedy block lagged behind in fourth. In the 10 p.m. hour, NBCs Love Bites attracted just under two million viewers.

title: A Rappers Still Stirring Things Up by Being Laid-Back
description: Very early on Thursday morning at the Blue Note, Rakim told a story about going to the house of the producer Marley Marl in the mid-1980s to record a song. Once there, he took the microphone and promptly sat on the couch. Marley Marl, he remembered, became agitated and suggested that he stand up to give the track more energy. Rakim demurred. That low-energy hum? Thats how I wanna sound.

title: This Sunday: More Memories, Please, Derek Jeter
description: Just as no music will ever sound as meaningful to you as your favorite bands did when you were a teenager, no athletes measure up to the idols of your childhood. For Derek Jeter, however, I claim an exception.

title: People, You Will See This Film. Right Now.
description: BEIJING  This month Chinas great masses are being mobilized by their leaders for an unusual purpose. Employees at state-owned companies and at all levels of government are joining students from grade school to universities as they leave their homes, head out into the heat and do their duty: ensure the financial success of the governments latest propaganda film, Beginning of the Great Revival.

title: In Hours, Online Readers Identify Nazi Photographer
description: It appeared to be something of a mystery: a little photo album that had fallen into the hands of a New York garment industry executive with debts to pay off. In one snapshot was a bus with German lettering on the side. In another, a kitten on a soldiers lap.

title: An Artist Who Disappears, Appearing at Ground Zero
Jazz Bands, Very Loud, Find Smaller Crowd
description: The Undead Jazzfest, in its second year, started on Thursday at half-capacity and double volume.

title: They Stumble That Run Fast, These Star-Crossed Shakespearean Lovers
description: BECKET, Mass.  In the 1980s and early 1990s, Jolle Bouvier, with her partner at the time, Rgis Obadia, was part of a vanguard of young choreographers who gave contemporary dance new prominence and glamour in France. Known for their onstage charisma, their eye for visual effect and an intense, often violent physicality, they were part of a certain movement style and aesthetic unmistakable to anyone who spent time watching French contemporary dance in the 1990s.

title: Podcast: Creating Jobs, and Juggling Them
description: The budget deficit has been grabbing many of the headlines and much of the attention in Washington. But its a distraction. Theres a more immediate economic problem.

title: Building Japans Nuclear Safety Myth
description: As the Japanese continue to search for answers to the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, some are digging deep into the national psyche and examining a national propensity to embrace a belief now widely seen as irrational.

title: At the Open Championships, a Slow Start and a Big Finish
description: At the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, the Mixed Teams event was won on Wednesday by the French team of Pierre Zimmermann, Bndicte Cronier, Philippe Cronier (the Croniers are married), Catherine dOvidio, Franck Multon and Sylvie Willard (although Zimmermann lives in Switzerland). They beat the Dutch team of Bep Vriend, Anton Maas, Carla Arnolds, Ton Bakkeren, Martine Verbeek and Huub Bertens, who had defeated the American team of Jim Mahaffey, Judi Radin, Sam Lev, Irina Levitina, Jacek Pszczola and Janice Seamon-Molson in the semifinals.

title: Shakespeare Troupe Starts Building Brooklyn Theater
description: Leaders of the Theater for a New Audience, one of New Yorks premier Shakespearean troupes, reached a milestone on Friday in their decades-long dream for a home as they held a groundbreaking ceremony for a $47.5 million theater. The project represents an unusually large financial commitment by the city to move an arts organization  in this case, a critically acclaimed theater company from Manhattan  into Brooklyn.

title: The Politics of the States DNA Database (Whos In It, Who Can See It)
description: A bill that would let the state take DNA samples from anyone convicted of any crime  including misdemeanors  has stalled in Albany, where the State Senate and the Assembly have butted heads over what the bill should include.

title: Jets Training Camp Moving
description: Citing the uncertainty of the N.F.L. lockout, the Jets said they would hold their training camp this year in Florham Park, N.J., and not at SUNY Cortland, where it has been held the past two years.

title: Google to End Health Records Service After It Fails to Attract Users
description: Google is giving up on its vision of helping people live healthier lives with online personal health records.

title: Azerbaijan and Armenia Fail to End Enclave Dispute
description: MOSCOW  Hopes for a breakthrough on a conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia were deflated Friday when Russia, which convened talks in the city of Kazan, released a statement saying that the leaders of the two countries had not agreed to the framework for a deal.

title: Florida Suit Says Arrests Are Retaliation for Atheism
description: MIAMI  An atheist in Central Florida filed suit in Federal District Court in Tampa on Friday, accusing the Polk County sheriff, an evangelical Christian, of harassing and unnecessarily arresting her as retaliation for not believing in God and for her efforts to keep prayer out of public meetings.

title: Play Soccer, Cook Brunch, Call Mom
description: In theory, Sunday is a day away from the grind for the chef-author-entrepreneur Marcus Samuelsson. But instead of indolence, soccer and food rule the agenda. A judge on the Food Networks 24 Hour Restaurant Battle, Mr. Samuelsson, 40, is the executive chef and co-owner of Red Rooster Harlem; his restaurant empire also includes the Blue Parrot in East Hampton and Aquavit. His latest venture is Food Republic, a lifestyle Web site-guide to manning up in the kitchen. He lives in Harlem with his wife, Maya Haile, a model. ROBIN FINN

title: Somalia: Foreign Helicopter Attack Kills 15 Rebels
description: At least 15 insurgents were killed in a foreign helicopter attack on a Shabab rebel military base near Kismayo, Somalia, witnesses and officials said Friday. The attack, which occurred on Thursday, killed at least 15 Shabab commanders, including eight foreigners, a local human rights organization said. It was not clear who carried out the attack. American Special Operations forces have attacked Somali militants by helicopter at least once before.

title: Sounds in the City
description: The City Critic visited several Make Music New York events on Tuesday, June 21.

title: Charity Goes Mobile to Appeal to Young
description: Nancy Lublin was sitting in her office in Manhattan one evening last December when she noticed her staff outside giving one another high fives, pumping their fists and generally engaged in raucous celebration.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Press Romney on Abortion Rights
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Seeking to distinguish themselves from Mitt Romney, the presumed Republican front-runner in the 2012 presidential race, challengers exploited a bit of daylight that opened between him and other candidates this week over abortion.

title: Could You Pipe Down? My Ears Thank You
description: My two friends and I dont expect a Nobel Prize. We dont expect to have a bridge or a building named after us. None of the great scientists think in those terms while pursuing their breakthroughs; they think only of the good their research might do for humanity.

title: Hacked Memos of State Police in Arizona Are Released
description: PHOENIX  A cache of internal documents released online on Thursday by hackers who gained access to the computer system of the Arizona Department of Public Safety revealed the array of potential outlaws on the state polices radar screen, from international terrorists to Mexican drug smugglers to motorcycle gang members.

title: Playing Nice Before the Match
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Imagine Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia loosening up for a start against the Red Sox by throwing to Boston catcher Jason Varitek. That is a battery that would assault the senses of either teams fans. It is different in tennis, where rivals warming each other up is a time-honored ritual, so ingrained in the game the players do not give it a second thought.

title: How Budget Cuts Affect the Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Cutlass Lessons and Tattoos for Aspiring Pirates
description: Sundry maritime marauders will be roaming the grounds of Philipsburg Manor over the July 4 weekend, transforming what was a farming, milling and trading center in 1750 into a swashbucklers festival.

title: A Musical Exploration, Monticello to Mali
description: FOUR years ago, the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, flush with a big new grant, began Sonidos Latinos, a comprehensive survey of Latin-American music. By the time the grant expired two years later, the projects evocative portraits of musical cultures had earned it an enviable reputation  one the festival stands to build on when, in four concerts over the next month, it explores four more cultures.

title: Deal Will Avert Plan to Lay Off City Teachers
description: The threatened layoffs of 4,100 teachers in New Yorks public schools were averted under a deal that the Bloomberg administration, the City Council and the teachers union reached on Friday night.
