description: To the Editor:

title: As Lockout Approaches, N.B.A. Players Wear Unity on Their Shirts
description: Two dozen men, all taller than average, dressed in matching gray T-shirts, filed out of a Midtown Manhattan hotel and into a waiting bus on Friday afternoon, their message conveyed in their uniformity.

title: Zimbabwe: Government Minister Arrested
description: One of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirais closet advisers, Jameson Timba, a minister of state, was arrested in Harare on Thursday. Mr. Tsvangirais spokesman, Luke Tamborinyoka, said the police had not specified the charge or admitted they had him in custody. Mr. Timbas driver saw him being arrested, Mr. Tamborinyoka said. More than a quarter of President Robert Mugabes opponents in Parliament have been arrested since their party, the Movement for Democratic Change, agreed to enter a troubled power-sharing government with his party, ZANU-PF.

title: How to Leave a War
description: President Obamas speech on Wednesday announcing the gradual withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan was certainly a news story of significance, and it quickly drew more commentary than even the most voracious national security policy hound could possibly absorb. But thats why were here. (The full text of the speech is here.)

title: My Reliable Dad
description: To the Editor:

title: When Victims Have Pasts of Their Own
description: A prosecutor later called the attack a siege of terror, but even that falls short.

title: Shakespeares Fools for Love, Fighting a Merry War
description: I couldnt help it. During the wedding scene in Shakespeare on the Sounds lively, likable production of Much Ado About Nothing, I found myself thinking about Pippa Middleton and Prince Harry.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Discussing Race in City Is Fraught After 10 Killings
description: A serial killer in Rocky Mount, N. C., a city about 50 miles northeast of Charlotte, is believed to have killed 10 people  all of them African-American drug users who worked as prostitutes. The murders have laid bare the areas fraught history of racism and mistrust. Some of the women had been missing for years. Even with an arrest in the case last year, the relationship between African-Americans and law enforcement here remains unsettled.

title: New Law in Kansas Seen as a Threat to Abortions
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan.  One in a series of abortion limits approved in Kansas since Republicans took full control of the state government this year  a new license law  is raising uncertainty about the future of all abortion providers in the state.

title: A Town Celebration, Fireworks and All
description: TIMOTHY J. HOGAN, chairman of this years KaBoomFest in Red Bank, remembers the first one he attended 10 years ago. He and his family had just moved there, he said, and we werent aware of the popularity of the fireworks that cap the annual townwide celebration, to take place July 1 to 3 this year.

title: Jazz Historians 15-Year Dream: Book on Louis Armstrong
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Julie Taymors Reputation
description: To the Editor:

title: All of His Crops Flourished. Too Bad They Were in a Park.
description: If they squint, neighbors say, the farm tilled by David Abreu begins to look a little like home  his cilantro is as green, his bean supply as tidy. And then there is the man himself: clutching his machete handle, pant legs stained black, surveying the soil like any farmer who takes pride in his land. He could be my father, said one neighbor, Jos Rodrguez, 52, originally from Santiago, Dominican Republic.

title: Cuomo Likely to Veto Bill on School Borrowing
description: ALBANY  State lawmakers on Friday approved a bill that would allow school districts to borrow as much as $1 billion without voter approval, but a spokesman for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the measure would most likely be vetoed.

title: A Question for the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: A Scoop of Urban Flavor
description: Local, a new ice cream shop and cafe in Chappaqua, is a slice of hipster Williamsburg that somehow delights in its suburban setting, mixing nourishment (kale salad with pistachios and miso-lemon dressing) with old-fashioned fun (chocolate fudge sundaes and banana splits served in traditional glass tulips and gondolas). The food comes from local producers and growers, there are no preservatives or artificial ingredients, and take-out containers are compostable.

title: Safety Myth Left Japan Ripe for Nuclear Crisis
description: SHIKA, Japan  Near a nuclear power plant facing the Sea of Japan, a series of exhibitions in a large public relations building here extols the virtues of the energy source with some help from Alice in Wonderland.

title: U.S. Faces Questions and a Familiar Foe
description: The United States will face Mexico in the Gold Cup final on Saturday night, which should surprise no one: those teams routinely dominate the event. But that does not mean that the tournament has not been full of surprises:

title: After Chinese Dance, Some Thoughts on Dating
description: That the New York of Sex and the City ended with the advent of high-speed Internet cable was not something we expected to learn at a performance by Shen Yun, the colorful gymnastic Chinese classical dance company, at Lincoln Center on Thursday night. But Candace Bushnell gave us an earful about the demise of Carrie Bradshaws New York.

title: Battle For Libya | June 24, 2011
description: Dozens of detained rebels returned Friday on a Red Cross ship to their eastern stronghold of Benghazi, detailing how they were tortured at the hands of Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi forces.

title: The U.N. and a Two-State Mideast Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Madoff Trustee Seeking Billions More From JPMorgan
description: Irving H. Picard, the trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoffs firm, said on Friday that he had filed a revised lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase & Company, demanding a minimum of $19 billion in damages.

title: Theres No Quitting in Managing
description: Like a lot of major league players, Prince Fielder of the Milwaukee Brewers is not signed for next season. This is by choice, really, because Fielder and the Brewers have not agreed on a contract extension. But, still, he is unsigned. So whats his approach?

title: Nationals Name Manager but Stress Interim Label
description: CHICAGO  Mike Rizzo grew up in suburban Park Ridge, Ill., and said he was looking forward to visiting family, friends and some old haunts during a weekend visit here.

title: Nevada: Truck Collides With Train
description: Two people were killed and at least 20 were injured on Friday morning when a tractor-trailer collided with a California-bound Amtrak train in a remote part of western Nevada. The crash occurred at a crossing about 75 miles east of Reno when the driver of the truck apparently drove into the side of the California Zephyr, which was traveling from Chicago to the Bay Area with more than 200 passengers and 14 crew members aboard, Amtrak officials said.

title: Inexpensive Thai Fare, With a Sunset View
description: WHEN it opened last March, Thai Elephant 2 promised some culinary relief from the many burger variations lining Route 22 in Patterson. And if you order right, it can be a pleasant oasis. The style of Thai food here isnt high end, with elaborately carved fruits and vegetables (though rice is charmingly presented in the shape of a star). It is workaday Thai, with some delicious dishes and some that need help, from a kitchen that at the moment lacks consistency. But it does offer a lovely view, food that can be satisfying and healthful and, not least, bargain prices, particularly at lunch.

title: Sympathy for the Devils
description: Miami

title: Canada: Drunken Passengers May Have Caused Plane Crash
description: The Transportation Safety Board of Canada said in a report that three drunken and argumentative passengers may have caused the crash of a chartered float plane that killed them as well as the pilot. The passengers boarded the brief flight between two islands off the coast of British Columbia in May 2010 after being refused water taxi service because they were carrying a case of beer and several bottles of liquor. In a report issued this week, the board said that it found evidence that one of the passengers, who had been quarreling among themselves, shoved the pilots seat from behind, forcing him against the aircrafts controls and causing a fatal dive into the water.

title: Berries, Ripe for the Picking
description: Even as Patricia DiVello, 52, watched several children gathering strawberries on a recent afternoon at Pattys Berries and Bunches, her pick-your-own farm in Mattituck, she was already looking forward to the next crop.

title: Move by Rangers Surprises Even the Player They Choose With the 15th Pick
description: ST. PAUL  The early hours of the first round of the N.H.L. entry draft proceeded without any major surprises  at least until the Rangers picked at No. 15. The stunned look on the face of center J. T. Miller, a member of the United States under-18 team, showed just how unexpected this was.

title: South Africa: Governing Party Seeks to Tone Down Secrecy Bill
description: The governing African National Congress, which has been pushing a bill that would have enshrouded much routine government activity in secrecy and punished whistleblowers and journalists with up to 25 years in prison, said Friday that it now favored drastically reducing the scope of the bill to apply only the countrys security services. It also said the harsh minimum prisons sentences should be removed from the legislation. In a statement, the party said the bill must ensure that the law would not be abused to hide corruption, the very outcome the bills critics had feared.

title: Parallel Lives from the Eastern Shore
description: Harriet Ross Tubman and Frederick Douglass, two of the best-known African Americans of the Civil War era, were both born into slavery on Marylands Eastern Shore, at roughly the same time. Perhaps because of its border-state decision to stay with the Union, Maryland and its slave-owning past are often forgotten today. And yet as the lives and scars of these two attested, slavery in rural Maryland could be as oppressive and isolated as the cotton fields of the Deep South. Swaths of white family-owned farmland were worked by thousands of enslaved people, who also worked on the water to bring back the rich catch of the Chesapeake Bay. And in no part of the state was slavery as brutal as the Eastern Shore  conditions exposed by the oddly parallel lives of these two famous Marylanders.

title: Them Thats Not Shall Lose
description: Anyone who has ever struggled with poverty knows how extremely expensive it is to be poor.

title: Venezuela: Chvez Breaks Silence; Says Little
description: President Hugo Chvez, recovering in Cuba after emergency surgery there this month, broke an unusual stretch of silence with four brief Twitter messages on Friday. The messages, laden with references to military glory, Venezuelas national anthem, the weather and an 1821 battle against Spain, were the first public communications from Mr. Chvez since June 12, when he spoke by telephone to a journalist two days after his surgery in Havana for a pelvic abscess. Mr. Chvez made no reference to his health or location, which have stirred fierce debate in Venezuela over the scant disclosure of such information. Still, he singled out Gen. Euclides Campos Aponte, commander of Venezuelas army, for praise. Good morning followers! he wrote in one message. Today is the day of my Army and the sun is shining! A gigantic hug to my soldiers and my beloved people!

title: Boehner Must Navigate Rocky Road to a Budget
description: WASHINGTON  The morning after Republicans claimed the House on Nov. 2, John A. Boehner, the soon-to-be speaker, was asked how he was ever going to get a multitrillion-dollar increase in the federal debt ceiling through his new Tea Party-infused majority.

title: Lottery Numbers
Local Wine, but Owners From Chile
description: When the Chilean owners of Laurel Lake Vineyards, in Laurel, bought the winery for $2 million in 1999, it was producing 5,100 cases of wine. By leasing additional acreage and planting more vines in stages, they raised the output at the 13-acre winery to 9,000 cases last year.

title: Indiana Law to Cut Planned Parenthood Funding Is Blocked
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Friday that the State of Indiana could not cut off money for Planned Parenthood clinics providing health care to low-income women on Medicaid.

title: Rustic Greek Cooking in a Casual Setting
description: MP TAVERNA opened in Roslyn in mid-May and immediately went to the head of the class. It is now on my list of favorite Long Island restaurants, and it is the least expensive of the group.

title: Giambi Returns to Stadium With a Smile and a New Role
description: Jason Giambi was a popular person as he walked through Yankee Stadium on Friday afternoon. He greeted a clubhouse attendant with a smile, clapped several reporters on the back and even hugged the police officer stationed outside the Colorado Rockies dugout during batting practice.

title: The Dairy Built on Stiletto Heels
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn.

title: Bread, Cheese, Four Walls
description: After almost 20 years of selling mozzarella and bread under canvas tents at farmers markets, Hoboken Farms finally has a real roof over its head. In May, Brad Finkel, who owns the business, added his first brick-and-mortar location  a tiny takeout sandwich shop  on the western edge of Summit.

title: Tastes of the Sea in a Shore-Like Setting
description: LIKE much of Asbury Park these days, the downtown feels like a work in progress, particularly around Cookman Avenue, where construction sites and window signs heralding the arrival of new businesses signal a fresh, if fragile, future for the neighborhood. And everywhere you look, hipper, more well-heeled aspirations rub up against a grittier, blue-collar past. It all gives the city its essential character, of course, that sense of being perpetually on the verge.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: The Return of Tim Riggins
description: We are covering the final season of Friday Night Lights according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

title: Saturday: Gnarly Waves, Dude!
description: Administrivial Solving Tips Alert: The question of how to solve a puzzle that has rebus elements in it when you are solving on computer  whether you are on Mac or PC, solving in Across Lite or the applet  has come up, and Id like to direct your attention to a new category on the right-hand side of the page in the Blogroll called Solving Tips. In it we will be putting helpful tips for (wait for it) solving. Our own Martin Herbach was kind enough to research and write up a new page about how to enter multiple letters for rebus entries, and there is an interesting article from puzzlemaster Will Shortz. Stay tuned for more additions, and if there is anything else you would like to see there, please contact me at deb.amlen@nytimes.com.

title: Two Are Accused of Stealing $16 Million Over Eight Years
description: A woman and her son were charged Friday with stealing more than $16 million from two textile companies in SoHo and using the money to support lavish lifestyles and the sons failed ambulance company.

title: Pick Raises Questions Knicks Say He Answered
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks selection of Georgia Tech guard Iman Shumpert with the 17th pick drew boos, puzzled television analysts and opened debate about the wisdom of the draft choice, probably the last major move by the team president Donnie Walsh.

title: With a Bit of Land Restored, Villagers End Campaign
description: BILIN, West Bank  Residents of this tiny Palestinian village, along with Israeli and foreign supporters, on Friday held what organizers billed as the last of their trademark weekly demonstrations against the Bilin section of Israels West Bank barrier. It was a milestone that illustrated both the success of the unarmed popular movement that was born here, and its limitations.

title: President Announces an Initiative in Technology
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Pa.  President Obama visited a university research center in Pittsburgh on Friday to announce a new partnership between the government, industries and leading universities to speed the movement of technological advances to commercial users. The trip was the latest of his increasingly frequent travels to battleground states to showcase administration efforts to create manufacturing jobs.

title: German E.Coli Sickens 8 in France
description: PARIS  The deadly German E. coli strain that killed at least 45 people has resurfaced in France, where officials said a cluster of eight people have fallen ill, apparently from eating contaminated sprouts grown in France.

title: Hitters With Blue Eyes Are Wary About Glare
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  In a 1956 recording, Chuck Berry sang: Round the third, he was headed for home. It was a brown-eyed handsome man.

title: The Great Corn Con
description: FEELING the need for an example of government policy run amok? Look no further than the box of cornflakes on your kitchen shelf. In its myriad corn-related interventions, Washington has managed simultaneously to help drive up food prices and add tens of billions of dollars to the deficit, while arguably increasing energy use and harming the environment.

title: Battling Over Bike Lanes, Online
description: New Yorks bicycle advocates turn to the Internet to make their voices, and message, heard over the citys car traffic.

title: When Bikers Clash, the Tape Rolls
description: WHEN Casey Neistat got a ticket on Second Avenue and Seventh Street in the East Village for riding his bicycle outside the designated bike lane in May, he did what many outraged cyclists do. He grabbed his cellphone and shot a video of his encounter with the ticketing officer, who admonished him to ride in the lane at all times.

title: Public or Private, Its Work
description: Sutton, Vt.

title: 2 by 2, or Not, Zoo Animals Escape Flood
description: MINOT, N.D.  As a historic flood threatened to drown this city, the animals from the local zoo were evacuated to a warehouse high above the valley floor. There were two of every sort  donkeys, hedgehogs, bald eagles, reindeer, toucans and many others  packed together in a makeshift sanctuary.

title: Long Series of Trials Could Prove to Be Mobsters Death Sentence
description: James (Whitey) Bulgers long flight back from Los Angeles to Boston on Friday was only the beginning of a much longer journey, a legal odyssey that is likely to keep him in court for years. Unless Mr. Bulger, who is 81, bypasses the long court process with plea deals, the trials themselves could be a death sentence.

title: An Unfair Burden
description: For all of the economic hardship of the last several years, there was reason to hope that the nation could avoid a crushing increase in the number of Americans living in poverty. That hope is fading fast.

title: Legislature Approves Bloomberg Plan to Allow Street Hails of Livery Cabs
description: The State Legislature voted on Friday to vastly expand the reach of regulated, metered taxi service in New York City, a move that would create a class of livery cabs that can be hailed legally on the street outside the busiest parts of Manhattan.

title: Yemens Security Forces Clash With Protesters at Funeral Procession for a Popular Activist
description: SANA, Yemen  Security forces fired at a funeral procession in the city of Aden on Friday and gunmen responded by attacking a military tank, the government and local journalists said. A total of five people were killed in the clashes.

title: Bullying in N.J.; Bargaining in N.Y.
description: New York and New Jersey, like so many other states, are struggling with big budget gaps and high health care expenses for union employees. The Cuomo administration in New York sat at the bargaining table and worked out a fair arrangement for bigger contributions by workers. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, by contrast, bullied and postured and got the Legislature to strip unions of collective-bargaining rights on health insurance.

title: Dangerous Imports
description: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed sensible steps to cope with the dangers posed by a flood of imported food, drugs, cosmetics and medical devices. The trouble is, Congressional Republicans are determined to cut the agencys budget when it ought to be getting an increase to deal with this worsening risk.

title: New York Allows Same-Sex Marriage, Becoming Largest State to Pass Law
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers voted late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, making New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples will be able to wed and giving the national gay-rights movement new momentum from the state where it was born.

title: How Gay Marriage Will Change Couples Financial Lives
description: Updated | June 27, 2011 Couples may marry for love, but the partnership is also an economic one. And now that New York has become the sixth state to perform same-sex marriage, couples who tie the knot here will gain a variety of financial benefits and legal rights.

description: Budget belt-tightening threatens to send school librarians the way of the card catalog.

title: Denmark Leads Nationalist Challenge to Europes Open Borders
description: COPENHAGEN  Ten years ago, as Denmark joined the European Unions visa-free open travel zone, the outraged Danish Peoples Party bought a decommissioned border guardhouse, vowing that one day it would be in use again.

title: On the Art of Puttering
description: We are a driven people, New Yorkers. Too much to do, not enough time. We keep lists; we crowd our schedules; we look for more efficient ways to organize ourselves  we get things done when were not too busy planning to get things done. Even our leisure time is focused, and there is something proactive about our procrastination. We dont merely put things off. We put things off by piling other things on top of them. As Robert Benchley once noted, anyone can do any amount of work, provided it isnt the work he is supposed to be doing at that moment.

title: Burnett Fizzles as Giambi Dazzles
description: A. J. Burnett walked slowly from the pitchers mound to the Yankees dugout Friday, head down and shoulders slumped as tepid applause mixed with half-hearted booing in the Yankee Stadium stands. It was as if the fans did not know what to do with Burnett; taken as a whole, their reaction to his departure in the seventh inning might best be described as collective indifference.

title: Urban Forager: An Irresistible Berry (Within Limits)
description: Ever since I discovered mulberries growing in a park in Flushing, Queens, on the day of my grandmothers death two years ago, the delight of finding summer berries has been bittersweet for me. Last week, I was having another difficult day when my fianc and I took a walk in Central Park to search for the linden trees, which I thought would be in full bloom and would make a lovely tea. But our most recent heat wave had spurred an early flowering, and when we arrived in the area I call Linden Hill, the creamy-colored blossoms were already browning with age.

description: ATHENS  Demonstrators projected the word across the facade of Parliament last week, and it underscored the hurdle that Prime Minister George Papandreou faces in selling an increasingly resentful electorate on a tough new round of austerity measures: Thieves.

title: In Another Red Bull Day, Vettel Again Crushes all the Competition
description: After again cruising at the top of the time sheets in Saturdays qualifying session in Valencia, Spain, Sebastian Vettel has now scored seven pole positions this season out of eight races. title: Q. and A. With Fox Soccers Eric Wynalda

After taking second place at the 10,000-meter race at the USA Track and Field Championships on Thursday, Kara Goucher took her 9-month-old son, Colt, from her husbands arms and ran a victory lap with him around the track. title: Is This Our Future?

And it wasnt when I drove the 100 or so miles from Manhattan to Southampton, N.Y., either. Although the batterys range is only about 40 miles, the car kept going even after the battery was drained; it just switched to its gasoline engine, in a transition so seamless I barely noticed it. description: Pixars Cars 2 overcame surprisingly negative critical reviews to overperform at the weekend box office, selling an estimated $68 million at North American theaters. That No. 1 finish extends Pixars perfect box-office track record  all 12 of its feature films have opened in first place. How sales hold up, however, will be watched carefully. Cars 2, directed by John Lasseter, chief creative officer at Pixar, represents an end to the studios perfect critical track record; only about 34 percent of reviews were positive, according to RottenTomatoes.com, by far the worst for any Pixar title.The R-rated comedy Bad Teacher (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was a stronger-than-expected second with about $31 million in ticket sales  a result that cements mega-raunchy films as one of Hollywoods best performers of the moment. Green Lantern (Warner Brothers) fell 65 percent in its second weekend to third place, taking in about $18.4 million for a new total of $89 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Super 8 (Paramount Pictures) continued to show strength in its third weekend, selling about $12 million for a new total of $95 million. Mr. Poppers Penguins (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10.3 million for a two-week total of $39.4 million.

title: And in Other Soccer Action: The Galaxys Accidental Goalkeeper
description: And in other soccer action on Saturday  no one will ever mistake Mike Magee for one of the great goalkeepers of Europe, the United States or anyplace else guys wear grotesquely padded gloves, stand between two posts and try to stop powerful shots launched at their heads.

title: How Fast Should Your Cameras Memory Card Be?
description: When you are shopping for a camera memory card, faster is better, right?

title: U.S. Plans Stealth Survey on Access to Doctors
description: WASHINGTON  Alarmed by a shortage of primary care doctors, Obama administration officials are recruiting a team of mystery shoppers to pose as patients, call doctors offices and request appointments to see how difficult it is for people to get care when they need it.

title: The Financiers Who Helped Back N.Y. Gay Marriage Campaign
description: Much of the attention around the legalization of same-sex marriage in New York has revolved around the back-room politicking involved: the deals, the cajoling, the organizing.

title: Money May Not Buy You Love, but It Might Help You Land a Spouse
description: What should Daisy Goodwin have called her novel about a Gilded Age Newport belle who heads for England to marry her way into a title? It was published in Britain as My Last Duchess, since it makes abundant reference to the chilling Robert Browning poem of that name. Now, for American readers, it has been given a forgettably bland name: The American Heiress. A hybrid of the two, The American Duchess, would have better described what Ms. Goodwins sly, glittery period piece is about.

title: Cheering a Gay Marriage Law, and Its Champions
description: Two days after New York became the sixth and largest state to legalize same-sex marriage, participants in the 42nd annual gay pride parade on Sunday used the occasion to reflect somberly on the gains and losses of the past year.

title: Left-Handers Have Edge in Slice and Singularity
description: WIMBLEDON, England  At half past noon on Sunday, there was a scene at the All England Clubs Aorangi Park usually seen once every blue moon: four left-handers hitting on three adjacent practice courts.

title: Fog Blurs Vision, and Lines, Between Performer and Audience
description: It was dark, and the air hummed with something ominous. A thick fog pressed in and the crowd, with a mix of familiar and unknown faces, was all made strange and a little sinister by the impenetrable haze. We were at Amidst, a new work by Pavel Zustiak, that is as much about the watchers as the watched.

title: Googles War on Nonsense
description: Imagine a sci-fi universe in which every letter, word and sentence is a commodity. Companies make money off chunks of language. Bosses drive writers to make more words faster and for less pay. Readers then pay for exposure to these cheaply made words in the precious currency of their attention.

title: Sometimes Pop Songs Double as Prayers
description: Milton Nascimento, the singer and songwriter who is one of Brazils national treasures, played up his jazzy side on Friday night at the Rose Theater, the home of Jazz at Lincoln Center. Thats the facet of his songwriting that smoothly and stealthily poses and solves musical challenges: how to make odd meters strut like a samba, how to make a chromatic labyrinth sound like a promenade. Its the kind of craftsmanship that has earned him admiring collaborators like Paul Simon and Wayne Shorter.

title: Perdue Goes to the Farm With an Earnest Approach
description: ADVERTISING for Perdue Farms is no longer strictly a family affair.

title: The Textbooks Were Right, Well, at Least This Time
description: When the final day  58 boards  began in the Mixed Pairs at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, on Thursday, Anna Zack Einarsson and Bengt-Erik Efraimsson from Sweden had a comfortable lead. But they had 24 under-average boards, including three zeros. This allowed Magdalena Ticha and Richard Ritmeijer from the Netherlands and Catherine dOvidio and Philippe Cronier from France to move into contention.

title: Songs of a Doubting Thomas at Bowery Ballroom
description: In the years since the dissolution of the Christian-themed indie rock band Pedro the Lion, its singer David Bazan has been a regular on the house-show circuit, popping up in someones living room for a night for audiences of a few dozen.

title: Companies Are Erecting In-House Social Networks
description: What would Facebook look like without photos of drunken nights out and tales of misbehaving cats? It might look a lot like the internal social network at the offices of Nikon Instruments.

title: Collaboration at 72 Beats Per Minute
description: Im supposed to remind you at this portion of the show that Im a composer, John Moran announced just over halfway through John Moran + Saori (... in Thailand), the 2010 piece he presented in its New York premiere at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn on Friday evening, and repeated on Saturday. Anyone new to Mr. Morans work probably welcomed an explanation; up to that point, little about his performance with the dancer Saori Tsukada had registered as music by any conventional notion.

title: Inuksuit
description: Morningside Park

title: Ethel
description: Abrons Arts Center

title: Comedian, Chastened, Gets Back to Laughs
description: About halfway through a raucous standup set on Saturday night in which he dispensed much unsolicited romantic advice and hit on several women seated near the stage, Tracy Morgan told the crowd at Carolines, the Times Square comedy club, he knew what it wanted to hear.

title: Monday: Celebrity Guest Solver Joel Stein
description: Administrivial Disappearing Comments Update: My apologies for the disappearing comments. Ive found them, and wouldnt you know, theyre always in the last place you look. A new system had been put in place and it was sending some of the comments on walkabout. After an epic battle, in which I wielded both power tools and my magic bullet-proof bracelets, that system has been shut down, so we should be back to normal. Thank you for your patience.

title: Sailing a Saucy Ship Into Bel Canto Seas
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Whats wrong with this picture? Since 1997 the Caramoor International Music Festival has presented an opera series devoted to the bel canto repertory, with an emphasis on Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and Verdi. Neither its name (Bel Canto at Caramoor) nor its mission has changed, but when the series and the festival opened on Saturday evening, the work at hand was Gilbert and Sullivans H.M.S. Pinafore or The Lass That Loved a Sailor.

title: A Decent Proposal
description: Supporters of same-sex marriage say gay people are entitled to be fully equal citizens, including in their yearning to make families. Opponents say the state has no business bestowing the blessings of marriage on those who do not fit the traditional template.

title: Scorecard | Raf Simons Wins!
description: Its a truism that in Paris suits are not for Suits, which Scorecard knows was exemplified Saturday by Kris Van Assches whiteout of superskinny-lapel jackets and dropped-crotch high-waters accessorized with wide-brimmed toppers on the Dior Homme runway. Too bad, then, that Raf Simons had to make it all look literally old hat with his witty display of that creative industry favorite  plaid  in a former bank headquarters. It might just be hip to be square.

title: Raves for Superstar
description: With the musicals Sister Act and The Book of Mormon now singing to the heavens on Broadway, and a revival of Godspell set to join them this fall, is there room in the congregation for a fourth musical with strong spiritual underpinnings? In Ontario, the Stratford Shakespeare Festivals new revival of Jesus Christ Superstar, the 1971 rock opera by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice about the last week of Jesus life, has received rave reviews from local theater critics, prompting New York producers and other critics to book flights to Toronto for a look. Mr. Lloyd Webber, who holds the rights to mount a Broadway revival, saw the production this month and called it fabulous, adding that it was very probably the best acted performance of the show I have ever seen. Mr. Rice has also seen it, adding to the buzz that the production might have a life beyond Stratford. The director, Des McAnuff, who is also artistic director of the festival, said in a telephone interview that were definitely taking calls from New York and elsewhere about having a future elsewhere, but its very much an open question. Asked about a transfer to Broadway, Mr. McAnuff said, We would of course love to move this and love an opportunity to take our Stratford company members with us if we go.

title: AMC Chief Responds to Killing Complaints
description: The president of the cable channel AMC said he didnt regret the cliffhanger ending of The Killing a week ago but admitted there was a lesson to be learned. We underestimated the passion viewers have for closure within a season, Charlie Collier  told Entertainment Weekly on Friday. If I could do anything differently, it would be to manage expectations. Many fans of The Killing (with Mireille Enos, above), which is about an investigation into the death of a teenage girl in Seattle, were left fuming when the first season ended on June 19 without an explanation for the crime. The anger was noticeable on social media Web sites, prompting Mr. Colliers acknowledgment. The audience has an important voice, we heard them and dont take them for granted, he said. Mr. Collier said he stood by the shows executive producer, Veena Sud, who told the public radio show The Business, last week that the investigation would be resolved in Season 2. Ms. Sud recounted a conversation on one Web site that had a viewer declaring, Ill never ever come back for season two. She said, On the same thread three more people popped up and said: I havent watched this show yet, but now I will because you guys are so emotional about it, its gotta be something to watch. So thats a great thing.

title: Womens Project Announces Lineup
description: A new play by Catherine Trieschmann will headline the 2011-12 Womens Project lineup, the theater company announced. How the World Began focuses on a teacher in rural Kansas whose comments about the origins of the universe have unforeseen consequences. Directed by Daniella Topol (Dead City), the play is the follow-up to the highly praised Crooked, Ms. Trieschmanns previous collaboration with Womens Project. The season will begin in October with Rebecca Taichmans production of Milk Like Sugar by Kirsten Greenidge (Bossa Nova), followed by How the World Began, and We Play for the Gods, which features contributions from 16 artists, connecting theater history with the current vision of the Womens Project Lab.

title: Shareholders Push Tepco to Abandon Nuclear Power
description: Masafumi Asada bought shares of the Tokyo Electric Power Company almost a decade ago with a single purpose: To vote against the use of nuclear power.

title: Bollywood Honors
description: Dabangg, an action musical about a corrupt police officer, dominated the International Indian Film Academy awards, Bollywoods version of the Oscars, over the weekend. Directed by Abhinav Kashyap, above left, and starring Salman Khan, the film won six awards, including best picture, The Associated Press reported. The ceremony, part of a three-day event, took place for the first time in North America; more than 22,000 fanspacked the Rogers Center in Toronto.

title: Talk of President Cuomo? 2016 Is a Long Way Off
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo took the heros stroll down Fifth Avenue Sunday, his reception from the Gay Pride masses somewhere between loving and rapturous. And who could argue?

title: Ballet and New Music Mix, Meet and Mingle
description: The word enterprising always applies to New Chamber Ballet. On Saturday night at Studio 4 in New York City Center, in addition to its usual accomplishments of presenting new and recent choreography with live music, it offered a program set entirely to music written in the last 30 years. Let nobody underrate this. Of the dozens of ballets seen in New York in the last two months, how many have been to music more recent than Stravinsky or Britten?

title: Against Fish, Key for Berdych Is Confidence
description: Tomas Berdych, last years surprise Wimbledon finalist, has regained his winning form on grass after a disappointing clay-court season. At 6-foot-4, Berdych has a big first serve and follows it up with a cleanly hit forehand that is fast, heavy and generated with little fuss. His tremendous power comes from his legs, which may be the strongest in tennis. His game is simple: serve big, keep the backhand deep and in play, and wallop his classic-style forehand.

title: From Scapegoat to Hero, Nunez Helps Yankees Secure Victory
description: The Yankees spent several hours early Sunday honoring the franchises storied past, with ceremonies and tributes and all the warm memories that come with Old-Timers Day. Then, once the game with the Colorado Rockies began, Eduardo Nunez  the youngest current Yankee  provided a glimpse into the sometimes-grim, sometimes-glorious existence that is a franchises future.

title: Flawed Man Draws a Good Woman
description: Daniel Sullivan plants a hot kiss smack in the middle of his captivating production of the thorny Alls Well That Ends Well for Shakespeare in the Park. Acts of osculation have of course been known to sweep people off their feet. But Mr. Sullivan ingeniously uses this one to ground his audience and to stabilize an uneasy play.

title: Concern at Nebraska Reactors as Floodwaters Rise
description: BROWNVILLE, Neb.  Like inhabitants of a city preparing for a siege, operators of the nuclear reactor here have spent days working to defend it against the swollen Missouri River at its doorstep. On Sunday, eight days after the river rose high enough to require the operators to declare a low-level emergency, a swarm of plant officials got to show off their preparations to the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Mets Again Empty in Homers and Overflowing in Hits
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Although the Mets scored a dozen more runs in their last two games than the Texas Rangers did, it would not be correct to say they outslugged their high-powered opponents.

title: When Fools Rush In
description: It turns out you can kid a kidder, and its easy to fool a fool. What about four fools? Theres no safety in numbers, certainly not in Double Dhamaal, a mind-contracting Hindi comedy that seems to take its cues from the Three Stooges, the Keystone Kops and every Bollywood clich it can chew up and spit back as farce.

title: Chaos in Yemen Creates Opening for Islamist Gangs
description: ADEN, Yemen  The ancient port city of Aden is now virtually surrounded by roving gangs of Islamist militia fighters  some linked to Al Qaeda  who have captured at least two towns, stormed prisons and looted banks and military depots in southern Yemen.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for May (Monday); S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for April and consumer confidence for June (Tuesday); Pending home sales for May (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the Chicago purchasing managers index for June (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for June, automakers report North American sales for June, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for June and construction spending for May (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: Mark Burnett, who more or less created the reality programming business in American television, is back in the ratings fast lane.

title: A Mission to See
description: The title Vincent Wants to Sea is a painfully unpunny translation of the original German title Vincent Will Meer, a homophone of Vincent will mehr or Vincent wants more. Both titles boldly underline the metaphorical significance of the films literal journey  a road-trip from Munich to the Mediterranean by way of the Swiss Alps. The exact meanings may get lost in translation, but trite is a universal language apparently.

title: Look, Two Hands: A Twist on a Golf Tradition
description: In a PGA Tour playoff duel between former Clemson teammates this season, the gloves were off. Lucas Glover dispatched Jonathan Byrd on the first extra hole in a shootout that thrilled Tigers fans and no doubt led to sweaty palms in the highly lucrative golf glove industry.

title: Rematch Between Wozniacki and Cibulkova Hinges on Aggressive Play
description: Caroline Wozniacki and Dominika Cibulkova, who play for a place in the quarterfinals Monday, met in the third round of the Australian Open. Cibulkova jumped out to an early lead by playing grip-it-and-rip-it tennis, going for winners early and often against the steady Wozniacki. It was impressive for the first few games, but Wozniacki gave Cibulkova one too many balls, and the unforced errors mounted for Cibulkova.

Others, like New Yorks mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, and its former schools chancellor Joel I. Klein have sent their children to private schools with small class sizes.

description: It has never been easy for a mayor to get things done in New York City, where every government proposal must navigate a thicket of community groups, policy boards, and empowered neighborhood gadflies who can blackball a project in a blink.

title: Average Price for U.S. Gas Falls to $3.63
description: The average price for regular gasoline at filling stations in the United States fell 11.22 cents to about $3.63 a gallon, according to the Lundberg Survey, a market research company.

title: Maneuvering to Control Future of Formula One
description: The fortunes of a Formula One race can change in a split second. When Sebastian Vettel, the 23-year-old star of the Red Bull Racing team, slipped up on the last lap of the Canadian Grand Prix this month, he allowed Jenson Button of McLaren to snatch away the victors Jeroboam of Champagne.

title: Peng Needs to Force Mistakes, Not Make Them
description: Peng Shuai has made only 12 unforced errors in reaching the round of 16 at Wimbledon. Thats an average of four mistakes a match, which are numbers we normally associate with Rafael Nadal on clay. Although few are predicting an upset, Peng has the mind and the moxie to give Maria Sharapova a serious test.

title: Braun and Brewers Arrive Together
description: MILWAUKEE  The savior of the Milwaukee Brewers was born in California in 1983, the first of 28 consecutive years in which the franchise has not won a playoff series. He grew up playing shortstop, following players like Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, whom he met on a recruiting trip to the University of Miami, where he enrolled and starred for three seasons.

title: A Day for Masters to Share the Track With Youthful Elite
description: EUGENE, Ore.  They may be in their 40s and 50s, and their races may be for the love of running and not to gain entry to the world championships in South Korea, but they still boast six-pack abdominals and four-plus-minute miles.

title: Bachmann Readies Presidential Campaign
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  On the eve of her presidential announcement, Michele Bachmann returned home to the city of her childhood on Sunday to reconnect with her Iowa roots, which she hopes to parlay into an advantage in her quest to win the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Yankees Legends Attend Their Family Reunion
description: Joe Torre awoke about 5 a.m. Sunday in a mild panic. In a few hours, he would be going to Yankee Stadium for his first Old-Timers Day, and it occurred to him that he did not have any cleats.

description: JERUSALEM  Israel threatened Sunday to bar for up to a decade any foreign journalist who boards a flotilla seeking to challenge an Israeli naval blockade of Gaza.

description: Alice Playten, a versatile character actress and musical comedy voice whose piping wail earned her comparisons to a baby Ethel Merman, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 63 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Robert Miller, Manhattan Art Dealer, Dies at 72
description: Robert Miller, an art dealer whose Manhattan gallery represented an eclectic list of prominent American painters, sculptors and photographers, notably Robert Mapplethorpe, died on Wednesday in Miami. He was 72 and lived in El Portal, Fla.

title: Even Boom States Get the Blues
description: MINOT, N.D.  For a very long time this state was derided as an empty expanse of windswept nothingness where snow stormed in and residents stormed out in predictable abundance. Then, as the rest of the country struggled the last few years, North Dakota started winning consistent praise as an oasis of economic prosperity. The snow kept coming, but suddenly so did new residents.

title: Dissolution of Hacker Group Might Not End Attacks
description: Facing increasing pressure from law enforcement agencies over its brazen computer attacks, the small group of hackers known as Lulz Security announced over the weekend that it would disband.

title: U.S. to Provide Guidelines to Bolster Computer Security
description: The Homeland Security Department plans to unveil on Monday a new system of guidance intended to help make the software behind many services  be they Web sites or power grids  less susceptible to hacking.

title: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Government Is Not Sharing the Power to Arrest Rivals
description: JOHANNESBURG  Jameson Timba, a senior aide to Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai of Zimbabwe, had just returned home on Friday from a conference in Barcelona on the rule of law when plainclothes policemen  answerable to President Robert Mugabe  arrested him in Harare, Zimbabwes capital. Mr. Timba was accused of a common crime: insulting Mr. Mugabe.

title: Canadian Parliament Orders Postal Union Back to Work
description: OTTAWA  Canadas Parliament passed legislation Sunday evening that ordered the countrys 48,000 postal workers back to work.

title: Spike in U.S. Deaths in Iraq Raises Worries
description: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers were killed Sunday in Iraq, the military command said, making June the worst month in combat-related fatalities for United States forces in Iraq in more than two years. The casualties also reflected the dangers ahead as the United States prepares to withdraw all its troops from Iraq by the end of the year.

description: Politico, an accelerant to the news cycle like wind is to brushfire, is taking on the one realm of political news that it has not yet sped up: book publishing.

description: The day in sports, from the Womens World Cup, to baseball, to rugby and track and field.

title: Hearsts Umbrella Ad Campaign
description: On Monday, Hearst Magazines is to begin an elaborate advertising campaign, aimed at advertisers and readers, to burnish its brand image rather than promote individual magazines like Esquire or Good Housekeeping. The campaign, with the Unbound theme, comes after significant business developments like the $892 million acquisition of 100 publications from Lagardre, the $325 million purchase of the digital marketing agency iCrossing and the joint venture with Scripps Network Interactive to introduce Food Network Magazine.

title: For Council Speaker, Enjoying a Run of Good Fortune
description: Whenever Christine C. Quinn became overly excited as a child, her father, Larry, would admonish her to save up her enthusiasm for the moment when she won the lottery. If you allow yourself to express all that happiness now, he told her, you wont have what you need for that day.

title: 160 Million and Counting
description: In 1990, the economist Amartya Sen published an essay in The New York Review of Books with a bombshell title: More Than 100 Million Women Are Missing. His subject was the wildly off-kilter sex ratios in India, China and elsewhere in the developing world. To explain the numbers, Sen invoked the neglect of third-world women, citing disparities in health care, nutrition and education. He also noted that under Chinas one-child policy, some evidence exists of female infanticide.

title: Byron Burford, Artist of Circus Life, Dies at 90
description: Byron Burford, a figurative artist who attracted a broad following, particularly in the Midwest, with vivid images of athletes, soldiers, factory workers, jazz musicians and a panoply of circus people, died on June 17 at his home in Iowa City. He was 90.

title: Behind Veneer, Doubt on Future of Natural Gas
description: Energy companies have worked hard to promote the idea that natural gas is the fossil fuel of tomorrow, and they have found reliable allies among policy makers in Washington.

title: Egyptian Leader Assures McCain and Kerry on Transition
description: CAIRO  After talks with the leader of Egypts ruling military council, Senator John McCain on Sunday expressed confidence that the caretaker military rulers wanted to transfer powers to an elected government as soon as possible.

description: Chicago

title: Across Europe, Irking Drivers Is Urban Policy
description: ZURICH  While American cities are synchronizing green lights to improve traffic flow and offering apps to help drivers find parking, many European cities are doing the opposite: creating environments openly hostile to cars. The methods vary, but the mission is clear  to make car use expensive and just plain miserable enough to tilt drivers toward more environmentally friendly modes of transportation.

title: Taking a Spin on the Hudson, and Earning Course Credit, Too
description: The sailboat raced across the murky soup of the Hudson River, piloted by two teenagers new to the water and one who was an old salt.

title: Old-Timers Day in Pictures
description: From Yogi Berra to Joe Torre to Bernie Williams, the Old-Timers returned to Yankee Stadium.

title: Gay Marriage: A Milestone
description: New York State has made a powerful and principled choice by giving all couples the right to wed and enjoy the legal rights of marriage. It is a proud moment for New Yorkers, thousands of whom took to the streets on Sunday to celebrate this step forward. But this moment does not erase the bigotry against gays and lesbians enshrined in the federal Defense of Marriage Act, which denies federal recognition of same-sex marriages and allows any state to refuse to recognize another states unions.

title: A Monday Full of Action and Answers at Wimbledon
description: The second Monday of Wimbledon is a special day because all 32 remaining singles players are in action. Christopher Clarey laid out many of the story lines for Week 2 at the All England Club. Who is your sentimental favorite  Roger Federer or Andy Murray? Which upstart do you want to see more off  Bernard Tomic or Sabine Lisicki? Which female star is closer to championship form  Maria Sharapova or Serena Williams?

title: Gay Marriage: Wheres Mr. Obama?
description: On Thursday night, when same-sex marriage in New York State was teetering on a razors edge, President Obama had a perfect opportunity to show the results of his supposed evolution on gay marriage.

title: Wheres the Reconciliation?
description: King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa of Bahrain has promised to launch a national dialogue aimed at reconciling his country after a brutal crackdown on antigovernment protesters. It is hard to take this seriously  or see any real chance of success  when many of the people who should be at the negotiating table are still in jail.

title: Legal Help for Indigent Parents

title: Philip Roth No Longer Reading Fiction

In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Roth, the ornery author more than two dozen novels (the FT credits him with 53 books) including Portnoys Complaint, The Human Stain and Nemesis, said that other peoples literary inventions are no longer part of his diet. Ive stopped reading fiction, he said. I dont read it at all. I read other things: history, biography. I dont have the same interest in fiction that I once did. title: Museum of Fine Arts Reaches Restitution Deal to Keep Painting
description: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting Two Nudes (Lovers); a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work.

Among the works audience members will get a chance to see later in the week are revivals of Merce Cunninghams Duets, with music by John Cage; Paul Taylors Black Tuesday, set to Depression-era music; and Ms. Tharps Sinatra Suite, which includes music sung by Frank Sinatra and costumes by Oscar de la Renta.

description: It was evening by the time forty-four-year-old Suzanne Kiner pulled into the parking lot at Woodinville Pediatrics, twenty miles from Seattle. Her nine-year-old daughter, Brianne, felt too weak to walk. Topping 250 pounds and with glasses and short wavy hair, Suzanne lifted her sixty-five-pound daughter from the backseat and carried her inside. Brianne had missed the previous day of school with a low-grade fever and stomach ache. Besides liquids, all Suzanne could get in her was raspberry popsicles. Then the diarrhea had started, along with the cramps that reduced Brianne to tears.

title: A Timely E. Coli Story, Spun as a Legal Thriller

With Poisoned, Jeff Benedict manages to deliver the full literary experience of a medico-legal thriller in a work of nonfiction that, fortuitously enough, could not be more relevant to recent headlines.

title: CBS Leads a Lackluster Sunday Night

NBC broadcast an encore of last weeks Americas Got Talent and it averaged 5.4 million viewers an hour from 8 to 10. ABC was third over all with repeats of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition (3.9 million), Castle (4.2 million), and Body of Proof (4 million). Fox ranked a distant fourth with reruns of its regular Sunday night comedies.

The society said that the retrospective, called Prince of the City: Remembering Sidney Lumet, will run from July 19 through 25 and will feature screenings of 16 films by that director, who died in April. Movies including Serpico, The Verdict and The Wiz will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater in Manhattan. The retrospective will also feature a Q-and-A with Walter Bernstein, the screenwriter of Fail Safe, after a showing of that film on July 20; the actor Treat Williams and the N.Y.P.D. detective Robert Leuci will appear after a screening of Prince of the City on July 24; and, of course, Lumets film Q&A will be followed by a Q-and-A with Luis Guzman, Paul Calderon and Judge Edwin Torres, the author of the novel from which the film was adapted.

The Bank of England faces the same kind conflict between what it should be doing and what its under pressure to do that faces the Fed, but in starker form. And if the BoE holds its ground, we should soon have a clear demonstration that one side is right and the other is wrong.

title: Alan Rickman to Return to Broadway in Seminar

But after playing the sinister Severus Snape in the final installment of that boy-wizard franchise this summer, Mr. Rickman will next be portraying another in his long line of memorable creeps in Seminar, a new play by Theresa Rebeck that will open on Broadway in the fall.

A confessed cinephile, Mr. Veloso has composed soundtracks for movies, performed in his friend Pedro Almodvars Talk to Her, written essays about his love for Italian neo-realist films and even recorded a CD tribute to Federico Fellini and Giulietta Masina.

title: Technology, Free Speech and Children
description: When my column about technology and children was published on Sunday, the Supreme Court had not yet ruled on Californias ban on the sale of violent video games to children under the age of 18. Yesterday as expected, the Supreme Court struck down the ban. It was a 7 to 2 decision, but that suggests greater agreement than there really was, as Adam Liptak maps out. Whats most interesting about the fissures on the court is the different thinking among the justices about the impact of technology on children, and the implications for other important clashes over teenagers free-speech rights that are percolating in the lower courts.

title: Film Festival | Documentaries About History

title: Bachelorette, Seeking Love, Wins Eyes
description: ABCs reality competition The Bachelorette posted its best ratings in three weeks on Monday, delivering the nights largest audience with eight million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The solid ratings helped ABC extended its winning streak to 16 weeks as the top-rated network on Monday night. NBC ranked second as Law & Order: LA finished in a tie with ABCs Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition at 10 p.m., each attracting 6.4 million viewers. Earlier, NBCs rerun of Americas Got Talent, at 8 p.m., garnered 5.8 million viewers and Law & Order: Criminal Intent drew 4.8 million at 9, less than the five million viewers who watched a new episode of Foxs MasterChef in the same time slot. For the night, however, Fox lagged behind CBS, which placed third with reruns of its sitcom line-up followed by a Hawaii Five-0 repeat at 10 p.m. (5.8 million).

title: A Tree Grows in Athens
description: Athens is in trouble. The boutiques on the posh shopping streets of Kolonaki are empty. Constitution Square is a landfill of protest placards. And the normally cheery summer afternoon ritual  an iced Nescaf paired with half a pack of cigarettes  has become an exercise in existential brooding. It makes me so sad, Stefania Flenga, an executive for the boutique hotel chain Yes! Hotels, said while surveying the slow simmer of civil unrest on view in front of the Greek parliament. She was no doubt thinking about how all these disturbances are bad for the tourism industry, which accounts for almost 18 percent of the Greek economy. Theyre shooting themselves in the foot, she said of the picketers.

title: Sudan Signs Pact With Opposition Forces

title: Shipwreck Show Postponed
description: The Smithsonian Institution has indefinitely postponed its plans to mount an exhibition of Chinese artifacts salvaged from a shipwreck because of opposition from archeologists who say the objects were collected by a commercial treasure hunter in a manner that violated professional standards. The exhibition, Shipwrecked: Tang Treasures and Monsoon Winds, was tentatively scheduled for next spring at the Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, the Smithsonians Asian art museums. A museum spokeswoman, Deborah Galyan, said that the earliest the museum might mount a Shipwrecked exhibit now would be 2013, a delay that she said would give the museums director, Julian Raby, who also curated the exhibition, time to address some of the archeologists concerns. The exhibition was conceived by the government of Singapore, which bought the artifacts for $32 million from the company that salvaged them from a wreck off the coast of Indonesia. It is currently on view at the ArtScience museum at the Marina Bay Sands resort and casino in Singapore. The salvage company has said it mined the artifacts quickly to avoid looting.

When he starts to partner her and demonstrate both love and protectiveness, her own diffidence is extreme; she keeps withdrawing from his arms, one way or another.

Last night at the Mondrian SoHo penthouse, the London-based, German-born designer Markus Lupfer premiered his collection with a mock sci-fi documentary. The director Tabitha Denholm was on hand to provide live commentary along with the actress Margo Stilley (who portrayed Dr. Lupfer). Cory Kennedy spun tracks with the city skyline providing the perfect backdrop. Tennessee Thomas of the Like slipped in and played Its My Party and Ill Cry if I Want To on the turntables. And all talk centered on the collection featuring bright colors and a clever fit. Heres our exclusive look behind the scenes of the film, above, directed by Sean Frank.

What is remarkable is that so little of it has bled into dramas or comedies.

title: Keeping Artificial Limbs Low-Cost, and High-Quality

You disappear from society, people avoid you, you become a burden  all for the lack of a piece of equipment. This is a very persuasive argument for why a low-cost wide-scale product like the Jaipur Limb is necessary.

That is the maximum allowed under the 1872 mining law.

Not only that, but it has almost a meditative quality, since all of the puns use the om sound. I hope you all did the puzzle in lotus pose, as I did. Dont worry too much if the theme entries were not soundalikes; theyre puns, and its O.K. for them to be a bit loose. Besides, too much complaining will harsh my mellow, man.

title: The Hague: Onus Put on Libyans

Muammar el-Qaddafi, one of his sons and his intelligence chief was mainly the responsibility of Libya because the war crimes investigation that led to the warrants had been ordered by a resolution of the United Nations Security Council. The prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, said at a news conference that two Libyan rebel leaders were in The Hague for talks with his office about their plans, and that arrests could be just months away.

Ralph Jennings was packing up his things after 26 years at WFUV-FM, where he had transformed a chaotic college radio station at Fordham University with a tiny audience into one of the leading public radio outlets in the country and a rare cultural force.

Mr. Walcott, who became schools chancellor in April, has spoken at 14 commencement ceremonies this month (a 15th was planned for Belmont Preparatory High School in the Bronx on Wednesday), far more than his predecessors (Joel I. Klein addressed four in each of the past two years). On Tuesday, Mr. Walcott spoke at the commencement of his alma mater, Francis Lewis High School.

The lure of toilet-related topics seems as inevitable as potty training itself, as if once out of diapers, children are unable to resist the conversational detritus they might otherwise have left behind.

description: June 29, 2011 - Greece's parliament passes the austerity plan, averting an immediate financial crisis, but sparking violent protests for a second day.

title: American Ballet Theater Partners With the University of North Carolina School of the Arts
description: American Ballet Theater and the School of Dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem are embarking on a five-year partnership that will teach ABTs National Training Curriculum throughout three divisions at the school: preparatory, high school and collegiate. The partnership will be announced officially on Thursday by Rachel S. Moore, Ballet Theaters executive director, and John Mauceri, chancellor of the school of the arts.

title: News Corporation Sells MySpace for $35 Million
description: 8:14 p.m. | Updated MySpace, the long-suffering Web site that the News Corporation bought six years ago for $580 million, was sold Wednesday to the advertising network Specific Media for roughly $35 million.

title: Argument, Truth and the Social Side of Reasoning
description: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.Philosophers rightly think of themselves as experts on reasoning. After all, it was a philosopher, Aristotle, who developed the science of logic. But psychologists have also had some interesting things to say about the subject. A fascinating paper by Dan Sperber and Hugo Mercier has recently generated a lot of discussion.

title: Bank of America's Big Settlement
description: Bank of America has agreed to set aside $14 billion to settle claims stemming from sales of mortgage-backed securities. Nelson D. Schwartz explains how the bank will come up with the cash.

The New York Timess business reporter Nelson D. Schwartz and finance editor Patrick Scott talk about how the settlement will affect the banks bottom line.

title: Egyptian Seeds Are Linked to E. Coli in Germany and France
description: European investigators fitting together the puzzle pieces of devastating E. coli outbreaks in Germany and France cautiously identified a likely source on Wednesday: contaminated fenugreek seeds from Egypt.

title: Barbie, the Klimt Edition
description: Over the last half-century, Barbie has come in about as many guises and get-ups as Inspector Clouseau: cheerleader, supermodel, ski queen, doctor, astronaut, lawyer. Last year, Mattel, the dolls maker, released Mad Men versions, giving Barbie a pile of fire-red hair and a fetching office-girl dress in her Joan Holloway incarnation.

title: Tough Week for Meatless Monday
description: Like every day in America, the Fourth of July is a celebration of protein. But the Fourth is a special day for burgers and ribs, not beans and rice, a day with contests to see who can eat the most hot dogs, not the most veggie patties. If youre anti-meat, the Fourth of July can feel anti-you.

Nadal Looks Fresh in Victory Over Fish
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Rafael Nadal of Spain, showing no sign of an injury he feared might force his withdrawal, overpowered Mardy Fish Wednesday, racing to a 6-3, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4 victory and a place in the Wimbledon semifinals.

title: Andy Walking
description: Had one of Andy Warhols more entrepreneurial visions come to fruition, the storefront at the northeast corner of 74th and Madison, today a vintage watch dealer, would be the site of the worlds first Andy-Mat, an international chain of fast-food restaurants for people who prefer to eat alone. I want to start a chain of restaurants for other people like me called Andy-Mats, Warhol said. The restaurant for the lonely person. You get your food and then take your tray into a booth and watch television. According to architectural drawings, customers would have placed their orders with the kitchen directly, through a system of pneumatic tubes. The food, prepared off-site and frozen, would have been delivered to the franchise and then reheated. The project fell through in 1977, but not before $40,000 in rent had been paid, $1 million in capital had been secured, and Maxine de la McKendry, a society hostess and onetime food columnist for Vogue, had prepared the menu: milk over ice, anyone?

title: A Fresh Take Adds a Jolt to a Standard
description: The modest idea of the New York Philharmonics Summertime Classics concerts, which began in 2004, is to provide a few postseason programs of lighter fare, novelties and a staple or two at reduced prices. The British conductor Bramwell Tovey, a lively musician who has charmed Avery Fisher Hall audiences with his avuncular commentaries on music, concert protocols or whatever else strikes him, remains the host of choice for these events. While they are perfectly pleasant, you do not attend to hear extraordinary performances at these concerts.

title: Film Festival | Documentaries About Science
description: Our summer experiments continue! Last week: Historic Headlines. This week: A collaboration with SnagLearning to bring you film festivals of classroom-worthy documentaries, each day on a different theme. Mondays collection was about technology, Tuesdays was about history and todays theme is science. The whole collection is available here.

title: At German Museum, Cars as a Medium of Mobility
description: Car Culture: Media of Mobility, a new exhibition at the Zentrum fr Kunst und Medientechnologie, or the Center of Art and Media, combines the legacy of two local discoveries: the car and the radio wave. The show runs through Jan. 8.

title: The Voice Lifts NBC Again
description: The final round of NBCs singing competition The Voice garnered its best ratings in four weeks on Tuesday as the four remaining contestants battled it out to be the last singer standing. According to Nielsens estimates, the two-hour episode delivered the nights largest audience, 12.5 million viewers, building on NBCs ratings at 8 p.m. for Americas Got Talent (12 million). No other network came close on the night. CBS placed second with reruns of NCIS (8.2 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (8 million) at 8 and 9. ABC was third, drawing its best ratings at 8 for Wipeout (5.5 million) and solid results at 9 for 101 Ways to Leave a Game Show (5.3 million). At 10, ABCs Combat Hospital (4.6 million) lagged just behind CBSs repeat of The Good Wife (4.8 million). Fox finished in fourth as MasterChef attracted 4.2 million viewers at 8 while back-to-back reruns of Raising Hope averaged 2.2 million viewers at 9 p.m.

title: Rhode Island Lawmakers Approve Civil Unions
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Less than a week after same-sex marriage was legalized in New York, the Rhode Island State Senate on Wednesday evening approved a bill allowing not marriage, but civil unions for gay couples, despite fierce opposition from gay rights advocates who called the legislation discriminatory.

title: Hostage Taking at Brooklyn Wine Store Ends Without Incident
description: Updated, 6:23 p.m. | A hostage taking that grew out of a foiled armed robbery attempt at a Brooklyn wine shop ended without incident on Wednesday afternoon, the police said, as two suspects surrendered to the authorities.

title: Fed Halves Debit Card Bank Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Fees paid by retailers to banks for debit card purchases, a $20 billion annual expense that has been the subject of a furious political battle over the last year, will be cut in half after the Federal Reserve voted Wednesday to cap the charges.

title: Weinsteins Place Madonnas New Film in Oscar Fray
description: The Weinstein Company, which recently acquired the Madonna-directed film W.E., announced Wednesday that it plans to release the film smack in the middle of Oscar season. W.E., which stars Abbie Cornish as a modern-day young woman who finds inspiration in the romance between Britains King Edward VIII and the American divorce Wallis Simpson, will be released on Dec. 9 in New York and Los Angeles. Besides Ms. Cornish, the cast includes Andrea Riseborough (Never Let Me Go), James DArcy (Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World) and Oscar Isaac (Drive).

title: New York Philharmonics Music Director Vows to Restore Parks Series
description: There will be no free concerts in the parks for the New York Philharmonic this summer. But Alan Gilbert, the orchestras music director, has given his word that situation will change in 2012. I am making a personal promise that these beloved free concerts will return next summer and continue for many years to come, he wrote in a letter sent via e-mail to The New York Times on Wednesday, following the publication of a critics notebook lamenting the orchestras decision to suspend the series, which began in 1965.

title: Mine Owners Misled Inspectors, Investigators Say
description: Federal investigators said Wednesday that Massey Energy, the owner of the West Virginia mine where 29 men were killed in an explosion last year, misled government inspectors by keeping accounts of hazardous conditions out of official record books where inspectors would see them.

title: Talking Dance and Art With David LaChapelle and John Byrne
description: John Byrne and David LaChapelle used to be a couple. The romance didnt last, but the two have continued their relationship through art. Mr. Byrne, a choreographer and former dancer for Paul Taylor, worked on Rize, Mr. LaChapelles 2005 documentary about krumping, as well as Elton John: The Red Piano. Now Mr. LaChapelle has produced Mr. Byrnes first full-length work of dance, Transcending Form, with Fred Torres, at Theater 80 every Wednesday through Aug. 24. In addition, Mr. Byrne has created a structured improvisation piece at Lever House, home to an exhibit of Mr. LaChapelles work, From Darkness To Light. Pedestrians can happen across this performance every Wednesday from 1 to 2 p.m. We talked to Mr. Byrne and Mr. LaChapelle about their new works, their collaboration and the melding of dance and art. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

title: Clashes as Greek Government Passes Austerity Measures
description: Greeces Parliament voted in favor of an austerity plan required by the countrys foreign lenders.

title: Who Made That Rainbow Flag?
description: Noah considered it a sign from God, Aristotle wrestled with its geometry and Dorothy sang about it as an escape from Kansas. For centuries, the semiotics of the rainbow have evolved through the fields of art, science and beyond, but have only more recently been associated with the lesbian-gay-bisexual-transgender community. Carried in abundance at this past weekends New York City Gay Pride Parade, the rainbow flag has become instantly recognizable as a symbol of diversity and acceptance.

title: Italian Experts Question Evidence in Knox Case
description: ROME  A report by forensic experts filed with an appeals court on Wednesday casts doubt on the DNA evidence used to convict Amanda Knox and her Italian ex-boyfriend for the 2007 murder of a British student. Lawyers for the defendants said the development significantly improved their chances of winning their appeal.
