title: Vote Adds to Historic-ness of Crown Heights
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday designated a 600-building swath of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as a historic district. The district, bound by Bergen Street and Eastern Parkway to the north and south, and Nostrand and Brooklyn Avenues to the west and east, adjoins the existing Crown Heights North Historic District, which includes 472 buildings and was designated in 2007.

title: The Rangers Part Ways With Their Captain
description: The Rangers have bought out the contract of Chris Drury, their 34-year-old captain, the team announced Wednesday. Drury will become an unrestricted free agent when the N.H.L.s signing period opens Friday at noon.

title: Paris Top 5 | Lanvin
description: Lanvins spring/summer 2012 collection finale in the rotunda of the historic Bourse de Commerce was an unexpectedly moving experience, with a parade of models neutrally and rather simply attired (for Lanvin standards), ascending a staircase from below and walking in a giant circle, melding into one continuous rotating mass until each model in succession retreated back downstairs. Maybe it was the stirring music. Maybe it was the simplicity of a stronger, more utilitarian look that seemed straight out of Claire Deniss meditation on the military, Beau Travail. Thegauzy gray mix of a layered double-breasted jacket worn with an airy duster and semisheer trousers tucked into combat boots was heroically beautiful.

title: Clip: de La Cruz
description: Xavier Cha's film for the de La Cruz Collection.

title: Fly by Night
description: BY day, Jobee, an unassuming Taiwanese restaurant on Howard Street, just east of the fashion temple Opening Ceremony and north of the fake handbags on Canal Street, serves bland sesame noodles and tasty mock Sichuan chicken to a sleepy lunch crowd. A menu is taped to the door. Kitschy paper lanterns swing from the ceiling.

title: Saudi Religious Police Detained 5 Women for Driving, Group Reports
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The religious police in Saudi Arabia arrested five women on Tuesday for driving in defiance of a ban on women getting behind the wheel in the conservative kingdom, according to activists and local media reports.

title: After 2nd Acquittal, Criminal Penalties Over Tower Fire Appear Unlikely
description: About a year after two New York City firefighters were killed while battling a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building, prosecutors in Manhattan released a report that made clear the deaths could have been avoided if not for a number of failures by various city agencies and private workers in the months before the fire.

title: Fashion Forward (or Guard)
description: FANS are still chuckling about Charles Barkley bursting out of the garish purple sports jacket he wore to the National Basketball Association draft more than a quarter-century ago. And who could forget Joakim Noah of the Chicago Bulls striding onstage in an oversize tan tuxedo and a giant paisley bow tie that seemed straight out of the Ringling Brothers fall mens line?

title: In Paris, Sensuality Saves the Day
description: PARIS  MAYBE its too many hours on Twitter that causes people to reduce fashion shows to a check-off list of essentials, but whatever it is, writers at the spring mens collections here were ticking the appropriate boxes: globalism, gender games, the new sobriety.

title: This Colorblind Woman Cant Distinguish Black From White
description: Yes We Can, a postmodern, postracial romp by Daniella Shoshan, is a pretty smart play. But youll only discover that if you read the script.

title: On Fuel Efficiency, Environmental Groups May Urge California to Go It Alone
description: According to numerous reports, the Obama administration has advanced a federal fuel efficiency fleet-average standard of 56.2 m.p.g. for 2025. But while an official number from the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is not expected until September, the reported White House disclosure has sparked intense jockeying among automakers and environmental groups and has retrained focus on California.

title: Conrad Black, Still in Prison, Finds Publisher for Memoir
description: OTTAWA _ A resentencing hearing last week in Chicago will soon return former newspaper publisher Conrad M. Black to prison. But his legal tribulations have not interfered with Mr. Blacks other occupation  as an author.

title: Just One Look | Ferragamo Resort Collection
description: If there was any doubt that resort is now a fully fledged season  and not just a smattering of pretty frocks and bikinis to fill the months between fall and spring  Massimiliano Giornetti, may have settled it, presenting his collection for Ferragamo last night to much fanfare at the former Doris Duke mansion on the Upper East Side. A fleet of nautical-inspired looks, evening gowns in a range of blue hues and this crisp, cotton scarf print top and skirt, harked back to the labels heyday in the 1930s and spoke to Giornettis ambition to complement the stylish lifestyle of a well-traveled heiress.

title: A Helsinki Cottage Serves as an Urban Getaway
description: Two architects created an eco-friendly second home in a tiny seafoam-green house in Lauttasaari Recreational Park.

title: Hand-Held Tools for Digital Scribblers
description: Even after the invention of the typewriter, many great writers stuck with longhand. Hemingway slashed out his words in pen and ink while standing at a specially made desk, and Margaret Mitchell scribbled Gone With the Wind in dozens of composition notebooks. But with the rise of the keyboard, and, more recently, the touch screen, it seems as if pen-and-paper lovers are out of luck.

title: Cripple Finally Comes to Inishmaan
description: INISHMAAN, Ireland  As captured by the dark imagination of the playwright Martin McDonagh, life on this storm-battered island near Galway inspired hardness, sarcasm and co-dependency in the characters in his 1996 play The Cripple of Inishmaan. It was home to a bachelor who both saved a drowning baby and called his mother a hairy-lipped fool and to a young dreamer so desperate to flee that he tricked a grieving friend into helping him escape.

title: So, Do I Look Like My Father in This Hat?
description: I DIDNT believe in hats even before every third underslept scruffster on the Lower East Side began abusing them. To me, they seemed to be the worst sort of peacocking, lazy and under thought, a mark of amateurism more than anything else, and almost uniformly detrimental. In winter, too, I leave my head uncovered  falling snow is no excuse to live in a cage.

title: Choosing a Hat
description: Summers here, and with it, relentless sun. Choosing a hat requires careful consideration.

title: Wainwright Offers Taste of Opera
description: With its plans for next season still a mystery as June winds to an end, New York City Opera raised its flag, briefly, on Tuesday at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, offering an evening of arias, ensembles and Rufus Wainwright songs. Mr. Wainwright was on hand to play his music and to explain, more or less, what the operatic excerpts were about.

title: A Wide-Ranging Festival Savors Some Late-Night Jazz
description: Among the many possible ways of gauging a good time at the second annual Undead Jazzfest, which wound down in the wee hours of Monday morning, there are a few that seem truest to the spirit of the event. If you were there, you might rate your experience by answering the following questions: Did you feel like a part of something vital and collegial? Did you momentarily forget the conventional wisdom about jazz as a withering art? Did you hear something new?

title: On a Hot Night, Intense Frenzied Punk
description: You can learn a lot about the Coathangers by watching the hands of the keyboard player Candice Jones. Sometimes they strike the keys precisely and carefully, picking out nimble little lines that give this bands punk some whimsy. And sometimes they appear to have an indifferent, or outright adversarial relationship to the keyboard, slamming on it casually, making the best of what comes out.

title: In Alliance, Nets Arena to Offer Arts
description: Its been a springboard for Brooklyn nostalgia, a debate about urban design and the politics of eminent domain and, depending on your perspective or basketball affiliation, a community uniter or divider. Now Atlantic Yards, the development that will bring the New Jersey Nets to Brooklyn, will also be a cultural center.

title: Strong Sales in London for Some German Artists
description: LONDON  Prices for contemporary German artists  Sigmar Polke, Georg Baselitz and Blinky Palermo, among others  soared to new levels at Sothebys here on Wednesday night in an auction that featured 34 works from the collection of Count Christian Duerckheim, a German industrialist who became obsessed with what he calls the art of his time. Beginning in the early 1970s Count Duerckheim got to know Mr. Polke and Mr. Baselitz along with Gerhard Richter and lesser-known artists including Jrg Immendorff, Konrad Lueg and Eugen Schnebeck. He often bought their work soon after it was made.

title: The Harness Has Them Champing at the Bit
description: DURING Lady Gagas performance of Judas on the season finale of Saturday Night Live, her backup dancers were clad in gold harnesses, custom-made by the Brooklyn designer Zana Bayne. They were worn either over a bikini top or bare skin, artfully framing the chest.

title: G.E. Extends Olympic Sponsorship
description: General Electric extended its global Olympic sponsorship on Wednesday through 2020, matching the decision three weeks ago by NBC Universal to acquire the rights to the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020 for $4.38 billion. G.E., which sold majority control of NBC Universal to Comcast, has sponsored the Olympics since 2008, adding an estimated $200 million sweetener to the $2 billion it paid for NBC to carry the 2008, 10 and 12 Games.

title: Visiting Artists | Xavier Cha
description: The performance artist Xavier Cha thrives on the unknown. Her process is largely improvisational and embraces the random variables many artists work hard to avoid. For Holiday Cruise!, her solo show at Taxter and Spengemann Gallery back in 2006, Cha enlisted about a hundred performers to interact with her as she played three different characters. One of the characters was dressed in a bodysuit completely covered with cornrows (and elicited numerous requests to dance). Another character simply lay in and among oversized fruits and vegetables in a massive Horn of Plenty. The third character, Polyhedra, was still as a statue.

description: The ax is about to fall at Goldman Sachs.

description: Three team competitions at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, finished on Wednesday.

description: WASHINGTON  After months of saying his position on same-sex marriage is evolving, President Obama traded that language on Wednesday for comments that stopped just short of endorsing the notion that gay people have the right to marry.

description: The City Council voted on Wednesday to approve a budget roughly the size of Kenyas economy. But for political savants, the most interesting part may be a tiny sliver of it: the $36.4 million set aside in discretionary money.

description: IF you are Brian Ellner, a tall, handsome, unrelentingly persistent New Yorker with an e-Rolodex that expands at every dinner party, you can always get through to someone impossible to reach.

title: Your Chair, Mr. Aalto. Yes, It Now Has Eyes.
description: WHAT is that sound coming from a cemetery in Finland? Might it be Alvar Aalto spinning in his grave? A New Yorker has just painted a big red heart on Chair 69, a seriously minimal piece that the architect designed 76 years ago. Do the eyes deceive, or are those ribbons wound around the chairs stiles and cross rail? And plastic jewels stuck on the seat?

title: David Hyde Pierce Will Be Your Host
description: In the new thriller The Perfect Host, David Hyde Pierce, held at knifepoint, delivers one of the more sublimely ridiculous movie lines in recent memory: You cant kill me. Im having a dinner party.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asked on Wednesday that the company that managed the troubled CityTime automated payroll project refund the city $600 million  all the money it has been paid for the project since 2003.

title: Tanzina Vega on interactive motion-controlled ads; the term "addressable TV;" the Yotel robot; news.
description: Game-style voice and motion controls will let Xbox Kinect users interact with ads. Betting Edelstein chats with Times media reporter Tanzina Vega about how this new mode of advertising works, and its implications. Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a look at the tech term "addressable TV." And J.D. Biersdorfer checks out the Yobot at the Yotel  a giant robot that handles luggage at a new Manhattan hotel. The news roundup includes the Supreme Court's ruling on violent video games; a class-action suit against Dropbox; e-reader ownership booming; new Windows malware that burrows deeply. J.D.'s tech tip: how to save emailed photos in the Mac Mail program directly into iPhoto.

title: On a Fools Mission in a Dying Colonial World
description: Combat experiences are like Tolstoys unhappy families: no two are alike, which may be why they often make for great novels, as Tolstoy also knew. The cause need not even be noble, since a hopeless situation and senseless violence can actually fortify a work of fiction. Certainly that is the case with Antnio Lobo Antuness Land at the End of the World, set in Angola in the early 1970s, as Portugals ludicrous effort to preserve its African empire was meandering to an inglorious end.

title: China: Tibetans Are Arrested After New Protests in Sichuan
description: At least 30 Tibetans have been detained in 15 incidents of protest this month in a restive part of Sichuan Province, in western China, according to a report this week by International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based outside China. Those detained are both monks and laypeople. The protests took place in an area that Tibetans call Kardze, known to the Chinese as Ganzi. The local police headquarters had no comment. The area has been unsettled since April 2008, when at least eight Tibetans were killed by Chinese security forces firing into a crowd of protestors, Tibetan exile groups said at the time. Those protests took place as part of a large uprising that began in Lhasa, Tibet, and unfolded across the Tibetan plateau. The report this week also said two monks from Kardze held a protest in the Barkhor market in Lhasa on June 22, possibly the first there since March 2008. Chinese officials have barred foreigners from going to central Tibet from late June to late July.

title: Senate Votes to Streamline the Confirmation Process

title: Senegal: Soldiers Sent Into Streets of Capital After Fiery Riots
description: Senegal has deployed troops around ministry buildings and an important route in the capital, Dakar, a spokesman said Wednesday, in a bid to forestall further rioting after several days of antigovernment violence. Offices of the state power company Senelec were burned in riots on Monday night by protesters angry over power cuts lasting hours. The situation is back to normal now, said Serigne Mback Ndiaye, a spokesman for President Abdoulaye Wade, adding that Mr. Wade, above, had decided to forgo a trip to the African Union summit meeting in Equatorial Guinea in order to watch over the situation in Senegal. Last week, the capital was rocked by riots over Mr. Wades plan, subsequently withdrawn, to change electoral rules in what demonstrators said was an effort to prolong his rule.

title: Knicks Make Offer to Brown

title: After a Derailed Dream, Working Her Way Up

Last summer, she completed a training program run by Fedcap, an agency that develops employment opportunities for the disadvantaged and the disabled. In September, at 24, she got her first-ever job in the Fedcap mailroom; two promotions later, she is an accounting clerk. title: Vain Glorious | Going to Great Lengths
description: If youve been noticing more and more women sporting longer, impossibly perfect locks, its not your imagination. Hair extensions are practically de rigueur. The newest are Platinum Seamless Hair Extensions, which are tiny, sticky strips applied to the hair in under two hours (not the seven or eight that other methods require), and are said to be less damaging to hair and more natural looking. Stylists say these last up to three months, which is just as well. Platinum can cost $2,500  no small chunk of change. At Ricardo Rojas, one of the few salons offering Platinum, that fee includes color match, installation, cut and styling. I tried them out last week and Rojas, whose clients include Eva Longoria and Bar Rafaeli, told it to me straight: You dont need these. But now that I have them, I know why women become addicted. My hair attracted a bizarre amount of attention, so much that I decided it deserved its own diary.

title: No Buyer for Chaplin Film at Auction
description: When it comes to motion pictures, Charlie Chaplin is the man, no? Well, an all-but-forgotten short film featuring footage of the comic star failed to sell at a London auction, defying expectations that it might fetch a six-figure sum, Reuters reported. The reserve price on the film at Wednesdays sale was 100,000 ($160,000) at Bonhams auctioneers, but apparently that was too high. Charlie Chaplin in Zepped,  is believed to be a propaganda film made in Britain during World War I. A collector discovered the seven-minute short inside an old film reel tin and bought it in 2009 for 3.20 (about $5) on the online auction site eBay. The film shows Chaplin taking on a German Zeppelin aircraft and features some of the earliest animation in film history. Chaplin probably never knew of the movies existence, said the film critic and Chaplin biographer David Robinson, according to Reuters. Mr. Robinson said an anonymous filmmaker had put together outtakes from three earlier Chaplin pictures  His New Profession (1914), A Jitney Elopement (1915) and The Tramp (1915)  and included sequences of stop-motion animation and other effects. Chaplin was not involved in the production of Zepped, but famously satirized Adolf Hitler in the 1940 movie The Great Dictator.

title: Folk Art Museums Final Week Before Close
description: Lovers of folk art have just a week left to visit the American Folk Art Museum at its home on West 53rd Street before it closes its doors there for good. Struggling under a heavy load of debt, the museum recently sold the building to the Museum of Modern Art. On Thursday it said its last day in the building would be July 8. The museum will remain in operation in its much smaller branch at 2 Lincoln Square, where it currently has a show of quilts from the collection. MoMA has not yet said what it plans to do with the building, which was designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien and opened in 2001. A spokeswoman for the folk art museum, Susan Flamm, said the museum would have 90 days to vacate the building after the sale closes, which she said would happen in mid-July.

I would add Peter Murphy. If you walk through the streets of New York with this on your iPod, every passing pedestrian looks like a lunatic just barely keeping it together  more than usual, I mean. In the musical the title character, played by Lindsie Van Winkle, is not a prostitute and has a romantic relationship with Jesus, or Yeshua (Shad Olsen), causing infighting among his circle of disciples and further invoking the ire of the Roman government. title: 36 Hours in Cape May, N.J.
description: AT the southernmost tip of New Jersey, where the Garden State Parkways exit numbers wind down to zero, Cape May, one of the oldest seaside resorts in the nation, has welcomed vacationers for more than 200 years. The images of the Jersey Shore conjured up in the reality TV show bear little resemblance to this family-oriented destination, with its charming Victorian homes and historic lighthouse. While Cape Mays vacation identity is still very much tied to house tours, horse-drawn carriages and dinner theaters, in recent years it has embraced a more stylish persona. Several of its once-faded grande dame hotels and low-slung motels have been updated and transformed into chic escapes, catering to well-to-do families from Philadelphia, northern New Jersey, New York City and beyond. But traditionalists need not fear  Cape May retains its laid-back charm with mini-golf courses, 25-cent Skee-Ball games and families pedaling around on surreys and bicycles built for two.

Just outside the future Olympics site, and shoehorned beneath the underpass of the A12 highway, Folly for a Flyover is the work of Assemble, a young collective of designers, artists and architects. The red brick structure  with a roof that peaks out between the eastbound and westbound lanes of highway above  was constructed by volunteers from reclaimed and donated materials. On the weekends the Folly houses a cafe, workshops and performances. Adventurous visitors can rent handmade rowboats from a small dock on the canal. In the evenings, from Friday to Sunday, there is a bar and an adjacent auditorium space underneath the highway, which hosts a series of screenings curated by the Barbican Art Gallery as part of its current exhibition Watch Me Move: The Animation Show.

description: Thousands of British public workers protest austerity measures; Nicholas D. Kristof on the Sudanese president's visit to China; and Jonathan Mahler speaks out on two Texas sports icons.

title: No Refunds in the Event Your Team Loses or You Dont Like the Film
description: When a Connecticut theater, the Avon in Stamford, posted a sign saying it wouldnt give refunds to patrons walking out of The Tree of Life, the news ricocheted around the Web. (A sampling of posts is here, here and here.) But Adam Birnbaum, the theaters director of film programming, says that the move has been widely misinterpreted as a snub of insufficiently arty filmgoers.

title: Wildfire Continues to Burn Near Nuclear Facility in New Mexico
description: Updated | 7:50 p.m. The Las Conchas wildfire in northern New Mexico has blazed through nearly 93,000 acres since Sunday and stands poised to become the largest in the states history, according to officials.

title: Artsbeat - June 30, 2011
description: Mike Hale interviews Grady Hendrix of the New York Asian Film Festival and Charles Isherwood reviews "Zarkana," the latest from Cirque Du Soleil.

title: Honors From a French Jury
description: Anthony Vaccarello has a new accolade to add to his list of accomplishments. The 31-year-old Belgian designer has been named this years winner of the ANDAM Fashion Award, the French equivalent of the Council of Fashion Designers of America prize. He follows in the footsteps of past winners who include Giles Deacon, Gareth Pugh, Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren of Viktor & Rolf, and Martin Margiela.

title: Sarkozy Is Assaulted as He Meets Voters
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France was rubbing shoulders with voters Thursday when one of them literally grabbed his, violently yanking his suit collar, and would have been pulled to the ground had it not been for a metal barricade that caught his fall.

title: Former Champion and New Face in the Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  There were some strange twists on Centre Court on Thursday. The womens semifinalist with by far the most experience at this heady stage of a Grand Slam tournament was the shakiest at the start. The match that deserved to end with a double fault did not, but the other did.

title: Senate Confirms Petraeus to C.I.A.
description: In a vote of 94-to-0, the Senate confirmed Gen. David H. Petraeuss nomination to serve as director of the Central Intelligence Agency on Thursday. General Petraeus, the architect of counter-insurgency strategies in Iraq and Afghanistan, will succeed Leon E. Panetta, who is in turn taking over for Robert M. Gates at the Pentagon.

title: Fox News to Replace Beck With The Five
description: The Fox News Channels temporary replacement for Glenn Beck will be a talk show featuring a rotating panel of opinionated people.

description: Movies

title: In the Picture: Atlanta, Africa and the Past
description: In 1972, when Radcliffe Bailey was 4 years old, his parents were looking for a change of scene from New Jersey, where most of his extended family had settled. They were considering California, Ontario and Florida, where they were headed on a road trip, when they stopped by chance at a restaurant in Atlanta and met the Rev. Lucius M. Tobin. Mr. Tobin, a onetime teacher of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at Morehouse College, gave the family members a tour that captivated them with its rich account of the citys history. Soon after, the ministers wife was returning with Mrs. Bailey to New Jersey to help her pack up the family home.

title: Sabathia Pitches Gem and Keeps Yankees Hot
description: C. C. Sabathia struck out Milwaukee Brewers left fielder Corey Hart, a former teammate, for the second time Thursday, and Hart slammed his useless bat and dropped his batting helmet where he stood. Harts only consolation, maybe, was that two teammates struck out three times.

title: Republicans Boycott a Hearing on Trade
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans boycotted a preliminary hearing Thursday on free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama, instead staging a simultaneous press conference and bringing the stop-and-go process to yet another halt.

title: Minnesota Government Shuts in Budget Fight
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Minnesota began what is expected to become the broadest shutdown of state services in its history early Friday, after Republicans and Democrats there failed to agree on how to solve the states budget woes in time for the new fiscal year.

title: U.S. Widens Inquiries Into 2 Jail Deaths
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department announced Thursday that it was opening a full criminal investigation into the deaths of two terrorism suspects in C.I.A. custody overseas, but it was closing inquiries into the treatment of nearly 100 other detainees over the last decade.

title: A Faberg Exhibition Without Fauxbergs
description: Whatever luxury accessory from the czars households that an American collector could desire, Armand Hammer could probably make it materialize. In the 1920s and 30s Hammer, the manufacturing tycoon, helped supply Western currency to the Soviets, in exchange for their loot of aristocrats Faberg jewelry, Easter eggs, picture frames and stone animals.

title: Hardware-Store Technology in the Legs of Weevils
description: Until now, the screw-and-nut system was thought to be a human innovation. But a new study reports that it exists in nature, in the legs of the Papuan weevil.

description: I DESIGNED my ideal boyfriend in a dorm room voodoo ceremony orchestrated by my roommate. Such spiritualism was out of character for her practical nature but fit perfectly with her ego: she would believe that the forces of the universe were taking orders directly from her.

title: What Google+ Is All About
description: On Tuesday, Google announced a restricted-access introduction of its new social network, Google+, pronounced Google plus. A relatively small number of people were invited to join the network.

description: Pawn shops have traditionally been associated with rundown neighborhoods and shady dealings  think of that violent scene in the movie Pulp Fiction.

title: On the Internet, Nobody Knows Youre a Youngster With Issues
description: LONDON  The Internet is a vast repository of music, but has it created any of note? The speak-singing of Youve got mail? The jangle of an instant message? They dont really cut it as art.

title: Ad for Subway (Sandwiches) Went a Step Too Far
description: Concerned, perhaps, that the contrails of atmospheric exhaust were not reaching prospective patrons as far away as the Avenue of the Americas intersection, the operators of the Subway restaurant at 31 West 43rd Street planted their flag firmly on the avenue itself.

title: Menacing Working Girls Stuck in Punishing Grind
description: BECKET, Mass.  Almost immediately after Sharon Eyals Love (2003) began on Wednesday night at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival here, during the American debut of Carte Blanche, the Norwegian national company of contemporary dance, two audience members hustled out of the theater. Had they reached a verdict that quickly? Its possible. After all, they had just seen pretty much the same dance before intermission.

title: City Life Isnt Always Uplifting
description: By the time the performers of Overground Physical Theater Company gathered onstage for their final bow, it had dawned on me that summer  hands down, the bleakest time for dance in New York  is officially here. In Urban Tao Evolution, a convoluted and rambling new work performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday night, the message had something to do with choosing spirituality over technology. What it really looked like was a New Age musical produced in a high school and performed, to a large extent, by the teachers.

title: Golf Phenom, Not Tiger Woods. Sure.
description: The Swinger is a novel about a very famous golfer who has an amazing career record, a slew of endorsement deals, a gorgeous wife and a squeaky-clean reputation  until his extracurricular kinks become a huge public embarrassment and spoil everything. The authors, Michael Bamberger (This Golfing Life) and Alan Shipnuck (Bud, Sweat and Tees), call this golfer Herbert X. Tremont, known as Tree, and his wife, Belinda. But they dont insult the readers intelligence by claiming that these characters bear no resemblance to persons living or dead.

title: Live: Glenn Beck Says Goodbye to Fox News
description: Glenn Beck is like no one else on television.

title: And, Im Back
description: Blame Canada  or at least Air Canada. My simple trip home from Toronto turned into an 8-hour ordeal. And today I not only had to get tomorrows column done, I had to discuss a (very good) paper on the financing of frozen chicken exports. Honest.

title: Images of Fossil Birds Show Ancient Pigments
description: Some fossils are not just rock.

title: Notes From the Underground | Kalup Linzy
description: It was a voyeuristic thrill watching the performance artist and Internet video sensation Kalup Linzy prance around the Boom Boom Room at the Standard Hotel, singing his heart out about his typically provocative subject matter. Clad in a green bathrobe (that had been cut into a dangerously short minidress) and a blond wig, Linzy sauntered barefoot before a relatively stodgy crowd of art-world types, who seemed to clutch their Champagne flutes in confusion. Hosted by Creative Time, the party celebrated the second installment of StandART, the hotels video art channel, which this time around includes works by Linzy, Terence Koh, Slater Bradley and Allison Schulnik, among others.

title: Once Again, Floor Plans Are Making the Sale
description: WHEN the real estate market was booming, buyers routinely signed contracts for apartments in yet-to-be-built buildings, making their decisions based on little more than an artists rendering and a miniature model of their new home.

title: Stymied in Middle Age, Reaching for a New Life
description: Larry Crowne is a rom-com fairy tale so tepid and well behaved that watching it feels like being stuck in traffic as giddy joy-riders in the opposite lane break the speed limit. You have little choice but to cool your heels and pretend that the parched crabgrass in the median is a field of flowers.

description: WITH interest rates low, biweekly mortgage payment plans are looking less attractive than ever.

title: Verlander Cools the Hot-Hitting Mets
description: DETROIT  For four record-setting games, it seemed as if no team, no park and no pitcher could stop the Mets unyielding run-producing machine. They scored 52 runs in that span, the most in franchise history, and were averaging 17.25 hits a game.

title: Twins, but They Dont Dress Alike
description: THE unique development of one West Side block produced an unusual pair of near-twin buildings. But no matter how far out the windows they stretch, the residents of the Evanston, at 90th and West End, will never be able to see the facade of its mate, the Admaston, at 89th and Broadway.

description: Renwick Gallery

title: Wrong To Be Right
description: Atrios is annoyed at David Wessel, and rightly so. Id summarize Wessels column a bit differently: its roughly Some people thought from the beginning that the stimulus should have been much bigger. Hahaha! Also, it turns out that the stimulus was too small, so we need some more.

description: Brooklyn Museum

description: Mr. Lebling, 47, is a senior vice president of Equity Residential, overseeing the real estate investment trusts Northeast market. He previously ran its residential operations in South Florida.

title: Showing Two Painters, Three Centuries Apart
description: LONDON  Nicolas Poussin and Cy Twombly may seem to have little in common, but an exhibition that opened on Wednesday at the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London shows that these painters are not such strange bedfellows.

title: Cinderella Goes to Europe, and Cute Meets Culture
description: The gal-pal comedy Monte Carlo comes with a bewildering PG rating for brief mild language (so brief I missed the offending words), when it really should have earned a Gee. Cheery, corny and perhaps calculatingly unoriginal, this is packaged entertainment so familiar it feels like a remake and so wholesome you could swear Sandra Dee starred in the 1959 original. Think of it as No Sex and the City for tweeners.

title: The Sounds of Silence
description: MANHATTAN can be too much with us. It can seem like a 23-square-mile rugby pitch, where on any given day nearly three million people are shoving elbows, blowing cigarette smoke, jabbering on cellphones or to themselves, all ready to rumble over the slightest slight. Not long ago a well-educated woman slapped another well-educated woman in a confrontation over a package of vegan pad Thai in the frozen-food section of Trader Joes. To which inhabitants of Manhattan might say: Yeah? So what?

title: A Restorative Racket
description: LIKE most commuters, I spend my days in the city but sleep out in the stillness of the suburbs, where at night its as quiet as the grave. The only thing you hear is the occasional scrabbling of raccoons trying to knock over the trash cans. But a couple of years ago I happened to spend the night at an Upper East Side hotel, where I was pleasantly startled by two phenomena: the abundant free pornography on cable TV and, around dawn, a whining, grinding, masticating sound that I eventually recognized as a garbage truck partaking of its morning feed. This was followed by some bus rumbling and horn honking and, a few blocks away, an insistent car alarm. The city was already awake and thrumming, going about its business with none of the suburban fussiness that makes it unmannerly, for example, to crank up your lawn mower or your leaf blower before breakfast.

title: In Greenwood Heights, a Place to Stay Put
description: AFTER he graduated from Binghamton University in 2006, Jason Fallon faced a decision. He could rent an apartment in New York City and begin his professional life or he could visit his girlfriend, Rebecca Bear Dallis, who was spending her junior year abroad at the University of Sydney.

title: Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Black and White
description: The mushroom cloud is one of those images thats hard to process without resorting to abstractions. In our minds this symbol of nuclear Armageddon has somehow become detached from the weapons deadly efficacy.

title: A Welcome to His World Is Accepted at Your Peril
description: Warwick Wilson, the prim, dapper title character of The Perfect Host, played by David Hyde Pierce, seems at first to be a clone of Waldo Lydecker, the snobbish newspaper columnist of Otto Premingers film-noir classic Laura. As Warwick jousts with John Taylor (Clayne Crawford), a scruffy bank robber on the lam who talks his way into Warwicks immaculate Los Angeles lair, you expect an insidious tug of war between an aesthete and a roughneck, similar to the power struggle of Clifton Webbs imperious dandy and Dana Andrewss earthy detective in Laura.

title: By the Bay, a Berth to Rest and to Mingle
description: Everyone savors those only in New York moments: watching the Nathans hot-dog-eating contest in Coney Island or spotting a movie star in a restaurant in Manhattan. But another, equal pleasure is often overlooked: the I cant believe Im still in New York moment.

title: Lawyers Expected to Seek to Ease Bail Conditions on Strauss-Kahn
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers in the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn will return to court on Friday, where his lawyers were expected to ask a judge to ease the restrictive bail conditions that were imposed, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Violence Close at Hand Shakes a Bucolic Setting
description: Ed Gass-Donnellys rural crime drama, Small Town Murder Songs, punctures the veneer of bucolic quiet in a mostly Mennonite farming community in Ontario. Beneath a deceptive calm, it uncovers a core of fear and loathing as ominous as the backwoods world of Winters Bone.

title: Horse Farm Prices Take a Tumble
description: A horse farm in Westchester for under $1 million? Unheard of five years ago, brokers say, but not so now.

title: Playing Make-Believe With Greece
description: If only C. David Ritter had been a central banker, rather than a commercial banker, he could be retiring with praise, rather than facing possible legal liability for following the time-dishonored practice of extend and pretend, in which bad loans are treated as if they were just fine.

title: Sounds of the City  Do You Prefer Cacophony or Quiet?
description: Forty thousand fireworks. Now thats bound to make some noise. There are New Yorkers who will love every decibel on the Fourth of July, when Macys puts on its biggest fireworks display in America. Other New Yorkers  well, theyd much rather see the rockets red glare than hear the bursting in air. Certainly all city dwellers are used to noise, but there are those who hear a symphony in the cacophony and those who seek out New Yorks many pockets of peace and quiet. Here, two views. Which do you prefer, the cacophony of New York or the quiet?

title: Clip: The First Mark
description:
Behind the scene sat Peter Nadin's farm, located in the Catskill Mountains of New York State.

Film by Natsuko Uchino and Aime Toledano. Written by Peter Nadin.

title: Federal Officials Cant Raise Unlimited Funds, F.E.C. Says
description: The comedian Stephen Colberts successful campaign to form a super PAC got plenty of attention on Thursday, but the Federal Election Commissions granting of Mr. Colberts request might not have been its most significant action of the day.

title: Another Teenage Misfit Trying to Like Himself
description: In outline the story told in Terri could not be more familiar: A misfit high school student, isolated and misunderstood, finds companionship with other oddballs, as well as a measure of self-acceptance. The same description could apply to Submarine and The Art of Getting By, restricting ourselves only to films currently playing in theaters. All three movies are sincere and thoughtful  necessary but not sufficient conditions for our interest and admiration.

title: Geithner Staying (for Now)
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Thursday that he planned to stay in his job for the foreseeable future.

title: An Artist Who Makes Much Out of Very Little
description: The less-is-more tradition in American art is rich and varied. It stretches from the glorious frugalities of Shaker furniture and Amish quilts to the sleek orthodox Minimalism of Donald Judds box sculptures and Agnes Martins horizontal-stripe paintings. And it also accommodates the modest, plain-spoken sculptures and wall pieces of the artist B. Wurtz.

title: Romney Says Closed Steel Plant Symbolizes Obamas Failures
description: ALLENTOWN, Penn. Standing before the locked gate of a steel plant that President Obama had once visited to promote his economic stimulus plan, Mitt Romney pointed out weeds and boarded-up windows on Friday and called the presidents handling of the economy a failure.

title: Finding His Inner Child, Cowboy and Housewife
description: A cowboy, a housewife, a retired widower, 1940s movie stars and kids of all ages: these are among the host of characters who people Cast of Thousands: Gillett Sings Carnelia, a one-man musical at the Laurie Beechman Theater. Its variety of humanity brings to mind the world of Lily Tomlin.

title: Tripoli Refugees Stream Into Libyas Mountains
description: RUJBAN, Libya  The people fleeing Tripoli on Thursday said that several neighborhoods filled with the sound of gunfire every night. At checkpoints throughout the capital, they said, paramilitaries from the dreaded Peoples Guard carried long lists of wanted men. The gas lines were five days long.

title: Emotions Expressed With a Glance
description: NOT all Russian ballerinas are created equal, but Polina Semionova is in a class by herself. Theres something disarmingly different about Ms. Semionova, a willowy, warm dancer who grew up in Moscow, lives in Berlin and, in May, made her long-awaited debut with American Ballet Theater in Don Quixote.

title: Separated at Birth?
description: These two search-and-rescue vehicles were conceived continents apart. Or were they?

title: A Rogue Film Festival Earns Respect (Sort Of)
description: The New York Asian Film Festival has an image to uphold, based on a well-honed story of low-rent beginnings and disreputable programming. This familiar narrative starts in 2002 with five young guys and their credit cards, and embraces rowdy, fiercely obsessive audiences jammed into downtown theaters watching movies about young Japanese women whose breasts double as machine guns.

title: A defiant President pushes back on GOP. Is this the new Barack Obama or a political strategy?
description: An apparently frustrated President Obama pushes back on GOP at a press conference this week. Is this the new President Obama or strategy as he enters a new political season? Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, Washington correspondent Mark Landler and Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman join Sam Roberts in New York.

title: Poor Reception for the Big Game
description: My husband is a sports fanatic. We will be attending a close friends wedding in Europe on the evening of (in his view) the game of the century. Worse, his favorite team is playing. The reception will be held in a mansion that certainly has a TV in it. How rude would it be for my husband to ask the bridegroom if he could slip in and out of the festivities to watch the game on one of the houses televisions?Sherri, Washington

title: The Red Bulls McCarty Is Hoping to Make a Name for Himself
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  Like many people, the Red Bulls newest player does not hear his given name unless hes in trouble: My dad only calls me Michael when hes really angry with me.

title: Caucus Click: Fiscal Scramble
Jon Caramanica on Beyoncs fourth solo album; Eleanor Friedberger on her album, Last Summer; and new releases.
description: This week: Jon Caramanica on Beyoncs fourth solo album, the fittingly titled 4; a conversation with Eleanor Friedberger about her first solo album, Last Summer; and a look at new releases from Dolly Parton, Gillian Welch and Big Sean. Jeremy Egner is the host.

title: A Warning on Dodd-Frank From F.D.I.C. Chief in Her Final Senate Hearing
description: Federal lawmakers could harm the financial system by failing to give regulators the money and power to put the Dodd-Frank Act into effect, Sheila C. Bair, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told lawmakers at a hearing on Thursday in Washington.

title: Seeking a Path to Justice
description: When the lawyers Nadia Costa and Joshua Safran first encountered Deborah Peagler, she had already served 20 years of a 25-years-to-life sentence for involvement in the 1982 murder of her pathologically abusive boyfriend. Taking advantage of a California law that allows reconsideration of cases involving battered women, the lawyers embarked on a pro bono journey to free her that would last eight years and unearth a reeking trail of perjury,  prosecutorial misconduct and political malfeasance.

description: Here are a few notable reports snagged from the nonstop flow on climate science and the policy debate over greenhouse gases:

description: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would pay for Provenge, the prostate cancer drug whose $93,000 price had set off debate about the cost of cancer treatments.

description: Photos of a new exhibition of works by the artist B. Wurtz.

description: A new exhibition of works by Radcliffe Bailey is on view in Atlanta.

description: Photos of preparations for the Royal Shakespeare Company at the Park Avenue Armory.

description: Photos of the National Pinball Museum in Washington.

title: Thursday at the Womens World Cup
description: France and Germany filled the first two slots in the quarterfinals. France routed Canada, 4-0, becoming the first team to score more than two goals in a game so far. Germany eliminated a hard-working Nigeria team, which was unlucky to lose both its games by 1-0 against strong opposition.

title: Cuomo Clarifies Fracking and Nuclear Plans
description: New York State Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos energy plans for the state are crystallizing. Through administrative moves, he has indicated that he sees the need to responsibly exploit the states enormous gas resource while moving toward ending nuclear power generation near New York City and its suburbs.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Weekend Miser, who we hope returns from Los Angeles relaxed but not Botoxed, will be back on duty next week. In the meantime, weve scoured the Internet and rifled through her in-box to drum up a few less traditional ways to celebrate our country this holiday weekend.

title: Rajaratnams Sentencing Is Delayed
description: Raj Rajaratnam will enjoy another two months of freedom.

title: Obama Is Fund-Raising in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama, speaking at a fund-raiser here on Thursday, did not roll out the aggressively partisan rhetoric he used at a news conference Wednesday to describe Republicans approach to budget negotiations.

title: The Draft Ends in Germany, but Questions of Identity Endure
description: BERLIN  Germany formally discontinued the draft at midnight on Thursday to make way for a smaller, tighter army that will draw people like Johannes Beckert and Steven Stadler, both volunteers signing up for duty at a sprawling, suburban recruitment center that once housed the East German militarys overseas espionage agency.

title: China Admits Officials Cannot Levitate
description: Despite what appeared to be clear photographic evidence published earlier this month on a Chinese government Web site, China has admitted that, in fact, its officials cannot levitate.

title: Nicklaus, a Doubles Player, Cheers On the Bryans
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Jack Nicklaus had a seat in the royal box at Centre Court on Thursday, but it was empty during the first womens semifinal between Victoria Azarenka and Petra Kvitova.

title: Italy Approves an Austerity Package
description: ROME  The Italian government on Thursday approved a $68 billion austerity package that is intended to reduce the countrys budget deficit and reassure financial markets and Italys European Union partners about its commitment to putting its finances in order.

title: Febreze Commercial
description: In a commercial for Febreze, people were asked to take part in a scent experiment.

title: Amazon.com Fights California Tax Collectors
description: Californians will have to start paying sales tax on their purchases from Amazon.com starting Friday after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation earlier this week requiring online retailers to collect the tax.

title: Diving Into Reeking Squalor to Test an Air Freshener
description: FOR all the freshening claims made by room deodorizer brands in commercials, the approach of the advertisements themselves can be pretty musty, following a predictable script.

title: Plan Issued to Save Northern Spotted Owl
description: SEATTLE  It has been two decades since the fate of a bashful bird that most people had never seen came to symbolize the bitter divide over whether to save or saw down the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest. Yet it was not until Thursday that the federal government offered its final plan to prevent the bird, the northern spotted owl, from going extinct.

title: Medicare Will Continue to Cover 2 Expensive Cancer Drugs
description: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would continue to pay for two expensive cancer drugs that had been at the center of debate  Avastin from Genentech for breast cancer and Provenge from Dendreon for prostate cancer.

title: Seeking to Avoid Uprising, Kuwait Escalates Budget
description: CAIRO  While many Arab nations have relied on force to try to crush popular aspirations for change, Kuwait, like other oil-rich kingdoms of the Persian Gulf, has instead tried to spend its way to stability.
